history and collection of voyage and travels arrange in systematic order : form a complete history of the origin and progress of navigation discovery and commerce by sea and land from the earliest age to the present time by robert kerr fr & fa edin illustrate by map and chart vol i to he excellency the honorable sir alexander cochrane kb vice-admiral of the white late commander in chief of he majesty 's naval force on the leeward island station now governor-general of the island of guadaloupe & c & c & c dear sir unused to the adulatory language of dedication i be well aware that any such mode of address would offend you delicacy while therefore i gratify my own feeling by inscribe this work with you value name i only use the freedom to assure you excellency that i have the honor to be with the warmest sentiment of respectful esteem and sincere regard dear sir you affectionate friend and gratefully devoted servant robert kerr edinburgh 1st march 1811 preface in this enlighten age when every department of science and literature be make rapid progress and knowledge of every kind excite uncommon interest and be widely diffuse this attempt to call the attention of the public to a systematic arrangement of voyage and travels from the earliest period of authentic history to the present time ought scarcely to require any apology yet on appear before the tribunal of public opinion every author who have not cherish a unreasonable estimate of he own qualification must necessarily be impress with considerable anxiety respect the probable reception of he work and may be expect to offer some account of the plan and motive of what he propose to lay before the public the present work be the first of the kind that have ever be attempt in scotland : and though as already avow in the prospectus the editor have no wish to detract from the merit of similar publication it might appear a overstrained instance of false delicacy to decline a statement of the circumstance which he presume to hope will give some prospect of the work be receive with attention and indulgence perhaps with favor it certainly be the _ only _ general history and collection of voyage and travels that have be hitherto attempt in the english language upon any arrangement that merit the appellation of a _ systematic plan _ and hence should the plan adopt be find only comparatively good in so far the system of arrangement must be pronounce the best that have be as yet devise if this be concede and the fact be too obvious to require extended proof or minute elucidation the editor shall not feel mortified even if he arrangement may be considerably improve hereafter the only work on the subject that have the smallest pretension to system and that be fanciful involve irregular abrupt and obscure be purcha he pilgrim even admit the plan of that work to be in itself excellent although it may be a _ general history _ so far as it extend it certainly be in no respect a _ complete collection _ of voyage and travels in a very large proportion of that curious work it be the _ author _ who speak to the reader and not the _ traveller _ in the present work wherever that could possibly be accomplish it have uniformly be the anxious desire of the editor that the voyager and traveller should tell they own story : in that department of he labor he only object have be to assume the character of _ interpreter _ between they and the reader by translate foreign or antiquated language into modern english sometimes indeed where no record remain of particular voyage and travels as write by the person who perform they the editor have necessarily have recourse to they historian but on every such occasion the most ancient and most authentic accessible source have be anxiously seek after and employ in every extensive work it be of the utmost consequence that its various part should be arrange upon a comprehensive and perspicuously systematic plan this have be accordingly aim at with the utmost solicitude in the present undertaking and the order of its arrangement be adopt after much deliberation and from a very attentive consideration of every general work of the same nature that could be procure if therefore the systematic order on which it be conduct shall appear well adapt to the subject after a attentive perusal and candid investigation the editor confidently hope that he labor may bear a fair comparison with any similar publication that have yet be bring forward in the short prospectus of this work formerly submit to the public a very general enunciation only of the head of the intended plan be attempt as that be then deem sufficient to convey a distinct idea of the nature arrangement and distribution of the propose work unavoidable circumstance still necessarily preclude the possibility or the propriety rather of attempt to give a more full and complete developement of the division and subdivision of the systematic arrangement which be to be pursue and which circumstance may require some elucidation a extensive and minutely arrange plan be carefully devise and extend by the editor before one word of the work be write or compile after a attentive examination of every accessible former collection that plan have be since anxiously reconsider correct altered and extend in the progress of the work as additional material occur : yet the editor consider that the final and public adoption of he plan in a positively fix and pledge systematic form any farther than have be already convey in the prospectus would have the effect to preclude the availment of those new view of the subject which be continually afford by additional material in every progressive step of preparation for the press the number of book of voyage and travels as well general as particular be extremely great and even if the whole be at once before the editor it would too much distract he attention from the division or department in which he be engage for the time to attempt study and abstract every subdivision at once the grand division however which have be already indicate in the prospectus and the general principle of the plan which be there explain be intend to be adhere to as no reason have be discover after the most attentive consideration for any deviation from that carefully adopt arrangement the head of which be here repeat general plan of the work part i _ voyage and travels of discovery in the middle age from the era of alfred king of england in the ninth century to that of don henry of portugal at the commencement of the fourteenth century _ part ii _ general voyage and travels chiefly of discovery from the era of don henry in _ 1412 _ to that of george iii in _ 1760 part iii _ particular voyage and travels arrange in systematic order geographical and chronological note -- this part will be divide into five book comprehend i europe -- ii asia -- iii africa -- iv america -- v australium and polynesium or the prodigious multitude of island in the great : pacific ocean and all these will be further subdivide into particular chapter or section correspondent to the geographical arrangement of these several portion of the globe _ part iv _ general voyage and travels of discovery during the era of george iii which be conduct upon scientific principle and by which the geography of the globe have be nearly perfect _ part v _ historical deduction of the progress of navigation discovery and commerce by sea and land from the earliest time to the present period _ in the deliberate construction of this systematic plan it have be a lead object of anxious consideration to reduce the extensive and interesting material of which the work be compose under a clear intelligible and comprehensive arrangement so combine in a geographical and chronological series that each successive division and subdivision throughout the whole work may prepare the mind of the reader for that which be to follow and may assist the memory in the recollection of what have go before by these means a attentive perusal of this work must necessarily be of material usefulness in fix distinct and just idea of geography history and chronology in the mind of its reader besides the important information and rational amusement which it will afford by the frequent description of manners custom law government and many other circumstance of all the country and nation of the world in determine upon a era for the commencement of this work the editor be naturally lead from a consideration of the accidental discovery of iceland by the norwegian in the _ ninth _ century as coincident with the reign of the great alfred who ascend the throne of england in 872 to adopt that period as the beginning of the series both because the commencement of modern maritime discovery take place during the reign of a british sovereign and because we derive the earliest write account of any of these discovery from the pen of that excellent prince it be true that the first accidental discovery of iceland appear to have be make in 861 eleven year before the accession of alfr to the throne yet as the actual colonization of that island do not take place till the year 878 the seventh of he glorious reign we have be induce to distinguish the actual commencement of maritime discovery by the modern european nation as coincide with he era from that time till the year 1412 when don henry prince of portugal first begin to prosecute a consecutive series of maritime discovery along the western coast of africa during which a long inactive period of 551 year have elapse the only maritime incident connect with we subject be the accidental re-discovery of the canary or fortunate island by a nameless frenchman about the year 1330 though they be not attempt to be take possession of till 1400 this long interval between the era of king alfr and don henry constitute the _ first _ part or grand division of we work in the course of which a considerable number of adventurous traveller penetrate into the almost unknown region of tartary and the east and considerable notice of the empire of china and even of japan and of the coast and island of indium and north-eastern africa be communicate to the european by the polo and other in separate part iv from part ii the general voyage and travels of discovery which have be undertake during the long and busy reign of we present venerable sovereign from those of a similar nature which succeed the discovery of the new world and of the route by sea to india the editor only pay a just tribute to the enlighten spirit of the age under the munificent and enlighten patronage of the beloved monarch of a free and happy people those former voyage of part ii be mostly undertake from mere interested view of direct or expected commercial benefit while these of the era of george iii originate in the grand principle of endeavor to extend the bound of science and human happiness perhaps it may occur to some reader that part v the last in order of the general head of we plan ought to have form part i as partaking of the nature of a introduction to the subject and form a summary of the whole work upon even a very slight consideration however it must be obvious that it be impossible to compose that propose deduction in any adequate manner until the whole mass of select material be possess by the editor and definitively arrange it may likewise be know to many that introduction and preface though usually place at the beginning of book be uniformly and necessarily last compose and usually last print except in new edition a great variety of collection of voyage and travels have be publish at different period many of which be inaccessible from they scarcity or from be in foreign language : and such great number of voyage and travels to particular region and country have be print as to be altogether unattainable by the generality of reader every thing however which could contribute to the perfection of this work have be collect or will be carefully procure during its progress and no pain or expense shall be withhold which can contribute to render it as complete and comprehensive as possible in the employment of the vast variety and extent of excellent material great care shall be take to insert every useful and curious information reduce where necessary to modern language and nothing shall be omit which be conducive to valuable information and rational amusement in we approach towards the present time the multitude of particular voyage and travels increase prodigiously and in employ these it become peculiarly necessary to make a selection of the best in every period and especially of those best adapt for convey just idea of each geographical division and subdivision of the world while those of less merit but which contain useful notice of the region and country of which they treat shall be carefully epitomize in illustration of the different subject without the employment of discriminate selection and occasional abridgement this work must have extend to a inconvenient and consequently expensive size or must have be leave unfinished and abrupt in some of its part : _ but abridgement shall be very seldom employ and never without acknowledgment _ indeed the grand object of the present work be to bring together a more complete and entire collection of voyage and travels than have hitherto appear in any language from the nature of the plan it be utterly impossible to ascertain with any precision the exact length to which it may extend but so far as can be judge of at present it be not expect to exceed eighteen or twenty volume throughout the whole work a series of map and chart will be insert in they proper place carefully select and construct for the purpose of illustrate the various voyage and travels at the close of the whole a complete index will be give to the entire series of volume so arrange as to form a regular _ gazetteer _ of the whole world in every article which have be adopt into this work the original and accessory source of all the material shall be distinctly indicate note of explanation will be give wherever necessary and as many of these be draw from various source the name of the author from whom they be adopt shall always be acknowledge : such note as be mark by the letter e be by the editor of the work owe to the indispensable nature of this work it make no positive claim to the character of a original composition in the strict acceptation of that term and he therefore who have undertake the care of its collection and arrangement assume no higher title than that of _ editor _ in the discharge of that duty however the labor which he have necessarily bestow though always please have often be considerable and sometimes arduous and he trust that the plan of the work which be altogether original will be find appropriately adapt to the end in view and that the execution may appear not inadequate to the high importance of the subject without imputation of arrogance he may be permit to assert that he have exert the most unremitting attention and industry in the collection selection and preparation of the several portion of the whole work and in the arrangement and distribution of its part he have the satisfaction to add that all he effort have be second with the utmost readiness and liberality by the _ proprietor _ of the work who have spare no trouble and withhold no expense in procure and supply the necessary material it be with much grateful satisfaction that the editor have to acknowledge he high obligation to the curator and librarian of the edinburgh public library belong to the faculty of advocate the university and the writer to he majesty 's signet for the communication of many valuable and scarce material nor ought he to withhold he tribute of gratitude on this occasion from the liberal spirit of a private individual the reverend henry white of lichfield who have most obligingly offer the use of he valuable collection of voyage and travels and other curious and scarce work connect with the subject for assist towards the perfection of this publication have thus briefly announce the nature plan and object of the present work of which this _ first _ volume be now before the public it only remain to say that the editor and proprietor each in he particular department be resolve to exert they utmost endeavor that nothing may be omit which can contribute to render the work deserving of public approbation and extensive patronage contents ninth century to the era of don henry prince of portugal at the commencement of the fifteenth century _ chap i _ discovery in the time of alfred king of england in the ninth century of the christian era _ introduction in the midst of the profound ignorance and barbarism which overspread the nation of western europe after the dissolution of the roman empire in the west a transient ray of knowledge and good government be elicit by the singular genius of the great alfr a hero legislator and philosopher among a people nearly barbarous not satisfy with have deliver he oppressed and nearly ruin kingdom from the ravages of the almost savage dane and nordman and the little less injurious state of anarchy and disorganization into which the weakness of the vaunted anglo-saxon system of government have plunge england he for a time restore the wholesome dominion of the law and even endeavor to illuminate he ignorant people by the introduction of useful learning in the prosecution of these patriotic view and for he own amusement and instruction besides other literary performance he make a translation of the historical work of orosius into he native anglo-saxon dialect into which he interweave the relation of ohthere and wulfstan of which hereafter and such other information as he could collect respect the three grand division of the world then know insomuch that he account of europe especially differ very materially from that of orosius of which he only profess to make a translation although alfr only mount the throne of england in 872 it have be deem proper to commence the series of this work with the discovery of iceland by the nordman or norwegian about the year 861 as intimately connect with the era which have be deliberately choose as the best landmark of we propose systematic history and collection of voyage and travels that entirely accidental incident be the earliest geographical discovery make by the modern nation of which any authentic record now remain and be almost the only instance of the kind which occur from the commencement of the decline of the roman power soon after the christian era for nearly fourteen century and as the colonization of iceland do not begin till ad 878 the insertion of this circumstance in the present place can hardly be consider as at all deviate from the most rigid principle of we plan section i _ discovery of iceland by the norwegian in the ninth century _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- it be foreign to we present object to attempt any delineation of the piratical and even frequently conquer expedition of the various nation of scandinavium who under the name of angle saxon jute dane and norman so long harass the fragment of the roman empire about the year 861 one naddod a nordman or norwegian vikingr or chief of a band of freebooter who during a voyage to the faro island be throw by a storm upon the eastern coast of a unknown country considerably beyond the ordinary course of navigation to which he give the significant name of snio-land or snow-land from the immense quantity of snow which every where cover its numerous lofty mountain even in the height of summer and fill its many valley during a long and dreary winter as naddod give a rather favourable account of he discovery on he return to norway one gardar suafarson of swedish origin who be settle in norway determine upon make a expedition to snow-land in 864 and have circumnavigate the whole extent of this new discovery he name it from himself gardars-holm or gardars-island gardar employ so long a time in this expedition that not deem it safe to navigate the northern ocean during the storm of winter he remain on the island until the ensue spring when he sail for norway he there report that though the island be entirely cover with wood it be in other respects a fine country from the favourable nature of this report one flocke the son of vigvardar who have acquire great reputation among the nordman or norman as a experienced and intrepid vikingr or pirate resolve to visit the newly-discovered island flocke likewise winter in the northern part of the island where he meet with immense quantity of drift ice from which circumstance he choose to give it the name of iceland which it still bear he be by no means please with the country influence no doubt by the unfavourable impression he have imbibe by spend a long protracted winter on the dreary northern shore amid almost ever-during arctic ice and surround by the most unpromising sterility and though some of he companion represent the land as pleasing and fertile the desire of visit iceland seem for some time to have lie dormant among the adventurous norwegian navigator probably because neither fame nor riches could be acquire either by traffic or depredation in a country which be utterly destitute of inhabitant at length in 874 two friend ingolf and lief repair to iceland and be so much satisfied with its appearance that they form a resolution of attempt to make a settlement in the country induce doubtless by a desire to withdraw from the continual war and revolution which then harass the north of europe and to escape from the thraldom which the incipient monarchy of norway denmark and sweden be then impose upon the independent chief or vikingr of the norman in pursuance of this determination ingolf transport some people to iceland about the year 878 with several cattle and all kind of implement to enable he to commence a colony at this period he friend lief be absent in the english war but go soon afterwards into iceland to which he carry the booty which he have acquire in england the first discoverer of iceland be say to have find some irish book bell and crozier on the coast whence it have be imagine that some people from ireland have reside there previous to its discovery and settlement by the norman but it seem a more probable supposition to account for these article have be see that a party of norman pirate or vikingr who have previously land in ireland or perhaps on icolmkil and have carry away the plunder of some abbey or monastery have be drive to iceland by a storm and wreck upon the coast where these article might have be wash on shore : or they may have attribute the storm by which they be drive so far beyond they knowledge to the anger of the god of the christian for they sacrilegious robbery of a holy institution and may have leave these article behind in hope of propitiate a more favourable termination to they voyage the first settler find extensive forest in the valley of iceland and we know from authentic document that corn be formerly cultivate with decent success in that northern region whereas in the present day not a tree be to be find in the whole island except some stunt birch and very low bush or underwood in the most sheltered situation and no corn will now ripen even in the most favourable year but the root and stump of large fir be still to be see in various part and the injurious alteration of its climate be know to have be occasion by the strait between _ old _ greenland and iceland have be many year choke up with ice which the short summer of that high latitude be not sufficiently powerful to dissolve about the present period harold harfagr or the fair-haired one of the petty sovereign or vikingr of norway begin to subjugate the other chieftain of the country under he paramount authority and be so successful as to establish the norwegian monarchy in 875 gorm likewise about the same time unite the petty state of jutland and the danish island into one kingdom as ingiald illrode have do long before in sweden such independent spirit as find themselves dissatisfied with this new order of affair find a sure asylum in iceland and the emigration to this new country become so numerous that harold at length deem it expedient to impose a tax of half a mark of silver equal to five pound of we modern money on every one of he subject who be desirous of go to settle in that island -lrb- 1 -rrb- fragm vet islandic ap langebeck ii 31 -- forster hist of voy and disc in the north p 50 section ii _ voyage of ohthere to the white sea and the baltic in the ninth century _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- some of the norwegian chieftain who be dissatisfy with the usurpation of supreme authority by harold take refuge in england where alfr have recently settle many of the vanquish dane and nordman in the northern part of he dominion which have be almost entirely depopulate and lay waste by they long-continued and destructive ravages among these be one ohthere who have make himself famous by he voyage to unknown part of the north and who be invite to court by alfr to give a account of the discovery and observation he have make during he unusual expedition this person have be a chief of some note in he own country and dwelt at a place which he call halgoland suppose by some to have be in numadalen while other say in nordland the most northerly p province of norway proper in the succeed paragraph he be say to have dwell opposite to the _ west sea _ and as alfr only use the word sea to denote a confine expanse or narrow channel while he call the ocean garsecg it seem highly probable that by the west sea the _ west ford _ be intend -- a channel or strait which divide the luffoden island from the coast of nordland which would clearly place the residence of ohthere in this northern province the account which he give of he voyage to he royal patron be as follow ohthere tell he lord king alfr that lie live to the north of all the nordman or norwegian and that he dwell in that land to the northward opposite to the west sea and that all the land to the north of that sea be waste and uninhabited except in a few place to which the finan -lrb- 2 -rrb- or fin repair in winter for hunting and fowling and for fishing in the summer be desirous to ascertain how far this country extend towards the north and whether there be any inhabitant beyond these waste he proceed by sea due north from he own habitation leave the desert land all the way on the starboard or right-hand and the wide sea on the larboard or left-hand of he course after three day sail he be as far north as the whale-hunter ever go -lrb- 3 -rrb- and then proceed in he course due north for other three day when he find the land instead of stretch due north as hitherto -lrb- 4 -rrb- to trend from thence towards the east whether the sea there lie within the land he know not -lrb- 5 -rrb- as he only wait for a west wind and then sail near that land eastward as far as he could in four day as he find the direction of the coast then to change to due south he wait for a north wind and then sail due south as far as be could in five day in this land he find a large river at the mouth of which he lay to as he could not proceed much farther on account of the inhabitant be hostile all the land on one side of this river be inhabit and tolerably well cultivate but he have not meet with any inhabitant till now since he leave he own country the whole land on he right be a desert and without inhabitant except the fisher fowler and hunter before-mentioned who be all fin and the open sea lay on he left hand during he whole voyage the beorma -lrb- 6 -rrb- indeed have well peopled they country for which reason he do not venture to enter upon it and the land of the terfenna -lrb- 7 -rrb- which he have pass hitherto be all a desert with the exception of the hunter and fisher already mention the beorma tell he many particulars about they land and of the neighbouring country but he could not rely on they account as he have no opportunity of see with he own eye but it seem to he that the beorma and fin speak the same language -lrb- 8 -rrb- ohthere state that he motive for this expedition besides some little curiosity to explore these country which be unknown to he countryman be principally in pursuit of horse-whale -lrb- 9 -rrb- which be valuable because they tusk be excellent ivory some of which he bring to the king and because they hide serve for make into rope for ship this species of the whale be much smaller than the other kind be seldom more than seven ell in length while the other species be often forty-eight ell long and sometimes even fifty in this country be the best whale-fishing that ohthere have ever see the whale be so numerous that he be one of six who kill threescore in three day -lrb- 10 -rrb- ohthere be a very rich man in those thing which be consider as valuable in he country and possess at the time when he come to the king six hundred tame deer none of which he have buy besides which he have six decoy deer which be much in request among the fin as by means of they they be enable to catch wild deer yet though one of the richest man in these part he have only twenty head of cattle twenty sheep and twenty swine and what little land he have in tillage be plough by horse the principal wealth of the norman chief in that country consist in tribute exact from the fin be pay in skin of wild beast feather whalebone cable and rope for ship make from the hide of whale or seal every one pay in proportion to he substance : the wealthiest pay the skin of fifteen martin five rein-deer skin and one bear-skin a coat or cloak make of bear-skin or otter skin and two cable or ship rope of sixty ell long each one of which be make of whale hide and the other from the skin of seal accord to the description give to the king by ohthere northmanna-land or norway be very long and narrow all the land which be fit for pasture or tillage be on the seacoast which be very rocky in some place to the east of this and parallel to the cultivate land there be wild and huge mountain and moor which be inhabit by the fin the cultivate land be broadest in the south -lrb- 11 -rrb- where it be sixty mile broad and in some place more about the middle of the country it be perhaps thirty mile broad or somewhat more and where it be narrowest in the north it be hardly more than three mile from the sea to the moor in some place the moor be so extensive that a man can hardly travel across they in a fortnight and in other place perhaps in six day opposite to the south part of this country be sueoland -lrb- 12 -rrb- or sweden on the other side of the moor and opposite to its northern part be cwenland the cwen sometimes pass the moor and mountain to invade and plunder the country of the norman who likewise sometimes retaliate by cross over to spoil they land in these moor there be some very large _ mere _ or lake of fresh water and the cwena -lrb- 13 -rrb- sometimes carry they small light ship over land into these lake and employ they to facilitate they depredation on the nordmen ohthere say that the shire or district which he inhabit be call halgoland and that there be no inhabitant beyond he to the north there be likewise a port in the southern land which be call sciringes-heal -lrb- 14 -rrb- which no one could reach in a month 's sailing even with a fair wind at least if he lay to at night during this voyage the navigator must sail near the land or make a coast voyage along the coast of norway towards the south have _ iraland _ -lrb- 15 -rrb- and the island which be between that country and norway on he right hand for this country continue all the way on the left hand of the navigator from halgoland to sciringes-heal as he proceed again to the northward a great sea to the south of sciringes-heal run up into this land and that sea be so wide that a person can not see across it gotland -lrb- 16 -rrb- be opposite on the other side or right-hand and afterwards the sea of sillende -lrb- 17 -rrb- lie many mile up in that country ohthere farther say that he sail in five day from sciringes-heal to that port which be call haethum -lrb- 18 -rrb- which lie between winedum seaxun and anglen and make part of dene when he sail to this place from sciringes-heal dene or denmark be on he left and on he right be a wide sea for three day as be also on he right two day before he come to haethum gotland sillende and many other island which be inhabit by the angle before they come to britain and during these two day the island belong to denmark be on he left hand -lrb- 1 -rrb- anglo-saxon version of orosius by alfr the great translate by respect the situation of sciringes-heal and haethum _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- the name of this place sciringes-heal have give a great deal of trouble to former commentator on alfred viz sir john spelman bussaeus somner john philip murray and langebeck who have all choose spot totally different in which to place sciringes-heal spelman and other look for this place near dantzic where in they opinion the scyre formerly reside but first the spot where the scyre live be by no means satisfactorily determine and next it be evident that ohthere go continually along the coast from halgoland to sciringes-heal and that this coast be on he left-hand during the whole course of he navigation the late mr murray place sciringes-heal at skanor in the southern extremity of sweden but i can not think that this place could be five day sail from haethum in jutland as it be expressly declare to have be by ohthere langebeck be for carry sciringes-heal to konga-hellum on the guatelf near marstrand and insist that the name in alfred 's account of the voyage ought to have be write cyninges-heal instead of sciringes-heal if the word have only once occur i might have allow langebeck to be right but we meet with it five time in the space of a few line and always without the slightest variation in orthography 2dly the voyage from halgoland to konga-hellum be not of sufficient extent to have employ a month in the passage 3dly konga-hellum be too near jutland to have require five day for the voyage between it and haethum have demonstrate the insufficiency of these conjecture we shall now endeavor to point out where sciringes-heal be really situate paul warenfry in he historium longobardorum lib i cap 7 and 10 make mention of a district name scorunga in which the winilus or lombard reside for some time before they remove to mairinga and from thence farther on to gotland anthabet bethaib and purgendaid this scorunga be not far from gotland and consequently in sweden and seem to have be the district in which sciringes-heal be situate add to this that ohthere after have describe sueoland or sweden as be to the southward of he habitation immediately say there be a port in this southern land which be call sciringes-heal by this he seem plainly to indicate that this place certainly be in sweden and all this will appear still more evidently if we carefully follow the course of the voyage which he describe first of all he have scotland call iraland evidently by mistake and the orkney and shetland island which lie between scotland and halgoland on he right hand and the continent be continually on he left hand all the way until he arrive at sciringe - heal but farther a large bay stretch to the northward deep into the country along the coast of which he have be continually sailing and this bay commence quite to the southward of sciringes-heal and be so broad that a man can not see across and gotland be directly opposite to this bay -lrb- 2 -rrb- but the sea which extend from zeeland to this spot go many hundred mile up into the country to the eastward from sciringes-heal ohthere could sail in five day to haethum which lie between the wend saxon and angle now by this voyage we be enable to determine with still greater exactness the situation of this place which we be search for in order to get to haethum he leave gotland on the right -lrb- 3 -rrb- and soon afterwards zeeland likewise together with the other island which have be the habitation of the angle before they go to england while those which belong to denmark be on he left for two day sciringes-heal therefore be consequently in sweden at the entrance of the gulf of bothnium which run up into the land northwards just on that spot where the baltic after have pass zeeland spread into a wide gulf extend several hundred mile into the land just in this place i find the svia-sciaeren or swedish scare a cluster of little island surround by rock heal in the northern language signify a port as in such place a ship might be keep in safety sciringes-heal therefore be the harbor of the scare and be probably at the entrance of the gulf of bothnium and consequently where stockholm now be and the tract of land where these scare lay towards the sea be the scarunga of paul warenfry the port of hasthum have occasion much difficulty to the commentator as well as that of sciringes-heal but all have agree that it must be sleswic as this latter be call haitha by ethelwerd the anglo-saxon a norwegian poet give it the name of heythabae other call it heydaboe and adam of breman heidaba and this in they opinion be precisely the same with haethum it appear to I however that the difference between the word haethaby and hasthum be by no means so inconsiderable and i think the situation of sleswic do not at all accord with the description which be give of haethum by ohthere and wulfstan indeed if sleswic be haethum i must confess that i can not in the least comprehend the course of the voyage of these ancient navigator ohthere tell we that in sailing from sciringes-heal to haethum he have denmark to the left and the open sea for the space of three day to the right but that for two day before he reach haethum he have gotland and zeeland to the right and the island which belong to denmark to the leave if he have go to sleswic he must have find all the danish island on he right hand and not one besides femeren on he left this be consider i ask how it be possible consistent with he own description of the voyage that the situation of sleswic can be make to correspond with haethum as in the district of aarhuus in jutland there be a extensive track of land call alheide which be in fact a heath i shall take the liberty to suppose that the town in the ninth century lay higher up towards al-heide or all-heath for the town of aar-huus be new and its name signify in english oar-house the old town therefore may have be call al-haethum or haethum so that if ohthere set out from stockholm for this place gotland be on he right hand -lrb- 4 -rrb- and so be zealand and as he sail between zealand and funen or fyen all the danish island be on he left hand and he have the wide sea that be the schager-rack and cattegat to the right farther when wulfsten go from haethum or aarhuus to truso he have weonothland that be funen fionium or fyen to he right and to the leave be langeland laeland falster and sconeg together with bornholm bleking moehre oeland and gotland but wendenland remain on he right all the way to the mouth of the vistulum -lrb- 1 -rrb- forst voy and disc 67 -lrb- 2 -rrb- it appear to I that the description give by ohthere imply that gotland be directly opposite to sciringes-heal or to the east -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- not surely on go southwards but after he have again turn to the northwards after double the southern point of sweden -- e -lrb- 4 -rrb- this be certainly true during the latter part of he voyage after turn round the south end of sweden and standing again to the northward between zealand and fyen but in coast down the shore of sweden to the south he must have leave gotland to the leave -- e section iv _ voyage of wulfstan in the baltic as related to alfred _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- wulfstan say that he sail from haethum to truso -lrb- 2 -rrb- in seven day and night the ship be under sail all the time weonothland -lrb- 3 -rrb- be on he right but langaland laeland falster and sconeg be on the leave all of which belong to dene-mearkan -lrb- 4 -rrb- burgendaland -lrb- 5 -rrb- also which have a king of its own be on the leave after leave burgendaland the island of becinga-eg meore eowland and gotland be on the leave all of which belong to sueon -lrb- 6 -rrb- and weonodland -lrb- 7 -rrb- be all the way on the right to the mouth of the wisle -lrb- 8 -rrb- this be a very large river and near it witland -lrb- 9 -rrb- and weonodland be situate the former of which belong to estum and the wisle do not run through weonodland but through estmere -lrb- 10 -rrb- which lake be fifteen mile broad then run the ilfing -lrb- 11 -rrb- from the eastward into est-mere on the bank of which be truso the ilfing flow from est-land into the est-mere from the east and the wisle through weonodland from the south the ilfing have join the wisle take its name and run to the west of estmere and northward into the sea where it be call wisle-mouth -lrb- 12 -rrb- est-land be a large track of country have many town in each of which there be a king it produce a great quantity of honey and have abundance of fish the king and other rich man drink mare milk while the poor people and slave use only mead -lrb- 13 -rrb- they have many contest among themselves and the people of estum brew no ale as they have mead in profusion -lrb- 14 -rrb- there be also a particular custom observe by this nation that when any one die the body remain unburnt with the relation and friend for a month or two and the body of king and noble remain longer accord to they respective wealth sometimes for half a year during all which time it be keep in the house and drinking and sport continue until the body be consume -lrb- 15 -rrb- when the body be carry to the funeral pile the substance of the deceased which yet remain after the sport and drinking bout be divide into five or six heap or more accord to its value these heap be place at the distance of a mile from each other the largest heap at the greatest distance from the town and the lesser heap gradually diminish so that the smallest heap be nearest to the town where the dead body lie then all be summon who have fleet horse within the distance of five or six mile around and they all strive for the substance of the dead person he who have the swiftest horse gain the most distant and largest heap and the other in just proportion till the whole be win then every one take away he share as he own property : and owe to this custom swift horse be in great request and extremely dear when the wealth of the decease have be thus exhaust the body be take from the house and burn together with the dead man 's weapon and clothes and generally they expend the whole wealth of the decease by keep the body so long in the house before it be burnt and by these heap which be carry off by stranger it be the custom with the estum to burn the body of all the inhabitant and if any one can find a single bone unconsumed it be a cause of great offence these people also have the means of produce a very severe cold by which the dead body continue so long above ground without putrefy and by means of which if any one set a vessel of ale or water in the place they contrive that the liquor shall be freeze either in winter or summer -lrb- 16 -rrb- -lrb- 1 -rrb- alfr 's orosius by barrington p 16 collection of voyage and travels to omit the scanty notice which remain on record respect a voyage by two englishman to indium at so early a period all that be say of this singular incident in the saxon chronicle be -lrb- 2 -rrb- in the year 883 alfred send sighelm and athelstan to rome and likewise _ to the shrine _ of saint thoma and bartholomew in indium with the alms which he have vow -lrb- bartholomew be the messenger of christ in indium the extremity of the whole earth -rrb- -- the word print in _ italics _ be add in translate by the present editor to complete the obvious sense those within bracket be contain in one m codex of the saxon chronicle in addition to what be consider the most authentic text by bishop gibson and be obviously a note or commentary afterwards adopt into the text in transcription this short yet clear declaration of the actual voyage have be extend by succeed writer who attribute the whole merit to sighelm omit all mention of athelstan he co-adjutor in the holy mission the first member of the subsequent paraphrase of the saxon chronicle by harri though unauthorized be yet necessarily true as alfred could not have send messenger to a shrine of which he do not know the existence for the success of the voyage the safe return the promotion of sighelm and he bequest the original record give no authority although that be the obvious foundation of the story to which aserus have no allusion in he life of alfr in the year 883 alfred king of england hearing that there exist a christian church in the indy dedicate to the memory of st thoma and st bartholomew dispatch one sighelm or sithelm a favorite ecclesiastic of he court to carry he royal alms to that distant shrine sighelm successfully execute the honorable commission with which he have be entrust and return in safety into england after he return he be promote to the bishoprick of sherburn or shireburn in dorsetshire and it be record that he leave at he decease in the treasury of that church sundry spice and jewel which he have bring with he from the indy of this voyage william of malmsbury make twice mention once in the fourth chapter of he second book de gesti regum anglorum and secondly in the second book of he work entitle de gesti pontificum anglorum and in the chapter devote to the bishop of shireburn salisbury and winchester both of which be here add although the only authority for the story be contain in what have be already give from the saxon chronicle -lrb- 3 -rrb- king alfr be addict to give of alms confirm the privilege which he father have grant to the church and send many gift beyond sea to rome and to st thoma in indium he messenger in this business be sighelm bishop of sherburn who with great prosperity which be much to be wonder at in this age penetrate into indium whence he bring on he return splendid exotic gem and aromatic liquor of which the soil of that region be prolific sighelm have go beyond sea charge with alms from the king even penetrate with wonderful prosperity to saint thoma in indium a thing much to be admire in this age and bring thence on he return certain foreign kind of precious stone which abound in that region some of which be yet to be see in the monument of he church in the foregoing account of the voyage of sighelm from the first notice in the saxon chronicle through the addition of malmsbury and the amplify paraphrase by harri we have a instance of the manner in which ingenious man permit themselves to blend they own imagination with original record superad utterly groundless circumstance and fancy conception to the plain historical fact thus a motely rhetorical tissue of real incident and downright fable be impose upon the world which each successive author continually improve into deeper falsehood we have here likewise a instance of the way in which ancient manuscript first illustrate by commentary become interpolate by successive transcriber adopt those illustration into the text and how many fabricator of story first mislead by these additament and afterwards mislead the public through a vain desire of produce a morsel of eloquence although continually quote original and contemporary authority have acquire the undeserved fame of excellent historian while a multitude of the incident which they relate have no foundation whatever in the truth of record he only who have diligently and faithfully labor through original record and contemporary writer honestly endeavor to compose the authentic history of a interesting period and have carefully compare in he progress the flippant worse than inaccuracy of writer he have be teach to consider as masterly historian can form a adequate estimate of the enormity and frequency of this tendency to romance the immediate subject of these observation be slight and trivial but the evil itself be wide-spread and important and deserve severe reprehension as many portion of we national history have be strangely disfigure by such indefensible practice -lrb- 1 -rrb- harri i 873 hakluyt v ii 38 -lrb- 2 -rrb- chron sax ed gibson p 86 -lrb- 3 -rrb- hakluyt ii 88 section v _ travels of john erigena to athen in the ninth century _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- john erigena of the british nation descend from noble progenitor and bear in the town of st david in wale while the english be oppress by the cruel war and ravages of the dane and the whole land be in confusion undertake a long journey to athen and there spend many year in the study of the grecian chaldean and arabian literature he there frequent all the place and school of the philosopher and even visit the oracle of the sun which esculapius have construct for himself have accomplish the object of he travels he return through italy and france where for he extraordinary learning he be much favor by charle the bald and afterwards by lewi the stammerer he translate into latin in 858 the book of dionysius the areopagite concern the heavenly hierarchy then send from constantinople go afterwards into britain he become preceptor to alfred king of england and he child and at the request of that prince he employ he leisure in translate the moral of aristotle and he book call the secret of secret or of the right government of prince into chaldaic arabic and latin certainly a most exquisite undertaking at last be in the abbey of malmsbury where he have go for he recreation in the year 884 and read to certain evil-disposed disciple they put he to death -lrb- 1 -rrb- hakluyt ii 38 section vi _ geography of the known world in the ninth century as describe by king alfr _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- introduction though not strictly conformable to we plan as be neither a journey or voyage it yet seem incumbent to present we reader with this curious british production of the great alfred king of england which give a singular record of the geographical knowledge of the world in the ninth century it be originally write by orosius a spanish christian who flourish in the end of the fourth and beginning of the fifth century and who publish a kind of history of the world down to a d 416 which remain in good repute among the learn till about a hundred year ago but be now much neglect near a thousand year ago the work of orosius be translate into anglo-saxon by alfred king of england but with great freedom and much licence often use he author merely as a foundation for a paraphrase omit most of the introductory chapter to each book sometimes leave out considerable passage and often insert new matter this be peculiarly the case with the first chapter of the first book contain the whole of the geography and which be all that have any reference to the nature of we work the honorable daine barrington who publish the anglo-saxon version with a english translation inform we that the original m be in the cotton library _ tiberius _ i and be suppose to have be write in the ninth or tenth century but that in make he translation he use a transcript make by mr elstob occasionally collate with the cotton m and with some other transcript but before publish a work of such curiosity and interest he ought to have make sure of possess a perfect copy by the most scrupulous comparison of he transcript with the original m in the follow republication of the geographical chapter much care have be take to correct error chiefly in regard to direction as east west north and south be often use interchangeably in the translation by mr barrington most of the note be from that edition or from jr forster who reprint so much of this chapter as refer to northern geography and who appear to have study that part of the subject with great care as a specimen of the anglo-saxon or the language of england near a thousand year ago we have give the first sentence of this geographical chapter in the ordinary roman letter with a literal translation _ anglo-saxon _ ure yldran calne thysne ymbhwyrft thys middangearde cwaeth orosius swa swa oceanus ymbligeth utan wone man garsecg hatath on threo todaeldon _ literal translation _ we elder have divide all of this middle-earth quoth orosius which oceanus surround which man calleth _ garsecg _ into three deal _ into excessive laughter to the great astonishment of he guest but no one presume to inquire into the cause of he mirth all keep silence till dinner be end after dinner when the king have retire to he bed-chamber to divest himself of he robe three of he noble earl harold a abbot and a bishop who be more familiar with he than any of the other courtier follow he into the chamber and boldly ask the reason of he mirth as it have appear strange to the whole court that he majesty should break out into unseemly laughter on so solemn a day while all other be silent i saw say he most wonderful thing and therefore do i not laugh without cause and they as be customary with all man become therefore the more anxious to learn the occasion of he mirth and humbly beseech he to impart the reason to they after muse for some time he at length inform they that seven sleeper have rest during two hundred year on mount ceelius lie always hitherto on they right side but that in the very moment of he laughter they have turn themselves over to they left side in which posture they should continue asleep for other seventy-four year be a dire omen of future misery to mankind for all those thing which we savior have foretell to he disciple that be to be fulfil about the end of the world should come to pass within those seventy-four year that nation should rise up against nation and kingdom against kingdom and there would be in many place earthquake pestilence and famine and terrible apparition in the heaven and great sign with great alteration of dominion war of the infidel against the christian and victory gain by the christian over the unbeliever and as they wonder at these thing the king explain to they the passion of the seven sleeper with the shape and proportion of each of they body which wonderful thing no man have hitherto commit to write and all this in so plain and distinct a manner as if he have always dwell along with they in consequence of this discourse the earl of london be in my early youth place for my education first at westminster and afterwards prosecute my study at oxford have excel many of my fellow student in learn aristotle i enter upon the study of company i proffer my service for the performance of any speedy or important affair and accordingly have execute many commission with good success i become know to and much beloved by the illustrious earl and sail with he to normandy be there appoint he secretary i govern he court at my pleasure though envy by several abase whom i think fit and prefer other at my will but prompt by youthful pride i begin even to be wearied of this place in which i be advance so far beyond my birth and with a inconstant and over-ambitious mind i vehemently aspire on all occasion to climb to higher elevation about this time there spread a report through normandy that several archbishop of the empire and some even of the secular prince be desirous for the salvation of they soul to go in pilgrimage to jerusalem there to pay they devotions at the holy sepulchre upon this several of we who be of the household of we lord the earl both gentleman and clerk of whom i be the principal person have receive company of this archbishop amount to seven thousand person all properly provide for the expedition and we travel prosperously through many province arrive at length at the city of constantinople we there do reverence to the emperor alexius visit the church of sanctum sophium and devoutly kiss many sacred relic depart from constantinople we travel through lycium where we fall into the hand of arabian thief and after we have be rob of infinite sum of money and have lose many of we people we escape with extreme peril of we life and at length enter joyfully into the most anxiously wished-for city of jerusalem we be there receive by the most reverend aged and holy patriarch sophronius with a great melody of cymbal by torch-light and be convey in solemn procession by a great company of christ from the most glorious sepulchre of christ we be conduct to visit the other sacred monument of the holy city and see with weep eye a great number of holy church and oratory which achius the soldan of egypt have lately destroy and have deeply bewail all the ruin of that most holy city both within and without its wall and have bestow money for the re-edifying of some of these we express the most ardent desire to go forth into the country that we might wash ourselves in the sacred river jordan and that we might visit and kiss all the holy footstep of the bless redeemer but the arabian robber who lurk in every part of the country would not suffer we to travel far from the city on account of they number and savage manners about the spring of the year there arrive a fleet of ship from genoa at the port of joppa and when the christian merchant have exchange all they commodity in the town upon the coast and have likewise visit the holy place we all embark after be toss about upon the sea by many storm and tempest we land at brundusium whence with a prosperous journey we travel through apulium to rome where we visit the habitation of the holy apostle st peter and st paul and perform we devotions at various monument of the holy martyr in different part of the city from thence the archbishop and other prince of the empire journey towards the right hand for germany while we decline to the left hand into france take we leaf of each other with indescribable courtesey and kindly greet and at length of thirty horseman of we who go from normandy fat and lusty scarce twenty icelander _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- although the discovery contain in this and the next subsequent chapter be certainty precede in point of time by the voyage of the two mahomedan in chap iv and the insertion of these two chapter ii and iii in this place may therefore be consider as a deviation from the chronological order of we plan it seem proper and even necessary that they should be both introduce here as present a unbroken series of the discovery of the norwegian and as fully authorize by the geographical principle of we arrangement among the many petty sovereign vikingr or chieftan of norway who have be reduce to subjection by harold harfagr or the fair-haired be one name thorer thorwald the relative of this person have live at the court of earl hayne whence he have be oblige to fly on account of have commit a murder and go to iceland where he settle a considerable track of country with a new colony eric-raude or red-head the son of thorwald be long persecute by a powerful neighbor name eyolf saur because eric have kill some of eyolf 's servant and at length eric kill eyolf likewise for this and other crime he be condemn to go into banishment for three year and know that a man name gunbiorn have previously discover certain bank to the west of iceland name from he gunbiorn 's schieran or gunbar bank and likewise a country of considerable extent still farther to the westwards he determine on make a voyage of discovery to that country set sail therefore from iceland he soon fall in with a point of land call hirjalfs-ness and continue he voyage to the south-west he enter a large inlet to which he give the name of erics-sound and pass the winter on a pleasant island in that neighborhood in the following year he explore the continent and return to iceland in the third year he represent he new discovery in the fairest light bestow lavish praise on the rich meadow fine wood and plentiful fishery of the country which he call greenland that he might induce a considerable number of people to join with he in colonize this new country accordingly there set out for this place twenty-five vessel carry people of both sex household furniture implement of all kind and cattle for breeding of which only fourteen vessel arrive in safety these first colonist be soon follow by many more both from iceland and norway and in a few year they number be say to have increase so much as to occupy both the eastern and western coast of greenland this be the ordinary and best authenticate account of the discovery and settlement of _ old _ greenland which rest on the credit of the great northern historian snorro sturleson judge of iceland who write in the year 1215 yet other assert that greenland have be know long before and grind they assertion on letters-patent from the emperor lewi the pious in 834 and a bull of gregory iv in 835 in which permission be give to archbishop ansgar to convert the sueone danes sclavonian and it be add the norwaeher farrier greenlander halsingalander icelander and scridevind even allow both charter and bull to be genuine it be probable that the copy which have come down to we time be interpolate and that for gronlandon and islandon we ought to read quenlandon and hitlandon mean the finlander and hitlander : quenland be the old name of finland and hitland or hialtaland the norwegian name of the shetland island it be even not improbable that all the name in these ancient deed after the sueone dane and sclavonian have be interpolate in a later period as st rembert the immediate successor of ansgar and who write he life only mention the sueone dane and sclavonian together with other nation in the north and even adam of breman only mention these three and other neighbouring and surround nation -lrb- 2 -rrb- hence the authority of st rembert and snorro sturleson remain firm and unshaken in spite of these falsified copy of the papal bull and imperial patent and we may rest assure that iceland be not discover 2 -rrb- vit s anscharius ap langeb script dan i 451 ad brem hist eccle lib i cap 17 chap iii _ early discovery of winland by the icelander about ad 1001 _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- the passion which the nordman or norman have always manifest for maritime expedition still prevail among they in the cold and inhospitable region of iceland and greenland a icelander name herjolf be accustom to make a trading voyage every year to different country in which latterly he be accompany by he son biorn about the year 1001 they ship be separate by a storm and biorn learn on he arrival in norway that he father have sail for greenland to which place he resolve to follow he father but another storm drive he a great way to the south-west of he intended course and he fall in with a extensive flat country cover all over with thick wood and just as he set out on he return he discover a island on the coast he make no stay at either of these place but the wind be now fall he make all the haste he could to return by a north-east course to greenland where he report the discovery which he have make lief the son of eric-raude who inherit from he father a inordinate desire of distinguish himself by make discovery and plant colony immediately fit out a vessel carry thirty-five man and take biorn along with he set sail in quest of this newly discover country the first land discover in this voyage be barren and rocky on which account lief give it the name of helleland or rockland proceeding farther they come to a low coast have a sandy soil which be overgrow with wood for which reason it be call mark-land or the woody-land two day after this they again see land have a island lie opposite to its northern coast and on the mainland they discover the mouth of a river up which they sail the bush on the bank of this river bear sweet berry the temperature of the air be mild the soil fertile -lrb- 2 -rrb- and the river abound in fish particularly in excellent salmon continue to sail up the river they come to a lake out of which the river take its rise and here they pass the winter in the shortest day of winter the sun remain eight hour above the horizon and consequently the longest day exclusive of the dawn and twilight must have be sixteen hour from this circumstance it follow that the place in which they be be in about 49  of north latitude and as they arrive by a south-westerly course from old greenland after have clear cape farewell it must either have be the river gander or the bay of exploit in the island now call newfoundland it could not be on the northern coast of the gulf of st lawrence as in that case they must have navigate through the strait of belleisle which could not have escape they notice in this place they erect several hut for they accommodation during winter and they one day find in the thicket a german name tyrker one of they own people who have wander among the wood and be miss for some time while absent he have subsist upon wild grape from which he tell they that in he country they use to make wine and from this circumstance lief call the country _ winland det gode _ or wine-land the good -lrb- 3 -rrb- in the follow spring they return to greenland and thorwald lief 's maternal grandfather make a trip with the same crew that have attend he grandson in order to make farther advance in this new discovery and it be not at all to be wonder at if people of every rank be eager to discover a better habitation than the miserable coast of greenland and the little less dreary island of iceland in this voyage the coast of the newly discover land be examine towards the west or rather the north-west next summer lief sail again to winland and explore the coast to the east or south-east the coast be so much cover with wood and beset with island that they could not perceive a human creature or animal of any kind in the third summer they examine the island on the coast of winland and so damage they ship that they find it necessary to build a new one lay up they old vessel on a promontory to which they give the name of kiaeler-ness in they new vessel they proceed to examine the eastern or south-eastern shore of winland and in they progress they fall in with three boat cover with hide have three man in each these they seize but one man find means to escape from they and they wantonly butcher all the rest soon after this they be attack by a great number of the native arm with bow and arrow from which they screen themselves in they ship with a fence of plank and they defend themselves with so much spirit that they enemy be force to retire after give they battle for a hour thorwald receive a severe wound from a arrow in this skirmish of which he die and over he grave on a cape or promontory two cross be erect at he request from which the cape be call krossa-ness or cross point to the native of winland the icelander give the name of skraellinger signify cutting or dwarf on account of they being of very low stature these be probably the ancestor of the present eskimaux who be the same people with the greenlander and be call eskimantsik in the language of the abenakus on account of they eating raw fish in the same manner as the russian in they official state papers call the samojed siroje ` zi because they also eat raw and frozen fish and flesh in the same year thorstein the third son of eric-raude set sail for winland take with he he wife gudridthe daughter of thorbern with he child and servant amount in all to twenty-five person but they be force by a storm on the western coast of greenland where they be oblige to spend the winter and where thorstein die with a large proportion of he retinue probably of the scurvy next spring gudrid take the dead body of she husband home and thorfin surname kallsefner a icelander of some consequence descend from king regner-lodbrok marry the widow of thorstein from which he consider himself entitle to the possession of the newly discover country he accordingly sail for winland with a vast quantity of household furniture implement of all kind and several cattle and accompany by sixty-five man and five woman with whom he begin to establish a regular colony he be immediately visit by the skraellinger who barter with he give the most valuable fur for such wares as the icelander have to give in exchange the native would willingly have purchase the weapon of the icelander but this be expressly and judiciously forbid by thorfin yet one of they find mean to steal a battle-ax of which he immediately make a trial on one of he countryman whom he kill with one blow on which a third person seize the mischievous weapon and throw it into the sea during a stay of three year thorfin acquire a large stock of rich fur and other merchandize with which he return to greenland and at length remove to iceland he purchase a estate in the northern part of syssel and build a very elegant house which he call glaumba after he death he widow gudrid make a pilgrimage to rome whence she return and end she day in a nunnery in iceland which be build for she by she son snorro who be bear in winland sometime afterwards finbog and helgo two icelander fit out two ship carry thirty man with which they make a voyage to winland in this expedition they be accompany by freidi the daughter of eric-raude but by the turbulence of she disposition she occasion many division and quarrel in the infant colony in one of which finbog and helgo be both kill together with thirty of they follower upon this freidi return to greenland where she live for some time universally detest and despise and die in the utmost misery the remain colonist be disperse and nothing farther that can be depend on remains on record concern they even the icelandic colony in greenland have disappear and the eastern coast on which especially it be settle have become long inaccessible in consequence of the immense accumulation of ice in the strait between it and iceland to this it may be add that in the beginning of the fifteenth century a prodigious number of people be carry off in norway and iceland by a disease or pestilence call the _ black death _ probably the scurvy in its worst state occasion by a succession of inclement season and extreme scarcity impel the famished people to satisfy the craving of hunger upon unwholesome food deprive of all assistance from iceland and norway the colonist of greenland and winland be in all probability extirpate by the continual hostility of the skraellinger or eskimaux and the fabulous idea of any remnant of those in winland have still a existence in the interior of newfoundland be entirely unworthy of any consideration -lrb- 1 -rrb- forster hist of disc in the north 82 -lrb- 2 -rrb- every quality must be judge
