new england new holland sandwich island society island and a multitude of much worse name -- e chap iv _ travels of two mahomedan in indium and china in the ninth century _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- introduction this curious remnant of antiquity be translate from the arabic and publish in 1718 by eusebius renaudot a learn member of the french academy and of the academy of inscription and belle lettre it be not know by whom the travels be actually perform neither can they exact date be ascertain as the commencement of the m which be translate by renaudot be imperfect but it appear to have be write in the 237th year of the hegira or in the year 851 of the christian era though entitle the travels of _ two _ mahomedan the travels seem to have be mostly perform by one person only the latter portion be chiefly a commentary upon the former and appear to have be the work of one abu zeid al hasan of siraf and to have be write about the 803d year of the hegira or ad 915 in this commentary indeed some report be give of the travels of another mahomedan into china the m employ by renaudot belong to the library of the count de seignelay and appear to have be write in the year 619 of the hegira or ad 1173 the great value of this work be that it contain the very earliest account of china pen above four hundred year earlier than the travels of marco polo who be esteem the first author on the subject before this publication appear there be many curious and remarkable passage in these travels which convey information respect custom and event that be nowhere else to be find and though some of these carry a fabulous appearance the greatest part of they have be confirm and justify by the best writer in succeed age the first portion or the actual narrative begin abruptly on account of some portion of the original manuscript be lose which would probably have give the name and country of the author and the date and occasion of he voyage in the accompany commentary by abu zeid we be inform that the date of the narrative be of the hegira 237 ad 851 which circumstance be probably contain in the miss part of the manuscript but though write then it be probable that the first journey of the author be undertake at least twenty year before that date or in 831 as he observe that he make a second journey into the same country sixteen year afterwards and we may allow four year for the time spend in the two journy and the intervene space besides the delay of composition after he last return though not mention it be probable he travels be undertake for the purpose of trade as we can hardly suppose he to have twice visit those distant country merely for the satisfaction of curiosity with regard to the second treatise or commentary it seem probable that when the affair of china become better know some prince or person of distinction have desire abu zeid to examine the former relation and to inform he how far the fact of the original work be confirm by succeed account the date of the commentary be not certainly ascertainable yet it appear that eben wahab travel into china ah 285 ad 898 and that abu zeid have converse with this man after he return and have receive from he the fact which be insert in he discourse which therefore be probably only sixty or seventy year posterior to the actual treatise of the nameless traveller -lrb- 1 -rrb- translation from renaudot 8vo lond 1733 see likewise harris i 522 section i _ original account of indium and china by a mahomedan traveller of the ninth century _ the _ third _ of the sea we have to mention be that of herkend -lrb- 1 -rrb- between this sea and that of delarowus there be many island say to be in number 1900 which divide those two sea from each other -lrb- 2 -rrb- and be govern by a queen -lrb- 3 -rrb- among these island they find ambergris in lump of extraordinary bigness and also in smaller piece which resemble plant tear up this amber be produce at the bottom of the sea in the same manner as plant be produce upon the earth and when the sea be tempestuous it be tear up from the bottom by the violence of the wave and wash to the shore in the form of a mushroom or truffle these island be full of that species of palm tree which bear the cocoa nut and they be from one to four league distant from each other all inhabit the wealth of the inhabitant consist in shell of which even the royal treasury be full the workman in these island be exceedingly expert and make shirt and vest or tunic all of one piece of the fiber of the cocoa nut of the same tree they build ship and house and they be skilful in all other workmanship they shell they have from the sea at certain time when they rise up to the surface and the inhabitant throw branch of the cocoa nut tree into the water to which the shell stick these shell they call kaptaje beyond these island and in the sea of herkend be serendib -lrb- 4 -rrb- or ceylon the chief of all these island which be call dobijat it be entirely surround by the sea and on its coast they fish for pearl in this country there be a mountain call rahun to the top of which adam be say to have ascend where he leave the print of he foot seventy cubit long on a rock and they say he other foot stand in the sea at the same time about this mountain there be mine of ruby opal and amethyst this island be of great extent and have two king and it produce aloe wood gold precious stone and pearl which last be fish for on the coast and there be also find a kind of large shell which be use for trumpet and much esteem in the same sea towards serendib there be other island not so many in number as those formerly mention but of vast extent and unknown one of these be call ramnus which be divide among a number of prince and in it be find plenty of gold the inhabitant have cocoa nut tree which supply they with food and with which also they paint they body and oil themselves the custom of the country be that no man can marry till he have kill a enemy and bring off he head if he have kill two he claim two wife and if he have slay fifty he may have fifty wife this custom proceed from the number of enemy with which they be surround so that he who kill the greatest number be the most consider these island of ramnus abound with elephant red-wood and tree call chairzan and the inhabitant eat human flesh these island separate the sea of herkend from the sea of shelabet and beyond they be other call najabalus which be pretty well people both man and woman go naked except that the woman wear apron make of leaf when shipping go among these island the inhabitant come off in boat bring with they ambergri and cocoa nut which they barter for iron for be free from the inconveniency either of extreme heat or cold they want no clothing beyond these two island be the sea of andaman the people on this coast eat human flesh quite raw they complexion be black with frizzled hair they countenance and eye frightful they foot very large almost a cubit in length and they go quite naked they have no sort of bark or other vessel or they would seize and devour all the passenger they could lay they hand upon when ship have be keep back by contrary wind and be oblige to anchor on this barbarous coast for procure water they commonly lose some of they man beyond this there be a inhabit mountainous island which be say to contain mine of silver but as it do not lie in the usual track of ship many have search for it in vain though remarkable for a very lofty mountain call kashenai a ship sailing in its latitude once get sight of this mountain and steer for the coast where some people be send on shore to cut wood : the man kindle a fire from which there run out some melt silver on which they conclude that there must have be a silver mine in the place and they ship a considerable quantity of the earth or ore but they encounter a terrible storm on they voyage back and be force to throw all they ore overboard to lighten the vessel since that time the mountain have be several time carefully seek for but no one have ever be able to find it again there be many such island in those sea more in number than can be reckon some inaccessible by seaman and some unknown to they it often happen in these sea that a whitish cloud suddenly appear over-head which let down a long thin tongue or spout quite to the surface of the water which be then turn swiftly round as if by a whirlwind and if a vessel happen to be in the way she be immediately swallow up in the vortex at length this cloud mount up again and discharge itself in prodigious rain but it be not know whether this water be suck up by the cloud or how this phenomenon come to pass all these sea be subject to prodigious storm which make they boil up like water over a fire at which time the wave dash the ship against the island with unspeakable violence to they utter destruction and even fish of all size be throw dead on shore against the rock by the extreme agitation of the sea the wind which commonly blow upon the sea of herkend be from a different quarter or from the nw but this sea be likewise subject to as violent agitation as those just mention and there ambergri be tear up from the bottom particularly where it be very deep and the deeper the sea so much the more valuable be the ambergris which it produce it be likewise observe that when this sea be toss by tempestuous wind it sparkle like fire and it be infested with a certain kind of fish call lockham which frequently prey upon man -lrb- 5 -rrb- \* \* \* \* \* among other circumstance the fire which frequently happen at canfu be not the least remarkable canfu be the port of all the ship of the arab who trade to china and fire be there very frequent because all the house be of wood or of split cane besides ship be often lose in go and come or they be plunder or oblige to make too long a stay in harbor or to sell they goods out of the country subject to the arab and there to make up they cargo in short ship be under a necessity of waste much time in refit and many other cause of delay soliman -lrb- 6 -rrb- the merchant write that at canfu which be a principal staple of merchant there be a mahomedan judge appoint by the emperor of china who be authorize to judge in every cause which arise among the mahomedan who resort to these part upon festival day he perform the public service of religion to the mahomedan and pronounce the usual sermon or _ kotbat _ which he conclude with the usual form of prayer for the sultan of the moslem the merchant of irak or persium who trade to canfu be no way dissatisfy with the conduct of this judge in the administration of he office because he decision be just and equitable and conformable to the koran respect the place whence ship depart and those they touch at many person affirm that the navigation be perform in the follow order : most of the chinese ship take in they cargo at siraff -lrb- 7 -rrb- where also they ship they goods which come from basra oman and other port and this be do because there be frequent storm and many shallows in those sea from basra to siraff be a hundred and twenty league and when ship have load at this latter place they take in water there also from thence they sail to a place call mascat in the extremity of the province of oman which be about two hundred league from siraff on the east coast of this sea between siraff and mascat be a place call nasir bani al sasack and a island call ebn kahowan and in this sea there be rock call oman and a narrow strait call dordur between two rock through which ship often venture to pass but the chinese snip dare not there be also two rock call kossir and howare which scarce appear above the water 's edge after they be clear of these rock they steer to a place call shitu oman and take in water at muscat which be draw up from well and be here also supply with cattle from the province of oman from mascat the ship take they departure for indium and first touch at kaucammalus which be a month 's sail from mascat with a fair wind this be a frontier place and the chief arsenal in the province of that name and here the chinese ship put in and be in safety and procure fresh water the chinese ship pay here a thousand dram for duty whereas other pay only from one dinar to ten from thence they begin to enter the sea of herkend and have sail through it they touch at a place call lajabalus where the inhabitant do not understand arabic or any other language in use among merchant they wear no clothes be white and weak in they foot it be say they woman be not to be see and that the man leave the island in canoe hollow out of one piece to go in quest of they and carry they cocoa nut mousa and palm wine this last liquor be white and when drink fresh be sweet like honey and have the taste of cocoa nut milk if keep some time it become as strong as wine but after some day change to vinegar these people give this wine and the small quantity of amber which be throw up on they coast for bit of iron the bargain be make by sign but they be extremely alert and be very apt to carry off iron from the merchant without make any return from lajabalus the ship steer for calabar the name of a kingdom on the right hand beyond the indy which depend on the kingdom of zabage _ bar _ signify a coast in the language of the country the inhabitant be dress in those sort of striped garment which the arab call fauta and they commonly wear only one at a time which fashion be common to people of all rank at this place they take in water which be draw from well that be feed by spring and which be prefer to that which be procure from cistern or tank calabar be about a month 's voyage from a place call kaukam which be almost upon the skirt of the sea of herkend in ten day after this ship reach betuma from whence in ten day more they come to kadrange in all the island and peninsula of the indy water be to be find by digging in this last mention place there be a very lofty mountain which be entirely inhabit by slave and fugitive from thence in ten day they arrive at senef where be fresh water and from whence come the aromatic wood which we call hud al senefus here be a king the inhabitant be black and they wear two striped garment have water at this place it be ten day passage to sanderfulat a island which have fresh water they then steer through the sea of sanjus and so to the gate of china for so they call certain rock and shallows which form a narrow strait in that sea through which the ship be oblige to pass it require a month to sail from sanderfulat to china and it take eight whole day to steer through among the rock and shoal when a ship have get through the before mention gate she go with the flood tide into a fresh water gulf and drop anchor in the chief port of china which be call canfu -lrb- 8 -rrb- where they have fresh water both from spring and river as also in most of the other city of china the city be adorn with large square and be supply with every thing necessary for defense against a enemy and in most of the other province of the empire there be city of strength similarly fortify in this port the tide ebb and flow twice in twenty-four hour but whereas from basra to the island of bani kahouan it flow when the moon be at full and ebb when she rise and when she set from near banus kahouan quite to the coast of china it be flood tide when the moon rise and ebb when she be at she height and so on the contrary when she set it be flow water and when she be quite hide under the horizon the tide fall they say that in the island of muljan between serendib and calum on the eastern shore of the indy there be negro who go quite naked and when they meet a stranger they hang he up by the heel and slice he into piece which they eat quite raw these negro who have no king feed chiefly on fish mousa cocoa nut and sugar cane it be report that in some part of this sea there be a small kind of fish which fly above the water and be call the sea locust that in another part there be a fish which leave the sea get up into the cocoa nut tree and have drain they of they juice return to the sea and it be add that there be a fish like a lobster or crab which petrify as soon as it be take out of its element and that when pulverize it be a good remedy for several disease of the eye they say also that near zabage there be a volcanic mountain which can not be approach which send forth a thick smoke by day and throw out flame at night at the foot of which be two spring of fresh water one hot and the other cold the chinese be dress in silk garment both in summer and winter and this dress be common both to the prince and peasant in winter they wear drawer of a particular make which reach to they foot and of these they put on two three four five or more one over the other if they can afford it and be very careful to be cover quite down to they foot because of the damp which be very great and of which they be extremely apprehensive in summer they only wear a single garment of silk or some such light dress but they have no turban they common food be rice which they eat frequently with a broth make of meat or fish like that use by the arab and which they pour upon the rice they king eat wheaten bread and the flesh of all kind of animal not except swine and some other not use by we they have several sort of fruit as apple lemon quince moulat sugar cane citrul fig grape cucumber of two sort tree which produce a substance like meal walnut almond filbert pistachio plumb apricot service and cocoa nut but no store of palm of which they have only a few about private house they drink be a kind of wine make of rice have no other wine in the country neither be any other import by they they do not even know what wine be nor will they drink of it they have vinegar also and a kind of comfit like that call _ natef _ by the arab and some other the chinese be by no means nice in point of cleanliness not wash with water when they ease nature but only wipe with paper they do not scruple to eat of animal which have die and they practice many other thing like the magian -lrb- 9 -rrb- and in truth the two religion be much similar they woman appear uncovered and adorn they head with many small ivory comb of which they wear sometimes a score at one time the head of the man be cover by a cap of a particular make thief be put to death as soon as catch the indian and chinese agree that there be four great or principal king in the world all of they allow that the king of the arab be the first and most powerful of king the most wealthy and the most excellent every way because he be the prince and head of a great religion and because no other surpass he the emperor of china reckon himself next after the king of the arab after he the king of the greek and lastly the balhara -lrb- 10 -rrb- or king of the moharmus al adon or people who have they ear bore the balhara be the most illustrious sovereign in all the indy and though all the other king in indium be master and independent each in they own dominion they thus so far acknowledge he preeminence that when he send ambassador to the other prince they be receive with extraordinary honor this king make magnificent present after the manner of the arab and have vast number of horse and elephant and great treasure in money he silver coin be what we call thartarian dram be equal to one and a half of the arabian dram they be coin with the die of the prince and bear the year of he reign count from the last year of the reign of he predecessor they compute not they year from the era of mahome like the arab but only by the year of they successive king most of these prince live a long time many of they have reign above fifty year and those of the country believe that the length of they life and reign be grant in recompence of they kindness to the arab for there be no prince more heartily affectionate to the arab and they subject profess the same kindness for we balhara be not a proper name but a appellative common to all those king like cosro and some other the country under the dominion of the prince begin on the coast of the province call kamcam and reach by land to the confines of china he be surround by the dominion of many king who be at war with he yet he never march against they one of these be the king of harez who have very numerous force and be stronger in cavalry than all the other prince of the indy he be a enemy to the arab neither be there any prince in indium who have a greater aversion to the mahomedan though he confess they king to be the greatest of prince he dominion be on a promontory where be much riches many camel and abundance of other cattle the inhabitant traffic for silver and they say there be mine of that metal on the continent there be no robber in this country nor in the rest of the indy on one side of this country be that of tafek which be not of very great extent this king have the finest white woman in all the indy but he be awed by the king about he as he army be very small he have a great affection for the arab as well as the balhara these kingdom border upon the land of a king call ramus who be at war with the king of harez and with the balhara likewise this prince be not much consider either for the dignity of he birth or the antiquity of he kingdom but he force be more numerous than those of the balhara and even than those of the king of harez and tafek it be say that he appear in the field at the head of fifty thousand elephant and commonly march in the rainy season because he elephant can not move at any other time as they be unable to bear thirst he army be say commonly to contain from ten to fifteen thousand tent in this country they make cotton garment of such extraordinary fineness and perfection as be to be see nowhere else these garment be mostly round and be wove so extremely fine that they may be draw through a moderately size ring shell be current in this country as small money and they have abundance of gold and silver aloe wood and sable skin of which they make they horse-furniture in this country be the famous karkandan that be the rhinoceros or unicorn which have but one horn on he forehead on which there be a round spot with the representation of a man the whole horn be black except the spot in the middle which be white the rhinoceros be much smaller than the elephant and resemble the buffalo from the neck downward and excel all other creature in extraordinary strength he leg be all one thickness from the shoulder to the foot and the hoof be not cleave the elephant fly from the rhinoceros whose lowing be like that of a ox with something of the cry of the camel he flesh be not forbid and we have eat of it there be great number of this creature in the fen of this country as also in all the other province of indium but the horn of these be most esteemed have generally upon they the figure of man peacock fish and other resemblance the chinese adorn they girdle with these sort of figure so that some of they girdle be worth two or three thousand piece of gold in china and sometimes more the price augment with the beauty of the figure all these thing be to be purchase in the kingdom of rahmus for shell which be the current money of the country after this country there be a inland state distant from the coast and call kaschbin of which the inhabitant be white and bear they ear they have camel and they country be for the most part desert and full of mountain farther on the coast there be a small kingdom call hitrange which be very poor but in its bay the sea throw up great quantity of ambergris and they have elephant tooth and pepper but the inhabitant eat this last green because of the small quantity they gather beyond these there be other kingdom but they number and name be unknown among these be one name mujet the inhabitant of which be white and dress after the chinese manner they country be full of mountain have white top and of very great extent in which there be great quantity of musk esteem the most exquisite of any in the world they have continual war with all the surround kingdom the kingdom of mabet be beyond that of mujet wherein be many city and the inhabitant have even a greater resemblance to the chinese than those of mujet for they have officer or eunuch like those who govern the city among the chinese the country of mabet border upon china and be at peace with the emperor but not subject to he the king of mabet send ambassador every year with present to the emperor of china who in return send ambassador and present to mabet but when the ambassador of mabet enter china they be very carefully watch lest they should survey the country and form design of conquest which would be no difficult matter as they country be very extensive and extremely populous and as they be only divide from china by rock and mountain it be say that in the country of china there be above two hundred city have jurisdiction over other each of which have a governor and a eunuch or lieutenant canfu be one of these city be the port for all shipping and have jurisdiction over twenty town a town be raise to the dignity of a city by the grant of certain large trumpet these be three or four cubit in length and as large about as can be grasp by both hand grow smaller towards the end which be fit to the mouth on the outside they be adorn with chinese ink and may be hear at the distance of a mile each city have four gate at each of which five of these trumpet be station which be sound at certain hour of the day and night there be also ten drum in each city which be beat at the same time and this be do as a public token of obedience to the emperor and to point out the hour of the day and night to the inhabitant and for ascertain the time they have sun dial and clock with weight -lrb- 11 -rrb- in china they use a great quantity of copper money like that name falus by the arabian which be the only sort of small money and be current all over the country and be indeed the only current coin yet they emperor have treasure like other king contain abundance of gold and silver with jewel pearl silk and vast quantity of rich stuff of all kind which be only consider as moveable or merchandize and from foreign commerce they derive ivory frankincense copper in bar tortoise shell and unicorn horn with which they adorn they girdle of animal they have abundance particularly of beast of burden such as oxen horse ass and camel but they have no arabian horse they have a excellent kind of earth of which they make a species of ware equal in fineness to glass and almost equally transparent when merchant arrive at canfu the chinese seize they cargo which they convey to warehouse where the goods be detain six month until the last merchant ship of the season have arrive they then detain three part in ten of every species of commodity or thirty per cent as duty and return the rest to the merchant besides which if the emperor have a mind for any particular article he officer have a right of take it in preference to any other person pay for it however to the utmost value and they dispatch this business with great expedition and without the least injustice they commonly take the whole importation of camphor on the account of the emperor and pay for it at the rate of fifty _ fakuge _ per _ man _ each fakuge be worth a thousand _ falus _ or piece of copper coin when it happen that the emperor do not take the camphor it sell for half as much again the chinese do not bury they dead till the day twelve month after they decease but keep they all this time in coffin in some part of they house have previously dry they by means of quicklime the body of they king be embalm with aloe and camphor they mourn during three whole year and whoever transgress this law be punish with the bamboo a chastisement to which both man and woman be subject and be at the same time reproach for not shew concern for the death of they parent they bury they dead in deep pit much like those in use among the arab during all the time that the dead body be preserve in the house meat and drink be regularly set before it every evening and if they find these go in the morning they imagine that the dead have consume all and all this time they cease not from bewail they loss insomuch that they expence upon these occasion in pay the last duty to they deceased relation be exorbitant and often consume they wealth and estate to the utter ruin of the living in former time they bury very rich apparel and those expensive girdle already mention with the body of they king and other of the blood royal but this custom be now discontinue because it have happen that the body have be dig up from they grave by thief for the sake of what be bury with they the whole nation great and small rich and poor be teach to read and write the title of they viceroy or governor be varied accord to the dignity and rank of the city under they government those of the smaller city be call _ tus _ which signify the governor of a town those of the greater city such as canfu be stile _ difu _ and the eunuch or lieutenant be stile _ tukam _ these lieutenant be select from among the inhabitant of the city there be also a supreme judge call _ lakshima-makvan _ and they have other name for other officer which we do not know how properly to express a person be never raise to the dignity of a prince or governor of a city until he have attain to he fortieth year for then they say he have acquire experience when one of these prince or viceroy hold he court in the city of he residence he be seat on a tribunal in great state and receive the petition or complaint of the people have a officer call _ lieu _ who stand behind the tribunal and indorse a answer upon the petition accord to the order of the viceroy for they null no application but what be in write and give all they decision in the same manner before party can present they petition to the viceroy they must be submit to the proper officer for examination who send they back if he discover any error and no person may draw up any of those writings which be to be present to the viceroy except a clerk versant in business who must mark at the bottom that it be write by such a man the son of such a man : and if the clerk be guilty of any error or mistake he be punish with the bamboo the viceroy never seat himself on he tribunal until he have eat and drink lest he should be mistake in some thing and he receive he subsistence from the public treasury of the city over which he preside the emperor who be above all these prince or petty king never appear in public but once in ten month under the idea that the people would lose they veneration for he if he shew himself oftener for they hold it as a maxim that government can only subsist by means of force as the people be ignorant of the principle of justice and that constraint and violence be necessary to maintain among they the majesty of empire there be no tax impose upon the land but all the man of the country be subject to a poll-tax in proportion to they substance when any failure of crop make necessaries dear the king open he store-house to the people and soil all sort of necessaries at much cheaper rate than they can be have in the market by which mean famine be prevent and no dearth be of any long continuance the sum that be gather by this capitation tax be lay up in the public treasury and i believe that from this tax fifty thousand dinar be pay every day into the null of canfu alone although that city be not one of the largest the emperor reserve to himself the revenue which arise from the salt mine and those which be derive from imposition upon a certain herb call _ tcha _ which they drink with hot water and of which vast quantity be sell in all the city in china this be produce from a shrub more bushy than the pomegranate tree and of a more pleasant smell but have a kind of a bitterish taste the way of use this herb be to pour boiling water upon the leaf and the infusion cure all disease whatever sum come into the public treasury arise from the capitation tax the duty upon salt and the tax upon this leaf in every city there be a small bell hang to the wall immediately over the head of the viceroy or governor which may be ring by a string which reach about three mile and cross the high way on purpose that all the people may have access to it und whenever the string be pull and the bell strike the person who thus demand justice be immediately command to be bring into the presence where he set forth he case in person if any person incline to travel from one part of the country to another he must have two pass along with he one from the governor and the other from the lieutenant the governor 's pass permit he to set out on he journey and specify the name of the traveller and of all that be in he company with they name and age for every person in china whether native arab or other foreigner be oblige to make a full declaration of every thing he know about himself the lieutenant 's pass specify the exact quantity of goods and money which the traveller and he company take along with they and this be do for the information of the frontier place where both pass be regularly examine for whenever a person arrive at any of these place it be enter in the register that such a one the son of such a one of such a family pass through the place in such a month day and year and in such company by this mean they prevent any one from carry off the money or effect of other or the loss of they own goods in case of accident so that if any thing have be take away unjustly or if the traveller should die on the road it may be immediately know where the thing be to be find that they may be restore to the claimant or to the heir of the decease the chinese administer justice with great strictness in all they tribunal when any person commence a suit against another he set down he claim in write and the defendant write down he defense which he sign and hold between he finger these two writings be deliver in at the same time and be examine sentence be pronounce in write each of the party have he papers return to he the defendant have he deliver first when one party deny what the other affirm he be order to return he write and if the defendant think he may do it safely and deliver in he papers a second time those of the plaintiff be likewise call for and he who deny the affirmation of the other be warn that if he do not make out what he deny he shall undergo twenty stroke of the bamboo on he buttock and shall pay a fine of twenty _ fakuge _ which amount to about two hundred dinar and the punishment of the bamboo be so severe that the criminal can hardly survive and no person in all china be permit to inflict it upon another by he own authority on pain of death and confiscation of he goods so that no one be ever so hardy as to expose himself to such certain danger by which mean justice be well administer to all no witness be require neither do they put the party upon oath when any person become bankrupt he be immediately commit to prison in the governor 's palace and be call upon for a declaration of he effect after he have remain a month in prison he be liberate by the governor 's order and a proclamation be make that such a person the son of such a one have consume the goods of such a one and that if any person possess any effect whatever belong to the bankrupt a full discovery must be make within one month if any discovery be make of effect belong to the bankrupt which he have omit to declare he suffer the punishment of the bamboo and be upbraid with have remain a month in prison eating and drinking although he have wherewithal to satisfy he creditor he be reproach for have fraudulently procure and embezzle the property of other and be chastise for strip other people of they substance but if after every inquiry the debtor do not appear to have be guilty of any fraud and if it be prove to the satisfaction of the magistrate that he have nothing in the world the creditor be call in and receive a part of they claim from the treasury of the bagbun this be the ordinary title of the emperor of china and signify the son of heaven which we ordinarily pronounce magbun after this it be publickly forbid to buy of or sell to the bankrupt that he may not again have a opportunity of defraud he creditor by conceal they money or effect if it be discover that the bankrupt have any money or effect in the hand of another and that person make no disclosure within the time limit the person guilty of this concealment be bamboo to death and the value discover be divide among the creditor but the debtor or bankrupt must never more concern himself with trade upon a stone ten cubit high erect in the public square of all the city the name of all sort of medicine with the exact price of each be engraven and when the poor stand in need of relief from physic they receive at the treasury the price that each medicine be rate at in china there be no tax upon land but every male subject pay a rateable capitation in proportion to he wealth and possession when a male child be bear he name be immediately enter in a public register and when he have attain he eighteenth year he begin to pay the poll-tax but when once a man have reach he eightieth year he not only cease to contribute but even receive a pension from the treasury as a provision for old age and in acknowledgment of what he pay during he youth there be school maintain at the public charge in every town where the child of the poor be teach to read and write the woman wear nothing on they head besides they hair but the man be cover in china there be a certain town call _ tayu _ have a castle advantageously situate on a hill and all the fortress in the kingdom be call by the same name the chinese be generally handsome of comely stature and of fair complexion and by no means addict to excess in wine they hair be blacker than that of any other nation in the world and the chinese woman wear it curl in the indy when one man accuse another of a capital crime it be usual to ask the accuse if he be willing to undergo the trial by fire and if he consent the ceremony be conduct in the follow manner : a piece of iron be heated red hot and the accuse be desire to stretch out he hand on which they put seven leaf of a certain tree and above these the red hot iron be place in this condition he walk backwards and forwards for some time and then throw off the iron immediately after this he hand be cover with a leathern bag which be seal with the prince 's signet and if at the end of three day he appear and declare that he have suffer no hurt they order he to take out he hand and if no sign of fire be visible he be declare innocent of the crime lay to he charge and the accuser be condemn to pay a fine of a _ man _ of gold to the prince sometimes they boil water in a caldron till it be so hot that no one can touch it they then throw in a iron ring and the accuse be command to thrust down he hand to bring up the ring i see one who do this and receive no manner of harm in this case likewise if the accuse remain unhurt the accuser pay a fine of a _ man _ of gold when a king die in the island of serendib which be the last of the island of the indy he body be lay in a open chariot in such a posture that he head hang backward almost touch the ground with he hair trail on the earth and the chariot be follow by a woman who sweep the dust on the face of the decease while she proclaim with a loud voice : o man behold you king he be yesterday you master but now the dominion which he exercise over you be at a end he be reduce to the state you now see have leave the world and the arbiter of life and death have withdraw he soul count not therefore o man upon the uncertain hope of this life this or a similar proclamation be continue for three day after which the body be embalm with sandal wood camphor and saffron and be then burn and the ash be scatter to the wind when they burn the body of a king it be usual for he wife to jump into the fire and burn along with he but this they be not constrain to do the same custom of burn the body of the dead prevail over all the indy in the indy there be man who devote themselves to live in the wood and mountain profess to despise what other man most value abstain from every thing but such wild herb and fruit as be to be find in the wood and they affix a iron buckle to they genitals in such a manner as to interdict all commerce with woman some of these go quite naked or have only the skin of a leopard throw over they and keep perpetually stand with they face to the sun i formerly see one in that posture and on my return to the indy sixteen year afterwards i find he in the very same attitude it be astonishing that he have not lose he sight by the heat and glare of the sun in all these kingdom the sovereign power reside in the royal family without ever depart from it and the heir of the family follow each other in regular succession in like manner there be family of learn man of physician and of all the artificer concern in the various art and none of these be ever mix with the family of a different profession the several state of the indy be not subject to one king but each province have its own though the balhara be consider in the indy as king of king the chinese be fond of gaming and all manner of diversion but the indian condemn they and have no pleasure in such employment they drink no wine neither do they use vinegar because it be make from wine although this abstinence do not proceed from any religious duty : but they allege that a king give to wine be not worthy of be a king for how should a drunkard be able to manage the affair of a kingdom especially as war be so frequent between the neighbouring state they war be not usually undertake to possess themselves of the dominion of other and i never hear of any except the people border on the pepper country that seize the dominion of they neighbor after victory when a prince master the dominion of a neighbor he confer the sovereignty upon some person of the royal family of the conquer country and thus retain it in dependence upon himself under the conviction that the native would never submit to be otherwise govern when any one of the prince or governor of city in china be guilty of a crime he be put to death and eat and in general it may be say that the chinese eat all those who be put to death when the indian and chinese be about to marry and the party be agree present be interchange and the marriage ceremony be solemnize amidst the noise of drum and various sort of instrument the present consist in money and all the relative and friend contribute as much as they can afford if any man in the indy run away with a woman and abuse she both be put to death unless it be prove that force have be use against the woman in which case the man only be punish theft be always punish capitally both in indium and china whether the theft be considerable or trifling but more particularly so in the indy where if a thief have steal even the value of a small piece of money he be impale alive the chinese be much addict to the abominable vice of pederasty which they even number among the strange act they perform in honor of they idol the chinese building be of wood with stone and plaster or brick and mortar the chinese and indian be not satisfy with one wife but both nation marry as many as they please or can maintain rice be the common food of the indian who eat no wheat but the chinese use both indifferently circumcision be not practice either by the chinese or indian the chinese worship idol before whom they fall down and make prayer and they have book which explain the article of they religion the indian suffer they beard to grow but have no whisker and i have see one with a beard three cubit long but the chinese for the most part wear no beard upon the death of a relation the indian shave both head and face when any man in the indy be throw into prison he be allow neither victuals nor drink for seven day together and this with they answer the end of other torture for extort from the criminal a confession of he guilt the chinese and indian have judge besides the governor who decide in cause between the subject both in indium and china there be leopard and wolf but no lion highway robber be punish with death both the indian and chinese imagine that the idol which they worship speak to they and give they answer neither of they kill they meat by cut the throat as be do by the mahomedan but by beat they on the head till they die they wash not with well water and the chinese wipe themselves with paper whereas the indian wash every day before eat the indian wash not only the mouth but the whole body before they eat but this be not do by the chinese the indy be larger in extent by a half than china and have a great many more kingdom but china be more populous it be not usual to see palm tree either in the indy or in china but they have many other sort of tree and fruit which we have not the indian have no grape and the chinese have not many but both abound in other fruit though the pomegranate thrive better in indium than in china the chinese have no science and they religion and most of they law be derive from the indian they even believe that the indian teach they they worship of idol both nation believe the metempsycosis though they differ in many of the precept and ceremony of they religion physic and philosophy be cultivate among the indian and the chinese have some skill in medicine but that almost entirely consist in the art of apply hot iron or cautery they have some smattering of astronomy but in this likewise the indian surpass the chinese i know not that even so much as one man of either nation have embrace mahomedism or have learn to speak the arabic language the indian have few horse and there be more in china but the chinese have no elephant and can not endure to have they in they country the indian dominion furnish a great number of soldier who be not pay by they king but when call out to war have to take the field and serve entirely at they own expense but the chinese allow they soldier much the same pay as be do by the arab china be a pleasant and fruitful country have numerous extensive and well fortify city with a more wholesome climate and less fenny country than indium in which most of the province have no city the air in china likewise be much better than in indium and there be scarcely any blind person or who be subject to disease of the eye and similar advantage be enjoy by several of the province of indium the river of both country be large and surpass we greatest river and much rain fall in both country in the lady there be many desert track but china be inhabit and cultivate through its whole extent the chinese be handsomer than the indian and come nearer to the arab in countenance and dress in they manners in the way of ride and in they ceremony wear long garment and girdle in the manner of belt while the indian wear two short vest and both man and woman wear golden bracelet adorn with precious stone beyond the kingdom of china there be a country call _ tagazgaz _ take its name from a nation of turk by which it be inhabit and also the country of kakhan which border on the turk the island of silum be inhabit by white people who send present to the emperor of china and who be persuade that if they be to neglect this the rain of heaven would not fall upon they country in that country there be white falcon but none of we people have be there to give we any particular information concern they -lrb- 1
