time by means of weight -- e section ii _ commentary upon the foregoing account by abu zeid al hasan of siraff _ have very carefully examine the book i be desire to peruse that i might confirm what the author relate so far as he agree with what i have learn concern the affair of navigation the kingdom on the coast and the state of the country of which he treat and that i might add what i have elsewhere collect concern these matter : i find that this book be compose in the year of the hegira 237 and that the account give by the author be conformable with what i have hear from merchant who have sail from _ irak _ or persium through these sea i find also all that the author have write to be agreeable to truth except some few passage in which he have be misinform speaking of the custom of the chinese in set meat before they dead and believe that the dead have eat we have be tell the same thing and once believe it but have since learn from a person of undoubted credit that this notion be entirely groundless as well as that the idolater believe they idol speak to they from that creditable person we have likewise be inform that the affair of china wear quite a different aspect since those day : and since much have be relate to explain why we voyage to china have be interrupted and how the country have be ruin many custom abolish and the empire divide i shall here declare what i know of that revolution the great trouble which have embroil the affair of this empire put a stop to the justice and righteousness there formerly practice and interrupt the ordinary navigation from siraff to china be occasion by the revolt of a officer name baichu in high employment though not of the royal family he begin by gather together a number of vagabond and disorderly people whom he win to he party by he liberality and form into a considerable body of troops with these he commit hostility in many part of the country to the great loss of the inhabitant and have greatly increase he army and put himself into a condition to attempt greater thing he begin to entertain a design of subdue the whole empire and march direct for canfu one of the most note city in china and at that time the great port for we arabian commerce this city stand upon a great river some day sail from the sea so that the water there be fresh the citizen shut they gate against he and he be oblige to besiege it a great while but at length he become master of the city and put all the inhabitant to the sword there be person fully acquaint with the affair of china who assure we that besides the chinese who be massacre upon this occasion there perish one hundred and twenty thousand mahomedan jew christian and parsee who be there on account of traffic and as the chinese be exceedingly nice in the register they keep of foreigner dwelling among they this number may be consider as authentic this take place in the year of the hegira 264 or of christ 877 he also cut down the mulberry tree which be carefully cultivate by the chinese for they leaf on which the silk worm be feed and owe to this the trade of silk have tail and that manufacture which use to be much prosecute in all the country under the arabian government be quite at a stand have sack and destroy canfu he possess himself of many other city which he demolish have first slay most of the inhabitant in the hope that he might involve all the member of the royal family in this general massacre that no one might remain to dispute with he for the empire he then advance to cumdan -lrb- 1 -rrb- the capital city whence the emperor be oblige to make a precipitate retreat to the city of hamdu on the frontier towards thibet puff up with these great success baichu make himself master of almost the whole country there be no one able to dispute he authority at length the emperor write to the king of the tagazgaz in turkestan with whom he be in some degree ally by marriage implore he assistance to subdue the rebellion the king of the tagazgaz dispatch he son at the head of a very numerous army into china and after a long and arduous contest and many battle baichu be utterly defeat and it be never know afterwards what become of he some believe that he fall in the last battle while other suppose that he end he day in a different manner the emperor of china now return to he capital much weaken and dispirit in consequence of the embezzlement of he treasure and the loss of the best of he officer and troops and the horrible devastation calamity and loss which he empire have sustain yet he make himself master of all the province which have revolt from he authority he would not however lay he hand upon the goods of he subject notwithstanding the exhaust state of he finances but satisfied himself with what be still leave in he coffer and the small remains of the public money that be to be find require nothing from he subject but what they be willing to give and only demand obedience to the law and to he authority consider that they have be already severely oppress in consequence of the rebellion thus china become like the empire of alexander after the defeat and death of darius when he divide the province among he chief who become so many king for now each of the chinese prince or viceroy join themselves into petty alliance make war among themselves without the authority of the emperor and when the stronger have subdue the weaker and acquire possession of he province the subject of the vanquish prince be unmercifully waste and plunder and even barbarously devour : a cruel practice allow by the law of they religion which even permit human flesh to be expose to public sale in the market there arise from all these confusion many unjust dealings with the merchant and there be no grievance so intolerable or treatment so bad but what be exercise upon the arab merchant and captain of ship extort from they what be altogether uncustomary seize upon they effect and behave towards they quite contrary to all the ancient usage so that we merchant be force to return in crowd to siraff and oman -lrb- 2 -rrb- the punishment of married person convict of adultery as well as for the crime of homicide and theft be as follow : the hand be bind fast together and force backwards over the head till they rest on the neck the right foot be then fasten to the right hand and the left foot to the left hand and all draw tight together behind the back so that the criminal be incapable to stir and by this torture the neck be dislocate the joint of the arm start from they socket and the thigh bone be disjointed -- in short the tortured wretch would soon expire without any farther process yet in that state he be beat by bamboo till at the last gasp and be then abandon to the people who devour the body there be woman in china who refuse to marry and prefer to live a dissolute life of perpetual debauchery a woman who have make this election present herself in full audience before the commanding officer of a city declare she aversion to marriage and desire to be enrol among the public woman she name be then insert in the register with the name of she family the place of she abode the number and description of she jewel and the particulars of she dress she have then a string put round she neck to which be append a copper ring mark with the king 's signet and she receive a write certify that she be receive into the list of prostitute and by which she be entitle to a pension from the public treasury of so many _ falus _ yearly and in which the punishment of death be denounce against any man who should take she to wife every year regulation be publish respect these woman and such as have grow old in the service be strike off the list in the evening these woman walk abroad in dress of different color unveil and prostitute themselves to all stranger who love debauchery but the chinese themselves send for they to they house whence they do not depart till next morning the chinese coin no money except the small piece of copper like those we _ falus _ nor will they allow gold and silver to be coin into specie like we dinar and dram for they allege that a thief may carry off ten thousand piece of gold from the house of a arab and almost as many of silver without be much burthen and so ruin the man who suffer the loss but in the house of a chinese he can only carry off ten thousand _ falus _ at the most which do not make above ten metical or gold dinar in value these piece of copper be alloy with some other metal and be about the size of a dram or the piece of silver call _ baglus _ have a large hole in the middle to string they by a thousand of they be worth a metical or gold dinar and they string they by thousand with a knot distinguish the hundred all they payment whether for land furniture merchandize or any thing else be make in this money of which there be some piece at siraff inscribe with chinese character the city of canfu be build of wood and cane interwoven just like we lattice-work of split cane the whole wash over with a kind of varnish make of hempseed which become as white as milk have a wonderfully fine gloss there be no stair in they house which be all of one storey and all they valuable be place in chest upon wheel which in case of fire can easily be draw from place to place without any hinderance from stair the inferior officer of the city and those commonly who have the direction of the custom and of the treasury be almost all eunuch some of whom have be capture on the frontier and make so while other be so treat by they father and send as present to the emperor these officer be at the head of the principal affair of state and have the management of the emperor 's private affair and of the treasury and those particularly who be send to canfu be select from this class it be customary for they and for the viceroy or governor of the city to appear abroad from time to time in solemn procession on these occasion they be precede by man who carry great piece of wood like those use in the levant instead of bell by the christian on which they make a noise which be hear at a great distance upon which every person get out of the way of the prince or eunuch even if a man be at he door he go in and keep he door shut till the great personage have go by thus not a soul be in the way and this be enjoin that they may strike a dread into the people and be hold in veneration and the people be not allow to see they often lest they should grow so familiar as to speak to they all these officer wear very magnificent dress of silk so fine that none such be bring into the country of the arab as the chinese hold it at a very high price one of we chief merchant a man of perfect credibility wait upon a eunuch who have be send to canfu to purchase some goods from the country of the arab the eunuch have upon he breast a short and beautiful silk vest which be under another silk vest and seem to have two other vest over that again and perceive that the arab eye he very steadfastly he ask he the cause and be tell that he admire the beauty of the little vest under he other garment the eunuch laugh and hold out he sleeve to he desire he to count how many vest he have above that which he so much admire he do so and find five one over the other and the little rich vest undermost these garment be all wove of raw silk which have never be wash or full and those worn by the prince or governor be still richer and more exquisitely work the chinese surpass all nation in all art and particularly in painting and they perform such perfect work as other can but faintly imitate when a artificer have finish a piece he carry it to the prince 's palace to demand the reward which he think he deserve for the beauty of he performance and the custom be for the prince to order the work to be leave at the gate of the palace for a whole year and if in that time no person find a just fault in the piece the artificer be reward and admit into the body of artist but if any fault be discover the piece be reject and the workman send off without reward it happen once that one of these artist paint a ear of corn with a bird perch upon it and he performance be very much admire this piece stand expose to public view as usual and one day a crooked fellow go past find fault with the picture and be immediately conduct to the prince or governor who send for the painter that he might hear he piece criticize be ask what fault he have to find he answer that every one know that a bird never settle on a ear of corn but it must bend under the weight whereas this painter have represent the ear of corn bolt upright though load with a bird the objection be hold just and the painter be dismiss without reward by such means they excite they workman to aim at perfection and to be exceedingly nice and circumspect in what they undertake and to apply they whole genius to any thing that have to go through they hand there dwell at basra one ebn wahab of the tribe of koreish descend from hebar the son of al asud who quit basra when it be sack and come to siraff where he see a ship prepare to sail for china -lrb- 3 -rrb- the humor take he to embark in this ship for china and he have the curiosity to visit the emperor 's court leave canfu he go to cumdan after a journey of two month and remain a long while at the court where he present several petition to the emperor setting forth that he be of the family of the prophet of the arab after a considerable interval the emperor order he to be lodge in a house appoint for the purpose and to be supply with every thing he might need the emperor then write to the governor of canfu to inquire carefully among the arabian merchant respect this man 's pretension and receive a full confirmation of he extraction receive he to a audience and make he rich present with which he return to irak when we see he this man be much advance in year but have he sens perfectly he tell we that the emperor ask he many question respect the arab and particularly how they have destroy the kingdom of the persian ebn wahab answer that they have do it by the assistance of god and because the persian be immerse in idolatry adore the sun moon and star instead of the almighty the emperor say that they have conquer the most illustrious kingdom of the earth the best cultivate the most populous the most pregnant of fine wit and of the highest fame the emperor then ask ebn wahab what account the arab make of the other king of the earth to which he answer that he know they not then the emperor cause the interpreter to say we admit but five great king he who be master of irak have the kingdom of widest extent which be surround by the territory of other king and we find he call king of king after he be the emperor of china who be style king of mankind for no king have more absolute authority over he subject and no people can be more dutiful and submissive than he subject next be the king of the turk whose kingdom border on china and who be style the king of lion next be the king of the elephant who be king of the indy whom we call king of wisdom last of all be the king of greece whom we call king of man as there be no man of better manners or comlier appearance on the face of the earth than he subject ebn wahab be then ask if he know he lord and master the prophet mohamm and if he have see he how could that be say wahab see that he be with god be then ask what manner of person he be he answer that he be very handsome then a great box be bring out of which another box be take and the interpreter be desire to shew he he lord and master ebn wahab upon look in saw the image of the prophet and the emperor observe he to move he lip desire he to be ask the reason on which he say he be pray inwardly in honor of the prophet be ask how he know they he say by the representation of they history as for instance one be noah and he ark who be save from the flood with those who be with they the emperor laugh and say he be right in regard to noah but deny the universal deluge which though it have cover part of the earth do not reach china or the indy on wahab observe that the next be mose with he rod and the child of israel the emperor agree that they country be of small extent and that mose have extirpate the ancient inhabitant wahab then point out jesus upon the ass accompany by he apostle to this the emperor say that he have be a short time upon earth all he transaction have very little exceed the space of thirty month on see the image of mohammed ride on a camel and he companion about he with arabian shoe and leathern girdle wahab weep and be ask the reason he answer it be on see he prophet and lord who be he cousin also the emperor then ask concern the age of the world and wahab answer that opinion vary on the subject as some reckon it to be six thousand year old while some would not allow so many and other extend it to a greater antiquity be ask why he have desert he own king to whom he be so near in blood he give information of the revolution which have happen at basra which have force he to fly to siraff where hearing of the glory of the emperor of china and the abundance of every thing in he empire he have be impel by curiosity to visit it but that he intend soon to return to the kingdom of he cousin where he should make a faithful report of the magnificence of china the vast extent of its province and of the kind usage he have meet with this seem to please the emperor who make he rich present and order he to be conduct to canfu on post horse -lrb- 4 -rrb- he write also to the governor of that city command he to be treat with honor and to the governor of the province through which he have to pass to shew he every civility he be treat handsomely during the remainder of he stay in china plentifully supply with all necessaries and honor with many present -lrb- 5 -rrb- from the information of ebn wahab we learn that cumdan where the emperor of china keep he court be a very large and extremely populous city divide into two part by a very long and broad street that the emperor he chief minister the supreme judge the eunuch the soldiery and all belong to the imperial household dwelt in that part of the city which be on the right hand eastward and that the people be not admit into that part of the city which be water by canal from different river the border of which be plant with tree and adorn by magnificent palace that portion of the city on the left hand westwards from the great street be inhabit by the ordinary kind of people and the merchant where also be great square and market for all the necessaries of life at day-break every morning the officer of the royal household with the inferior servant purveyor and the domestic of the grandee of the court come into that division of the city some on horseback and other on foot to the public market and the shop of those who deal in all sort of goods where they buy whatever they want and do not return again till they occasion call they back next morning the city be very pleasantly situate in the midst of a most fertile soil water by several river and hardly deficient in any thing except palm tree which grow not there in we time a discovery have be make of a circumstance quite new and unknown to we ancestor no one ever imagine that the great sea which extend from the indy to china have any communication with the sea of syrium yet we have hear that in the sea of rum or the mediterranean there be find the wreck of a arabian ship which have be shatter by a tempest in which all she man have perish she remains be drive by the wind and weather into the sea of the chozar and thence by the canal of the mediterranean sea and be at last throw upon the coast of syrium hence it be evident that the sea surround all the country of china and silum or cilum the uttermost part of turkestan and the country of the chozar and that it communicate by the strait with that which wash the coast of syrium this be prove by the structure of the wreck of which the plank be not nail or bolt like all those build in the mediterranean or on the coast of syrium but join together in a extraordinary manner as if sew and none but the ship of siraff be so fasten we have also hear it report that ambergris have be find on the coast of syrium which seem hard to believe and be unknown to former time if this be true it be impossible that amber should have be throw up on the sea of syrium but by the sea of aden and kolsum which have communication with the sea where amber be find and as god have put a separation between these sea it must have necessarily be that this amber be drive from the indian sea into the other in the same direction with the vessel of siraff -lrb- 6 -rrb- the province of zapage be opposite to china and distant from thence a month 's sail or less if the wind be fair the king of this country be style mehrage and he dominion be say to be 900 league in circumference besides which he command over many island which lie around so that altogether this kingdom be above 1000 league in extent one of these island be call _ serbeza _ which be say to be 400 league in compass another be call _ rhami _ which be 800 league round and produce red-wood camphor and many other commodity in the same kingdom be the island of _ calum _ which be the mid passage between china and the country of the arab this island be 80 league in circumference and to it they bring all sort of merchandize as aloe wood of several kind camphor sandal wood ivory the wood call _ cabahi _ ebony red-wood all sort of spice and many other and at present the trade be carry on between this island and that of oman the mehrage be sovereign over all these island and that of zapage in which he reside be extremely fertile and so populous that the town almost touch each other no part of the land be uncultivated the palace of the king or mehrage stand on a river as broad as the tigri at bagdat or bassora but the sea intercept its course and drive its water back with the tide yet during the ebb the fresh water flow out a good way into the sea the river water be let into a small pond close to the king 's palace and every morning the master of the household bring a ingot of gold work in a particular manner and throw it into the pond in presence of the king when the king die he successor cause all these ingot which have be accumulate during the reign of he predecessor to be take out and the sum arise from this great quantity of gold be distribute among the royal household in certain proportion accord to they respective rank and the surplus be give to the poor komar be the country whence the aloe wood which we call hud al komari be bring and it be a very populous kingdom of which the inhabitant be very courageous in this country the boundless commerce with woman be forbid and indeed it have no wine the kingdom of zapage and komar be about ten or twenty day easy sail from each other and the kingdom be in peace with other when the follow event be say in they ancient history to have occur the young and high-spirited king of komar be one day in he palace which look upon a river much like the euphrate at the entrance and be only a day 's journey from the sea one day in a discourse with he prime minister the conversation turn upon the glory and population of the kingdom of the mehrage and the multitude of its dependent island when the king of komar express a wish to see the head of the mehrage of zapage on a dish before he the minister endeavor to dissuade he from so unjust and rash a attempt but the king afterwards propose the same exploit to the other officer of he court intelligence of this project be convey to the mehrage who be a wise and active prince of consummate experience and in the flower of he age and who immediately order a thousand small ship to be fit out with all necessary arm and provision and man with as many of he best troops as they be able to transport carefully conceal the purpose of this armament but give out that he mean to visit the different island under he authority and even cause letter to be write to the tributary king of these island to prepare for he reception when every thing be in readiness he sail over to the kingdom of komar the king of which and all he courtier be a set of effeminate creature who do nothing all day long but view they face in mirror and pick they tooth the mehrage land he troops without delay and immediately invest the palace in which the king be make prisoner all he attendant have flee without fight then the mehrage cause proclamation to be make grant entire security of life and property to all the inhabitant of the country and seat himself on the throne cause the captive king and the prime minister to be bring into he presence address himself to the fall monarch he demand he reason for entertain a project so unjust and beyond he power to execute and what be he ultimate intention if he have succeed to this the king of komar make no answer and the mehrage order he head to be strike off to the minister the mehrage make many compliment for the good advice he have give he master and order he to place the person who best deserve to succeed upon the vacant throne and then depart to he own dominion without do the smallest violence or injury to the kingdom of komar the news of this action be report to the king of china and the indy add greatly to they respect for the mehrage and from that time it have be the custom for the king of komar to prostrate themselves every morning towards the country of zapage in honor of the mehrage -lrb- 7 -rrb- all the king of china and the indy believe in the metempsychosis or transmigration of soul as a article of they religion of which the follow story relate by a person of credibility be a singular instance one of these prince have view himself in a mirror after recover from the small-pox and notice how dreadfully he face be disfigured observe that no person have ever remain in he body after such a change and as the soul pass instantly into another body he be determine to separate ha soul from its present frightful body that he might pass into another wherefore he command he nephew to mount the throne and call for a sharp and keen scymitar order he own head to be cut off that he soul might be set free to inhabit a new body he order be comply with and he body be burnt accord to the custom of the country until the late revolution have reduce they to they present state of anarchy the chinese be wonderfully regular and exact in every thing relative to government of which the follow incident afford a striking example a merchant of chorassan who have deal largely in irak and who embark from thence for china with a quantity of goods have a dispute at canfu with a eunuch who be send to purchase some ivory and other goods for the emperor and at length the dispute run so high that the merchant refuse to sell he he goods this eunuch be keeper of the imperial treasury and presume so much on the favor and confidence which he enjoy with he master that he take he choice of all the goods he want from the merchant by force regardless of every thing that the merchant could say the merchant go privately from canfu to cumdan the residence of the emperor which be two month journey and immediately go to the string of the bell mention in the former section which he pull accord to the custom of the country he be convey to a place at the distance of ten day journey where he be commit to prison for two month after which he be bring before the viceroy of the province who represent to he that he have involve himself in a situation which would tend to he utter ruin and even the loss of he life if he do not speak out the real truth : because there be minister and governor appoint to distribute justice to all stranger who be ready to see he right and if the nature of the wrong which he have to represent do not appear such as to entitle he to this application to the emperor he would assuredly be put to death as a warn to other not to follow he example the viceroy therefore advise he to withdraw he appeal and to return immediately to canfu the rule on such occasion be that if the party should endeavor to recede after this exhortation he would have receive fifty blow of a bamboo and have be immediately send out of the country : but if he persist in he appeal he be immediately admit to a audience of the emperor the merchant strenuously persist in he demand for justice and be at length admit to the presence of the emperor to whom he relate the injustice of the eunuch in take away he goods by force upon this the merchant be throw into prison and the emperor order he prime minister to write to the governor of canfu to make strict inquiry into the complaint which he have exhibit against the eunuch and to make a faithful report of all the circumstance and he at the same time give similar order to three other principal officer to make the same inquiry all separate and unknown to each other these officer who be call of the right of the left and of the center accord to they rank have the command of the imperial force under the prime minister they be entrust with the guard of the emperor person : and when he take the field on any military enterprise or on any other account these officer be station near he each accord to he rank all of these make accordingly the strictest inquiry into the allegation of the merchant and all separately give in they report assure the emperor that these complaint be just and well-founded : and these be follow and confirm by many other information the eunuch be in consequence deprive of he office of treasurer find all he effect be confiscate on which occasion the emperor address he as follow death ought to have be you doom for give occasion of complaint against I to this man who have come from chorassan which be on the border of my empire he have be in the country of the arab whence he come into the kingdom of the indy and thence into my empire seek he advantage by trade and you would have occasion he to return across all these region say to all the people in he way that he have be abused and strip of he substance in china in consideration of you former service and the rank you have hold in my household i grant you life but as you have not discharge you duty in regard to the living i will confer upon you the charge of the dead the eunuch be accordingly send to take the custody of the imperial tomb and to remain there for the remainder of he life before the late commotion the good order observe in the administration of justice and the majesty of they tribunal be very admirable to fill these the chinese choose man who be perfectly versant in the law man of sincerity and zealous in the cause of justice who be not to be biass by the interference of the great and who always administer the law with impartiality neither oppress the poor nor accept bribe from the rich when any one be to be promote to the office of principal judge he be previously send to all the chief city of the empire to remain a month or two in each inquire minutely into the various custom and affair of the people and inform himself of all such person as be worthy of be credit in they testimony that he judgment might be regulate in the future discharge of he high office by this preliminary knowledge after go through all the city in this manner and make some stay in those which be most considerable he repair to the imperial court and be invest with the dignity of supreme judge to he the nomination of all the other judge be confide after acquaint the emperor with the name of all who in he estimation be most worthy of exercise jurisdiction in the various city and province every day the supreme judge cause proclamation to be make that of any man have be wrong by the viceroy or governor or by any of he relation or officer or any other person he shall receive ample justice a viceroy or governor be never degrade except by letter issue from the council or divan of king and this be do only for some flagrant malversation or for the refusal or delay of justice the post of judicature be confer upon none but man of probity and justice good order be efectually maintain the province of chorassan be almost on the border of china from china to sogd be about two month journey through impracticable desert of sand where there be no water for which reason the chorassanian can make no irruption into china the most westerly province of china be _ medu _ which border on thibet and the two nation be often at war a person who have be in china inform we that he have see a man at canfu who have travel from _ samare _ all the way on foot through all the city in china with a vessel of musk on he back for sale which he might easily do as the part of thibet which produce musk be contiguous to china the chinese carry off as many of the animal which produce musk as they can procure but the musk of thibet be far better than that of china because the animal feed on aromatic plant in the mountain of thibet while in china it have to subsist upon the ordinary pasture and because the inhabitant of thibet preserve they cod of musk in its natural state of purity while the chinese adulterate all that get into they hand for which reason the musk of thibet be in great request among the arab the most exquisite of all the sort of musk be that which the musk animal leave behind they in rub themselves on the rock of they native mountain the humor whence the musk be generate fall down towards the navel of the animal where it gather into tumor like grumous blood and when this tumor be ripe it produce a painful itch on which the animal rub himself against rock or stone till he burst the tumor and the contents run out and coagulate on the stone after which the wound heal and the humor gather again as before there be man in thibet who make it they business to collect this species of musk which they preserve in bladder and which have ripen naturally surpass all other in goodness just as ripe fruit exceed in flavor that which be pull green there be another way of procure musk either by ensnare the animal or shoot they with arrow but the hunter often cut out the bag before the musk be ripe or fully elaborate in which case the musk at first have a bad scent till the humor thicken after which it turn to good musk though this sometimes take a long while the musk animal be like we roebuck he skin and color the same with slender leg and smooth slightly bent horn have on each side two small white tooth about half a finger-length which rise about he muzzle not much unlike the form of the tooth of the elephant and by which he be distinguish from other roebuck the letter from the emperor of china to the viceroy governor eunuch and lieutenant be convey on post-horse which be distinguish by cut tail and these be disposed at regular station all over the empire almost like the post among the arab in china every man from the emperor to the meanest of the people make water standing -lrb- 8 -rrb- and for this purpose person of dignity have gilded hollow cane a cubit long to convey they water to a distance they be of opinion that pain in the kidney strangury and even the stone be occasion by urining in a sit posture as the rein can not free themselves absolutely from evil humor except by evacuate in a erect position they do not mould the head of new bear infant into a round form as we do as they allege that this practice injure the brain and impair the sens they suffer they hair to grow which be carefully comb the nation be divide into tribe like those of the arab and some other and no man ever marry in he own tribe : just as the child of thummim among the arab never take a wife from that tribe or for example a man of the tribe of robayat marry a daughter of the tribe modzar and a modzar marry a robayat and they be of opinion that such alliance add to the dignity and power of they child in the kingdom of the balhara and all the other kingdom of the indy there be man who burn themselves in consequence of they belief in the doctrine of transmigration when a man have come to this resolution he ask leave of the king which be obtain he go in procession round all the public square of the city and proceed to the place appoint where a pile of dry wood be ready for the purpose have many person all round to feed the fire which blaze prodigiously at last the person come forward precede by a number of instrument and move round the pile in the midst of he friend and relation during this ceremony some person place on he head a garland of straw or dry herb fill with burn coal on which they pour _ sandrach _ which take fire as strongly as naphtha notwithstanding of which he continue he progress without betray any sense of pain or change of countenance though the crown of he head be all on fire and the stench of he burn flesh be feel all round at length he come up to the pile and throw himself in where he be soon reduce to ash a credible person say he once see a indian burn himself and when he come near the pile he draw out a cangiar or sharp knife with which he rip himself open and pull out the lap of he liver with he left hand cut off a piece of it with he cangiar and give it to one of he brother talk all the time with the most invincible contempt of death and torture and at length leap into the fire in he passage to hell at the accession of some king of the indy the following ceremony be observe : a large quantity of rice be dress and spread out upon leaf of mousa in presence of the king then three or four hundred person come of they own accord without any constraint whatever and after the king have eat of the rice he give some of it to all that come forwards in succession which they eat in he presence and by this ceremony they engage to burn themselves on the day when this king die or be slay and they punctually fulfil they promise in the mountainous part of indium there be tribe who differ little from those we call _ kanisians _ and _ jelidians _ and who be addict to all manner of superstition and vice between whom and the inhabitant of the people on the coast there subsist great emulation each daring the other to imitate they in the performance of strange superstitious torture there once come a man from the mountain on this errand who gather a multitude of the inhabitant of the coast to the follow strange exhibition daring they to imitate he or otherwise to acknowledge themselves overcome he sit down in a place plant with cane and cause a strong one to be forcibly bent down to which he strongly fasten the hair of he head now say he i be go to cut off my own head with this cangiar and as soon as it be sever from my body let go the cane and when my head fly up into the air i will laugh and you shall hear I but the people of the coast have not courage to imitate he -lrb- 9 -rrb- the person who relate this do it without emotion or wonder and in we time these fact be generally know as this part of the indy be in the neighborhood of the country of the arab and we hear from thence every day in the indy they burn they dead and it be customary for man and woman to desire they family to throw they into the fire or to drown they when they be grow old or perceive themselves to sink under the pressure of disease firmly believe that they be to return into other body it have often happen in the isle of serendib where there be a mine of precious stone in a mountain a pearl-fishery and other extraordinary thing that a indian would come into the bazar or market-place arm with a _ kri _ and seize upon the most wealthy merchant there present lead he out of the market through a throng of people hold the kris to he throat while no one dare to attempt he rescue as the indian be sure in such a case to kill the merchant and make away with himself and when he have get the merchant out of the city the indian obliged he to redeem he life with a sum of money to put a end to such outrage a order be issue to seize such trespasser but on attempt to execute this order several merchant be kill both arab and indian and the order be oblige to be repeal in the mountain of serendib precious stone be find of various color red green and yellow -lrb- 10 -rrb- most of which be wash from cavern or crevice by rain and torrent in these place the king have officer to watch over the people who gather the precious stone in some place these be dig out of mine like the ore of metal and the rock have often to be break be expend on incense and in one of these temple there be a great idol all of pure gold but concern the weight of which traveller be not agree in the same island there be great number of jew and person extreme beauty and chequer with grove and plain water and mead and bless with a wholesome air a sheep may be there buy for half a dram and for the same as much of they drink make of palm-honey boil and prepare with _ tarus _ or toddi as will suffice for many person the inhabitant be much addict to gaming particularly draught they other principal diversion be cock-fight they cock be very large and better provide with spur than ordinary and besides this the indian arm they with blade of iron in the form of cangiar or dagger on these combat they bet gold and silver land or farm and they game with such fury that debauchee and desperate people often stake the end of they finger when they other property be exhaust while at play for this extraordinary stake they have a fire by they on which a small pot of walnut oil or oil of sesamum be keep boil and when one have win a game he chop off the end of the loser 's finger who immediately dip the stump into the boiling oil to stem the blood and some will persist so obstinately as to have all they finger thus mutilate some even will take a burning wick and apply it to some member till the scent of the burnt flesh be feel all around while the stoic continue to play without betray the least sense of pain both man and woman be so exceedingly addict to debauchery that a foreign merchant have be know to send even for a king 's daughter to attend he at the fishing grounds in quality of mistress wherefore the mahomedan doctor at siraff strictly warn young people not to go there in the indy there be heavy rain call _ jasara _ which last incessantly day and night for three month every year the indian prepare against these to the best of they power as they shut themselves up in they house during the whole time all work be then perform within door and during this time they be subject to ulcer in the sole of they foot occasion by the damp yet these rain be of indispensable necessity as when they fail the indian be reduce to the utmost want as they rice field be water only by the rain it never rain during summer the indian have doctor or devout man name bramin they have poet also who compose poem fill with the grossest flattery to they king and great man they have also astrologer philosopher soothsayer man who observe the flight of bird and other who pretend to the calculation of nativity particularly at kaduge a great city in the kingdom of gozar -lrb- 11 -rrb- there be certain man call _ bicar _ who go all they life naked and suffer they hair to grow till it hide they hinder part they also allow they nail to grow till they become pointed and sharp like sword each have a string round he neck to which hang a earthen dish and when hungry they go to any house whence the inhabitant cheerfully supply they with boil rice they have many law and religious precept by which they imagine that they please god part of they devotion consist in build _ kan _ or inn on the highway for the accommodation of traveller where also certain pedlar or small dealer be establish from whom the passenger may purchase what they stand in need of there be also public woman who expose themselves to traveller some of these be call _ woman of the idol _ the origin of which institution be this : when a woman have lay herself under a vow that she may have child if she happen to produce a handsome daughter she carry she child to the _ bod _ -lrb- 12 -rrb- so the idol be call when this girl have attain the proper age she take a apartment in the temple and wait the arrival of stranger to whom she prostitute herself for a certain hire and deliver she gain to the priest for the support of the temple all these thing they reckon among they meritorious deed praise be god who have free we from the sin which defile the people involve in unbelief not very far from almansur there be a famous idol call multan to which the indian resort in pilgrimage from the remotest part some of the pilgrim bring the odoriferous wood call hud ul camrunus so call from camrun where there be excellent aloes-wood some of this be worth 200 _ dinar _ the mawn and be commonly mark with a seal to distinguish it from another kind of less value this the devotee give to the priest that it may be burn before the idol but merchant often buy it from these priest there be some indian make profession of piety who go in search of unknown island or those newly discover on purpose to plant cocoa nut tree and to sink well for the use of ship there be people at oman who cross to these island that produce the cocoa nut tree of plank make from which they build ship sew the plank with yarn make from the bark of the tree the mast be make of the same wood the sail be form from the leaf and the bark be work up into cordage : and have thus complete they vessel they load she with cocoa nut which they bring to oman for sale the country of the zinge or negro be of vast extent -lrb- 13 -rrb- these people commonly sow millet which be the chief food of the negro they have also sugar-canes and other tree but they sugar be very black the negro be divide among a great number of king who be eternally at war with each other they king be attend by certain man call moharamin each of whom have a ring in he nose and a chain round he neck when about to join battle with the enemy each of the moharamin take the end of he neighbor 's chain and pass it through the ring in he own nose by which the whole be chained together so that no one can possibly run away deputy be then send to endeavor to make peace and if that be do the chain be unfastened and they retire without fight but otherwise when once the sword be unsheathed every one of these man must conquer or die on the spot -lrb- 14 -rrb- these people have a profound veneration for the arab and when they meet any one they fall down before he say this man come from the land of date of which they be very fond they have preacher among they who harangue with wonderful ability and perseverance some of these profess a religious life and be cover with the skin of leopard or ape one of these man will gather a multitude of people to whom he will preach all day long concern god or about the action of they ancestor from this country they bring the leopard skin call zingiet which be very large and broad and ornamented with red and black spot in this sea be the island of socotra whence come the best aloe this island be near the land of the zinge or negro and be likewise near arabium and most of its inhabitant be christian which be thus account for : when alexander have subdue the empire of persium he preceptor aristotle desire he to search out the island of socotra which afford aloe and without which the famous medicine hiera -lrb- 15 -rrb- could not be compound desire he likewise to remove the native and to plant there a colony of greek who might supply syrium greece and egypt with aloe this be do accordingly and when god send jesus christ into the world the greek of this isle embrace the christian faith like the rest of they nation and have persevere in it to this day like all the other inhabitant of the island -lrb- 16 -rrb- in the first book no mention be make of the sea which stretch away to the right as ship depart from oman and the coast of arabium to launch out into the great sea : and the author describe only the sea on the left hand in which be comprehend the sea of indium and china in this sea to the right as you leave oman be the country of sihar or shihr where frankincense grow and other country possess by the nation of ad hamyar jorham and thabatcha who have the sonna in arabic of very ancient date but differ in many thing from what be in the hand of the arab and contain many tradition unknown to we they have no far as the coast of syrium and end at kolzum the sea at this place be divide by a slip of land which god have fix as a line of separation between the two sea -lrb- 17 -rrb- from kolzum the sea stretch along the coast of the barbarian to the west coast which be opposite to yaman and then along the coast of ethiopium from whence we have the leopard skin of barbary -lrb- 18 -rrb- which be the best of all and the most skilfully dress and lastly along the coast of zeilah whence come excellent amber and tortoiseshell when the siraff ship arrive in the red sea they go no farther than judda whence they cargo be transport to cairo or _ kahira _ by ship of kolsum the pilot of which be acquaint with the navigation of the upper end of this sea which be full of rock up to the water 's edge because also along the coast there be no king -lrb- 19 -rrb- and scarcely any inhabitant and because every night ship be oblige to put into some place for safety for fear of striking on the rock or must ride all night at anchor sailing only in the day-time this sea be likewise subject to very thick fog and to violent gale of wind and be therefore of very dangerous navigation and devoid of any safe or pleasant anchorage it be not like the sea of indium and china whose bottom be rich with pearl and ambergris whose mountain be store with gold precious stone and ivory whose coast produce ebony redwood aloe camphor nutmeg clove sandal and all other spice and aromatic where parrot and peacock be bird of the forest and in which musk and civet be collect in abundance : so productive in short be these shore of article of infinite variety and inestimable value that it be vain to endeavor to make any enumeration ambergris be throw upon this coast by the flux of the sea but its origin be unknown it be find on the coast of the indy but the best which be of a bluish white and in round lump be get upon the barbarian coast : or on the confines of the land of the negro towards sihar and that neighborhood the inhabitant of that country have camel train for the purpose on which they ride along the shore in moonshine night and when the camel perceive a piece of amber he bend he knee on which the rider dismount and secure he prize there be another kind which swim on the surface of the sea in great lump sometimes as big as the body of a ox or somewhat less when a certain fish name _ tal _ of the whale tribe see these float lump he swallow they and be thereby kill and when the people who be accustom to this fishery see a whale float on the surface they know that this whale have swallow ambergris and go out in they boat they dart they harpoon into its body and tow it on shore and split the animal down the back to get out the ambergris what be find about the belly of the whale be commonly spoil by the wet and have a unpleasant scent but the ambergris which be not contaminate by the ordure in the belly of the whale be perfectly good -lrb- 20 -rrb- it be not unusual to employ the vertebra of this species of whale as stool and it be say there be many house in the village of tain ten league from siraff in which the lintel of the door be make of whale rib a eye-witness tell I that he go to see a whale which have be cast ashore near siraff and find the people mount on its back by means of ladder that they dig pit in different part of he body and when the sun have melt the grease into oil they collect this and sell it to the master of ship who mix it up with some other matter use by seaman for the purpose of serve the bottom of they vessel and secure the seam of the plank to prevent or to stop leak this whale-oil sell for a great deal of money and the bone of the whale be sell by the druggist of bagdat and bassora the pearl oyster be at first a small thin tender substance resemble the leaf of the plant call _ anjedana _ and swim on the surface of the sea where it stick to the side of ship under water it there harden grow larger and become cover by a shell after which it become heavy and fall to the bottom of the sea where it subsist and grow in a way of which we be ignorant the include animal resemble a piece of red flesh or like the tongue of a animal towards the root have no bone vein or sinew one opinion of the production of pearl in this shell-fish be that the oyster rise to the surface when it rain and by gaping catch the drop of rain which harden into pearl the more likely opinion be that the pearl be generate within the body of the oyster for most of they be fix and not moveable such as be loose be call _ seed _ pearl a arab come once to bassora with a pearl of great value which he shew to a merchant and be astonish when he get so large a sum for it as a hundred dram of silver with which he purchase corn to carry back to he own country but the merchant carry he acquisition to bagdad where he sell it for a large sum of money by which he be afterwards enable to extend he dealings to a great amount the arab give the follow account of the way in which he have find this large pearl : go one day along the shore near saman in the district of bahrein -lrb- 21 -rrb- he see a fox lie dead with something hang at he muzzle which hold he fast which he discover to be a white lucid shell in which he find this pearl he conclude that the oyster have be throw ashore by a tempest and lay with its shell open on the beach when the fox attract by the smell have thrust in he muzzle to get at the meat on which the oyster close its shell and hold he fast till he die : for it be a property of the oyster never to let go its hold except forcibly open by thrust in a iron instrument between the shell carefully guard its include pearl as a mother preserve she child the king of the indy wear ear-ring of gold set with precious stone and they wear collar of great value adorn with gem of various color chiefly green and red yet pearl be most esteemed and they value surpass that of all other jewel and these they hoard up in they treasury with they most precious thing the grandee of they court they great officer and the military commander wear similar jewel in they collar they dress be a kind of half vest and they carry parasol make of peacock feather to shade they from the sun and be surround by great train of servant among the indian there be certain people who never eat two out of the same dish or even at the same table on account of some religious opinion when these come to siraf and be invite by we considerable merchant be there a hundred of they more or less they must each have a separate dish without the least communication with the rest they king and principal person have fresh table make for they every day with little dish and plate weave of the cocoa nut leaf out of which they eat they victuals and when they meal be over the table dish and plate be all throw into the water together with the fragment of they food so that they must have a fresh service for every meal to the indy the merchant use formerly to carry the dinar call sindiat or gold coin of the _ sind _ which pass there for three of we dinar or even more thither also be carry emerald from egypt which be much use for set in ring
