africa from spain to china between ad 1160 and 1173 _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- this spanish jew be the son of rabbi jona of tudelum a small town in navarre accord to the testimony of rabbi abraham zuka a celebrated professor of astronomy at salamanca it be suppose that rabbi benjamin travel from 1160 to 1173 young barratier a prodigy of early literary genius assert that benjamin never make the journey at all but patch up the whole work from contemporary writer there be no doubt that he work be full of incredible tale yet many of the anomaly it contain may have proceed from mistake of copyist exaggeration be the taste of the time and other traveller who be believe actually to have travel be not behind he in the marvellous these often relate the miracle of pretended christian saint while he detail the wonder perform by jewish rabbi he contain however many curious piece of information not to be find anywhere else and it seem necessary and proper to give a full abstract of he travels in this place travel by land to marseille benjamin embark for genoa and proceed to rome from whence he go through the kingdom of naple to otranto where he cross over to corfu and butrinto and journey by land through greece to constantinople have previously visit the country of wallachium all this take up the four first chapter which be omit in harri in the fifth he give a account of the city and court of constantinople as follow : constantinople be a exceedingly great city the capital of the javanite -lrb- 2 -rrb- or the nation call greek and the principal seat of the emperor emanuel -lrb- 3 -rrb- whose command be obey by twelve king for every one of whom there be several palace in constantinople and they have fortress and government in other place of the empire and to they the whole land be subject the principal of these be the apripus _ praepositus _ or prime minister the second mega dumastukitz -lrb- greek : meza domesticho -rrb- or great chamberlain the third dominot _ domino _ or lord : but he peculiar office or department do not appear the fourth mackducus -lrb- greek : meza docha -rrb- great duke or high admiral the fifth iknomus meglus -lrb- greek : oichonomo meza -rrb- or lord high steward of the household and the rest have name like unto these -lrb- 4 -rrb- constantinople be eighteen mile in circuit half of it be on the sea and the other half towards the continent it stand on two arm of the sea into one of which the sea flow from russium and into the other from spain and its port be frequent by many trader from the country and province of babylon senaar media persium egypt canaan russium hungary _ psiankus -lrb- 5 -rrb- buria _ lombardy and spain the city be extremely populous and have none to compare with it except bagdat the mighty city of the ismaelite -lrb- 6 -rrb- in it be the magnificent temple of st sophium where dwell the patriarch of the greek who do not agree in doctrine with the pope of rome this temple contain as many altar as there be day in the year and it have a revenue beyond all estimation great from the offering and riches bring continually from diver country island fort castle and place so that the wealth of no other temple on earth can be compare to the riches which it contain in the middle of this temple there be pillar of gold and silver huge candlestick lantern lamp and other ornament of these precious metal more than can be reckon close to this temple there be a place set apart for the diversion of the emperor call the hippodrome where great spectacles be represent yearly on the birth-day of jesus of nazareth in which man in the habit of all the various people of the earth appear before the emperor and empress with lion bear leopard and wild ass which be make to fight together and in no country on earth be such princely sport to be see besides the palace leave he by he ancestor manuel have build one for himself call bilberna -lrb- 7 -rrb- the pillar and wall of which be overlay with beaten gold and silver on which all the war of he ancestor be represent in this palace there be a throne of gold and precious stone over which a golden crown enrich with precious stone and pearl be suspend on high the value of which be beyond computation and its lustre so great that it shine and may be see in the night there be other thing in this palace of such value and profusion as be quite incredible and immense tribute be bring yearly into it by which the tower be fill with scarlet and purple garment and gold so that the like example of sumptuous building and enormous riches can nowhere else be find in the world it be affirm that the revenue of the city only from its market harbor and tribute of merchant amount to 20000 crown daily the greek inhabitant of this city and country be exceedingly rich in gold and jewel and be sumptuously dress in crimson garment intermingle with gold or splendidly embroidered and be all carry on horse as if they be the child of king the country itself be very extensive and abound with all sort of fruit and have great plenty of corn wine and cattle of all kind and a finer country be nowhere to be find the people be learn also and skilful in the philosophy of the greek : but give themselves up entirely to luxury they eat and drink every man under he own vine and under he own fig-tree they have mercenary soldier hire from all nation whom they call barbarian to fight against the soldan king of the child of togorma who be commonly call turk for the grecian themselves through sloth and luxury have become quite effeminate and unfit for war and entirely devote to pleasure no jew be permit to dwell in the city but be oblige to reside in pera on the other side of the sea of sophium and be not even allow to come to the city except in boat for the sake of commerce in pera there be about 2000 jewish rabbinist disciple of the wise man among whom be abtalion the great rabbi abdia aaron cuspus joseph starginus and eliakim the governor who have the chief authority besides these there be 500 karaite -lrb- 8 -rrb- who be separate from the rabbinist by a wall among the jew there be some manufacturer of silken garment and many very rich merchant no jew be permit to ride on horseback except solomon the egyptian who be physician to the emperor and through whose interest the jew be comfort and ease in they captivity which be very grievous for they be much hate by the grecian who make no distinction between the good and the evil among they and insult and beat they in the street they be worst use by the tanner who pour out the filthy water in which they have dress they skin into the street before they door yet among the jew there be some very rich man as i have say before good and merciful man who observe the commandment and who patiently endure the misery of the captivity from constantinople benjamin continue he journey to tyre jerusalem and the holy land and thence to damascus balbeck and palmyra which he call tadmor and in which he say there then be 2000 jew he next give a account of bagdat the court of the caliph and the condition of the jew there he afterwards give a account of a country which he call thema where he place a whole nation of jew which some have deem a entire forgery -lrb- 9 -rrb- he next proceeds to botzra balsora or bassora on the tigri and thence to persium of which he give the follow account the river samoura -lrb- 10 -rrb- be esteem the limit of the kingdom of persium and near it stand the city of the same name in which there be 1500 jew here be the sepulchre of esdras the scribe and priest who die in this place on he return from jerusalem to the court of artaxerx we people have build a great synagogue beside he tomb and the ismaelite arabian or mahometan have build a mosque close by as they have a great respect for esdra and the jew it be four mile from hence to chuzestan which be the same with the ancient city of elam now almost ruin and uninhabited at one end surround by ruin be the castle of susa formerly the palace of ahasuerus of which there be still some remains in this place there be 7000 jew and fourteen synagogue before one of which stand the tomb of daniel the river tigri -lrb- 11 -rrb- run through this city over which there be a bridge all the jew on one side of the river be very rich have well fill shop and carry on great trade while those on the other side be very poor have neither market shop garden or orchard this cause they once to make a insurrection from a notion that the glory and riches of those on the other side of the river be occasion by they have the sepulchre of the prophet daniel on they side the insurgent therefore demand to have he tomb transfer to they side which be vehemently oppose by the other and war ensue between they : but both party grow weary of the war it be agree that the coffin of daniel should remain one year on one side of the river and next year on the other this treaty be observe for some time but be cancel in the sequel by sanigar-shah son to the great shah of persium who rule over forty-five prince this great king be call in arabic sultan phar al-chabir he empire extend from the river samoura to samarcand the river gozan the province of gisbor include the city of the mede the mountain of haphton and to the province of thibet in the forest of which country be find the animal which produce musk and the empire be four month and four day journey in length sangiar be at elam see the elder of the people transport the coffin of daniel from one side of the river to the other attend by a immense crowd of jew and ismaelite and be inform of the cause give order that the coffin should be suspend in a glass case by chain of iron from the middle of the bridge and that a spacious synagogue should be erect in the same place open to all whether jew or gentile who might incline to pray there and he command from reverence for daniel that no fish should be take in the river for a mile above or below the bridge from elam to robat-bar be three day journey where dwell 20000 israelite among whom be many disciple of the wise man some of they be very rich but they live under the authority of a strange prince in two day journey more be the river vanth near which dwell 4000 jew four day journey farther be the country of molhat full of strong mountain the inhabitant of which obey a elder who reside in the country of alchesisin and they do not believe the doctrine of mahomet among this people there be four college of jew who go forth to war with the inhabitant invade the neighbouring country and drive away great spoil for they be not under the dominion of the king of persium the jew in this country be disciple of the wise man and obey the head of the captivity of babylon in five day journey you reach omarium where be 25000 israelite and here begin the synagogue of the mountain of haphton which exceed one hundred in number and in this place the country of media begin these jew be of the first captivity carry away by salmanazar but they speak the chaldean language and among they be the disciple of the wise man the chief city be omarium and all this country be under the dominion of persium to which the inhabitant pay tribute the tribute for male above fifteen year old in all the country of the ismaelite be one gold _ amir _ or half-a-crown of we money about twelve year ago there arise in the city of omarium a man name david elrous who be the disciple of chafdaus the head of the captivity and of jacob the chief of the levite at bagdat david be very learn in the law of mose and in the book of doctrine and in all wisdom even in the language of the ismaelite and in the book of the magus and the enchanter and he take it into he head to gather together the jew who dwell in the mountain of haphton and to make war against the king of persium and to go to jerusalem and win it by assault for this purpose he endeavor to draw the jew to he party by many deceitful sign affirm that he be send from god to free they from the yoke of the nation and to restore they to the holy city and he succeed in persuade many that he be the messiah -lrb- 12 -rrb- hearing of this insurrection the king of persium send for david who go to he without fear and even avowed himself to be king of the jew on which he be throw into prison in the city of dabrestan near the great river gozan after this the king hold a great council of he prince and minister to consult how to put a end to this insurrection of the jew and david make he appearance there unseen of any but the king the king ask who have deliver thee from prison and bring thee here to whom david answer mine own wisdom for i fear not thee or any of thy servant then the king command he servant to seize he but they say the voice be hear by all but they see not david then david cry out with a loud voice lo i go my way and he walk out and the king follow he and all he servant follow the king but they see no one come to the bank of the river david spread he handkerchief on the water and he pass over dry and then he be see of all who be present and they endeavor to pursue he in boat but all in vain and every one marvel and say that no enchanter could be compare to this man david during that day travel a ten day journey and come to omarium related all that have befall he and when the people be amaze he attribute all that have befall he to he knowledge of the ineffable name of jehovah -lrb- 13 -rrb- the king send messenger to inform the caliph of bagdat of what have happen request that he would get david restrain from he seditious practice by order from the head of the captivity and the chief ruler of the assembly of the jew otherwise threaten total destruction to all the jew in he dominion all the synagogue in persium be in great fear write to the head of the captivity and the assembly of elder at bagdat to the same purpose and they write to david command he to desist from he enterprize under pain of be excommunicate and cut off from among the people of israel but all be in vain for david persist in he wicked course till at length zinaldin a king of the togarmim or turk in subjection to the king of persium persuade the father-in-law of david by a bribe of ten thousand piece of gold to kill he privately and he thrust david through with a sword in he bed while asleep yet be not the anger of the king of persium pacify towards the jew of the mountain until the head of the captivity go and appease he with mild and wise speech and by the gift of a hundred talent of gold since which time there have be peace and quiet in the land from these mountain it be twelve day journey to hamadan the chief city of media in which there be 50000 jew and near one of they synagogue be the sepulchre of mordecaus and esther dabrestan near the river gozan be four day journey from hamadan and 4000 jew dwell there from thence it be seven day journey to ispahan which be a very great city and the capital of the whole country be twelve mile in circumference in this city there be about 12000 jew over whom and all the rest of we nation who dwell in the kingdom of persium shallum be appoint to rule by the head of the captivity four day journey from ispahan be siaphaz -lrb- 14 -rrb- the most ancient city of this country formerly persidi whence the whole province be name in which there be almost 10000 jew from siaphaz you come in seven day journey to the city of ginah near the river gozan where there be about 8000 jew and to this place merchant resort of all nation and language five day journey from ginah be the famous samarcand the farthest city of this kingdom where there be 50000 israelite many of whom be wise and rich man and over whom obedia be ruler four day journey from thence be the city of thibet -lrb- 15 -rrb- the capital of the province of that name in the forest of which the animal be find that produce musk the mountain of nisbor which be situate near the river gozan be about twenty-eight day journey from thibet and some of the jew in persium affirm that the four tribe of israel carry away in the first captivity by salmanazar still inhabit the city of nisbor they country extend twenty day journey in length all full of mountain and have the river gozan run on one side with many inhabit city town and castle and the inhabitant be entirely free be govern by joseph amrael a levite and among they be many disciple of the wise man they sow and reap and be at war with the child of chus who dwell in the desert -lrb- 16 -rrb- these jew be in league with the copheral turk a people who dwell in the desert and eat no bread neither do they drink any wine but feed on the raw or dry flesh of beast clean or unclean devour they newly kill while yet tremble with the warm life-blood and uncooked yea even feed on the limb tear from beast yet alive this last people seem to want nose have only as it be two hole in they face through which they breathe -lrb- 17 -rrb- these copheral turk invade persium about fifteen year ago about 1145 with a great army and destroy the metropolitan city of reus -lrb- 18 -rrb- and carry off vast spoil into the desert enrage at this insult the king of persium endeavor to pursue they with a powerful army that he might extirpate these destroyer from the earth and procure a guide who undertake to conduct he to they dwelling and recommend to he to take bread and water for fifteen day along with the army as it would occupy that time to pass the desert after march these fifteen day the army be without subsistence for man and beast and no sign could be perceive of any habitation of mankind on be interrogate the guide pretend to have lose he way and be put to death as a traitor after march for thirteen day more in prodigious distress during which they have to eat up all the beast that carry they baggage they arrive at the mountain of nisbor inhabit by the jew and incamped among garden and orchard water by canal draw from the river gozan and be then the season of ripe fruit they eat what they please no one appear to oppose they at a distance among the mountain they observe some hamlet and fort and two scout be send to discover what manner of people inhabit the mountain after proceed a short way they find a well build bridge with a strong barrier and a very large city at the farther end of the bridge they here learn by a interpreter that the city belong to a independent nation of jew who have a prince of they own and be in alliance with the copheral turk the scout return to the camp with this intelligence and the jew have collect they force offer battle on the day follow to the persian the king decline this declare that he only object be against the copheral turk and that if the jew attack he he would revenge himself by put all they brethren in persium to the sword but he demand free passage for he army and to be supply with provision for ready money out of regard for they brethren in persium the jew agree to this proposal and the persian army remain fifteen day in the country of the jew where they be honourably entertain in the mean time the jews send intelligence of the situation of the persian to they confederate and the turk gather they force assail the persian at certain pass in the mountain and give they a terrible overthrow so that the king escape with great difficulty into persium with a small remnant of he host on this occasion one of the persian horseman seduce a jew name mose to accompany he into persium and then make he a slave on a public exhibition of archery in the king 's presence this man appear to be the most expert archer in all persium and be call before the king declare how he have be trepan and make a slave the king restore he to liberty clothe he in purple and silken garment and enriched he with liberal gift offer he great riches and the government of the royal household if he would embrace the religion of the country and when he courteously decline this he be place by the king with rabbi shallum the prince of the synagogue at ispahan whose daughter he afterwards married and this mose related to I the whole story i have here related depart from these country i return to khosistan through which the tigri run into _ hodu _ the indian sea or persian gulf and in its passage encompass the island of nekroki -lrb- 19 -rrb- near its mouth which be six day journey in extent there be only one canal of fresh water in this island and they have no other water to drink but what be gather during rain and preserve in cistern for which reason the land be not cultivate yet it be famous for commerce with indium and the island of the indian sea and merchant from sennar arabium and persium bring thither all sort of silk and purple manufacture hemp cotton flax and indian cloth with plenty of wheat barley millet and rice the indian merchant bring also great quantity of spice and the native act as factor and interpreter by which they make great gain but in that place there be not above 500 jew sail thence with a favourable wind i arrive in ten day at kathipha -lrb- 20 -rrb- where be 5000 jew in these place pearl be find make by a wonderful artifice of nature for on the 24th of the month nisan -lrb- 21 -rrb- a certain dew fall into the water which be suck in by the oyster they sink immediately to the bottom of the sea and afterwards about the middle of the month tisrus man dive to the bottom and bring up great quantity of the oyster by means of cord from which they take out the pearl in seven day journey from thence i come to oulam -lrb- 22 -rrb- which be the entrance of the kingdom of these people who worship the sun and be prone to astrology being of the child of chus they be man of a dark complexion sincere and faithful in all they dealings when any stranger arrive in they haven they name be all set down by three secretary who carry they list to the king afterwards they introduce the merchant to he and he receive all they goods under he protection cause they to be land at a place where they may remain in safety even without a watch there be a particular magistrate to whom all thing that happen to be lose or casually remove be bring and who return they to the owner on give the mark or description of they property and this strict fidelity and honest dealing be universal over all this kingdom in this country from the passover to the beginning of the succeed year the sun shine with such insufferable heat that the people remain shut up in they house from the third hour of the day until evening and then lamp be light up in all the street and market and the people labor at they respective calling all night in this country pepper grow on tree plant in the field belong to every city all the inhabitant have they proper garden particularly assign and know the shrub be small and produce a white seed or berry which after be gather be first steep in hot water and then dry in the sun when it become black cinnamon and ginger be likewise find here and many other kind of spice in this country the body of the dead be embalm with diver drug and spice and set up in niche in regular order cover over with net they there dry up completely without corruption and every one know he ancestor for many generation back they worship the sun say have many large altar erect along the coast about half a mile without the city to pay they devotions on these altar there be consecrated sphere make by magic art resemble the circle of the sun and when the sun rise these orb seem to be inflamed and whirl round with a great noise -lrb- 23 -rrb- in they orison every person carry a censer in which he burn incense in honor of the sun but among these people there be about a thousand family of jew as black as the rest of the native yet good honest man and strict observer of the law of mose and not entirely ignorant of the doctrine of the talmud from this country i sail in twenty-two day to the island of cinrog the inhabitant of which be call dogbiim and be worshipper of fire among whom 23000 jew be settle the dogbiim have many priest to officiate in they temple who be the most skilful sorcerer and enchanter in the world before every temple there be a large pit in which a great fire be kindle every day call alhuta through which they child be make to pass as a purification into it likewise they cast the body of they dead and even some of they noble occasionally be so superstitious as to devote themselves to be consume alive in honor of the deity in which they be encourage by they relation as ensure they eternal welfare on the day appoint for the performance of this vow the devoted person first give a entertainment and be then carry to the appoint spot if rich on horseback but on foot if poor accompany by a multitude of he friend and other and immediately leap into the midst of the burning pit all he friend and kindred celebrate the festival with music and dancing until he be entirely consume three day afterwards two of the priest go to the house of the devoted person and command he family to prepare for a visit from the decease on the same day the priest then take certain person along with they as witness of the transaction and carry with they to the house a figure resemble the deceased which they affirm to be himself the widow and child as instruct by the priest then demand how it fare with he in the other world : to which he answer i come to my companion who will not receive I until i have discharge my duty to my friend and kindred he then make a distribution of he effect among he child order all he debt to be pay and whatever be owe to he to be demand the witness set down all this in write and then he vanish by these art of juggling and collusion the priest govern every thing as they please in the space of forty day one may travel to the frontier of tzin which be the very extremity of the east some hold that this country be wash by the nikpha or coagulated sea which be liable to prodigious storm by which when mariner be surprise they be reduce to such extremity that not be able to get out they be miserably starve to death after expend all they provision -lrb- 24 -rrb- from cinrog it be three day journey to gingalum where there be above a thousand jew from thence in seven day one may sail to coulan where there be none of we nation it be twelve day journey to zabid where there be some jew and in eight day more you get to the opposite coast where there be very high mountain inhabit by multitude of israelite who be not under the yoke of the gentile but have great city and strong fortress of they own they descend from thence in party into the flat country of abyssinium whence they return with they plunder into the mountain where they be secure against pursuit many as to go through the whole law once in every year but the other divide each parascha into three _ sedarim _ or smaller section so that they read over the whole law only once in three year yet both of these join in they solemn prayer twice every year over the whole nathaniel preside be head of the sanhedrim and ruler of all the synagogue in egypt to which he appoint master and elder he be likewise large market and public building and contain many rich jew the country be never trouble with rain ice or snow but be often afflict with insufferable heat it be water by the nile which begin to swell every year in the month elul and continue swell during that month and tisrus -lrb- 30 -rrb- make the earth fruitful the old egyptian erect a fine marble pillar of excellent workmanship in a island at this place rise twelve cubit above the ordinary surface of the river and when the water overflow that column the inhabitant be satisfied that they whole country be overspread for fifteen day journey if the water rise only half the height of the pillar they then conclude that only half the country be overflow a person be station by the pillar who proclaim the height of the water every day at noon when the water rise to a sufficient height it indicate a year of fertility and plenty in egypt but when it do not overflow nothing be sow and sterility and famine be the consequence the people of the country have trench dig in they grounds in which great number of fish be catch when the river recede which they either use in they family or salt they for sale these fish be very fat and supply oil travels refer -- e chap vi _ travels of a englishman into tartary and thence into poland hungary and germany in 1243 _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- this earliest remain direct account of the tartar or mongol receive that name which be extremely short and inconclusive be record by matthew pari in a letter from yvo de narbonne to the archbishop of bourdeaux and be here give as a literary curiosity \* \* \* \* \* provoke by the sin of the christian the lord have become as it be a destroy enemy and a dreadful avenger have send among we a prodigiously numerous most barbarous and inhuman people whose law be lawless and whose wrath be furious even as the rod of god 's anger overrunning and utterly ruin infinite country and cruelly destroy every thing where they come with fire and sword this present summer that nation which be call tartar leave hungary which they have surprise by treason lay siege with many thousand soldier to the town of newstadt in which i then dwell in which there be not above fifty man at arm and twenty cross-bow-man leave in garrison all these observe from certain high place the vast army of the enemy and abhor the beastly cruelty of the accomplice of antichrist signify to the governor the hideous lamentation of he christian subject who in all the adjoining province be surprised and cruelly destroy without any respect of rank fortune age or sex the tartarian chieftain and they brutishly savage follower glut themselves with the carcass of the inhabitant leave nothing for the vulture but the bare bone and strange to tell the greedy and ravenous vulture disclaim to prey on the remains leave by the tartar old and deform woman they give for daily sustenance to they cannibal : the young and beautiful they devour hot but smother they shriek and lament under they force and unnatural ravishment and cut off the breast of tender virgin to present as dainty to they leader they feed themselves upon they body they spy have descry from the top of a high mountain the duke of austrium the king of bohemia the patriarch of aquileium the duke of carindium and as some say the earl of baden approach with a mighty power towards they the accursed crew immediately retire into the distressed and vanquished land of hungary depart as suddenly as they have invade and astonishing all man by the celerity of they motion the prince of dalmatium take eight of the fugitive one of whom be recognize by the duke of austrium as a englishman who have be perpetually banish from england for certain crime this man have be send twice as a messenger and interpreter from the most tyrannical king of the tartar to the king of hungary menacing and fortell those mischief which afterwards happen unless he would submit himself and he kingdom to the yoke of the tartar be urge by we prince to confess the truth this man make such oath and protestation as i think might have serve to make even the devil be trust he report of himself that presently after he banishment be then about thirty year of age and have lose all he possess at dice in the city of acon -lrb- 2 -rrb- he set off from thence in the middle of winter wear nothing but a shirt of sack a pair of shoe and a hairy cap and be shave like a fool he utter a uncouth noise as if he have be dumb and wander about through many country in search of food at length through fatigue and change of air and diet he fall grievously sick in chaldea insomuch that he be weary of he life be compel to remain there a long time to recover he strength and have some learning he begin to write down the word he hear speak and in a short time make himself so much master of the language as to be repute a native and in this manner he attain expertness in many language the tartar get notice of this man by means of they spy and draw he by force among they and have be admonish by a oracle or vision to extend they dominion over the whole earth they allure he by many offer of reward to serve they as a interpreter he give the follow account of the manners and superstition of the tartar of the disposition and stature of they body and of they country and manner of fight the tartar be covetous irascible deceitful and merciless beyond all man yet through the rigor of discipline which be exercise by they superior they be restrain from brawl and mutual strife they esteem the ancient founder and father of they tribe as god in whose honor they celebrate solemn feast at certain fixed time and these deity be very numerous though only four be consider as general god of the nation they consider all thing as create for they sole use and do not therefore think themselves cruel or unjust in waste and destroy the surround nation whom they esteem rebel against they legitimate authority they body though lean be hardy and strong with broad chest and square high shoulder strong well knit joint and firm sinew thick and large thigh with short leg so that be equal to we in stature what they want in they leg be supply in the upper part of they body they face be pale with short flat nose they eye black and inconstant have large eyebrow extend down to the nose long sharp chin they upper jaw low and decline they tooth long and thin they countenance distorted fierce and terrible in ancient time they country which be situate far beyond chaldea be utterly waste and barren from whence they have expel the lion bear and other wild beast of the tan hide of beast they make for themselves light but impenetrable armor and they back be only slightly arm that they may not flee in battle they use small but strong horse which be maintain with little provender in fight they use javelin mace battle-axis and sword but be particularly expert in the use of bow and arrow when engage in battle they never retire till they see the chief standard of they general give back when vanquish they ask no quarter and in victory they shew no compassion and though many million in number they all persist as one man in resolve to subdue the whole world under they dominion they have 60000 courier who be send before upon light horse to prepare a place for the army to encamp and these will gallop in one night as far as we troops can march in three day when they invade a country they suddenly diffuse themselves over the whole land surprising the people unarmed unprovided and dispersed and make such horrible slaughter and devastation that the king or prince of the invade land can not collect a sufficient force to give they battle sometimes they say they intend to go to cologne to bring home the three wise king into they own country sometimes they propose to punish the avarice and pride of the roman who formerly oppress they sometimes to conquer the barbarous nation of the north sometimes to moderate the fury of the german with they own mildness sometimes in derision they say that they intend go in pilgrimage to the shrine of st jame in galicium by means of these pretence some indiscreet governor of province have enter into league with they and have grant they free passage through they territory but which league they have ever violate to the certain ruin and destruction of these prince and they unhappy country -lrb- 1 -rrb- hakluyt i 22 -lrb- 2 -rrb- acre in palestine -- e chap vii _ sketch of the revolution in tartary _ we limit do not admit of any detailed account of the history of those numerous and warlike pastoral nation which in all age have occupy the vast bound of that region which have be usually denominate scythium by the ancient and tartary by the modern : yet it seem necessary to give in this place a comprehensive sketch of the revolution which have so strikingly characterize that storehouse of devastate conqueror to elucidate the various travels into tartary which be contain in this first book of we work and in this division of we plan we have be chiefly guide by the masterly delineation on the same subject of the eloquent historian of the decline and fall of the roman empire -lrb- 1 -rrb- in they navigation of the euxine and by plant colony on its coast the greek become acquaint with western scythium extend from the danube along the northern frontier of thrace to mount caucasus the great extent of the ancient persian empire which reach at one period from the danube to the indus expose its whole northern frontier to the scythian nation as far to the east as the mountain of imaus or caf now call the belur-tag the still more eastern part of scythium or tartary be know of old to the chinese and stretch to the utmost north-eastern bound of asia thus from the danube and carpathian mountain in long 26  e to the promontory of tschuts-koi-no or the east cape of asia in long 190  e this vast region extend in length 160 degree of longitude or not less than 8000 mile its southern boundary be more difficultly ascertainable : but except where they be press northwards by the anciently civilized empire of china these may be assume at a medium on the thirty-fifth degree of north latitude from whence scythium or tartary extend in breadth to the extremity of the frozen north next to the nomadic nation of western scythium who encounter and baffle the arm of darius king of persium under the general name of scythian who be perhaps congeneric or the same with those afterwards know by the name of goth the dreaded name of the hun become know to the decline roman empire but we object do not require we to attempt to trace the history of these nation under they various appellation of hun topa geougen turk chozar and other till the establishment of the vast empire of zingi connect the history and devastate conquest of the tartar with the affair of modern europe -lrb- 2 -rrb- in the beginning of the thirteenth century temugin the son of a mogul chief lay the foundation of a vast empire in the north east of tartary or mongolia he father have reign over thirteen horde or tribe of the mogul moal or mongul : and as it be not customary for these warlike tribe to submit to be rule over by a boy temugen who at the death of he father be only thirteen year of age have to contend with he revolted subject and have to obey a conqueror of he own nation in a new attempt to recover the command over the subject of he father he be more successful : and under the new appellation of _ zingi _ which signify _ most great _ he become the conqueror of a empire of prodigious extent in person or by means of he lieutenant he successfully reduce the nation tribe or horde of tartary or scythium from china to the volga and establish he undisputed authority over the whole pastoral world he afterwards subjugate the five northern province of china which be long imperfectly know under the name of kathay and successively reduce carisme or transoxiana now great bucharium chorassan and persium : and he die in 1227 after have exhort and instruct he son to persevere in the career of conquest and more particularly to complete the conquest of china the vast empire establish by zingi be apportion among he four principal son toushi zagataus octaus and tulus who have be respectively he great huntsman chief judge prime minister and grand general firmly unite among themselves and faithful to they own and the public interest three of these brother and they family and descendant be satisfy with subordinate command and octaus by general consent of the maol or noble be proclaimed _ khan _ or emperor of the mogul and tartar octaus be succeed by he son gayuk after whose death the empire devolve successively on he cousin mangou or mangu and cublai the son of tulus and the grandson of zingi during the sixty-eight year of the reign of these four successor of zingi the mogul subdue almost all asia and a considerable portion of europe the great khan at first establish he royal court at kara-kum in the desert and follow the tarter custom of move about with the golden horde attend by numerous flock and herd accord to the change of the season : but mangu-khan and cublai-khan establish they principal seat of empire in the new city of pe-king or khan-balu and perfect the conquest of china reduce corea tonkin cochin-china pegu bengal and thibet to different degree of subjection or tribute under the direct influence of the great khan and he peculiar lieutenant the conquest of persium be complete by holagu the son of tulus and grandson of zingi who of course be ' brother to the two successive emperor mangu and cublaus from persium the mogul spread they ravages and conquest over syrium armenia and anatolium or what be now call turkey in asia but arabium be protect by its burning desert and egypt be successfully defend by the arm of the mamaluke who even repel the mogul from syrium batu another son of tulus conquer turkestan and kipzak -lrb- 3 -rrb- astracan and cazan and reduce georgium and circassium to dependence advance from the black sea to livonium on the baltic moscow and kiow be reduce to ash and russium submit to pay tribute they victorious arm penetrate into poland in which they destroy the city of lublin and cracow and they even defeat the confederate army of the duke of silesium the polish palatine and the great master of the teutonic knight at lignitz the most western extremity of they destructive march from lignitz they turn aside into hungary and reduce the whole of that country to the north of the danube during the winter they cross the danube on the ice gran the capital of hungary be take by storm and belum the unfortunate king of hungary have to take shelter in one of the island at the head of the adriatic so terrible be the alarm in europe that the inhabitant of sweden and the north of germany neglect in 1238 to send they ship as usual to the herring-fishery on the coast of england and as observe by gibbon it be whimsical enough to learn that the price of herring in the english market be lower in consequence of the order of a barbarous mogul khan who reside on the border of china -lrb- 4 -rrb- the tide of ruin be stem at newstadt in austrium by the bravery of fifty knight and twenty cross-bow-man and the tartar awed by the fame of the valor and arm of the frank or inhabitant of western europe raise the siege on the approach of a german army command by the emperor frederic the second after lay waste the kingdom of servium bosnium and bulgarium the adventurous batu slowly retreat from the danube to the volga and establish he seat of command in the city and palace of seraus both of which he have cause to be build upon the eastern arm of that noble river another of the son of tulus shaibani-khan lead a horde of 15000 tartar family into the wild of siberium and he descendant reign above three century at tobolsk in that secluded region and even reduce the miserable samoyede in the neighborhood of the polar circle such be the establishment and extent of the first tartar or mogul empire the descendant of cublaus give themselves up to luxury in the palace of peke amidst a mischievous crowd of eunuch concubine and astrologer and they mogul army dissolve and disperse in a vast and populous country forget the discipline and bravery of they ancestor the secondary mogul sovereign of the west assume entire independence and the great khan be satisfy with the empire of china and eastern mongalium in 1367 one hundred and forty year after the death of zingi rouse to rebellion by a dreadful famine in which thirteen million of the inhabitant of china perish the native chinese expel they degenerate mogul oppressor and the great khan become a wanderer in the desert the vast empire establish by zingi and he immediate successor be now break down into four vast fragment each a powerful empire mongalium kipzak zagtaus or transoxiana and persium and these four khan often contend with each other on they ruin in lesser asia arise the formidable more permanent and still subsist empire of the ottoman turk whose youthful energy threaten the subversion of the last remains of the greek empire which they at last effect and might perhaps have conquer the whole of western europe if they progress have not be arrest by the power of a new mogul dynasty in the distribution of the vast empire of zingi we have already see that zagathaus one of he son receive the subordinate rule of transoxiana or the rich country on the river jihon or amu and the sir or sihon the oxus and jaxarte of the ancient this extensive and fertile country now call western turkestan great bucharium kharism chorassan and balk with some other smaller territory be bound on the west by the caspian on the east by the belur-tag or imaus on the north by the desert of western tartary and on the south by the mountain of the hindoo-koh and the desert of margiana the descendant of zagataus be long consider as the khan or sovereign of this fair empire which fall into civil war and anarchy through the division and subdivision of the horde the uncertain law of succession and the ambition of the minister of state who reduce they degenerate master to mere state puppet and elevated or depose successive khan at they pleasure and the divide and distract country be subject or oppress by the invasion of the khan of kashgar who rule over the calmuck or gete in eastern turkestan or little bucharium on the cast of imaus or the belur-tag in this state of misery and depression a new hero arise in 1361 to vindicate and re-establish the fame and empire of the mogul -lrb- 5 -rrb- timor usually call tamerlane be the son of the hereditary chief of cash a small but fruitful territory about forty mile to the south of samarcand he be the fifth in descent from carashar-nevian who have be vizir or prime minister to zagathaus of which sovereign timor be descend in the female line after various fortune he in 1370 render himself absolute sovereign of transoxiana then call zagataus after its first mogul ruler but for some time he affect to govern as prime minister or general to a nominal khan of the house of zingi who serve as a private officer at the head of he family horde in the army of he servant after establish he authority in zagataus and conquer kharism and candahar he turn he arm against persium or iran which have fall into disorganization by the extinction of the descendant of the great holacou and which country he reduce under subjection he successively reduce cashgar or eastern turkestan and kipzak or western tartary and invade syrium and anatolium in this invasion in 1402 be fight the great battle of angora in which bajazet the great sultan of the turk be defeat and take prisoner by this great victory the progress of the turkish arm be check for a time and perhaps europe be save on that day from be subject to the law of mahomet yet the vast empire which timor establish fall into fragment after he death in 1405 and he descendant have sink into oblivion while the race of othman and bajazet still rule over a large empire in europe and asia nearly commensurate with the eastern roman empire still call rumus in the east have thus trace a outline of the revolution of empire in tartary down to what may be consider as modern history it be only necessary farther to mention that all eastern tartary and mongalium be now subject to china and kipzac and all the northern to russia hardly any part of it now remain independent except zagataus or transoxiana kharism tartar _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- introduction in the collection of early voyage travels and discovery by hakluyt publish originally in 1599 and reprint at london in 1809 with addition there be two separate relation of these travels the _ first _ in p 24 be the journal of john de plano carpini a italian minorite who accompany by friar benedict a polander go in 1246 by the north of the caspian sea to the residence of batu-khan and thence to kajuk - khan whom he call cuyne the chief or emperor of all the mongol the _ second _ in p 42 be a relation take from the speculum historiale of vincentius beluacensis lib xxxii ch 2 of the mission of certain friar predicant and minorite in the same year 1246 to the same country and in p 59 of the same collection there be a translation by hakluyt into antiquated english of this second account from this second narrative it appear that vincentius have receive a account of the journey of the second mission from simon de st quintin a minorite friar belong to the party and that he have work up along with this the whole of the narrative which have be separately publish by carpinus of he journey which indeed form by far the larger and more interesting portion of the work publish by vincentius this latter edition therefore have be consider as sufficient for the present collection because to have give both would have be a unnecessary repetition and it be here translate from the latin of hakluyt i 42 the object of this mission or embassy seem to have be as follow : a prodigious alarm be excite in europe by the victorious and destructive progress of the mongal or tartar who under the command of tuschi-khan and of batu-khan the son of tuschi advance through kipzhak russium poland and hungary all of which they have most horribly ravage and lay waste have penetrate even into silesium while by the eastern side or the caspian penetrate through transoxiana and persium under the command of zagatai-khan likewise a son of zingus and holagu-khan a nephew of zagataus they have make they appearance on the bank of the euphrate and tigri in this alarming conjuncture it be think advisable by pope innocent iv in a convocation of the clergy at lyon in 1245 to send ambassador to these formidable conqueror to endeavor to pacify they and induce they to turn the destructive tide of they conquest in some other direction and perhaps partly in the hope of endeavor if possible to convert they to the christian faith and induce they to direct they arm against the turk and saracen who oppress the holy land for this purpose six monk be select from the new and severe order of predicant and minorite john de plano carpinus and benedict travel through bohemia and poland to kiow in russium and thence by the mouth of the dnieper to the camp of korrensa or corrensa a general of the mongal whence cross the don and wolga or volga they come to the encampment of bata-khan call also baty and baatu who send they to kajuk-khan the emperor of the mongal whom they call cuyne the other ambassador be asceline with friar alexander albert and simon de st quintin : who go by the south of the caspian through syrium persium and chorassan to the court of baiju-nojan or as they call he bajothnoy : but of the particulars of this journey very little have be preserve by vincentius so that in fact the travels here publish belong almost exclusively to carpini the full title give by hakluyt to this relation be worth preserve as a literary curiosity and be as follow : the long and wonderful voyage of friar john de plano carpini send ambassador by pope innocent iv ad 1246 to the great can of tartacium wherein he pass through bohemia polonium russium and so to the city of kiow upon boristhene and from thence ride continually post for the space of sixe moneth through comanium over the mighty and famous river tanais volga and jaie and through the country of the people call kangittae bisermini karakitay naimanus and so to the native country of the mongol or tartar situate in the extreme north-eastern parte of all asia and thence back again the same way to russium and polonium and so to rome spending in the whole voyage among the sayd tartar one whole year and above four moneth : take out of the 32 booke of vincentius beluacensis he speculum historiale -lrb- 1 -rrb- hakluyt i 24 and 42 for the latin of the two relation and p 59 for the old english translation of the second section i _ introductory epistle by john de plano carpinus _ to all the faithful in christ to whom this writing may come i friar john de plano carpinus of the order of minorite legate and messenger from the apostolic see to the tartar and other nation of the east wish the grace of god in this life and glory in the next and perpetual triumph over all the enemy of the lord have learn the will of we lord the pope and the venerable cardinal and receive the command of the holy see that we should go to the tartar and other nation of the east we determine to go in the first place to the tartar because we dread that the most imminent and nearest danger to the church of god arise from they and although we personally dread from these tartar and other nation that we might be skin or reduce to perpetual slavery or should suffer hunger and thirst the extreme of heat and cold reproach and excessive fatigue beyond we strength all of which except death and captivity we have endure even beyond we first fear yet do we not spare ourselves that we might obey the will of god accord to the order of we lord the pope that we might be useful in any thing to the christian or at least that the will and intention of these people might be assuredly know and make manifest to christendom lest suddenly invade we they might find we unprepared and might make incredible slaughter of the christian people hence what we now write be for you advantage that you may be on you guard and more secure be what we see with we own eye while we sojourn with and among these people during more than a year and four month or which we have learn from christian captive reside among they and whom we believe to be worthy of credit we be likewise enjoin by the supreme pontiff that we should examine and inquire into every thing very diligently all of which both myself and friar benedict of the same order my companion in affliction and interpreter have carefully perform section ii _ of the first mission of friar predicant and minorite to the tartar _ at the same period pope innocent iv send friar asceline of the order of friar predicant with three other friar from different convent with apostolical letter to the army of the tartar exhort they to desist from slaughter mankind and to adopt the true christian faith and from one of these lately return friar simon de st quintin of the minorite order i have receive the relation concern the transaction of the tartar which be here set down at the same period friar john de plano carpinus of the order of minorite with some other be send to the tartar and remain travel among they for sixteen month this friar john have write a little history which be come to we hand of what he see among the tartar or learn from diver person live in captivity from which i have insert such thing in the follow relation as be want in the account give I by friar simon section iii _ of the situation and quality of the land of the tartar from carpinus _ the land of mongolium or tartary be in the east part of the world where the east and north be believe to unite -lrb- 1 -rrb- hay the country of kathay and the people call solangus on the east on the south the country of the saracen the land of the huinus on the south-east on the west the province of naimanus and the ocean on the north in some part it be full of mountain in other part quite plain but everywhere intersperse with sandy barren not a hundredth part of the whole being fertile as it can not be cultivate except where it be water with river which be very rare hence there be no town or city except one name cracurim -lrb- 2 -rrb- which be say to be tolerably good we do not see that place although within half a day 's journey when we be at the horde of syra the court of they great emperor although otherwise infertile this land be well adapt for the pasture of cattle in some place there be wood of small extent but the land be mostly destitute of tree insomuch that even the emperor and prince and all other warm themselves and cook they victuals with fire of horse and cow dung the climate be very intemperate as in the middle of summer there be terrible storm of thunder and lightning by which many people be kill and even then there be great fall of snow and there blow such tempest of cold wind that sometimes people can hardly sit on horseback in one of these when near the syra horde by which name they signify the station of the emperor or of any of they prince we have to throw ourselves prostrate on the ground and could not see by reason of the prodigious dust it never rain in winter but frequently in summer yet so gently as scarcely to lay the dust or to moisten the root of the grass but there be often prodigious shower of hail insomuch that by the sudden melting of one of these at the time when the emperor elect be about to be place on he throne at which time we be at the imperial court above a hundred and sixty person be drown and many habitation and much valuable thing be sweep away in summer there be often sudden and intolerable heat quickly follow by extreme cold -lrb- 1 -rrb- this strange personification of the east and north as if they be stationary geographical term not merely relative only mean that mongalium lay in the most north-easterly part of the then known world -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- call likewise karakum or caracorum and say to signify the _ black sand _ -- e section iv _ of the appearance dress and manner of living of the tartar _ the appearance of the mongol or tartar be quite different from all other nation be much wider between the eye and cheek and they cheek be very prominent with small flat nose and small eye have the upper lid open up to the eyebrow and they crown be shave like priest on each side leave some long hair in the middle the remainder be allow to grow long like woman which they twist into two tail or lock and bind behind they ear the garment of the man and woman be alike use neither cloak hat nor cap but they wear strange tunic make of bucram purple or baldequin they gown be make of skin dress in the hair and open behind they never wash they clothes neither do they allow other to wash especially in time of thunder till that be over they house be round and artificially make like tent of rod and twig interwoven have a round hole in the middle of the roof for the admission of light and the passage of smoke the whole be cover with feel of which likewise the door be make some of these be easily take to piece or put together and be carry on sumpter-cattle while other be not capable of be take to piece and be carry on cart wherever they go whether to war or only travel to fresh pasture these be carry with they they have vast number of camel oxen sheep and goat and such prodigious multitude of horse and mare as be not to be find in all the rest of the world but they have no swine they emperor duke and other noble be extremely rich in gold and silver silk and gem they eat of every thing that be eatable and we have even see they eat vermin they drink milk in great quantity and particularly prefer that of mare but as in winter none but the rich can have mare milk they make a drink of millet boil in water every one drinking one or two cup in the morning and sometimes have no other food all day but in the evening every one have a small quantity of flesh and they drink the broth in which it be boil in summer when they have abundance of mare milk they eat little flesh unless it be give they or when they catch venison or bird section v _ of they good and bad custom _ -lrb- illustration : map of the western part of tartary & adjacent country -rrb- some of they custom be commendable and other execrable they be more obedient to they lord than any other people give they vast reverence and never deceive they in word or action they seldom quarrel and brawl wound or manslaughter hardly ever occur thief and robber be nowhere find so that they house and cart in which all they treasure be keep be never lock or bar if any animal go astray the finder either leave it or drive it to those who be appoint to seek for stray and the owner get it back without difficulty they be very courteous and though victuals be scarce among they they communicate freely to each other they be very patient under privation and though they may have fast for a day or two will sing and make merry as if they be well satisfy in journey they bear cold or heat with great fortitude they never fall out and though often drunk never quarrel in they cup no one despise another but every one assist he neighbor to the utmost they woman be chaste yet they conversation be frequently immodest towards other people they be exceedingly proud and overbearing look upon all other man with contempt however noble for we see in the emperor 's court the great duke of russium the son of the king of georgium and many sultan and other great man who receive no honor or respect so that even the tartar appoint to attend they however low they condition always go before they and take the upper place and even often oblige they to sit behind they back they be irritable and disdainful to other man and beyond belief deceitful speaking always fair at first but afterwards sting like scorpion they be crafty and fraudulent and cheat all man if they can whatever mischief they intend they carefully conceal that no one may provide or find a remedy for they wickedness they be filthy in they meat and drink and in all they action drunkenness be honorable among they so that when one have drink to excess and throw up he begin again to drink they be most importunate beggar and covetous possessor and most niggardly giver and they consider the slaughter of other people as nothing section vi _ of the law and custom of the tartar _ man and woman guilty of adultery or even of fornication be punish with death those detect in robbery or theft be likewise slay if any one divulge they council especially with regard to a intended war he receive a hundred blow on he buttock with a great cudgel as hard as a strong man can lay on when any of the meaner sort commit offence they be severely punish by they superior in marriage they pay no attention to nearness of kindred except they mother daughter or sister by the same mother for they will even marry they sister from other mother and they father wife after he death the younger brother also or some other of the kindred be bind to marry the wife of a deceased brother while i remain in the country a russian duke name andrew -lrb- 1 -rrb- be accuse before duke baatu of convey tartar horse out of the country and sell they to other nation be put to death although the fact be not prove against he after this the widow and younger brother of andrew come to baatu supplicate that they might not be deprive of the dukedom upon which baatu command they to be marry accord to the tartar custom and though both refuse as contrary to the religion and law of russium they be compel to this incestuous union after the death of they husband the tartar widow seldom marry unless when a man choose to wed he brother 's wife or he stepmother they make no difference between the son of a wife or of a concubine of which the follow be a memorable example the late king of georgium leave two son melich and david of whom the former be lawful and the other bear in adultery but he leave part of he dominion to he bastard melich appeal to the tartar emperor for justice and david go likewise to the court carry large gift and the emperor confirm the will of they father even appoint david to have the superior authority because eldest bear when a tartar have more than one wife each have she own house and establishment and the husband eat drink and sleep sometimes with one and sometimes with another one be consider as principal wife and with she he reside oftener than with the other and though they be sometimes numerous they very seldom quarrel among themselves -lrb- 1 -rrb- in the previous account of the travels of carpinus hakl i 27 this andrew be say to have be duke of sarvogle or seirvogle perhaps mean yeroslave -- e section vii _ of they superstitious tradition _ in consequence of certain tradition they consider many indifferent action as criminal one be to thrust a knife into the fire or any way to touch a fire with a knife to take meat from the pot with a knife or even to hew any thing with a axe near a fire as they consider all these thing as take away the force of the fire another be to lean upon a whip for they use no spur or to touch arrow with they whip to strike they horse with they bridle to take or kill young bird or to break one bone upon another likewise to spill milk or any drink or food on the ground or to make water in a house for the last offence if intentional a man be slay or he must pay a heavy fine to the soothsayer to be purify in which case the house and all that it contain have to pass between two fire before which ceremony no person must enter the house nor must any thing be remove from it if any one take a bit of meat that he can not swallow and spit it out a hole be make in the floor of the house through which he be drag and put to death if any one tread on the threshold of a house belong to one of they duke he be put to death many such thing they account high offence but to slay man to invade the territory of other to take away the goods of other people and to act contrary to the command of god be no crime among they and they know nothing of the life to come or of eternal damnation but they believe in a future life in which they shall tend flock eat and drink and do those very thing which they do in this life at new moon or when the moon be full they begin any new enterprise they call the moon the great emperor and they worship that luminary on they knee all who dwell in they house must undergo purification by fire which be perform in this manner have kindle two fire at a convenient distance they fix two spear in the earth one near each fire stretch a cord between the top of these spear and about the cord they hang some rag of buckram under which cord and between which fire all the man and beast and house must pass and all the while a woman stand on each side sprinkling water on the passenger and recite certain verse if any one be kill by lightning all that dwell in the same house with the dead person must be thus purify otherwise the house bed cart felt garment and every thing else would be abandon as unclean when any messenger prince or other person arrive they and they gift must pass between two fire for purification lest they should bring witchcraft poison or any other mischief section viii _ of the beginning of they empire _ the land of mongolium be formerly divide among four different tribe or nation one of these be the yeka-mongal or the great mongol the second su-mongal or the water mongol who call themselves tartar from a river of that name in they territory the third be name merkat and the fourth metrit all these tribe resemble each other in form and complexion and speak the same language though they be divide into distinct province under separate prince in the land of the yeka-mongal live one name zingi a great hunter who use to rob and take much prey go into the neighbouring district where he seize all that come in he way and associate many under he command till at length the people of he nation attach themselves to he and follow he as they leader to do evil after some time zingi go to war with the su-mongal or tartars slew they duke and subjugate the nation and he successively reduce the merkat and metrite to he grow dominion the naymanus to whom all the surround tribe then pay tribute be much indignant at the elevation of zingi but they great emperor have lately die leave the authority divide among he son who be young and foolish and know not how to rule the people yet they invade the territory of the mongal slaying the inhabitant and carry off much prey on this zingi collect the whole strength of he subject and the naymani unite with the cara-cathayan gather a mighty army in a certain narrow valley to oppose he in which a great battle be fight and the mongal obtain the victory the confederate be mostly slay and those who escape be reduce to subjection zingi establish he son occoday ug daus or octai-khan in the land of the kara-kitayan where he build a town call omyl or chamyl -lrb- 1 -rrb- near which and to the south there be a vast desert in which there be say to be certain wild man who do not speak and have no joint in they leg yet have sufficient art to make feel of camel wool for garment to protect they from the weather -lrb- 1 -rrb- call chamil or hamus in the map in lat 43  n and long 92  e it stand in a province of the same name on the north side of the great desert of cobus and to the ne of the land of the kalmuk or little bucharium -- e section ix _ of the mutual victory of the mongal and cathayan _ after they return from conquer the naymanus and cara-cathayan the mongal prepare to go to war with the kythao or cathayan -lrb- 1 -rrb- but the mongal be defeat in a great battle and all they noble be slay except seven zingi and the rest who have escape from this defeat soon afterwards attack and conquer the people call huyrus -lrb- 2 -rrb- who be nestorian christian from whom they learn the art of write after this they conquer the land of sarugur and the country of the karanite and the land of hudirat and return into they own country take a short respite from war again assemble a great army they invade cathay and after a long struggle they conquer the greater part of that country and besiege the emperor in he greatest city the siege last so long that the army of the mongal come to be in want of provision and zingi be say to have command that every tenth man of he own army should be slay as food for the rest at length by great exertion the mongal dig a mine underneath the wall of the city through which a party enter and open the gate for the rest of the army so that the city be carry and the emperor and many of the citizen put to the sword have appoint deputy to rule over he conquest zingi return into mongalium with immense quantity of gold and silver and other precious spoil but the southern part of this empire as it lie within the sea have not be conquer by the mongal to this day -lrb- 3 -rrb- the people of cathay be pagan have a peculiar kind of writing of they own in which they be report to possess the scripture of the old and new testament they have also life of the father and house in which they pray at stated time build like church they be even say to have saint to worship one god to venerate the lord jesus christ and to believe eternal life but they be not baptise -lrb- 4 -rrb- they have no beard and they partly resemble the mongal in they feature they country be exceed fruitful in corn and abound in gold and silver wine and silk and all manner of rich commodity and the whole world have not more expert artificer in all kind of work and manufacture -lrb- 1 -rrb- the inhabitant of northern china then a separate kingdom from mangus or southern china -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- the huir or uigur -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- this probably allude to the difficulty experience by the mongal in force a passage across the great river hoang-ho and kian-ku -- e -lrb- 4 -rrb- these absurd notion must have be pick up by the credulous papal messenger from ignorant or design nestorian in mongolium -- e section x _ of the war of the mongal against the greater and lesser indium _ when zingi and he people have rest some time after they conquest of cathay he divide he army and send one of he son name thosut - khan -lrb- 1 -rrb- against the comaniam whom he vanquish in many battle and then return into he own country another of he son be send with a army against the indian who subdue the lesser indium these indian be the black saracen who be also name ethiopian from thence the mongal army march to fight against the christian dwelling in the greater indium and the king of that country know by the name of prester john come forth with he army against they this prince cause a number of hollow copper figure to be make resemble man which be stuff with combustible and set upon horse each have a man behind on the horse with a pair of bellows to stir up the fire when approach to give battle these mount image be first send forwards against the enemy and the man who ride behind set fire by some means to the combustible and blow strongly with they bellows and the mongal man and horse be burn with wildfire and the air be darken with smoke then the indian charge the mongal many of whom be wound and slay and they be expel from the country in great confusion and we have not hear that they ever venture to return -lrb- 2 -rrb- -lrb- 1 -rrb- probably tuschi-khan -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- it be needless to remark upon the confused and ignorant geography and the idle tale of a christian empire in indium in this section the strangely ill-told story of the copper image by which the mongal be scorch with wild-fire may refer to the actual employment either of cannon or rocket against the mongal in this invasion -- e section xi _ of monstrous man like dog and of the conquest of burithabeth _ in return through the desert we be tell by some russian priest at the emperor 's court that the mongal find certain woman who be ask where they man be say that all the woman of that country have human shape but that the male have the shape of great dog after some time they meet the dog on the other side of a river it be in winter the dog plunge into the water and then roll themselves in the dust on the land till the dust and water be freeze on they back and have do this repeatedly till the ice be thick and strong they attack the mongal with great fury but when the mongal throw they dart or shoot they arrow at they they rebound as if they have fall on stone neither could they weapon in any way hurt they but the dog kill some of the tartar and wound many with they tooth and finally drive they out of the country -lrb- 1 -rrb- on they return home the mongal come into the country of burithabeth of which the inhabitant be pagan and conquer the people in battle these people have a strange custom of eat they kindred when they die they have no beard for we see some of they go about with certain iron instrument in they hand with which they pluck out any hair they find on they face -lrb- 2 -rrb- -lrb- 1 -rrb- it be surely unnecessary to remark on this ridiculous story of the canine man which no commentary could reduce to sense -- e -lrb-
