e section xiv _ of the power of the emperor and of he duke _ the tartar emperor enjoy incontrollable power over all he subject insomuch that no man dare abide in any other place than he have assign and he even appoint the residence of all the duke the duke appoint the residence of the millenary or commander of a thousand man the millenary do the same with the centurion or captain of hundred and the centurion direct in what place the decurion or commander of ten be to dwell whatsoever order any of these officer receive from they immediate superior must be instantly and implicitly obey if the emperor demand the virgin daughter or sister of any one she be instantly deliver up nay he often collect the virgin from all the tartar dominion and retain such as he please for himself give away other among he follower all he messenger must be everywhere provide with horse and necessaries without delay : and all messenger come to he with tribute or otherwise must be provide on they way with horse carriage and all necessaries yet messenger from strange country suffer great distress and much want of provision and clothing especially when send to any of the prince and when they have to make any stay as they often allot for ten man what would hardly suffice for two and if they suffer any injury it be even dangerous to complain many gift be demand of they both by the prince and other and if these be refuse they be contemn owe to this we be constrain to expend in present a large portion of what have be bestow upon we by well disposed person to defray we expence in fine every thing whatever belong to the emperor so that no one dare to say that any thing be he own and the duke and prince exercise a equally incontrollable dominion upon all below they section xv _ of the election of the emperor occoday and of the expedition of duke bathy _ on the death of zingis-chan the duke assemble and elect he son occoday ugadaus or oktai-khan emperor in he place who immediately in a council of the noble divide the army and send bathy or baatu-khan who be next in authority against the land of altissodan and the country of the bisserminus -lrb- 1 -rrb- who be saracen though they speak the language of the comanian bathy defeat these people in battle but the city of barchin which be surround with strong wall resist for a long while until the tartar fill up the ditch and win the place which they destroy sargat surrender without resistance for which the city be not destroy but many of the citizen be slay and make captive and much spoil be take and the city be fill with new inhabitant the tartar march next against the rich and populous city of orna in which be many christian gassarian russian and alanian and many saracen the lord of the city being of that nation this town stand on a large river and be a kind of port exercise great trade be unable to reduce this place by force the tartar dam up the river and drown the whole city with the inhabitant and they goods hence they invade russium and besiege kiow a long while which they at length take and massacre the inhabitant this be a large and populous city but be now reduce to nothing and scarcely have two hundred house : and when we pass through russium we find immense number of human skull and bone scatter about from russium and comanium they proceed against the hungarian and polonian where many of they be slay : and have the hungarian withstand they manfully the tartar have be utterly defeat in they return from thence they invade and defeat the pagan morduan : whence they march against the bylerus of greater bulgarium which they almost entirely destroy thence they proceed to the north against the bastarcus of greater hungary whom they conquer and go farther north they come to the parossita and thence to the samogetae reach even to the ocean and from thence return into comanium -lrb- 1 -rrb- the busurman musurman or mahometan inhabitant of turkestan -- e section xvi _ of the expedition of duke cyrpodan _ at the same time occoday-khan send duke cyrpodan with a army to the south against the pagan kergi who have no beard whom he subdue after which he march against the armenian whom he conquer and likewise subdue a part of georgium the other part of that country be likewise under subjection and pay a yearly tribute of 20000 yperpera he thence march into the dominion of the great and powerful soldan of the deurus whom he defeat and proceed to the country of the soldan of aleppo which he subdue and afterwards reduce the caliph of baldach or bagdat to subjection who be force to pay a daily tribute of 400 byzant besides baldekin -lrb- 1 -rrb- and other gift every year the tartar emperor send messenger to require the presence of the caliph who send back great gift besides the regular tribute to prevail on the emperor to excuse he absence duke cyrpodan and he army still propose to invade more distant country and have not yet return into tartary -lrb- 1 -rrb- this be probably a manufacture of bagdat or baldach from whence its name and may have be flower silk or cloth of gold -- e section xvii _ of the military conduct of the tartar _ zingis-khan divide the tartar into company or division of ten of a hundred and of a thousand each every one of which have its appropriate officer over every ten millenary he place one general and over a army of several body of ten thousand man two or three duke one of whom have the superior command when they join battle against they enemy unless the whole army retreat by common consent all who fly be put to death if one two or more of a decury proceed bravely to battle and the rest do not follow the coward be slay if one two or more of the decury be make prisoner and the rest do not rescue they they be put to death every man must have two bow or at least one good bow three quiver full of arrow a axe and certain rope to draw the military machine the rich or officer have sharp-pointed sword somewhat curved and sharp on one edge they wear helmet coat of mail and cuiss and they horse even be arm some have they own armor and that of they horse make of leather ingeniously double and even triple the upper part of they helmet be of iron or steel but the hood which protect they neck and throat be of leather some have all they defensive armor compose of many small plate of iron a hand-breadth long and a inch broad perforated with eight small hole by which they be tie with small leather thong to strong thong of leather underneath so that the plate overlap each other in regular series and be firmly knit together the armor both of man and horse be often make in this fashion and be keep finely burnish some carry lance have hook to pull they enemy from horseback they arrow-head be exceedingly sharp on both edge and every man carry a file to sharpen they they target be make of wicker but they be hardly ever carry except by the night guard especially those in attendance upon the emperor and the prince the tartar be exceedingly crafty in war in which they have be continually engage for the last forty-two year against all the surround nation when they have to pass river the principal people secure they garment in bag of thin leather draw together like purse and closely tie they fix these to they saddle along with they other baggage and tie the whole to they horse 's tail sit upon the whole bundle as a kind of boat or float and the man who guide the horse be make to swim in a similar manner sometimes have two oar to assist in rowing as it be across the river the horse be then force into the river and all the other horse follow and in this manner they pass across deep and rapid river -lrb- 1 -rrb- the poorer people have each a purse or bag of leather well sew into which they pack up all they thing well tie up at the mouth which they hang to the tail of they horse and thus swim across -lrb- 1 -rrb- this mode of pass over river though carefully translate be by no means obviously describe i be apt to suppose that the leathern bag besides hold the apparel and other valuable be large enough to be blow up with air so as to serve as float like those use by the ancient macedonian a practice which they may have learn from the scythian the latin of vincentius beluacensis appear to have be translate from the french original of carpinus from the follow circumstance : what be here translate they _ other baggage _ be in the latin _ alias re duriore _ almost with certainty mistakenly render from the french _ leur autre harde _ -- e section xviii _ how the tartar ought to be resist _ no single kingdom or province can resist the tartar as they gather man for war from every land that be subject to they dominion and if any neighbouring province refuse to join they they invade and lay it waste slaughter the inhabitant or carry they into captivity and then proceed against another nation they place they captive in the front of battle and if they do not fight courageously they be put to the sword wherefore if the prince and ruler of christendom mean to resist they progress it be requisite that they should make common cause and oppose they with unite council they ought likewise to have many soldier arm with strong bow and plenty of cross-bow -lrb- 1 -rrb- of which the tartar be much afraid besides these there ought to be man arm with good iron mace or with axis have long handle the steel arrow-head should be temper in the tartar manner by be plunge while hot into water mixed with salt that they may the better be able to penetrate the armor of the tartar we man ought likewise to have good sword and lance with hook to drag they from they saddle which be a easy matter and ought to have good helmet and armor of proof for themselves and horse : and those who be not so armed ought to keep in the rear of those who be to discharge they arrow and quarrel over the head of they companion we army ought to be marshal after the order of the tartar already describe and under the same rigorous law of war whoever betake himself to plunder before victory be perfectly ascertain should suffer death the field of battle ought to be choose if possible in a plain where every thing may be see around the army should by no means be draw up in one body but in many division not too distant one band ought to be dispatch against those who first advance while another remain prepared to assist in time of need scout ought to be send out on every side to give notice of the approach of the enemy that band may always be send to meet band as they come on as the tartar be always anxious to surround they enemy each band ought however to be cautious not to pursue too far when they enemy fly lest they fall into a snare or ambush as the tartar fight more by stratagem than by main force and this the rather that we people may not fatigue they horse in which we do not abound while the tartar always have such number that they seldom remount one horse till after three or four day rest should even the tartar retire towards they own country we army ought by no means to retreat or separate as they often practice this stratagem to delude they enemy and induce they to divide and then return suddenly to destroy the country at they pleasure we general ought to keep they troops day and night on the alert and always armed ready for battle as the tartar be always vigilant like the devil and be ever devise how to commit mischief finally when a tartar fall from he horse in battle he ought immediately to be take or slay as when on foot even they be excellent archer and destructive to man and horse -lrb- 2 -rrb- -lrb- 1 -rrb- the word here use in the latin _ balistai _ be probably corrupt in transcription for _ balistarii _ and may either mean cross-bow-men or man for work balistae the ancient artillery if the expression be allowable arcubalistarius be the appropriate middle age latin for man arm with cross-bow -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- we good minorite seem in this chapter to have study the old proverb _ fa est ab hoste docerus _ but except in the lead political advice of the section he might have be better employ in follow the adage of _ ne sutor ultra crepidam _ -- e section xix _ of the journey of friar john de plano carpinus to the first guard of the tartar _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- set out by command from the apostolic see upon we journey to the tartar lest there might arise danger from they proximity to the church of god we come first to the king of bohemia with whom we be acquaint and who advise we to travel through poland and russium because he have kinsman in poland through whose assistance we might be enable to travel in russium and he supply we with recommendatory letter and passport give we free passage as he charge through he dominion whence we proceed to the court of boleslaus duke of silesium he nephew who be likewise know and friendly to we he treat we in the same hospitable manner and transmit we free of expense to conrad duke of lautiscium or masovium where by god 's grace wasilico -lrb- 2 -rrb- duke of russium then be from whom we fully learn the art of the tartar as he have send messenger to they who be already return learn that it be necessary for we to make present we cause some skin of beaver and other animal to be purchase with part of the money which have be give we in charity to defray we expence and we receive more of the same skin from duke conrad from grimislava duchess of cracow from the bishop and from certain noble of that place and at the request of the duke bishop and noble of cracow wasilico conduct we into he country and entertain we there for some day at he expense likewise he convene he bishop at we request to whom we read the pope 's letter admonish they to return into the unity of the church add we own exhortation to the same purpose but because duke daniel the brother of wasilico be absent at the court of baatu they could not then give a satisfactory answer after this wasilico send we forward to kiow the chief city of russium under the conduct of one of he servant in which journey we be in great danger of we life from the lithuanian who often invade the border of russium in the very place through which we have to pass but by means of this servant we be secure against any injury from the russian of whom indeed the greater part have be slay or carry into captivity by the tartar in this journey we have almost perish of cold at danilou -lrb- 3 -rrb- through the prodigious depth of the snow although we travel in a wagon on we arrival at kiow and consulting with the millenary -lrb- 4 -rrb- and other noble respect we farther journey we be advise not to carry the horse we then have into tartary as they would all certainly die by the way as they be not use to dig under the snow in search of grass like the tartar horse and no food could be procure for they as the tartar make no provision of hay or straw or any other provender against winter we determine therefore to leave they behind under the care of two servant till we return and by means of present we prevail on the millenary to allow we post-horse and a guide we begin we journey on the second day after the purification -lrb- 5 -rrb- and arrive at canow which be under the immediate dominion of the tartar the governor allow we horse and a guide to another town of which one michea a most malicious person be governor who gain by we present conduct we to the first station of the tartar -lrb- 1 -rrb- the journal of carpinus begin here that of asceline never appear -- e section xx _ of he first reception by the tartar _ on the first Saturday after ash-wednesday while we be take up we quarter for the night near sunset a number of armed tartar come suddenly upon we in a threatening manner demand who we be have tell they that we be messenger from the pope and give they some victuals they immediately go away when we proceed on we journey next morning the chief of this guard meet we and demand to know the purpose of we journey we answer that we be messenger from we lord the pope the father and lord of the christian go to they emperor and prince and the whole tartar nation to desire peace and friendship between the tartar and the christian : and as the pope wish the tartar to become great and to acquire the favor of god he admonish they by we and by he letter to embrace the faith of christ without which they could not be save : that the pope be astonish to hear of they monstrous slaughter of mankind more especially of the hungarian mountaineer and polander who be he subject and who have neither injure or attempt to injure the tartar and as god be sore offend by such proceedings the pope admonish they to refrain in future and to repent of what they have do and request a answer as to they future intention on which they promise we horse and a guide to corrensa but for which favor they demand present some of they ride swiftly on before to inform corrensa of we message and we follow this corrensa be general or duke of all the tartar who be place as a guard against the people of the west lest some enemy might suddenly invade they and be say to have 60000 man under he command section xxi _ he reception at the court of corrensa _ on we arrival at the residence of corrensa we tent be order to be pitch at a considerable distance and he agent come to demand what gift we would offer in pay we obeisance to he we answer that we lord the pope have send no gift as he be uncertain if we should ever arrive at they country consider the dangerous place we have to pass through but that we should honor he with part of those thing which have be give we to defray the charge of we journey have receive we gift we be conduct to the orda or tent of the duke corrensa and instruct to bow we left knee thrice before he door take great care not to set we foot on the threshold and when enter we be to repeat on we knee the word which we have say before this do we present the letter of the pope but the interpreter whom we have hire at kiow be not able to explain they sufficiently nor could any one be find equal to the task from this place post-horse be appoint to conduct we with all speed to duke baatu under the guidance of three tartar this baatu be the most powerful prince among they next to they emperor we begin we journey to he court on the first Tuesday in lend and ride as fast as we could trot though we change we horse twice or thrice every day and often travel in the night it be maunday Thursday before we accomplish we journey the whole of this journey be through the land of comanium which be all a uniform plain water by four large river the first of these be the dnieper or boristhene on the russian side of which the duke corrensa and montij march up and down the latter who march on the other side of the plain be the more powerful of the two -lrb- 1 -rrb- the second river be the don or tanai of the ancient on the bank of which a certain prince name tirbon sojourn who be marry to the daughter of baatu the third and largest be the volga or rha on which baatu reside the fourth be the jaik or rhymnus on each bank of which a millenary command all these descend southwards in winter to the sea and travel in summer up these river towards the northern mountain all these river especially the volga abound in fish and run into the great sea from which the arm of st george extend past constantinople -lrb- 2 -rrb- while on the dnieper we travel many day upon the ice and on the shore of the sea we find the ice three league broad before we arrival at the residence of baatu two of we tartar ride on before to give he a account of what we have say to corrensa -lrb- 1 -rrb- it be difficult to understand the ambiguity here use unless we suppose that the station of montij be on the right bank of the dnieper while certainly that of corrensa be on the left or north-east bank -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- the euxine and caspian be here confound as one sea it be scarcely necessary to observe that the dnieper and don run into the euxine while the volga and jaik or ural be discharge into the caspian -- e section xxii _ the reception of carpinus at the court of baatu _ when we arrive at the residence of baatu in the land of comanium we be order to pitch we tent a full league from he station and when we be to be introduce at he court we be inform that it be previously necessary for we to pass between two fire we refuse this at first but be tell there be no danger and that it be only precautionary in case we intend any mischief to they lord or should have bring poison along with we as the fire would remove all evil on which we comply that we might remove all suspicion of any such sinister intention after this when we come to the orda we be question by eldegay the agent of the prince respect the gift we mean to offer and make the same reply we have give at the court of corrensa we gift be offer and accept and have declare the object of we journey we be introduce into the presence make we obeisance and be admonish respect the threshold as formerly mention we then rehearse we former oration on we knee and produce we letter and request the aid of interpreter to translate they these be send we on good Friday and with they assistance we letter be carefully translate into the russian tartarian and saracen language and present to baatu who read they with attention we be then conduct back to we lodging but no food be give we except a little millet in a dish on the first evening of we arrival baatu carry himself with great magnificence have porter and all other officer after the manner of the emperor and sit in a elevated place like a throne along with one of he wife some of he brother and son and noble sit below he on bench and all other on the ground behind the rest the man be on he right and the woman on he left he use some beautiful and large linen tent which formerly belong to the king of hungary and no person however great presume to enter he tent without leave except he own family at this interview we be seat on he left hand but on we return from the emperor we be place on the right a table stand near the door of the tent or house on which there be abundance of drink in golden and silver vessel neither baatu nor any of the tartar prince drink in public without have singer and harper play before they when he ride there be a small tent canopy or umbrella carry over he head on the point of a spear and the same be do to all the tartar prince and they wife baatu be extremely courteous to he people yet be hold in great awe he be exceedingly sagacious crafty in war and inexorably cruel in battle and have be long experience in the conduct of warlike enterprise section xxiii _ the journey through the land of comanium and of the kangittae _ on easter eve we be again call to the court and eldegay whom we have mention before as the agent of baatu come out to we from the tent say that we must go forwards to the court of they emperor : but they detain a part of we company under pretence of send they back to the pope we accordingly give letter to these person recite all that have hitherto occur but they get no farther than the residence of duke montij where we join they on we return homewards next day be easter after prayer and a slight breakfast we depart from the court of baatu in much dejection of spirit accompany by two guide we be so feeble that we could hardly support the fatigue of ride we only food during lend have be millet boil with water and we only drink melt snow pass eastward through comanium we travel continually with great expedition change we horse five time a day and sometimes oftener except when we have to pass through desert on which occasion we have stronger horse allow that be able to undergo the whole labor in this manner we travel almost without cease from the beginning of lend until eight day after easter include we journey to the court of baatu on the north of comanium immediately beyond russium lie the people call morduyni-byleri -lrb- 1 -rrb- in great bulgarium and the bastarcus in great hungary beyond the bastarcus be the parosita and samogeta and beyond these on the desert shore of the ocean a people who be say to have dog face on the south comania have the alani circassian gazarian greece and constantinople the land of the iberian the catte the brutach who be say to be jew who shave the whole of they head and the land of the scythian georgian armenian and turk on the west be hungary and russium comanium be a country of great length and breadth the inhabitant of which be mostly extirpate by the tartar though many of they be reduce to bondage and some flee but the fugitive have in general return and now serve the tartar we next enter the land of the kangittae which have few inhabitant owe to a great scarcity of water from this circumstance several of the servant of jeroslaus duke of russium perish in the desert when travel to join he in the land of the tartar both here and in comanium we find many human bone and skull in large heap -lrb- 2 -rrb- the comanian and kangitta be pagan who dwell in tent and live entirely on the produce of they flock and herd without practise any tillage whatever on they conquest a great part of the kangittae be root out by the tartar and the remnant reduce to bondage -lrb- 1 -rrb- the morduynus mordua or merda be probably the same people with those now call tscheremiss who call themselves mari-murt or the people of marus -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- probably tartar trophy of victory even timor the great mongol conqueror after zingi so much vaunted by many writer for he virtue and humanity use to order the erection of immense pyramid of recent human head in memory of victory -- e section xxiv _ the arrival of carpinus at the first station of the new emperor _ from the land of the kangittae we enter the country of the biserminus who speak the comanian language and observe the law of mahomet in this country we see innumerable ruin city and castle and many town leave desolate the former sovereign of this country which be full of high mountain be call alti soldan who with all he lineage be destroy by the tartar on the south side lie jerusalem and baldach or bagdat and on its nearest border dwell two tartar duke burin and cadan son of thiaday the son of zingis-chan to the north be the land of the black kitayan and the ocean -lrb- 1 -rrb- syban the brother of baatu dwells in the land of the biserminus we travel in this country from ascension-day until eight day before the feast of st john the baptist 16th June when we enter the land of the black kitayan in which the emperor have build a house where we be invite to drink and the resident there for the emperor cause the principal people of the city and even he own two son to dance before we -lrb- 2 -rrb- go from thence we come to a certain sea have a small mountain on its bank in which there be say to be a hole whence such vehement tempest of wind issue in winter that traveller can hardly pass without imminent danger in summer the noise of the wind be hear proceed from this hole but it be then quite gentle we travel along the shore of this sea for several day leave it upon we left and though this sea be not of very large dimension it contain a considerable number of island -lrb- 3 -rrb- ordu whom we have already mention as the senior of all the tartar duke dwell in this country in the orda or court of he father where one of he wife bear rule for accord to the tartar custom the court of prince and noble be never dissolve at they death but be keep up under the government of one of he wife to whom the gift be continue which use to be give to they lord in this place therefore we arrive at the first court under the immediate jurisdiction of the emperor in which one of he wife dwell but as we have not yet be present to the emperor we be not invite or even permit to enter the station but be exceedingly well entertain in we tent after the tartar fashion and be allow to remain there one day for rest and refreshment -lrb- 1 -rrb- the confused geographical notice of this traveller be so uninstructive as not to merit any commentary a good account of the present state of these immense region will be find in pinkerton 's modern geography article independent tartary chinese tartary and asiatic russium the ancient and perpetually change distribution of nation in scythium or tartary in its most extended sense almost elude research and would require lengthen dissertation instead of illustrative note -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- from the subsequent travels of rubruqui it will appear that this ceremony be in honor of the tartar messenger go from baatu to the emperor not from respect to the papal envoy -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- this sea be obviously the lake balkash or palkati-nor at the south end of which we map represent a group of island -- e section xxv _ the arrival of carpinus at the court of the emperor elect _ leave this place on the eve of st peter and paul 28th June we enter the country of the pagan naymanus -lrb- 1 -rrb- and next day be excessively cold attend by a great fall of snow indeed this country be very mountainous and excessively cold and have very little plain ground wherefore these nation have no tillage but dwelt in tent which be destroy by the tartar we travel through this country for many day and at length enter the land of the mongal whom we call tartar through this latter country we continue we journey for about three week continually ride with great expedition and at length arrive at the residence of the emperor elect on the feast of mary magdalen 22d July in the whole of this journey we use extraordinary exertion as we tartar guide be order to bring we with all expedition to attend the solemn court which have be long appoint for the election of the emperor : on which account we always travel from early morning till night without stop to take food and we often come to we quarter so late as not to get any food that night but be force to eat in the morning what we ought to have have for supper we change horse frequently every day and travel constantly as hard as we horse could trot -lrb- 1 -rrb- the soongarium of modern geography -- e section xxvi _ of the reception of the papal nuncio at the court of kujak or cuyne-khan _ on we arrival at the court of cuyne he order we to be provide with a tent and all necessary expence after the tartar custom and he people treat we with more attention and respect than they shew to any other messenger we be not admit into he presence as he have not be formally elect and invest in the empire but the translation of the pope 's letter and of we speech have be transmit to he by baatu after remain in this place for five or six day we be send to he mother who keep a solemn court in this place we behold a immense tent so vast in we opinion that it could have contain two thousand man around which there be a enclosure of plank paint with various figure all the tartar duke be assemble in this neighborhood with they attendant and amuse themselves in ride about the hill and vally the first day these be all clothe in white robe the second day on which cuyne come to the great tent they be dress in scarlet the third day they be dress in blue and on the fourth in rich robe of baldakin -lrb- 1 -rrb- in the wall of board encircle the great tent there be two gate through one of which the emperor alone be allow to enter and though it stand continually open there be no guard as no one dare to enter or come out by that way all who be admit enter by the other gate at which there be guard arm with bow arrow and sword if any one presume to approach the tent beyond the assign limit he be severely beat if catch or if he attempt to run away he be shoot at with arrow many of the people whom we see here have upon they saddle bridle and other trappings of they horse to the value of twenty mark in pure gold accord to we estimation -lrb- 2 -rrb- the duke assemble in the great tent and consult together as we think about the election of the emperor the rest of the people be collect all round the wooden wall and at a considerable distance and in this manner they continue till almost noon then they begin to drink mare milk or cosmos and continue to drink amazing quantity till evening we be invite among they and they treat we with ale as we do not drink cosmos they intend this as a great honor but they make we drink so much in comparison with we ordinary diet as we be not able to endure but on make they understand that it be hurtful to we they desist from insist on we compliance on the outside of the door stand jeroslaus duke of susdal in russium a great many duke of the kithayan and solangus the two son of the king of georgium the envoy of the caliph of bagdat himself a sultan and more than ten other saracen sultan we be inform by the agent that there be above four thousand messenger present partly from those who pay tribute or send present and from other sultan and duke who come to make they submission or who have be send for and from the various governor of country and place under they authority all these be place on the outside of the wooden wall of the great tent and be supply with drink and they almost all give to we and the duke jeroslaus the place of honor when in they company -lrb- 1 -rrb- this term probably signify the manufacture of baldach or bagdat and may refer to silken stuff damasced or weave with gold flower -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- take the mark of gold at 84 oz and value the ounce at 4 # 17s 6d the sum of 20 mark amount to l 780 sterling -- e section xxvii _ of the exaltation of cuyne as emperor _ we remain in this place call syra orda about four week in we opinion the election be make here though it be not publish because always when cuyne come out of the tent he be greet with a noise of music and be salute with beautiful rod tipt with scarlet wool which be not do to any of the other duke leave this place we all ride three or four mile to a fine plain near a river among the mountain where we find another tent erect call the golden orda in which cuyne be to have be install in the imperial seat on the festival of the assumption 15th August but on account of a vast fall of hail formerly mention the ceremony be defer this tent be erect upon pillar cover over with plate of gold and other beam be fix to the pillar by gold nail the whole be superbly cover over with baldakin have other cloth on the outside we remain here till the feast of st bartholomew 24th August on which day a immense multitude convene stand with they face to the south certain person at about a stone 's throw distance from the rest be continually employ in make prayer and genuflexion always proceed slowly to the south we do not know whether they be make incantation or whether they bow they knee to god or otherwise and we therefore make no genuflexion when this ceremony have continue a long while the whole company return to the tent and cuyne be place upon the imperial throne on which all the duke kneel before he and the same be do by all the people except by we who be not he subject section xxviii _ of the age and demeanor of cuyne and of he seal _ when exalt to the imperial dignity cuyne seem to be about forty or forty-five year old he be of middle stature exceedingly prudent politic serious and grave in he demeanor and be hardly ever see to laugh or to behave lightly in any respect as be report to we by certain christian who be continually about he these christian of he family assure we likewise that he would certainly become a christian because he always keep some christian priest about he person and have at all time a chapel of christian establish near he great tent in which the clergy sing they devotions publickly and openly and strike the regular hour on bell accord to the custom of the greek church whatever number of tartar or other might be in the presence while no other of the tartar duke do any thing like this it be the custom of this emperor never to converse himself with any stranger however high he rank but always to hear as it be and to answer through a intermediate person : whoever propose any matter to he consideration or listen to he reply however great he quality must remain on he knee the whole time and no one must presume to speak on any subject after the determination of the emperor be express for the dispatch of affair both public and private he have agent secretary scribe and officer of all kind except pleader as every thing be conclude accord to he will and pleasure without strife or judicial noise : and the other prince of the tartar act exactly in the same manner while we remain at he court the emperor and all he prince erect a standard of defiance against the church of god the roman empire and all the christian kingdom and nation of the west unless they should become obedient to he command they avowed intention be to subdue the whole earth under they authority as they be command by zingis-khan and they have only abstain from this intention of late on account of the death of occaday-khan the emperor 's father who be poison of all the nation under heaven they be in some fear of the christian only and on this account they be now prepare to make war on we in all he letter they emperor style himself the power of god and the emperor of mankind and the seal of the present emperor be thus inscribe : god in heaven and cuyne-khan on earth the power of god : the seal of the emperor of all man section xxix _ of the admission of the papal and other envoy to the emperor _ we be call into the presence of the emperor in the same place where he have be inaugurate and chingay he chief secretary have write down we name and the name of those who send we and the name of the duke of solangus and other he read over all these name in a loud voice to the emperor and the assemble duke then everyone of we bow the knee four time before he and have warn we to beware of touch the threshold we be carefully search lest we might have any conceal weapon after which we enter within the precinct of the imperial tent at the east gate not even the tartar duke dare presume to enter at the west gate which be reserve for the emperor alone yet the lower people do not pay much regard to this ceremonious injunction at this time likewise all the other envoy now at the imperial residence be present but very few of they be admit within the tent on this occasion infinite quantity of rich gift of all kind be present to the emperor by the various envoy and messenger in samite purple robe baldakin silken girdle work with gold rich fur and other thing innumerable among these there be a splendid umbrella or small canopy to be carry over the head of the emperor all cover over with gem the governor of one of the province bring a great number of camel have housing of baldakin and carry richly ornamented saddle on which be place certain machine within each of which a man might sit many horse and mule likewise be present to he richly caparison and arm some with leather and some with iron we be likewise question as to what gift we have to offer but we be unable to present any thing as almost we whole substance be already consume at a considerable distance from the court there stand in sight on a hill above five hundred cart all fill with gold and silver and silken garment all these thing be divide between the emperor and he duke and the duke divide they portion among they follower each accord to he pleasure section xxx _ of the separation between the emperor and he mother and of the death of jeroslaus duke of russium _ leave this place we come to another where a wonderfully grand tent all of red cloth be pitch the gift of the cathayan at this place likewise we be introduce into the presence and always on these occasion we be offer beer and wine to drink and boil flesh to eat when we be incline in this tent there be a lofty gallery make of board on which the imperial throne be place most exquisitely carve in ivory and richly decorate with gold and precious stone and if we rightly remember there be several step by which to ascend the throne this throne be round above there be bench all around where the lady sit on the left hand upon stool and no one sit aloft on the right hand but the duke sit below on bench in the middle of the tent other sit behind they and every day there come great number of lady to the court these three tent which we have mention be of wonderful magnitude and the wife of the emperor have other tent sufficiently large and beautiful make of white feel at this place the emperor take leave of he mother who go to one part of the land and he to another to distribute justice about this time a concubine belong to the emperor be detect who have poison he father at the time when the tartar army be in hungary and owe to which incident they have be order to return she and a considerable number of she accomplice be try and put to death soon afterwards jeroslaus the great duke of soldal -lrb- 1 -rrb- in russium be invite as if to do he honor by the emperor 's mother to receive meat and drink from she hand grow sick immediately after return to he lodging and die in seven day illness he whole body become strangely of a blue color and it be currently report that he have be poison that the tartar might freely and totally possess he land -lrb- 1 -rrb- call susdal in a former passage -- e section xxxi _ how the friar in the presence of the emperor interchange letter _ soon afterwards the emperor send we to he mother as he intend to set up a flag of defiance against all the nation of the west as have be mention before and he be desirous to keep this circumstance from we knowledge have remain some day with he mother we return to he court where we continue a whole month in such extreme distress for victuals and drink that we could hardly keep ourselves alive for the provision allow we for four day be scarcely sufficient to serve we for one day neither could we go to purchase at the public market as it be too far from we but god send to we aid a russian goldsmith name cosma who be considerably favor by the emperor and who procure we some food this man shew we the imperial throne and seal both of which he have be employ to make after some time the emperor send for we and intimate by chingay he secretary that we should write down we message and affair and deliver they to he which we do accordingly many day afterwards we be again call to the presence and be ask if there be any person about the pope who understand the russian arabic or tartarian language to this we answer that we be ignorant of these language and though there be saracen in we land they inhabit at a great distance from we lord the pope and we propose that when they have write in the tartar language they might explain the meaning to we which we would carefully write down in we language and would then deliver both the original and the translation to he holiness on this they go from we to the emperor we be again call upon at martinma when kadac the chief minister of the empire with chingay and balum and several scribe come to we and explain the emperor 's letter word for word and when we have write it in latin they make we interpret every sentence to they to see if we have any way err and when both letter be write they make we read they over twice more lest any thing be mistake : say take heed that every thing be well understand as great inconvenience might arise from wrong conception they give we likewise a copy of the emperor 's letter in arabic in case any one might be find who could explain they in we country section xxxii _ the papal envoy receive a licence to depart _ these tartar minister inform we that the emperor propose to send envoy along with we and it seem to we that they wish we should ask this from the emperor and one of the principal among they advise we to make that request but this do not appear at all convenient and we answer that it do not become we to make any such petition but if it be the pleasure of the emperor to send envoy we should use we utmost endeavor with god 's assistance to conduct they in safety we be averse from this measure for the follow reason : lest see the war and dissension which subsist among the christian they should be the more encouraged to make war upon we : we be afraid that the messenger be mean to act as spy to examine the approach to we land : we dread that they might be slay by the way : for when the servant which attend we by desire of the cardinal legate of germany be on they return to he they be well nigh stone to death by the german and force to put off that hateful dress : and it be the custom of the tartar never to make peace with those who have slay they messenger till they have take a severe revenge fourthly we fear they messenger might be take from we by main force and lastly because no good could arise from they as they be to have no other commission or authority except merely to deliver the letter of the emperor to the pope and prince of christendom which letter we already have the third day after this be the feast of st brice 13th November we receive we passport and a letter seal with the emperor 's own seal and go to the emperor 's mother she give each of we a gown make of fox-skin have the hair outwards and a linen robe from every one of which we tartar attendant steal a yard and from those that be give to we servant they steal a full half we be perfectly aware of this knavery but do not think it convenient to take any notice section xxxiii _ the return of the papal envoy to europe _ at length we take we departure and travel the whole winter through the desert often sleep all night on the snow unless when we clear a piece of ground with we foot and frequently in the morning we find ourselves entirely cover by the snow which have drift over we during the night on ascension day we arrive at the court of baatu of whom we inquire what message we should deliver in he name to the pope to this he answer that he have no message to give we in charge but only that we should carefully deliver what we have receive from the emperor have receive additional passport from he we continue we journey and arrive at the station of montij on the sabbath after the whitson week where we companion and servant who have be keep so long from we be return at we desire from thence we travel to the station of corrensa who again require present from we but we now have none to give he however appoint two comanian of the lowest order of the tartar subject to accompany we to kiow in russium but we tartar guide do not quit we till we be beyond the tartar bound after which the comanian who have be order by corrensa to attend we bring we in six day from the last guard of the tartar to the city of kiow where we arrive fifteen day before the festival of john the baptist 9th June 1248 on receive notice of we approach the whole inhabitant of kiow come out joyfully to receive we congratulating we as man return from death to life and we be receive in a similar manner in we whole progress through russium poland and bohemia daniel and he brother wasilico feast we splendidly and detain we contrary to we desire for eight day in the meantime they and they bishop and noble have consult on those matter which we have propound to they when on we journey towards the tartar make a unanimous declaration that they would henceforward hold the pope as they special lord and holy father and would adhere to the roman church as they lady and mistress confirm all thing which they have previously send on this subject by they own abbot to the pope before we return and in ratification of all this they send envoy and letter along with we to the pope -lrb- 1 -rrb- -lrb- 1 -rrb- in section xix of this journey wasilico or wasiley be mention as duke of russium but who must only have be duke of some of william de rubruquis into tartary about the year _ 1253 _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- introduction these travels be undertake by order of loui ix of france usually call st loui in the original or at least in the print copy which have come down to we time rubruqui be say to have commence he journey in the year 1253 but this date be attend with some difficulty as we be certain that king loui be a prisoner from 1249 to 1254 it be possible indeed that he may have dispatch this mission while a prisoner yet it be more probable that the date may have be vitiate in transcription the real name of this early traveller who be a friar of the minorite order be say to have be van ruysbroek -lrb- 2 -rrb- from a village of that name near brussels latinized or frenchified rather into de rubruquis by hakluyt he harris i 556 -lrb- 2 -rrb- pinkerton mod geogr ii xvi _ dedication by the author _ to the most excellent and most christian lord loui by the grace of god the illustrious king of the french friar william de rubruqus the meanest of the minorite order wisheth health and continual triumph in christ jesus it be write in the book of ecclesiasticus that the truly wise man shall travel through strange country for he have try the good and evil among man all this sire i have perform and i wish i may have do so as a wise man and not as a fool for many do foolishly those thing which have be do by wise man and i fear i may be reckon among that number but as you be please to command I at my departure that i should write down every thing i saw among the tartar and should not fear to write long letter i now therefore obey you order yet with awe and reverence as want fit language in which to address so great a king section i _ commencement of the journey _ be it known therefore to you sacred majesty that in the year 1253 on the 7th of may we enter into the sea of pontus which the bulgarian call the great sea -lrb- 1 -rrb- which i be inform by certain merchant be 1008 mile in length and be in a manner divide about its middle into two part by means of two province which project into it one on the north and the other on the south that which be on the south be call synope and contain the castle and port of the sultan of the turk the northern province be call gasarium by the latin -lrb- 2 -rrb- and cassarium by the greek inhabitant of its coast which be the same with caesarium and from thence certain headland extend southwards into the sea towards synope from the nearest part of which they be 300 mile distant so that the distance from these point to constantinople be 700 mile in length and breadth and 700 mile to hiberia in the east which be a province of georgium we arrive in the province of gasarium or casarium which be of a triangular form have a city name kersova on its western extremity in which st clement suffer martyrdom while sail past that city we see a island contain a church which be say to have be build by the angel in the middle of this province and on a cape to the south stand the city of soldaium directly face synope and here all merchant land who come from turkey in they way to the north and embark here again on they return from russium and the north for turkey these latter bring ermine and martin and other valuable fur and the former carry cloth make of cotton or bombasin and silk web and aromatic spice on the east of this province be the city of matriga -lrb- 3 -rrb- where the tanai flow into the pontus by a mouth of twelve mile wide -lrb- 4 -rrb- before this river enter the euxine it form itself into a sea towards the north of seven hundred mile in length and breadth but in no place above six pace deep so that it be not navigable for large vessel : for which reason the merchant of constantinople when they arrive at the city of matriga send they bark to the tanai where they purchase dry fish sturgeon thosas barbel and many other sort of fish this province of casarium have the sea on three side on the west where stand kersova or the city of st clement on the south where be the city of soldaium at which we land and on the east where matriga be situate at the mouth of the tanai to the east of that mouth be the city of zikium and the country of the suevus and hiberus still further east all of which be not under the dominion of the tartar to the south be trebisond which have its own prince name guido who although of the imperial race of constantinople be under the tartar dominion and next to it be synope which belong to the sultan of the turk who be likewise subject to the tartar beyond this be the country of vastacius whose son be name astar after he maternal grandfather and this country be not under the dominion of the tartar from the mouth of the tanai to the danube and even beyond the danube towards constantinople include walachium which be the country of assanus and the lesser bulgarium as far as solonia pay tribute to the tartar who of late year have exact a axe from each family and all the corn which they find in heap in addition to the regular tribute we land at soldaium -lrb- 5 -rrb- on the 21st of may where certain merchant of constantinople have previously arrive who report that ambassador from the holy land be come thither on they way to sartach although i have publickly declare on palm Sunday in the church of st sophium that i be no ambassador from you or any one and only travel to these infidel in conformity with the rule of we order on we arrival these merchant advise I to be cautious of what i say for as they have already report that i be a ambassador if i should now say the contrary i should be refuse a free passage upon this i address myself to the lieutenant of the city because the captain have go with the tribute to baatu and be not yet return : say we have hear in the holy land that you lord sartach -lrb- 6 -rrb- have become a christian which have greatly rejoice all the christian and especially the most christian king of the french who be there in pilgrimage fighting against the saracen that he may redeem the holy land out of they hand : wherefore i desire to go to sartach that i may carry he letter from the king my master in which he give he intelligence of importance to all christendom they receive we graciously and entertain we hospitably in the cathedral church the bishop have be at the court of sartach and tell I many good thing concern he which i do not find afterwards to be true they then give we we choice either to have cart draw by ox for carry we baggage or sumpter horse and the constantinopolitan merchant advise I to purchase covered cart like those in which the russian carry they peltry in which i should put every thing which be want for daily use because if i be to take packhorse i should be constrain to pack and unpack at every baiting place and that besides i should ride more easily in the cart than on horseback by follow they evil advice i be two month in travel to sartach which i might have accomplish in one on horseback i have bring with I from constantinople fruit of various kind muscadel wine and delicate biscuit to present to the captain that i might obtain free passage have be advise by the merchant that these person give a very cold reception to such as apply to they empty hand the governor or captain be absent i cause all these thing to be pack up in one of the cart be inform that they would be acceptable present to sartach we begin we journey about the beginning of June have four covered cart of we own and two other which they furnish to we in which we carry we bedding and we be allow five ride horse for ourselves we company consist of five person viz myself and my companion friar bartholomew of cremona goset the bearer of these letter the man of god turgeman -lrb- 7 -rrb- and a servant or slave name nichola whom i have purchase at constantinople out of the alms we have receive the people of soldaium likewise allow we two man to drive we cart and to take care of we horse and ox there be several lofty promontory on the shore of casarium between kersova -lrb- 8 -rrb- and the mouth of the tanai and there be forty castle between kersova and soldaium at almost each of which a distinct language be speak and among these be many goth who speak the teutonic language -lrb- 9 -rrb- beyond these mountain towards the north extend a most beautiful wood in a plain which be full of spring and rivulet and beyond this wood be a extensive plain continue for five day journey to the northern extremity of this province where it contract into a narrow space have the sea on the east and west and a great ditch be draw between these two sea in this plain the comani dwelt before the come of the tartar and compel the before-mentioned city and castle to pay tribute and upon the come of the tartar so vast a multitude of the comani take refuge in this province fly to the sea shore that the living be force to feed upon the die as i be assure by a merchant a eye-witness who declare that the survivor tear in piece with they tooth and devour the raw flesh of the dead as dog do carrion towards the extremity of this province there be many large lake have salt spring on they bank and when the water of these spring reach the lake it coagulate into hard salt like ice from these salt spring sartach and baatu draw large revenue as people come from all part of russium to procure salt and for each cart-load they pay two web of cotton cloth equal in value to half a yperpera many vessel come likewise by sea for salt all of which pay tribute in proportion to the quantity which they carry away on the third day after leave soldaium we fall in with the tartar on join whom i think myself enter into a new world wherefore i shall use my best endeavor to describe they manners and way of life -lrb- 1 -rrb- the euxine or black sea though not express in the text he probably take he departure from constantinople -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- by the latin be here obviously mean the jew -- forst section ii _ of the tartar and they house _ they have no permanent city and they be ignorant of the future they divide all scythium among they and each leader accord to the number of he follower know the boundary of he pasture and where he ought to feed he flock in winter and summer and in spring and autumn in winter they descend into the warmer region of the south and in summer they travel towards the colder country of the north such pasture as have no water be reserve for winter use when there be snow on the ground as the snow there serve instead of water the house in which they sleep be found on a round structure of wattled rod and the roof be form of wicker meet above in a small roundel from which arise a neck like a chimney all of which they cover with white feel and they often cover over the feel with lime or white earth and powdered bone to make it bright : sometimes they house be black and the feel about the neck of the dome be decorate with a variety of picture before the door likewise they hang a feel ornamented with painting and they employ much color feel paint with vine tree bird and beast for decorate they dwelling some of these house be so large as to measure thirty foot in breadth i once measure the distance between the wheel rut of one of they waggon to be twenty foot and when the house be upon the waggon it spread beyond the wheel at least five foot on each side i have count twenty-two bullock drag one waggon surmount by a house eleven in one row accord to the breadth or the waggon and other eleven before these the axle of this waggon be very large like the mast of a ship and one man stand in the door of the house upon the waggon urge on the ox they likewise make quadrangular structure of small split wicker like large chest and frame for they a arched lid or cover of similar twig have a small door at the front end and they cover this chest or small house with black feel smear over with suet or sheep ' milk -lrb- 1 -rrb- to prevent the rain from penetrate and these be likewise decorate with painting or feather in these they put all they household goods and treasure and they bind these upon higher cart draw by camel that they may be able to cross river without injure they contents these chest be never take down from the cart to which they belong when they dwelling-house be unloaded from the waggon they door be always turn to the south and the cart with the chest which belong to each house be draw up in two row one on each side of the dwelling at about the distance of a stone 's throw the married woman get most beautiful cart make for themselves which i be unable to describe without the aid of painting and which i would have draw for you majesty if i have possess sufficient talent one rich moal or tartar will have from a hundred to two hundred such cart with chest baatu have sixteen wife each of whom have one large house besides several small one serve as chamber for she female attendant and which be place behind the large house and to the large house of each wife there belong two hundred chest-cart when the camp be form the house of the first wife be place on the west and all the rest extend in one line eastward so that the last wife be on the east or left of all and between the station of each wife there be the distance of a stone 's throw so that the court of a rich moal appear like a large city but in which there be very few man one girl be able to lead twenty or thirty cart for the ground be quite plain they fasten the cart whether draw by camel or oxen behind each other and the girl sit on the front of the foremost cart of the string direct the cattle while all the rest follow with a equable motion if they come to any difficult passage the cart be untied from each other and conduct across singly and they travel at a very slow pace only so fast as a ox or a lamb can easily walk -lrb- 1 -rrb- the butter from ewe-milk be probably here mean -- e section iii _ of they bed and drinking-cup _ after have place the house on the ground with its door turn to the south the bed of the master be place to the north opposite the door the place of the woman be always on the east or on the master leave hand where he sit on he bed with he face to the south and the place of the man on he right hand to the west and when any man enter into the house they never hang up they quiver on the women side over the head of the lord there be place a image or puppet of feel which be call the master brother and a similar image over the head of the mistress which be call she brother and a little higher between these there be one very small and thin which be as it be the keeper of the house the mistress place at the foot of she bed on the right hand in a conspicuous place the skin of a kid stuff with wool or some such material and beside that a small puppet look towards the maiden and woman near the door on the women side of the house there be another image with a cow udder as the guardian of the woman who milk the kine on the master side of the door be another image have the udder of a mare be the tutelary deity of the man who milk the mare when they meet together for drink they in the first place sprinkle the master 's idol with some of the liquor and then all the rest in they order after which a servant go out of the house with a cup of drink and sprinkle thrice towards the south make a genuflexion between each in honor of the fire then towards the east in honor of the air next towards the west in honor of the water and lastly towards the north for the dead when the lord take the cup in he hand to drink he first pour a part on the ground and if he be to drink on horseback he first spill a portion on the neck and mane of he horse after the servant have make he libation to the four quarter of the world he return into the house and two other servant be ready with two other cup and salver to carry drink to the lord and he wife who sit together on a bed when he have more than one wife she with whom he sleep the night before sit beside he that day and all the other wife must come to she house that day to drink and all the gift which the lord receive that day be deposit in she chest upon a bench there stand vessel of milk and other drink and drinking cup section iv _ of they kind of drink and fashion of drinking _ in winter they make excellent drink of rice millet and honey which be clear like wine and they have wine bring to they from distant country in summer they care not for any drink except cosmos which always stand within the door and beside it be a minstrel with he instrument of music i see no citern lute and viol such as ours but they have many other instrument which we have not when the lord begin to drink one of he servant exclaim aloud ha and the minstrel begin to play when they make a great feast all the guest clap they hand and dance to the music the man before the lord and the woman before the lady of the house when the lord have drink the servant call out as before and the minstrel cease then all drink round in they turn both man and woman and they sometimes carouse on hear the news of a victory to a shameful and beastly degree when they desire to provoke one to drink they seize he by the ear drag they strongly as if to widen he throat clap they hand and dancing before he when they mean to do great honor to any person one take a full cup have one on he right hand and another on he left and these three advance towards he who be to receive the cup singing and dancing before he but when he reach out he hand to receive the cup they suddenly draw back and come forwards again in the same manner and they thus delude he three or four time till he seem very eager when they give he the cup and keep dancing singing and stamp with they foot till he have finish he draught section v _ of they food _ they eat indifferently of all dead animal even such as have die of disease and among such number of cattle and flock many animal must die almost continually bat in summer when they have plenty of cosmos or mare milk they care little for any other food when a ox or horse happen to die they cut its flesh into thin slice which they dry in the sun and air which preserve it from corruption and free from all bad smell from the intestine of they horse they make sausage better than those which be make of pork and which they eat when newly make but the rest of the flesh be reserve for winter use of the hide of ox they form large bag which they dry in a wonderful manner in the smoke of the hinder part of they horse skin they fabricate excellent sandal they will make a meal for fifty or even a hundred man of the carcase of one ram this they mince in a bowl mix with salt and water which be they only seasoning and then with the point of a knife or a little fork make on purpose like those with which we eat pear and apple stew in wine they reach to every one of the company a morsel or two accord to the number the master of the house have first serve himself to he mind before any of the rest and if he give a particular portion to any one that person must eat it up without give any of it to another or if he be unable to eat the whole he take it home with he or give it to he servant to take care of if he have one otherwise he put it into he own _ saptargat _ or square leather bag which they carry always with they for such purpose or for preserve any bone which they have not time to pick thoroughly that they may clean they well afterwards and that nothing may be lose section vi _ how they make the drink call cosmos _ cosmos be make from mare milk in the follow manner : they fasten a long line between two post fix in the ground and to it they tie the young foal of the mare which be to be milk by which mean the mare be induce to stand quietly beside they foal and allow themselves to be milk if any mare happen to be unruly she foal be bring and allow to suck a little after which the milker again succeed have thus procure a quantity of new draw milk it be pour into a large skin bag which be immediately agitate by blow with a wooden club have its lower end hollow and as large as a man 's head after some time the milk begin to ferment like new wine and to acquire a degree of sourness the agitation be continue in the same manner until the butter come after which it be fit for drinking and have a pungent yet pleasant taste like raspberry wine leave a flavor on the palate like almond milk this liquor be exceedingly pleasant and of a diuretic quality be exhilarating to the spirit and even intoxicate to weak head cara-cosmos which mean black cosmos be make for the great lord in the follow manner : the agitation as before describe be continue until all the lees or coagulated portion of the milk subside to the bottom like the lees of wine and the thin part remain above like whey or clear must of wine the white lees be give to the servant and have a strong soporific quality the clear supernatent liquor be call cara-cosmos and be a exceedingly pleasant and wholesome beverage -lrb- 1 -rrb- baatu have thirty farm around he dwelling-place at about a day 's journey distant each of which supply he daily with the caracosmo from the milk of a hundred mare so that he receive the daily produce of three thousand mare besides white cosmos which the rest of he subject contribute : for as the inhabitant of syrium pay the third part of they production to they lord so the tartar pay they mare milk every third day from the milk of they cow they make butter which they do not salt for preservation but boil and clarify it after which it be pour into bag make of sheep-skin and preserve for winter use the residue of the milk be keep till it become quite sour after which it be boil and the coagulum or curd which form be dry in the sun till quite hard and be preserve in bag for winter provision this sour curd which they call _ gryut _ when want for use in winter when they have no milk be put into a bag with hot water and by dilligent beating and agitation be dissolve into a sour white liquor which they drink instead of milk for they have a great aversion to drink water by itself section vii _ of the beast they eat of they garment and of they hunting party _ the great lord have farm in the southern part of they dominion from whence millet and flour be bring they for winter provision and the meaner people procure these in exchange for sheep and skin the slave content themselves with thick water -lrb- 2 -rrb- they do not eat either long tail or short tail mouse there be many marmot in they country which they call sogur which gather during winter in company of twenty or thirty together in burrow where they sleep for six month these they catch in great number and use as food there be likewise a kind of rabbit with long tail like cat have black and white hair at the extremity of they tail they have many other small animal fit for eat with which they be well acquaint i have see no deer and very few hare but many antelope i see vast number of wild ass which resemble mule likewise a animal resemble a ram call _ artak _ with crooked horn of such amazing size that i be hardly able to lift a pair of they with one hand of these horn they make large drinking-cup they have falcon gyrfalcon and other hawk in great abundance all of which they carry on they right hand every hawk have a small thong of leather fasten round he neck the end of which hang down to the middle of he breast and before cast off after game they bow down the hawk 's head towards he breast by means of this thong with they left hand lest he be toss by the wind or should soar too high -lrb- 3 -rrb- the tartar be most expert hunter and procure a great part of they sustenance by the chase when the tartar intend to hunt wild beast a vast multitude of people be collect together by whom the country be surround to a large extent in a great circle and by gradually contract this circle towards its center they at length collect all the include game into a small space into which the sportsman enter and dispatch the game with they arrow from cataya and other region of the east and from persium and other country of the south they procure silk stuff cloth of gold and cotton cloth of which they make they summer garment from russium moxel greater bulgarium pascatir which be the greater hungary and kersis all of which be northern country and full of wood and from other country towards the north which be subject to they authority they procure valuable fur of many kind which i have not see in we part with these they make they winter garment and they have always at least two fur gown one of which have the fur inwards and the other have the fur outwards to the wind and snow which outer garment be usually make of the skin of wolf fox or bear but while they sit within door they have gown of finer and more costly material the garment of the meaner sort be make of the skin of dog and goat they likewise have breeches make of skin the rich often line they garment with silk shag which be exceedingly soft light and warm the poor line theirs with cotton cloth wad with the finest wool which they can sort out from they fleece and of the coarser wool they make felt for cover they house and chest and for sleep upon they rope be likewise make of wool mix with a third part of horse hair of feel they also make cloth to lay under they saddle and cap to defend they head from rain in all these thing they use vast quantity of wool you majesty have see the habit of these people -lrb- 4 -rrb- -lrb- 1 -rrb- under the name of kumyss this liquor be much use by the russian gentry as a restorative for constitution weaken by disease or debauchery
