_ of the fashion of they hair and the ornament of they woman _ the man have a square tonsure on they crown from the two front corner of which they shave two seam down to they temple the temple also and hinder part of the head to the nape of the neck be shave and the forehead except one small lock which fall down to the eye on each angle of the hind head they leave a long lock of hair which they braid and knot together under each ear the dress of unmarried woman differ little from that of the man except in be somewhat longer but on the day after marriage the head be shave from the middle down to the forehead and the woman put on a wide gown like that of a monk but wider and longer this open before and be tie under the right side in this the tartar and turk differ as the turk tie they garment always on the left side they have a ornament for they head which they call botta which be make of the bark of a tree or any other very light substance make in a round form so thick as may be grasp with both hand become square at the upper extremity and in all about two foot long somewhat resemble the capital of a pillar this cap be hollow within and be cover over with rich silk on the top of this they erect a bunch of quill or slender rod about a cubit long or even more which they ornament with peacock feather on the top and all around with the feather of a wild drake and even with precious stone the rich lady wear this ornament on the top of they head bind it on strongly with a kind of hat or coif which have a hole in its crown adapt for this purpose and under this they collect they hair from the back of the head lap up in a kind of knot or bundle within the botta and the whole be fix on by means of a ligature under they throat hence when a number of these lady be see together on horseback they appear at a distance like soldier arm with helmet and lance the woman all sit astride on horseback like man bind they mantle round they waist with silken scarf of a sky-blue color and they bind another scarf round they breast they likewise have a white veil tie on just below they eye which reach down to they breast the woman be amazingly fat and the smaller they nose they be esteem the more beautiful they daub over they face most nastily with grease and they never keep they bed on account of child-bearing section ix _ of the duty and labor of the woman and of they nuptials _ the employment of the woman be to lead the waggon to load and unload the horse to milk the cow to make butter and gryut to dress skin and to sew they together which they generally do with sinew finely split and twist into long thread they likewise make sandal and sock and other garment and felt for cover they house they never wash they garment allege that it would offend god and that hang they up to dry would occasion thunder and they even beat any person who pretend to wash they garment and take they clothes from they they be astonishingly afraid of thunder during which they turn all stranger from they dwelling and wrap themselves in black feel remain cover up till it be over they never wash they bowl or dish or if they do wash the platter into which the boil meat be to be put they do it merely with the scalding broth which they throw back into the pot the man make bow and arrow saddle bridle and stirrup construct house and cart take care of the horse and milk the mare agitate the cosmos or mare milk make leather sack in which these be keep take care of and load the camel tend the cow sheep and goat and these be sometimes milk by the man sometimes by the woman they dress hide with sheep milk thicken and salt when they mean to wash they head and hand they fill they mouth with water which they squirt out gradually on they hand and moisten they hair or wash they head no man can have a wife unless by purchase so that many maid be rather old before marriage as they parent always keep they till they can get a good market they keep the first and second degree of consanguinity inviolate but pay no regard to affinity as one man may have either at once or successively two sister widow never marry as they belief be that all who have serve a man in this life shall do so in the next so that widow believe that they shall return after death to they husband hence arise a abominable custom among they that the son sometimes marry all he father 's wife except he own mother for the court or household of the father and mother always devolve to the younger son and he have to provide for all he father 's wife which fall to he share along with the inheritance and he consider that if he take he father 's wife it will be no injury or disgrace to he though they go to he father in the next world when any one have make a bargain with another for he daughter the father of the maid give a feast to the bridegroom and the bride run away and hide herself in the house of one of she relation then the father say to the bridegroom my daughter be now yours take she wherever you can find she on which he seek for she with the assistance of he friend till he discover she concealment and then lead she as if by violence to he house section x _ of they law and judgment and of they death and burial _ when two man fight no one must interfere to part they neither may a father presume to aid he own son but he who consider himself injure must appeal to the court of he lord and whoever shall offer he any violence after this appeal be put to death he who be appeal against must go without delay and the appellant lead he as a prisoner no one be punish capitally unless take in the act or unless he confess but when witness against by many he be severely tortured to extort confession homicide adultery and fornication be punish with death but a man may use he own slave as he please great theft be punish capitally but for small one as for steal a sheep when the party be not catch in the fact but otherwise detect the thief be cruelly beat and when a hundred stroke be to be give by order of the court a hundred separate rod be require one for each blow pretend messenger be punish with death as be likewise sacrilegious person whom they esteem witch of which more will be say hereafter when any one die he be mourn for with violent howling and the mourner be free from tribute during a whole year any one who happen to enter a house in which a grow up person lie dead must not enter the house of mangu-khan during a whole year if the dead person be a child he be only debar for one lunation one house be always leave near the grave of the deceased but the burial place of any of the prince of the race of jenghis-khan be always keep secret yet there be always a family leave in charge of the sepulchre of they noble though i do not find that they deposit any treasure in these tomb the comanian raise a large barrow or tomb over they dead and erect a statue of the person with he face turn towards the east hold a drinking cup in he hand they erect likewise over the tomb of the rich certain pyramid or sharp pinnacle in some place i observe large tower build of burnt brick and other of stone though no stone be to be find about the place i see the grave of a person newly bury in honor of whom there be hang up sixteen horse hide four of which towards each quarter of the world between high pole and beside the grave they have set cosmos that the deceased might drink and flesh for he to eat although the person be say to have be baptize farther east i see other kind of sepulchre consist of large area pave with stone some round and other square have four large stone place upright around the pavement and front the four cardinal point when any one lie sick in bed a mark be affix to the house that no one may enter as no one ever visit the sick except he own servant and when any one belong to the great court be sick watchman be place at a great distance all round that no one may enter the precinct as they dread lest evil spirit or bad wind might enter along with visitor they consider they soothsayer or people who practice divination as priest section xi _ of we first enter among the tartar and of they ingratitude _ when we first enter among these tartar after have make we wait for they a long time under the shade of certain black cart a considerable number of they on horseback surround we they first question be whether we have ever before be among they and be answer in the negative they begin impudently to beg some of we victuals and we give they some of the biscuit and wine which we have bring with we from constantinople have drink one flaggon of we wine they demand more say that a man do not enter a house with one foot only but we excuse ourselves as not be well provide they next inquire whence we come and whither we be go to this i answer that hearing sartach be become a christian we wish to go to he that we might present you majesty letter to he they then ask if we come of we own accord or be send upon this errand to this i say that no one have compel I and that i have come voluntarily and by the desire of my superior be cautious not to say that i be the ambassador from you majesty they then require to know if we cart contain gold and silver or precious vestment as present for sartach to which i answer that sartach should see what we carry when we come to he presence and that they have nothing to do with such question but ought to conduct I to they captain that he if he think proper might direct I to be carry to sartach otherwise i should return there then be in this province one scacataus or zagathaus related to baatu to whom the emperor of constantinople have write requisitorial letter that i might be permit to proceed on my journey on be inform of this they supply we with horse and ox and appoint two man to conduct we on we journey and those which we have bring with we from soldaium return yet they make we wait a long while continually beg we bread to give to they child and they admire and covet every thing they see about we servant as they knife glove purse and point but when we excuse ourselves from they importunity allege that we have a long journey before we and must not give away those thing which be necessary for ourselves they revile I as a niggard and though they take nothing by force they be exceedingly impudent and importunate in beg to have every thing they see if a man give they any thing it may be consider as throw away for they have no gratitude and as they look upon themselves as the lord of the world they think that nothing should be refuse to they by any one yet if one give they nothing and afterwards stand in need of they assistance they will not help he they give we some of they butter milk call _ apram _ which be extremely sour after this we leave they think that we have escape out of the hand of the demon and the next day we arrive at the quarter of they captain from the tune when we leave soldaium till we get to sartach which take we two month we never lay under a house or a tent but always in the open air or under we cart neither do we see any town or the vestige of any building where a village have be though we see vast number of the tomb of the comanian on the same evening we conductor give we some cosmos which be very pleasant to drink but not have be accustom to that liquor it occasion I to sweat most profusely section xii _ of the court of zagathaus and how the christian drink no cosmos _ next morning we meet the cart of zagathaus laden with house and i think that a great city be travel towards we i be astonish at the prodigious drove of ox and horse and the immense flock of sheep though i see very few man to guide they which make I inquire how many man he have under he command and i be tell he have not above 500 in all half of whom we have already pass at another station then the servant who conduct we inform I that it be requisite for we to make a present to zagathaus and desire we to stop while he go forwards to announce we arrival it be then past three o'clock and the tartar unlade they house near a certain water after this the interpreter of zagathaus come to we and learn that we have not be before among they he demand some of we victuals which we give he he also require to have some garment as a reward for he trouble in interpret for we to he master but we excuse ourselves on account of we poverty he then ask we what we intend to present to he lord when we shew he a flaggon of wine and fill a basket with biscuit and a platter with apple and other fruit but he be not satisfy as we have not buy he some rich stuff however we enter into the presence of zagathaus with fear and bashfulness he be sit on a bed have a small citern or lute in he hand and he wife sit beside he who i really believe have amputate she nose between the eye that it might be the flatter for she have no nose in that part of she face which be smear over with black ointment as be also she eyebrow which seem very filthy in we eye i then repeat to he the exact same word which i have use before respect the object of we journey as we have be admonish by some who have be among they formerly never to vary in we word i request that he would deign to accept we small gift for be monk it be contrary to the rule of we order to possess gold or silver or rich garment on which account we have no such thing to offer and hope he would accept some portion of we victuals as a blessing he receive those thing and immediately distribute they among he man who be meet in he house to drink i likewise present to he the letter from the emperor of constantinople he then send these to soldaium to be translate because be in greek there be no person about he who understand that language he ask if we would drink cosmos for the russian greek and alanian christian who happen to be among the tartar and conform strictly to they own law do not drink that liquor and even think they be not christian who do so and they priest after such conduct formally reconcile they again to the church as if they have thereby renounce the christian faith i answer that we have still a sufficiency of we own drink but when that be do we should be under the necessity of use what might be give we he next ask we what the letter contain which we carry to sartach i answer that these be seal and contain only the word of friendship and good will he ask what i mean to say to sartach to this i answer that i should speak to he the word of the christian faith he ask what these be as he would willingly hear they i then expound to he the apostle creed as well as i be able by means of we interpreter who be by no means clever or eloquent on hear this he shake he head but make no reply he then appoint oxen and horse for we use and two man to attend upon we but he desire we to abide with he until the messenger should return with the translation of the emperor letter from soldaium we arrive at the horde of zagathaus in the ascension week and we remain with he until the day after pentecost or whitsun Tuesday be ten day in all section xiii _ how some alanian visit they on the eve of pentecost _ on the eve of pentecost or whitsunday there come to we certain alanian call there acia or aka who be christian after the greek form use greek book and have grecian priest but they be not schismatic like the greek as they honor all christian without exception these man bring we some sodden flesh which they offer we to eat and request we to pray for one of they company who have die but i explain to they the solemnity of the festival and that we could eat no flesh at this time they be much pleased with we exposition as they be ignorant of every thing relative to the christian rite the name of christ alone except they and many other christian both russian and hungarian demand of we if they might be save have be constrain to drink cosmos and to eat the flesh of animal that have be slay by the saracen and other infidel which the greek and russian priest consider as thing strangle or offer to idol they be likewise ignorant of the time of fasting neither could they have observe these in this region even if they have know they time and season i then instruct they as well as i could and strengthen they in the faith we reserve the flesh which they have bring we until the feast day for there be nothing to be buy among the tartar for gold and silver but only for cloth and garment which we have not to dispose of when we servant offer any of the coin which they call yperpera -lrb- 1 -rrb- they rub it with they finger and smell it to see whether it be copper all the food they supply we with be sour and filthy cow milk and the water be so foul and muddy by reason of they numerous horse that we could not drink it if it have not be for the grace of god and the biscuit we bring with we we have surely perish -lrb- 1 -rrb- or hyperpyron a coin say to be of the value of two german dollar or six and eightpence sterling -- e section xiv _ of a saracen who desire to be baptize and of man who seem leper _ upon the day of pentecost a saracen come to visit we to whom we explain the article of the christian faith particularly the salvation of sinner through the incarnation of jesus the resurrection of the dead and judgment to come and how through baptism all sin be wash out he seem much affect with these doctrine and even express a desire to be baptize but when we be prepare for that ceremony he suddenly mount on horseback say that he must first consult he wife and he return next day decline to receive baptism because he would not then be allow to drink cosmos without which he could not live in that country from this opinion i could not move he by any argument so that these people be much estrange from become christian by the assertion of that opinion by the russian and other christian who come among they in great number on the same day which be the morrow of the feast of pentecost zagathaus give we one man to conduct we to sartach and two other to guide we to the next station which be at the distance of five day journey for we ox we be present also with a goat to serve we as food and a great many skin bag of cow milk but they give we very little cosmos as that liquor be in great estimation among themselves from the station of zagathaus we travel directly north and we attendant begin to pilfer largely from we because we take too little heed of we property but experience at length teach we wisdom at length we reach the bound of this province which be fortify by a deep ditch from sea to sea -lrb- 1 -rrb- immediately beyond this ditch we come to the station to which we conductor belong where all the inhabitant seem to be infect with leprosy and certain base people be place here to receive the tribute from all who come for salt from the salt pit formerly mention we be tell that we should have to travel fifteen day farther before meet with any other inhabitant with these people we drink cosmos and we present they in return with a basket of fruit and biscuit and they give we eight ox and a goat and a vast number of bladder full of milk to serve as provision during we long journey but by change we ox we be enable in ten day to attain the next station and through the whole way we only find water in some ditch dig on purpose in the vally and in two small river from leave the province of casarium we travel directly eastward have the sea of azoph on we right hand and a vast desert on the north which in some place be twenty day journey in breadth without mountain tree or even stone but it be all excellent pasture in this waste the comani call capchat -lrb- 2 -rrb- use to feed they cattle the german call these people valanus and the province valanium but isidore term the whole country from the tanai along the paulus maeoti alanium this great extent would require a journey of two month from one end to the other even if a man be to travel post as fast as the tartar usually ride and be entirely inhabit by the capchat comanian who likewise possess the country between the tanai which divide europe from asia and the river edil or volga which be a long ten day journey to the north of this province of comanium russium be situate which be all over full of wood and reach from the north of poland and hungary all the way to the tanai or don this country have be all waste by the tartar and be even yet often plunder by they the tartar prefer the saracen to the russian because the latter be christian : and when the russian be unable to satisfy they demand for gold and silver they drive they and they child in multitude into the desert where they constrain they to tend they flock and herd beyond russium be the country of prussium which the teutonic knight have lately subdue and they might easily win russium likewise if they so inclined for if the tartar be to learn that the sovereign pontiff have proclaim a crusade against they they would all flee into they solitude -lrb- 1 -rrb- from this circumstance it be obvious that the journey have be hitherto confine to casarium or the crimea and that he have now reach the line or isthmus of precop -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- in the english translation of hakluyt this word be change to capthak and in the collection of harri to capthai it be probably the kiptschak of the russian -- e section xv _ of we distress and of the comanian funeral _ in we journey eastward we see nothing but the earth and sky have sometimes the sea of tanai within sight on we right hand and sometimes we see the sepulchre in which the comanian use to bury they dead at the distance of a league or two from the line of we journey so long as we travel in the desert matter be tolerably well with we but i can not sufficiently express the irksome and tedious plague and trouble we have to encounter in the dwelling of the tartar for we guide insist upon we make present to every one of the tartar captain which we be utterly unable to afford and we be eight person in all continually use we provision as the three tartar who accompany we insist that we should feed they and the flesh which have be give we be by no means sufficient and we could not get any to buy while we sit under the shadow of we cart to shelter we from the extreme heat of the sun they would intrude into we company and even tread upon we that they might see what we have and when they have to ease nature would hardly withdraw a few yard distance shamelessly talk to we the whole lime what distressed I most of all be when i wish to address they upon religious subject my foolish interpreter use to say you shall not make I a preacher and i neither will nor can rehearse these word nay after i begin to acquire some little knowledge of they language i find when i speak one thing he would say quite differently whatever chance to come uppermost in he senseless mind thus see the danger i might incur in speaking by so faithless a interpreter i resolve rather to be silent we thus journey on from station to station till at length a few day before the festival of mary magdalen 22d July we arrive on the bank of the mighty river tanai or don which divide europe from asia at this place baatu and sartach have establish a station of russian on the eastern bank of the river on purpose to transport merchant and messenger across they ferry we over in the first place and then we cart and they boat be so small that they be oblige to use two boat tie together for one cart put a wheel into each in this place we guide act most foolishly for believe that the russian would provide we with horse and ox they send back those we have from the western side of the river to they master but when relay be demand from the russian they allege that they have a privilege from baatu exempt they from all service except those belong to the ferry and for which they be even accustom to receive considerable reward from such merchant as pass that way we be therefore constrain to remain three day in this place the first day they give we a large fresh fish -lrb- 1 -rrb- the second day the magistrate of the village gather from every house for we and present we with rye-bread and some flesh and the third day they give we dry fish of which they have great abundance the river tanai at this place be as broad as the seine at paris and before arrive on its bank we have pass many goodly water full of fish : but the rude tartar know not now to catch they neither do they hold fish in any estimation unless large enough to feed a company this river be the eastern limit of russium and arise from certain marsh which extend to the northern ocean and it discharge itself in the south into a large sea of 700 mile extent before fall into the euxine and all the river we have pass run with a full stream in the same direction beyond this place the tartar advance no farther to the north and they be now about the first of August begin to return into the south and they have another village somewhat lower down the river where passenger be ferry over in winter at this time the people be reap they rye wheat do not succeed in they soil but they have abundance of millet the russian woman attire they head like those in we country and they ornament they gown with fur of different kind from about the knee downward the man wear a dress like the german have high crown conical hat make of feel like sugar loave with sharp point at length after represent that we journey be intend for the common benefit of all christian they provide we with ox and man to proceed upon we journey but as we get no horse we be ourselves under the necessity of travel on foot in this manner we journy for three day without meet any people and when both we ox and ourselves be weary and faint with fatigue two horse come run towards we to we great joy : we guide and interpreter mount upon these and set out to see if they could fall in with any inhabitant at length on the fourth day have find some people we rejoice like seafaring man who have escape from a tempest into a safe harbor then get fresh horse and ox we pass on from station to the dominion and subject of sartach _ the region beyond the tanai be very beautiful especially towards the north where there be fine river and extensive forest in these dwell two different nation one of these name the moxel be ignorant pagan without any law who dwell in cottage among the wood and have no city they lord and the greater part of the nation be carry to the confines of germany by the tartar and be there slay by the german who be hold in great estimation by the nation who be subject to the tartar as they hope through they means to be free from the tartar yoke when a merchant come among these people the first person with whom he stop be oblige to provide he with all necessaries during he stay in the district and they be so little jealous of they wife that husband pay little regard to they infidelity unless directly under they eye these people have abundance of swine honey and wax precious fur and falcon beyond these dwell the merda -lrb- 1 -rrb- or merduus who be saracen or mahometan beyond they be the etilium or volga the largest river i ever behold which come out of the north from the country of the greater bulgarium and run southwards into a vast lake of four month journey in circuit of which i shall speak afterwards in the northern region by which we travel the tanai and volga be not above ten day journey asunder but towards the south they be at a much farther distance the tanai fall into the euxine and the volga into the before mention sea or lake which likewise receive many river from persium in the course of we journey we leave to the south certain great mountain on whose side towards the desert dwell the cergi and the alanus or aca who be christian and still carry on war with the tartar beyond these near the sea or lake of etilia or the caspian be certain mahometan name lesgi who be subject to the tartar beyond these again be the _ irongate _ which be construct by alexander to exclude the barbarian from persium of which i shall speak hereafter horda appear to we very large and magnificent as he have six wife and he eldest son three and each of these lady have a great house like those already describe besides that each have several smaller house and 200 of the chest-cart already mention we guide go immediately to a certain nestorian name coiat who have great influence at the court of sartach and this man carry we in the evening a considerable distance to a officer call in the tartar language the lord gate to whom belong the duty of receive messenger or ambassador we guide inquire what we have ready to present to this person and seem much offend when he find we have nothing to offer when we come into he presence he sit majestically have music and dancing perform before he i then speak to he the word formerly mention give a account of the cause of we mission and request that he would bring we and we letter into the presence of he lord i excused myself also that as i be a monk neither give receive or use any gold silver or other costly thing except we book and the vestment in which we serve god that i could bring no present to he or he lord and have abandon my own goods i could not transport such thing for other man he courteously answer that be a monk i act well in observe my vow : and that he stand in no need of any of we thing but on the contrary be ready to give we what we might need he then cause we to sit down and drink of he milk and afterwards desire that we should recite a benediction for he which we do he inquire who be the greatest sovereign among the franc to which i answer the emperor if he could enjoy he dominion in peace not so say he but the king of france for he have hear of you majesty from the lord baldwin of hainault i find also at this court one of the knight templar who have be at cyprus and have make a report of all that he have see there concern you majesty we then return to we lodgings whence we send a flaggon of we muscadel wine which have keep well during the journey and a box of we biscuit to this officer who receive the present very graciously and retain we servant all night in he dwelling in the morning he order we to come to court and to bring the king letter and we book and vestment along with we as he lord desire to see these thing this we do accordingly lade one cart with we book and vestment and another with wine biscuit and fruit then he cause all we book and vestment to be spread out and ask if we mean to bestow all these thing upon he lord a multitude of tartar christian and mahometan be around we on horseback at this time and i be sore grieve and afraid at this question but dissemble as well as i could i say that we humbly request he lord and master to accept we bread wine and fruit not as a present for it be too mean but as a benevolence lest we should appear to come empty handed that he lord would see the letter of the king my master which would explain the reason of we journey after which we and all we have would remain at he command : but that we vestment be holy and be unlawful to be touch or use by any except priest we be then command to array ourselves in we sacred vestment that we might appear in they before he lord then put on we most precious ornament i take a rich cushion in my arm together with the bible i have from you majesty and the beautiful psalter ornament with fine painting which the queen bestow upon I my companion carry the missal and a crucifix and the clerk clothe in he surplice carry a censer in he hand in this order we present ourselves and the feel hanging before the lord door be withdraw we appear in he presence then the clerk and interpreter be order to make three genuflexion from which humiliation we be exempt and they admonish we to be exceedingly careful in go in and out of the lord dwelling not to touch the threshold of he door and we be desire to sing a benediction or prayer for they lord and we accordingly enter in sing the salve regina immediately within the door there stand a bench plant with cosmos and drinking cup all sartach wife be assemble in the house and the moal or rich tartar press in along with we incommode we exceedingly then coiat carry the censer with incense to sartach who take it in he hand examine it narrowly he next carry he the psalter which he and the wife who sit next he minutely inspect after which the bible be carry to he on which he ask if it contain we gospel to which i answer that it contain that and all we other holy scripture i next deliver to he you majesty letter with its translation into the arabian and syriac language which i have procure to be do at acon -lrb- 1 -rrb- and there happen to be present certain armenian priest who be skilful in the turkish and arabian language and likewise the before mention templar have unwilling to be call christian which they consider as a national appellation and they look upon they own name of moal as worthy to be exalt above all other neither do they allow themselves to be call time when the franc take antioch from the saracen -lrb- 1 -rrb- a prince name con-can or khen-khan hold dominion over all the northern region of tartary con be a proper name and can or khan be a title of dignity signify a diviner or soothsayer and be apply to all prince in these country because the government of the people belong to they through divination to this prince the turk of antioch send for assistance against the franc as the whole nation of the turk come originally from the region of tartary con-khan be of the nation call kara-catay or the black catay which be use to distinguish they from the other nation of catayan who inhabit to the eastward upon the ocean of whom i shall speak afterwards these kara-catayan dwell upon certain high mountain through which i travel and in a certain plain country within these mountain there dwell a nestorian shepherd who be supreme governor over the people call yayman or nayman who be christian of the nestorian sect after the death of con-khan this nestorian prince exalt himself to the kingdom and be call king john or prester john of whom ten time more be report than be true accord to the usual custom of the nestorian for they be apt to raise great story on no foundation thus they give out that sartach be a christian and they propagate similar story of mangu-khan and even of con-khan merely because these prince shew great respect to the christian the story of king john have no better foundation for when i travel through he territory no one there know any thing at all about he except only a few nestorian in these region likewise dwell con-khan formerly mention at whose court friar andrew once be and i pass through that region in my return this john have a brother a powerful prince and a shepherd like himself who be name vut-khan or unc-khan who dwell beyond the mountain of kara-kitay at the distance of three week journey from the residence of john this vut-khan be lord of a small village name caracarum and he subject be call crit or merkit be christian of the nestorian sect but vut-khan abandon the christian worship and follow idolatry retain priest to he idol who be all sorcerer and worshipper of the devil ten or fifteen day journey beyond the territory of vut-khan lay the pasture of the moal a poor nation without law or government except that they be much give to sorcery and divination and near they be another poor nation call tartar on the death of john the khan of the cara - kitayan without male issue he brother vut succeed to all he great riches and get himself to be proclaimed khan the flock and herd of this vut-khan pastured to the border of the moal among whom be one zingi a blacksmith who use to steal as many cattle as he possibly could from the flock of vut-khan at length the herd complain to they lord of the reiterate robbery which be commit by zingi and vut-khan go with a army to seize he but zingi flee and hide himself among the tartar and the troops of vut-khan return to they own country after have make considerable spoil both from the moal and the tartar then zingi remonstrate with the moal and tartar upon they want of a supreme ruler to defend they from the oppression of they neighbor and they be induce by he suggestion to appoint he to be they khan or ruler immediately after he elevation zingi gather a army secretly together and make a sudden invasion of the territory belong to vut whom he defeat in battle and force to fly for refuge into katay during this invasion one of the daughter of vut be make prisoner whom zingi give in marriage to one of he son and to whom she bear mangu-khan the presently reign great khan of the moal and tartar in all he subsequent war zingi use continually to send the tartar before he in the van of he army : by which mean they name come to be spread abroad in the world as wherever they make they appearance the astonished people be in use to run away cry out the tartar the tartar in consequence of almost continual war this nation of the tartar be now almost utterly extirpate yet the name remain although the moal use every effort to abolish that name and to exalt they own the country where these tartar formerly inhabit and where the court of zingi still remain be now call mancherule and as this be the center of all they conquest they still esteem it as they royal residence and there the great khan be for the most part elect -lrb- 1 -rrb- about the year 1097 section xx _ of the russian hungarian alanian and of the caspian _ i know not whether sartach really believe in christ but be certain that he refuse pay they gift and tribute to baatu and who make present to berta in they way this person profess himself to be of the mahometan faith and will not permit swine flesh to be eat in he dominion but it the space of four day which we spend in the court of sartach we have no victuals allow we except once a little cosmos and during we journey to the residence of he father baatu we travel in great fear on account of certain russian hungarian and alanian servant of the tartar who often assemble secretly in the night in troops of twenty or thirty together and be arm with bow and arrow murder and rob whoever they meet with hide themselves during the day these man be always on horseback and when they horse tire they steal other from the ordinary pasture of the tartar and each man have generally one or two spare horse to serve as food in case of need we guide therefore be in great fear lest we might fall in with some of these straggler besides this danger we must have perish during this journey if we have not fortunately carry some of we biscuit along with we we at length reach the great river etilium or volga which be four time the size of the seine and of great depth this river rise in the north of greater bulgarium and discharge itself into the hircanian sea call the caspian by isidore have the caspian mountain and the land of persium on the south the mountain of musihet or of the assassin on the east which join the caspian mountain and on the north be the great desert now occupy by the tartar where formerly there dwell certain people call canglae or cangitae and on that side it receive the etilium or volga which overflow in summer like the nile in egypt on the west side of this sea be the mountain of the alanus and lesgi the iron-gate or derbent and the mountain of georgium this sea therefore be environ on three side by mountain but by plain ground on the north friar andrew in he journey travel along its south and east side and i pass its north side both in go and return between baatu and mangu-khan and along its western side in my way from baatu into syrium one may travel entirely round it in four month and it be by no means true as report by isidore that it be a bay of the ocean with which it nowhere join but be environ on all side by the land at the region from the west shore of the caspian where the iron-gate of alexander be situate now call derbent and from the mountain of the alanus and along the palus moeoti or sea of azoph into which the tanai fall to the northern ocean be anciently call albanium in which isidore say that there be dog of such strength and fierceness as to fight with bull and even to overcome lion which i have be assure by several person to be true and even that towards the northern ocean they have dog of such size and strength that the inhabitant make they draw cart like ox -lrb- 1 -rrb- -lrb- 1 -rrb- it be astonishing how easily a small exaggeration convert truth to fable here the ill-told story of the light sledge of the tshutkus draw by dog of a very ordinary size be innocently magnify into cart drag by gigantic mastiff -- e section xxi _ of the court of baatu and we entertainment there _ on that part he house while i sit look down upon the ground he desire I to look up either wish to observe I more distinctly or out of some superstitious fancy : for these people look upon it as a sign of that region and even beyond it be inhabit by the people name changle or kangittae who be descend from the roman upon the north side we have the country of the greater bulgarium and to the south the caspian sea -lrb- 1 -rrb- this however be only to be understand of what may be term the pretorian or royal horde in a time of profound peace travel in they usual and perpetual round in quest of forage the almost boundless space of the desert must have be intersperse with numerous subordinate horde and though the usual guard of baatu might not have exceed 500 head of family the military force of he dominion though subordinate to mangu-khan certainly exceed 200000 fight man -- e section xxiii _ of the river jaic or ural and of sundry region and nation _ at the end of twelve day journey from the etilium or volga we come to a great river name the jagag -lrb- jaic or ural -rrb- which issue from the land of pascatir -lrb- of zibier or of the baschir now siberia -rrb- fall into the caspian the language of the baschir and of the hungarian be the same and they be all shepherd have no city and they land be bound on the west by the greater bulgarium from which country eastward in these northern part there be no city whatsoever so that the greater bulgarium be the last country which possess town and city from this country of pascatir the hun go who be afterwards call hungarian isidore write that with swift horse they pass the wall of alexander and the rock of caucasus which oppose the barbarian and even exact tribute from egypt and lay waste the whole of europe as far as france be even more warlike in they day than the tartar be now with they the blacian or walachian the bulgarian and the vandal unite these bulgarian come from the greater bulgarium the people name ilac or vlac who inhabit beyond the danube from constantinople not far from pascatir be the same people be properly name blac or blacian but as the tartar can not pronounce the letter b they be call ilac vlac or wallachian from they likewise the inhabitant of the land of the assanus be descend both have the same name in the russian polish and bohemian language the sclavonian and the vandal speak the same language and all of these join themselves formerly with the hun as they now do with the tartar all this that i have write concern the land of pascatir i be inform by certain friar predicant who have travel there before the irruption of the tartar and as they have be subdue by they neighbor the bulgarian who be mahometan many of they adopt that faith other matter respect these people may be know from various chronicle but it be obvious that those province beyond constantinople which be now call bulgarium wallachium and sclavonium -lrb- 1 -rrb- formerly belong to the greek empire and hungary be formerly name pannonium we continue ride through the land of the changle or kangittae as before mention from holy cross-day till all-saint travel every day as well as i could guess about as far as from pari to orlean and sometimes farther -lrb- 2 -rrb- accord as we happen to be provide with relay for sometimes we would change horse two or three time a-day and then we travel quicker while sometimes we have to travel two or three day without find any inhabitant to supply we and then we be force to travel more deliberately out of thirty or forty horse we be always sure to have the worst be stranger as every one take they choice before it come to we turn they always however provide I with a strong horse because i be corpulent and heavy but whether he pace happen to be hard or gentle be all one to they and i dare not to make any complaint we horse often tire before we could fall in with any of the inhabitant and we be then oblige to beat and whip they up be oblige to lay we garment upon spare horse and sometimes two of we oblige to ride on one horse -lrb- 1 -rrb- probably intend for what be now call servium -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- this may be take at a medium of thirty mile a day which in forty-six day would amount to 1380 mile no doubt a very fatiguing journey for a corpulent heavy man as he describe himself -- e section xxiv _ of the hunger thirst and other misery we endure _ there be no end of hunger and thirst and cold and weariness in the morning they give we something to drink or some boil millet but afterwards we have nothing to eat until the evening when they bestow some flesh upon we be generally the shoulder and breast of a ram and every one be allow a proportion of the broth to drink and we consider ourselves fortunate when we have enough of broth as it be exceedingly refreshing pleasant and nutritive sometimes we be constrain to eat we meat half boil or even almost raw for want of fuel especially when we be benighted and oblige to pass the night in the field because we could not conveniently gather horse or cow-dung to make a fire and we seldom find any other fuel except a few thorn here and there and a few rare wood on the bank of some river every Saturday i remain fasting until night and be then constrain to my great grief to eat flesh as i could not procure any other food in the desert in the beginning of we journey we guide disdain we exceedingly and seem quite indignant at be oblige to take charge of such base fellow as he seem to esteem we but he afterwards behave better and often take we purposely to the court of rich moal who request we to pray for they and if i have be so fortunate as to have a good interpreter i might have be able to do some good among these ignorant people zingi the first great khan or emperor of the tartar leave four son from whom descend many grandson who be daily multiply and disperse over that immense waste desert which be boundless like the ocean these moal whom we visit and pray for be astonish when we refuse they proffer gift of gold and silver and fine garment they often enquire whether the great pope be actually 500 year old as they have hear from report they likewise enquire into the nature and production of we country especially whether we have abundance of cattle sheep and horse when we speak to they about the ocean they could form no adequate conception of its immense expanse without bank or limit on the feast of all-saint 1st November as the people have now descend very much to the southwards we now discontinue we eastern route and journy directly south for eight day along certain high mountain in the desert we see many wild ass resemble mule call colan or coulan by the tartar which we guide and he companion often chase with great eagerness but without success owe to the great swiftness of these animal upon the seventh day of we southern route we see directly before we some exceedingly high mountain and we enter upon a fine cultivate plain which be irrigate like a garden next day 7th November we arrive at a town belong to the mahometan name kenchat the governor of which come out to meet we guide with ale and other refreshment for it be the custom of all the subject city to welcome the messenger of baatu and mangu with meat and drink on they arrival at this season the ice be fully bear and we find frost in the desert before the feast of st michael 29th September i inquire the name of the province but be in a strange land they could not inform I and could only tell I the name of this city which be very small into this district a large river descend from the mountain which the inhabitant lead off to water or irrigate the whole region so that this river do not discharge itself into any sea but after form many pool or marsh be absorb into the earth in this region we see vine grow and drink twice of they wine section xxv _ of the execution of ban and concern the residence of certain german _ the next day we come to another village nearer to the mountain which i understand be call caucasus and that they reach from the eastern to the western sea even pass the caspian to the west i likewise inquire concern the town of tala in which accord to friar andrew -lrb- 1 -rrb- there be certain german in the service of one _ buri _ and i have formerly make inquiry concern they at the court of sartach and baatu -lrb- 2 -rrb- but i could only learn that they master _ ban _ have be put to death on the follow occasion this ban happen to have he appoint residence in inferior pasture and one day when drunk he say to he people that be of the race of zingi as well as baatu whose brother or nephew he be he think himself entitle to feed he flock on the fine plain of the volga as freely as baatu himself these speech be report to baatu who immediately write to the servant of ban to bring they lord bind before he then baatu demand whether he have speak the word which be report and ban acknowledge they but plead that he be drunk at the time and it be usual among the tartar to forgive the word and action of drunk man but baatu reproach he for daring to use he name in he cup and order he head to be immediately strike off on my arrival at the court of mangu-khan i learn that the before mention german have be remove from the jurisdiction of baatu to a place name bolac a month journey to the east of talus where they be employ to dig for gold and to fabricate arm in the before mention town we learn that tala be near the mountain behind we at the distance of six day journey from the before mention village near the mountain -lrb- 3 -rrb- we go directly eastward coast these mountain and from that time we travel among the immediate subject of mangu-khan who in all place sing and dance in honor of we guide because he be the messenger of baatu it be the custom for the subject of mangu-khan to receive the messenger of baatu in this manner and reciprocally the subject of baatu shew like honor to the messenger of mnngu yet the subject of baatu be more independently spirited and do not evince so much courtesy a few day afterwards we enter upon the mountain where the cara-catayan use to dwell where we find a large river which we have to pass in boat we afterwards come to a cultivate valley in which be the ruin of a castle which have be surround by wall of mud or earth after this we come to a large village call equius inhabit by mahometan who speak persian although so far remove from persium on the day follow have pass those alp which descend from the high mountain towards the south we enter a most beautiful plain have high mountain upon we right hand and a sea or lake on we left which be fifteen day journey in circumference -lrb- 4 -rrb- this plain be water or irrigate at will by means of stream descend from these mountain all of which fall into the before mention lake in the subsequent summer we return by the north side of this lake where likewise there be great mountain -lrb- 5 -rrb- in this plain there use to be many town but most of these have be destroy by the tartar that the excellent land around they might be convert into pasture for they cattle we still find one large town name cailac in which be a market frequent by many merchant and we remain fifteen day at this place wait for one of baatu 's scribe who be to assist we guide in the management of certain affair at the court of mangu this country use to be call organum -lrb- 6 -rrb- and the people organa as i be tell because the people be excellent performer on the organ -lrb- 7 -rrb- or lute and they have a distinct language and peculiar manner of write it be now entirely inhabit by the contomannus whose language and write be use by the nestorian of these part i here first see idolater of whom there be many sect in the east tribe originally inhabit the bank of the konta or khonda who have afterwards settle on the bank of the river ili and lake of balkash -- forst section xxvi _ how the nestorian and mahometan be mix with idolater _ in the first place arc the jugurs whose country border upon the land of organum among the mountain towards the east and in all they town nestorian and mahometan be mixed among the native and they be diffused likewise in all the town of the mahometan towards persium in the city of cailac or cealac there be three idol temple two of which i go into to observe they folly in one of these i find a person have a cross mark with ink upon he hand whence i suppose he a christian and to all my question he answer like a christian i ask he wherefore he have not the cross and image of christ and he answer that it be not they custom wherefore i conclude the people be actually christian but omit these thing for want of instruction behind a certain chest which serve for a altar and on which they place candle and oblation i see a image with wing like that of st michael and other image hold out they finger as if blessing the spectator that evening i could make no farther discovery for though the saracen invite one into they temple they will not speak of they religion -lrb- 1 -rrb- insomuch that when i inquire at they about they ceremony they be much offended next day be the kalends 1st December be the passover of the saracen and i change my lodging to the neighborhood of another temple of idol for the people of this place shew hospitality to all messenger every one accord to he ability in this other temple i find the priest of the idol who open and adorn the temple at the kalends and the people make offering of bread and fruit i shall first describe the general rite of idolatry and then those of the jugur who be a kind of sect different from the other they all worship towards the north with join hand prostrate themselves upon they knee to the earth and rest they forehead on they hand for which reason the nestorian never join they hand in prayer but spread they hand on they breast they temple be build from east to west have a chamber or vestry for the priest on the north or if the building be square they have a similar chamber on the middle of the north side in place of a choir and before it be place a long broad chest like a table behind which face the south stand the principal idol that which i see at caracarum be as large as the picture of st christopher a nestorian priest who come from catay tell I there be a idol in that country so large that it could be see at the distance of two day journey -lrb- 2 -rrb- other idol be place around the principal one and all be beautifully gilt all the gate of they temple open to the south contrary to the custom of the mahometan and they have large bell as be the case with we wherefore the oriental christian will not use they though they be customary among the russian and the greek in casarium -lrb- 1 -rrb- the saracen be here much abuse by the mistake of we traveller as however erroneous they religious opinion they worship the true god only and abhor even the least semblance of idolatry -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- the nestorian probably say a idol-house mean one of the high tower usually erect near chinese temple : and even this must have stand upon a very elevated situation in a extensive plain to be see from so great a distance perhaps of sixty mile -- e section xxvii _ of they temple and idol and the worship of they god _ all they priest shave they head and beard and be clothe in yellow and they live in company of one or two hundred together observe strict celibacy on holy day they sit in the temple on long bench place directly opposite each other hold book in they hand which they sometimes lay on the bench and all the time they remain in the temple they have they head bare and they read to themselves keep profound silence : insomuch that when i go into the temple and endeavor all i could to provoke they to speak i could not succeed wherever they go they carry a string with a hundred or two hundred nut-shell like we rosary and they be continually utter the word _ ou mam hactani _ which be explain to I as signify _ o god thou knowest _ and as often as they pronounce these word in remembrance of god they expect a proportional reward -lrb- 1 -rrb- round the temple there be always a handsome court environ by a high wall on the south side of which be a large portal in which they sit to confer together and over this portal they erect a long pole rise if possible above the whole city that every one may know where to find the temple these thing be common to all the idolater on go to visit this temple i find the priest sit under the outer portal and those whom i saw appear by they shaven beard like french friar they wear conical cap of paper on they head and all the priest of the jugur wear this cap continually and yellow strait tunic fasten down the middle like those in france besides which they wear a cloak on they left shoulder flow loosely before and behind but leave the right arm free somewhat like a deacon carry the pix in lend they mode of write be adopt by the tartar they begin to write at the top of the page and extend they line downward read and write from leave to right they make great use of write papers in they magical incantation and they temple be hung round with short written sentence the letter send by mangu-khan to you majesty be write in these character and in the language of the moal these people burn they dead in the manner of the ancient and deposit the ash on the top of certain pyramid after sit for some time beside these priest and have enter they temple to look at they many image some large and other small i ask what be they belief concern god to which they answer that they believe in one god only on ask they whether he be a spirit or of a corporeal nature they say he be a spirit be ask if god have ever assume the human mature they answer never since then say i you believe god to be a spirit wherefore do yow make so many image of he and as you believe that he never take upon he the human form wherefore do you represent he under the image of a man rather than of any other creature to this they answer we do not make image of god but when any of we rich man die or they wife or child or dear friend they cause image to be make of the deceased which be place in the temple which we venerate in respect to they memory then say i you do these thing in flattery of man : but they insist it be only in remembrance they then ask I as if in derision where be god to this i answer by another question where be you soul and they say in we body then say i be it not in every part of you body ruling over the whole yet can not be see even in the same manner god be everywhere rule all thing yet be invisible be intelligence and wisdom i would willingly have proceed in this conference but my interpreter become weary and unable to express my meaning so that i be oblige to desist the moal and tartar follow the same religion in so far that they believe in one only god but they make image in feel of they depart friend which they cover with fine costly garment these they carry about with they in one or two appropriate cart which no person must touch except they priest or soothsayer who have the care of they this be to be understand only of the great man who be of the race of zingi for the poor or meaner people have none such these soothsayer constantly attend upon the court of mangu and other great personage and when the court move these man precede the march like the pillar of cloud before the child of israel they determine on the site of the new encampment and unload they house first after which they be imitate by the whole court on day of festival such as the kalends or commencement of they month these image be place in order around they idol house and the moal enter in and bow themselves before these image to do they reverence stranger be never permit to enter so that once endeavor to go into one of these tabernacle i be sore chidden for my presumption -lrb- 1 -rrb- the follow more complete account of this superstition have be deem worthy of insertion these suppose nestorian christian be undoubtedly professor of the religion of the dalai-lama who have several usage and ceremony resemble corrupt christianity like the roman catholic they have rosary contain 108 bead and they prayer be _ hom-mani-pema - hum _ this do not signify as assert by rubruqui _ god thou knowest it _ nor as suppose by messerschmid _ god have mercy on we _ but its true import be that _ manus _ who hold the flower of the lotus _ and be the beginning and end of the higher magic _ may _ hear _ they prayer be _ propitious _ to they and render they _ happy _ they have roll or cylinder inscribe with they prayer which they twirl round on a axis continually pronounce these mystic word and they believe that all the prayer on these roll be virtually pronounced at each turn of the roll the religion of the dalai-lama be a branch of the shamanian and braminical superstition and have for its foundation the manichaean doctrine of the two principle which mane attempt to incorporate into the christian religion so that it be no wonder the practice of the follower of the dalai-lama should resemble those of the manichaean and nestorian christian -- forst voy and disc 105 section xxviii _ of sundry nation and of certain people who use to eat they parent _ i be convince that these jugur who be mix with christian and mahometan have arrive at the knowledge and belief of one god by frequent disputation with they this nation dwell in city which be bring under subjection to zingi who give he daughter in marriage to they king even caracarum be in a manner in they territory the whole country of prester john and of vut or unc he brother lay round the territory of the jugur only that the subject of the former inhabit the pasture land on the north while the jugurs dwelt among the mountain to the south as the moal have adopt the writing of the jugur these latter be the chief scribe among the tartar and almost all the nestorian be acquaint with they letter next to the jugur among the mountain to the east be the tangut a powerful people who once make zingi prisoner in battle but have conclude peace he be set at liberty and afterwards subdue they among the tangut there be ox of great strength have flow tail like horse and they back and belly cover with long hair these be shorter leg than other ox but much fiercer have long slender straight and very sharp pointed horn and they be much use for draw the great house of the moal but the cow will not allow themselves to be yoke unless they be sing to at the same time these animal be of the nature of the buffalo for when they see a person clothe in red they run furiously upon he to put he to death beyond these be the people of tebet who be wont to eat the dead body of they parent from a motive of piety consider that to be the most honorable sepulchre but they have discontinue this custom which be look upon as abominable by all other nation they still however continue to make handsome drinking cup of the skull of they parent that they may call they to remembrance even in they mirth i receive this information from a eye-witness in they country there be much gold so that any one who be in want dig till he find enough for he necessity and leave the rest behind for another occasion for they have a opinion that god would conceal all other gold from they in the earth if they be to hoard any in they house i see some of these people who be much deform the people of tangut be tall lusty man of a brown complexion the jugur be of middle stature like ourselves and they language be the root or origin of the turkish and comanian language beyond tebet be the people of langa and solanga -lrb- 1 -rrb- whose messenger i saw in the court of mangu-khan who have along with they more than ten great cart each draw by six ox these be little brown man like the spaniard and be dress in tunic or jacket like we deacon with straiter sleeve they wear a kind of cap like the mitre of we bishop but the fore part be less than the hinder part and end square instead of be point these be make of straw stiffen by great heat and so well polish that they glister in the sun like a mirror or well polished helmet round they temple they have long band of the same material fix to they cap which stream to the wind like two long horn from they temple when too much toss by the wind they fold these over the top of they cap when the principal messenger enter the court he hold in he hand a smooth ivory tablet about a foot long and a palm broad and when speak to by the khan or any other great man he always look on he tablet as if he have see there what be speak never look to the right or the left or to the person who speak to he even in come into the presence and in retire he look perpetually at he tablet beyond these people as i have be tell for truth there be a nation call muc inhabit town in whose country there be numerous flock and herd which be never tend as no person appropriate any of these exclusively but when any one be in need of a beast he ascend a hill and give a loud cry on which all the cattle within hear flock around he and suffer themselves to be take as if they be domesticate when a messenger or any stranger go into that country he be immediately shut up in a house where all necessaries be provide for he till he business be conclude for they affirm that if any stranger be to travel about they country the animal would flee away from he scent and become wild beyond the country of these people lie great cathaya whose inhabitant i believe to have be the sere -lrb- 2 -rrb- of the ancient as from thence come the most excellent silken stuff and these people be call sere after the name of one of they town i have be tell that in that country there be a town have wall of silver and tower of gold in that land there be many province the greater part of which be not yet subject to the moal and the sea be interpose between they and indium these kathayan be man of small stature with small eye and speak much through the nose they be excellent workman in all kind of handicraft they physician judge exactly of disease by the pulse and be very skilful in the use of herb but have no knowledge in regard to the urine of sick person some of these people i see at caracarum where there be always considerable number and the child be always bring up to the same employment with they father they pay to the moal or mongal a tribute of 1500 cassino or jascot every day -lrb- 3 -rrb- besides large quantity of silk and provision and they perform many other service all the nation between mount caucasus and from the north of these mountain to the east sea and in all the south of scythium which be inhabit by the moal shepherd be tributary and be all addict to idolatry the nestorian and saracen be intermix with they as stranger as far as kathay in which country the nestorian inhabit fifteen city and have a bishop in a city call segan -lrb- 4 -rrb- these nestorian be very ignorant for they say they service in the syrian tongue in which all they holy book be write and of which language they be entirely ignorant and sing they service as we monk do who have not learn latin they be great usurer and drunkard and some of they who live among the tartar have adopt they custom and even have many wife when they enter the church they wash they lower part like the saracen eat no flesh on friday and hold they festival on the same day with they they bishop come seldom into the country perhaps only once in fifty year and then cause all the little child to be make priest some even in the cradle so that almost every nestorian man be a priest yet all have wife which be contrary to the decree of the father they be even bigamist for they priest when they wife die marry again they be all simonist as they give no holy thing without pay they be careful of they wife and child apply themselves to gain and not to propagate the faith hence though some of they be employ to educate the child of the mongal nobility and even teach they the article of the christian faith yet by they evil life they drive they from christianity as the moral conduct of the mongal and tuinian -lrb- 5 -rrb- who be downright idolater be far more upright than theirs -lrb- 1 -rrb- forster conjecture that the original word of of rubruqui be probably the manichean -- forst section xxix _ of cailac and the country of the nayman _ we depart from the city of cailac on st andrew 's day 30th of November and in three league we mention sea which seem as tempestuous as the ocean and in which we see a large island the water be slightly salt yet might be drink opposite to it be a valley with another salt sea from which a river run into this one there be so strong a wind that the passage be dangerous as we much fear to be blow into the lake wherefore we go north into the hilly country cover with deep snow and on st nichola day 6th December we hasten we journey as we find no inhabitant except the _ janus _ or man appoint to conduct the messenger from one day 's journey to another on the 7th of December we pass between two terrible rock when the guide send entreat I to pray to god : we sing accordingly with a loud voice the _ credo _ and other hymn and by the grace of god we get through in safety after this the tartar entreat I to write papers for they but i offer to teach they word to carry in they heart whereby they soul should be save yet want a interpreter for this i write they the creed and the lord 's prayer desire they to believe what be write in the one and that the other contain a prayer to god for all that be necessary to man and that though they could not understand these i hope god would save they section xxx _ description of the country of the nayman with a account of the death of ken-khan and of he wife and eldest son _ after this we enter into the country where the court of ken-khan use to be hold which be formerly call the country of the nayman who be the peculiar subject of prester john though i do not see that court till my return i shall briefly mention what befel he son and wife ken-khan be dead baatu desire that mangu should be khan but i could not learn exactly the manner of ken-khan 's death friar andrew say he die of the effect of a medicine which baatu be suspect of have procure to be give he i hear on the other hand that he summon baatu to do he homage who accordingly begin he journey with much external pomp but with great inward apprehension send forward he brother stichin who when he come to keu-khan and ought to have present he with the cup high word arise between they and they slew one another the widow of stichin keep we a whole day at she house that we might pray for she and bless she when ken be dead and mangu choose emperor by the consent of baatu which be when friar andrew be there siremon the brother of ken at the instigation of the wife and peculiar vassal of ken go with a great train as if to do homage to mangu but with the intention of put he and all he court to death when within a few day journey of the court of mangu one of he waggon break down and a servant of mangu happen to assist the waggoner in repair it this man be very inquisitive into the object of the journey and the waggoner reveal the whole plot to he pretend to make very light of the matter he go privately and take a good horse from the herd and ride with great speed with the intelligence to the court of mangu who quickly assemble he force and place a strong guard around he court send the rest against siremon and bring he and all he follower prisoner to court he confess he intention and he and he eldest son with 300 noble tartar of they party be put to death the lady be also send for who be concern in the plot and be beat with burn fire-brand till they confess be slay likewise kon the youngest son of siremon who be incapable of enter into the conspiracy from he youth be permit to enjoy the inheritance of he father but we guide dare not enter the house either in go or return section xxxi _ arrival at the court of mangu-khan _ we still travel in the high country trend towards the north and on st stephen 's day 26th December we come to a great plain on which not the smallest inequality be to be see and the next day we arrive at the court of the great khan while at the distance of five day we host want we to have go so far about as would have take we fifteen day 's journey and we guide have much difficulty in be allow to take the direct road my opinion of this procedure in we host be that we might have go by onam and cherule the original residence of zingi -lrb- 1 -rrb- on the way the secretary tell I that baatu in he letter to mangu say that we want the assistance of a tartar army against the saracen by which i be much astonished as i know the letter from you majesty require no army and only advise the khan to be a friend to all christian to exalt the cross and to be a enemy to all the enemy of the cross of christ and as all the interpreter be from the greater armenia who greatly hate the saracen i fear they might have interpret falsely to serve they own purpose i therefore hold my peace fear to gainsay the word of baatu on we arrival at court we guide have a large house appoint for he and only a small cottage be give to we three which would hardly contain we baggage we bed and a small fire many come to we guide with drink make of rice in long necked bottle which have no difference from the best wine except that it smell otherwise we be call soon after and examine upon we business i answer that hearing sartach have become a christian the king we master have send we to he with a letter that he have send we to baatu who have send we hither and that he therefore ought to have assign the cause of we be here they then demand if we would make peace with they to this i answer that have do they no wrong they have no cause of go to war with you majesty that you majesty as a just king if you have do any wrong would make reparation and desire peace but if war against without cause we trust in the help of a just god at this they seem all astonished constantly exclaim do you not come to make peace for they be so puff up with pride that they think the whole world should make peace with they but if i might be suffer i would preach war against they to the utmost of my power i dare not deliver the true cause of my journey lest in so do i might contradict what have be write by baatu and therefore always say we come because he send we the day follow i go to the court barefoot at which the people stare but a hungarian boy who be among diem know we order and tell they the reason on which a nestorian who be chief secretary ask many question at the hungarian and we go back to we lodgings on we return at the end of the court towards the east i see a small house with a little cross at top at which i greatly rejoice suppose there might be some christian there i go in boldly and find a altar well furnished have a golden cloth adorn with image of christ the virgin st john the baptist and two angel the line of they body and garment be form with small pearl on the altar be a large silver cross ornament with precious stone and many other embroidering and a lamp with eight light burn before the altar sit beside the altar i see a armenian monk somewhat black and lean clad in a rough hairy coat to the middle of he leg above which be a coarse black cloak fur with spotted skin and he be gird with iron under he haircloth before salute the monk we fall flat on the earth singing ave regina and other hymn and the monk join in we prayer these be finish we sit down beside the monk who have a small fire before he in a pan he tell we that he have come a month before we be a hermit in the territory of jerusalem who have be warn by god in a vision to go to the prince of the tartar after some conversation we go to we lodgings have eat nothing that day we make a little broth of flesh and millet for we supper we guide and he companion be make drunk at the court and very little care be take of we next morning the end of my toe be so frostbit by the extreme cold of the country that i could no longer go barefoot from the time when the frost begin it never cease till may and even then it freeze every night and morning but thaw with the heat of the sun during the day if they have much wind in that country during winter as we have nothing could live there but they have always mild weather till April and then the wind rise and at that season while we be there the cold rise with the wind kill multitude of animal in the winter little snow fall there but about easter which be that year in the latter end of April there fall so great a snow that the street of caracarum be so full it have to be carry out in cart -lrb- 1 -rrb- the country on the onon and kerlon in daourium or the land of the tungus -- forst section xxxii _ the introduction of rubruqui to mangu-khan _ the people bring we from the court ram-skin coat and breeches of the same with shoe which my companion and interpreter accept but i think the fur garment which i bring from baatu be sufficient for I on the 5th of January we be bring to the court and some nestorian priest whom i do not know to be christian come and ask I which way we worship to which i say that we worship to the east the reason of they make this demand be that we have shave we head by the advice of we guide that we might appear before the khan after the fashion of we country which make the nestorian take we for tuinian or idolater on be demand what reverence we would pay to the khan i say that though as priest dedicate to god the highest in we country do not suffer we to bow the knee yet we be willing to humble ourselves to all man for the sake of the lord that we come from a far country and with permission would first sing praise to god who have bring we hither in safety and should afterwards do whatever might please the khan provide he command nothing that be derogatory to the worship and honor of god then they go into the presence and report what we have say and they bring we before the entrance of the hall lift up the feel which hang before the decor and we sing _ a soli ortus cardine _ & c when we have sing this hymn they search we bosom to see that we have no conceal weapon and they make we interpreter leave he girdle and knife with one of the doorkeeper when we come in we interpreter be
