thorn wormwood - root and cowdung the khan sit upon a couch cover with a bright and shine spotted fur like seal 's skin he be a flat-nosed man of middle stature about forty-five year of age and one of he wife a pretty little young woman sit beside he likewise one of he daughter name cerina a hard-favoured young woman with some younger child sit on another couch next to they the house have belong to the mother of cerina who be a christian and the daughter be mistress of this court which have belong to she deceased mother we be ask whether we would drink wine of _ caracina _ which be a drink make of rice or caracosmo or _ ball _ which be mead make of honey for they use these four kind of liquor in winter i answer that we have no pleasure in drink and would be contented with what he please to order on which we be serve with caracina which be clear and well flavor like white wine of which i taste a little out of respect after a long interval during which the khan amuse himself with some falcon and other bird we be commend to speak and have to bow the knee the khan have he interpreter a nestorian but we interpreter have receive so much liquor from the butler at the sideboard that he be quite drunk i address the khan in the follow term : we give thanks and praise to god who have bring we from such remote part of the world to the presence of mangu-khan on whom he have bestow such great power and we beseech we god to grant he a long and prosperous reign have hear that sartach be become a christian the christian of the west especially the king of the french be much rejoice and send we onto he with letter testify that we be servant of the lord and entreat he to permit we to abide in he country as it be we office to teach man the law of god sartach send we forwards to he father baatu and he have send we to you to whom god have give great dominion upon the earth we therefore entreat you highness to permit we to continue in you country that we may pray to god for you you wife and child we have neither gold nor silver nor precious jewel to offer but we present ourselves to do you service and to pray to god for you at least be please to permit we to remain till the cold be past as my companion be so weak that he can not travel on horseback without danger of m life he answer be to this effect : even as sun shed he beam everywhere so we power and that of baa extend everywhere around so that we have no need of you gold or silver i entreated he highness not to be displeased at I for mention gold and silver as i speak in that manner only to evince we desire to do he honor and to serve he in heavenly thing hitherto i have understand we interpreter but he be now drunk and could not make out any perfect sentence and it appear to I that the khan be drunk likewise wherefore i hold my peace then he make we rise and sit down again and after a few word of compliment we withdraw from the presence one of the secretary and the interpreter who have the charge of educate one of he daughter go with we and be very inquisitive about the kingdom of france particularly inquire whether it have plenty of sheep cattle and horse as if they mean to make it all they own and i have often to bridle my indignation and anger at they presumptuous boasting they appoint one to take care of we and we go to the monk and when we be about to return to we lodge the interpreter come to we say that mangu-khan give we two month to stay till the extreme cold be past and we might either go ten day 's journey from thence to the city of caracarum or might remain with the court then i answer god preserve mangu-khan and grant he a long and happy life : we have find this monk whom we think a holy man and we would willingly remain and pray along with he for the prosperity of the khan we then go to we dwelling which we find very cold as we have no fuel and we be yet fasting though it be then night but he who have the care of we provide we some fuel and a little food and we guide who be now to return to baatu beg a carpet from we which we have leave in that court which we give he and he depart in peace section xxxiii _ of a woman of lorain and a goldsmith of pari and several other christian whom they find at the court of mangu-kkan _ we have the good fortune to meet with a woman name pascha from metz in lorain who belong to the court of whom she have three fine child and this woman contribute all in she power to we comfort she tell we that there be a goldsmith at caracarura one william bouchier from paris the son of lawrence bouchier and who have a brother roger bouchier yet live upon the great bridge she tell I likewise that he have a son who be a excellent interpreter but that manga-khan have deliver to the goldsmith 300 jascot of silver equal to 3000 mark and fifty workman to make a certain piece of work so that she fear he would not then be able to spare he son to interpret for we i write to this goldsmith request he to send he son to I he say in answer that he could not at the time but would send he next moon when he work would be finish at the court of baatu no intercourse could be have with other ambassador as each be under the charge of a particular _ janus _ but in that of mangu all be under one janus and might see and converse with each other we find here a certain christian from damascus who say that he come from the sultan of mon regali and crax who desire to become the ally and tributary of the great khan the year before i come thither there be a certain clerk of aeon or ptolemai in syrium who call himself raimund but he true name be theodolus this man go with friar andrew from cyprus into persium and procure certain instrument from amoricus who remain in persium after andrew return theodolus go forwards with these instrument to the khan pretend that a certain bishop have receive letter from heaven in gold character say that the khan should be king of the whole earth but that he horse have flee from he among wood and mountain so that he have lose all and theodolus engage to conduct ambassador from the khan to the pope and the king of france then mangu cause a exceedingly strong bow to be make which two man could hardly bend and two arrow make of silver full of hole in they head which whistle when they be shoot and he choose a moal to accompany theodolus as he ambassador order he to present these thing to the king of france and to say if he would have peace with the tartar they would conquer the country of the saracen and would grant he ail the other country of the west but if the king refuse the moal be to bring back the bow and arrow and to inform the king that the tartar shoot far and sharp with such bow the khan then cause theodolus to go out and the son of william bouchier who act as interpreter for theodolus hear the khan order the moal who be to accompany he to mark well all the way and the castle and the people and the mountain in the course of he journey and the young man blame theodolus for engage to conduct the tartar messenger as they go only to spy the land but theodolus say he would take they by sea so that they should not know the way mangu give to he moal a golden bull or tablet of a hand breadth and half a cubit long inscribe with he order and whoever bear this may everywhere command what he please on they journey through the dominion of vestacius whence theodolus mean to pass over to the pope that he might deceive he as he have do mangu vestacius demand of he whether he have letter for the pope but have none to show vestacius turkey and from they i learn all that happen to theodolus section xxxiv _ of a grand feast give by mangu-khan and of the ceremony of the nestorian _ epiphany be now at hand and the armenian monk the censer and incense after wait some time cotata caten -lrb- 1 -rrb- the principal wife of the khan come into the chapel attend by many lady and have with she baltu she eldest son and several other the khan by a christian mother come to the chapel and act in a similar manner but not with so much solemnity and only give the priest to drink and some parched millet to eat before the first Sunday in lend the nestorian fast three day which they call the fast of jona and the armenian fast five day in honor of st lorkis they tutelary saint the nestorian begin they fast on Tuesday and end it on Thursday and on Friday they bless the flesh as if it be the paschal lamb the monk send to mangu to fast that week which he do and on the armenian easter he go in procession to the house of mangu accompany by we and the nestorian priest while we go in some servant meet we carry out some shoulder-blade of sheep burnt as black as coal and on enquire i learn that the khan perform a divination before undertake any important matter in this manner he cause three of these bone to be bring to he unburnt which be seek for all over the _ leskar _ or tartar camp for this purpose and these bone be burn in a particular fire and then bring to he again if the bone be crack across or round piece fly out of they in burn it be consider a evil omen but if they crack lengthway even one of the three he then proceed in he design when we go in before mangu the nestorian priest give he incense which he put upon the censer with which they perfumed he then they sing and bless he cup which be do next by the monk and lastly by we after he have drunk the attendant give drink to the priest but we go out and my companion stay last turn round near the door to make he obeisance to the khan and hastily turn again to follow we stumble on the threshold for which he be seize and carry before the _ bulgaus _ who be the chancellor or chief secretary of the court and judge those who be arraign on matter of life and death but i know not of all this as miss he on look back i think he have be detain to receive thinner apparel for he be very weak and could hardly walk under he load of garment he be send home in the evening and the monk sharply rebuke he for have touch the threshold next day the bulgaus come to I and demand to know if any one have warn we against touch the threshold to which i answer that as we have not we interpreter along with we we should not have understand they if the caution have be give on this my companion be pardon but be never allow afterwards to come into any of the house of mangu-khan from the house of the khan we go to that of he eldest son who have two wife and lodge next on the right from he father as soon as he see we approach he leap from he bed and prostrate himself before the cross strike the ground with he forehead then rise and kiss the cross he cause it to be place on a new cloth in a high place very reverently he have a tutor name david to return to we oratory the monk accompany we with great howling and outcry in they drunkenness as they have be plentifully supply with drink at every visit but this be not consider as blameable or of the wife of mangu-khan _ sometime after the lady cota be sick almost to death and the divination by lot of the idolater do she no good mangu-khan then send for the monk who indiscreetly engage to propose to prepare some holy water accord to the rite of the church of rome which have great power to cast out devil as i understand the lady be vex of a devil -lrb- 1 -rrb- at he request i consecrate article of we holy faith neither advise she to be baptize nor do they find fault with any kind of sorcery for i see four sword half draw out of they sheath one at the head of she bed one at the foot and one on either side of she door i observe likewise one of we silver chalice probably take from some church in hungary which hang against the wall full of ash on the top of which lay a black stone but these priest not only do not teach they that such thing be evil but even practice similar thing we continue we visit for three day by which time she be restore to perfect health during these visit she continue to rally I on my silence and endeavor to teach I they language i honor the monk sergius as my bishop because he could speak the language though he be totally uneducated and i afterwards learn when i come to he own country on my return that he be no priest but merely a adventurous weaver in many thing he act in a way that much displeased I for he cause to be make for himself a folding chair such as bishop use and glove and a cap of peacock feather with a small gold cross but i be well please with the cross he have scab foot which he endeavor to palliate with ointment -lrb- 3 -rrb- be very presumptuous in speech be present at many of the vain and idolatrous rite of the nestorian and have many other vanity with which i be much displeased yet we join he society for die honor of the cross as he get a banner full of cross on a cane as long as a lance and we carry the cross aloft through among all the tent of the tartar singing _ vexillum regi prodeant _ & c to the great regret of the mahometan who be envious of we favor i be inform of a certain armenian who come as he say from jerusalem along with the monk sergius carry a silver cross of about four mark weight adorn with rebuild that church be ask how much that might cost he say two hundred jascot or two thousand mark and the khan order letter to be give he order those who receive the tribute of persium and the greater armenia to pay he that sum in silver -lrb- 4 -rrb- the monk continue to carry this cross about with he wherever he go and the nestorian priest become envious of the profit which he derive from money a most magnificent present to a itinerant beggar -- e section xxxvi _ account of the country under the dominion of the great khan of the manners and custom of he subject of a wonderful piece of mechanism construct by a french goldsmith and of the palace of the khan at caracarum _ from the time of we arrival at the court of mangu-khan the leskar or camp make only two day journey towards the south and it then begin its progress northwards in the direction of caracarum in the whole of my journey i be convince of the truth of what i have be inform by baldwin de hainault at constantinople that the whole way eastward be by a continual ascent as all the river run from the east towards the west sometimes deviate towards the north or south more or less directly but never run east but this be farther confirm to I by the priest who come from kathay -lrb- 1 -rrb- from the place where i find mangukhan it be twenty day journey south-east to kathay and ten day journey right east to oman kerule the original country of the moal and of zingi -lrb- 2 -rrb- in those part there be no city but the country be inhabit by a people call su-moall or mongol of the water who live upon fish and hunting and have neither flock nor herd farther north likewise there be no city but a poor people of herdsman who be call kerki the orangin be there also who bind smooth bone under they foot and thrust themselves with such velocity over the ice and snow as to overtake beast in the chase there be many other poor nation in those part inhabit as far to the north as the cold will permit who join on the west with the country of pascatir or the greater hungary of which i have make mention before -lrb- 3 -rrb- in the north the mountain be perpetually cover with snow and the bound be unknown by reason of the extreme cold all these nation be poor yet they must all betake themselves to some employment as zingi establish a law that none be to be free from service till so old as to be unable for work i be inquisitive about the monstrous man of whom isidore and solinus make mention but no one have ever see any such and i therefore doubt whether it be true once a priest of kathay sit by I clothe in red of whom i ask how that color be procure he tell I that on certain high craggy rock in the east of kathay there dwell certain creature like man not above a cubit long and all hairy who leap rather than walk and dwelt in inaccessible cave that those who go to hunt they carry strong drink which they leave in hole of the rock and then hide themselves these little creature come out from they hole and have taste the drink call out _ chin-chin _ on which multitude gather together and drink till they be drunk and fall asleep then the hunter come and bind they after which they draw a few drop of blood from the vein of the neck of each of these creature and let they go free and this blood be the most precious purple dye he tell I likewise that there be a province beyond kathay into which if a man enter he always continue of the same age at which he enter but this i do not believe -lrb- 4 -rrb- kathay be on the ocean and i be tell by the french goldsmith at caracarum that there be a people or nation call tante and manse inhabit certain island the sea around which be freeze in winter so that the tartar might invade they but they send messenger to the great khan offer a tribute of 2000 tueman or jascot yearly to permit they to live in peace -lrb- 5 -rrb- a tuemen toman or jascot be a piece of money equal to ten mark the ordinary money of kathay be of paper make like pasteboard the breadth and length of a hand on which line be print like the seal of mangu they write with a pencil like that use by we painter and in one figure they comprehend many letter form one word -lrb- 6 -rrb- the people of thibet write as we do and they character be very like we own those of tangut write from right to leave like the arab and multiply they line ascend while the jugurs write in descend column the common money of the rutenian or russian consist in spotted or grizzled fur when we quinquagesima come which be the lend time of all the people of the east the lady cota fast all that week and come every day to we oratory give meat to the priest and other christian of whom a great company come daily to attend the service but the porter of the court see such multitude come daily to we chapel which be within the precinct of the court send one to tell the monk that they would not allow such multitude to come within they bound to this the monk make a sharp reply and threaten to accuse they to the khan but they prevent he and lodge a complaint before mangu that the monk be too full of word and gather too great a multitude to hear he speak on this he be call before the khan who reprove he severely say that as a holy man he should employ himself in prayer to god and not in speech to man but he be afterwards reconcile by promise to go to the pope and to induce all the nation of the west to yield obedience to the khan on he return to the oratory the monk ask I if i think he might gain admission to the pope as the messenger of mangu and whether the pope would supply he with horse to go to st jame in galicium and whether you majesty would send you son to the court of mangu but i counsel he to beware of make false promise to mangu and that god need not the service of lie or deceitful speaking about this time a dispute arise between the monk and one of the nestorian priest more learn than the rest as the monk assert that man be create before paradise which the other deny on reference to I i say that paradise be create on the _ second _ day when the other tree be make whereas man be make on the sixth then the monk say that the devil bring clay on die first day from all the corner of the earth of which he make the body of man which god inspire with a soul on this i sharply reprove he for he heretical ignorance and he scorn I for my ignorance of the language : i depart therefore from he to we own house but when he and the priest go afterwards in procession to the court without call I mangu earnestly enquire the reason of my absence and the priest be afraid excuse themselves as well as they could and report to I the word of the khan murmur at the monk after this the monk be reconcile to I and i entreated he to aid I in acquire the language promise to help he to the knowledge of the holy scripture after the first week of fast the lady cease from come to the oratory and to give meat and drink so that we have nothing but brown bread and paste boil in melted snow or ice which be exceedingly bad my companion be much grieve at this diet on which i acquaint david the teacher of the khan eldest son with we necessity who make a report to the khan and we be then supply with wine flour and oil the nestorian and armenian eat no fish in lend but the monk have a chest under the altar with almond and raisin and dry prune and other fruit on which he feed when alone about the middle of lend the goldsmith son come from caracarum bring a silver cross make in the french fashion with a image of christ as a present for bulgaus the chief secretary of the court and the young man inform mangu that the great work he have command to be make by he father be complete in the neighborhood of caracarum mangu have a large court inclose with a brick wall like we priory within that court be a great palace in which the khan hold feast twice a-year once in easter and the other in summer but the latter be the greater as all the noble meet then at the court when the khan distribute garment among they and display all he magnificence beside the palace there be many great building like we barn in which the victuals and treasure belong to the khan be store because it be indecent to have flaggon go about the hall of the palace as in a tavern william the goldsmith construct a great silver tree just without the middle entrance of the great hall at the root of which be four silver lion have pipe discharge pure cow milk four pipe be convey up the body of the tree to its top which spread out into four great bough hang downward on each of these bough be a golden serpent all they tail twine about the body of the tree and each of these form a pipe one discharging wine a second caracosmo a third ball or mead make of honey and the fourth _ teracina _ or drink make of rice each particular drink have a vessel at the foot of the tree to receive it on the top between the four pipe there stand a image of a angel with a trumpet under the tree there be a vault in which a man be hide and from he a pipe ascend to the angel and when the butler command to sound the trumpet the man below blow strongly and the trumpet emit a shrill sound in a chamber without the palace the liquor be store and servant who be wait pour the liquor each in its proper pipe at the signal when they be convey by conceal pipe up the body of the tree and discharge into they appropriate vessel whence they be distribute by the under butler to the visitor the tree be all ornament with silver bough and leave and fruit all of silver the palace be like a church have a middle aisle and two side one beyond two row of pillar and have three gate to the south and before the middle gate stand the silver tree the khan sit at the north wall on a high place that he may be see of all and there be two flight of step ascend to he by one of which he cup-bearer go up and come down by the other the middle space between the throne and the silver tree be leave vacant for the cup-bearer and the messenger who bring present on the right side of the khan the man sit and the woman on the left one woman only sit beside he but not so high as he about passion Sunday the khan go before with he small house only leave the great one behind and the monk and we follow on the journey we have to pass through a hilly country -lrb- 7 -rrb- where we encounter high wind extreme cold and much snow about midnight the khan send to the monk and we request we to pray to god to mitigate the severity of the weather as the beast in he train be in great jeopardy be mostly with young and about to bring forth then the monk send he incense desire he to put it on the coal as a offering to god : whether he do this or no i know not but the tempest cease which have last two day on palm Sunday we be near caracarum and at dawn of day we bless the willow bough on which as yet there be no bud about nine o'clock we enter the city of caracarum carry the cross aloft with the banner and pass through the street of the saracen in which the market be hold we proceed to the church where the nestorian meet we in procession we find they prepared to celebrate the mass and they all communicate but i decline this have already drink and the sacrament should always be receive lasting after mass be now evening william bouchier the goldsmith bring we to sup at he lodging he have a wife bear in hungary of mahometan parent who speak french and the language of the comanian we find here also one basilicus the son of a englishman likewise bear in hungary who be likewise skilled in these language after supper we retire to we cottage which with the oratory of the monk be place near the nestorian church which be of considerable size and very handsomely build and all the ceiling be cover with silk work with gold i much deliberate with myself whether i should continue in communion with the monk and the nestorian because i see they action full of idolatry and sorcery but i fear to give offence to the khan in separate from the other christian as i see that my presence please he for which reason i always accompany they to court but when there i do not join in they mummery pray always in a loud voice for the church and that god would direct the khan in the right way of salvation on one occasion the khan promise to come to the church next day but he depart on he journey to the northward desire the priest to excuse he because he have learn that the dead be carry thither but we remain behind that we might celebrate the festival of easter there be a vast multitude of hungarian alan rutenian or russian georgian and armenian who have not receive the sacrament since they be take prisoner as the nestorian would not admit they into they church unless they be rebaptize yet they offer they sacrament freely to we and allow I to see they manner of consecration on the vigil of easter i see they ceremony of baptism they pretend to have the ointment with which mary magdalen anoint the foot of jesus and they put in so much of that oil in knead they sacramental bread for all the people of the east use butter or oil or fat from a sheep tail in they bread instead of leaven they pretend also to have of the flour of which the bread be make which be consecrate by we lord at he last supper as they always keep a small piece of dough from each bake to mix up with the new which they consecrate with great reverence in administer this to the people they divide the consecrate loaf first into twelve portion after the number of the apostle which they afterwards break down into smaller piece in proportion to the number of communicant give the body of christ into the hand of every one who take it from he own palm with much reverence and afterwards lay he hand on the top of he head i be much at a loss how to act as the nestorian entreat I to celebrate the festival and i have neither vestment chalice nor altar but the goldsmith furnish I with vestment and make a oratory on a chariot decently paint with scripture history he make also a silver box or pix for the host and a image of the bless virgin and cause a iron instrument to be make for we to make host in we way then i make the before mention christian to confess to I as well as i could by means of a interpreter explain to they the ten commandment the seven deadly sin and other matter exhort they to confession and penitence : but all of they publickly excuse themselves respect theft say that they could not otherwise live as they master neither provide they with food or raiment and i say they might lawfully take necessaries from they master especially as they have forcibly deprive they of they subsistence and liberty some who be soldier excuse themselves from have go to the war as otherwise they would be slay these i forbid to go against christian declare that if slay for they refusal god would account they as martyr after this i give the holy communion to these people on easter day and i hope with the blessing of god to many be assist by the nestorian who lend I they chalice and paten they baptize above threescore person on easter eve with great solemnity to the great joy of all the christian soon after this william bouchier be grievously sick and when recover the monk sergius visit he and give he so great a doze of rhubarb as have almost kill he on this i expostulate with the monk that he ought either to go about as a apostle do miracle by the virtue of prayer and the holy ghost or as a physician accord to the rule of the medical aid and not to administer strong potion to people who be not prepare about this time the principal priest of the nestorian who be a kind of archdeacon over the rest become sick $ and when i endeavor at the request of he family to prevail upon the monk to visit he he say let he alone for he and three other intend to procure a order from mangu-khan to expel you and i and i learn afterwards that there be a dispute between they as mangu-khan have send four jascot on easter eve to the monk to distribute among the priest and sergius keep one to himself have give three to the priest one be a counterfeit and the priest think sergius have keep too great a share to himself find the archdeacon in a die way i administer to he the eucharist and extreme unction which he receive with great humility and devotion but by the advice of the monk i quit he before he die as otherwise i could not have enter the court of mangu-khan for a whole year when he be dead the monk say to I never mind it : this man only among the nestorian have any learning and oppose we henceforwards mangu-khan and all the rest will crouch at we foot he even pretend that he have kill he by he prayer i afterwards learn that the monk practice divination with the aid of a russian deacon though when i challenge he he pretend to excuse himself and to deny the truth of what have be report to I : but i could not leave he have be place there by command of the khan so that i dare not to remove without he special command exclusive of the palace of the khan caracarum be not so good as the town of st deni and the monastery of st denni be worth more than ten time the value of the palace itself it contain two principal street : that of the saracen in which the fair be hold and to which many merchant resort as the court be always near the other be the street of the kathayan which be full of artificer besides these street there be many palace in which be the court of the secretary of the khan there be twelve idol temple belong to different nation two mahometan mosque and one nestorian church at the end of the town the town itself be inclose with a mud wall and have four gate on the east side there be a market for millet and other grain but which be ill supply on the west sheep and goat be sell on the north side ox and waggon and on the south side horse mangu-khan have eight brother three by the mother and five by the father one of these on the mother side he send into the country of the assassine call _ mulibet _ by the tartar with order to kill they all another be send into persium who be suppose to have order to send army into turkey and from thence against bagdat and vestacius one of he other brother have be send into kathay to reduce certain rebel he youngest maternal brother name arabucha live with he and keep up he mother court who be a christian about this time on account of a violent quarrel between the monk and certain mahometan and because a rumor be propagate of four hundred assassin have go forth in diver habit with a intention to murder the khan we be order to depart from we accustomed place before the court and to remove to the place where other messenger dwell hitherto i have always hope for the arrival of the king of armenia -lrb- 8 -rrb- and have not therefore make any application for leave to depart but hear no news of the king or a certain german priest who be likewise expect and fear lest we should return in the winter the severity of which i have already experienced i send to demand the pleasure of the khan whether we be to remain with he or to return and represent that it would be easier for we to return in summer than in winter the khan send to desire that i should not go far off as he mean to speak with I next day to which i answer request he to send for the son of the goldsmith to interpret between we as my interpreter be very incompetent -lrb- 1 -rrb- so for as be travel by rubruqui and in the route which he pursue on the north of the alak mountain this court of mangu-khan respect religion _ next day i be bring to the court and some of the chief secretary of the khan come to I one of whom be a moal who be cup-bearer to the khan and the rest be saracen these man demand on the part of the khan wherefore i have come there to this i answer as i have do before that i come to sartach who send I to baatu and he have order I to the khan to whom i have nothing to say on the part of any man unless i should speak the word of god if he would hear they for the khan should know best what baatu have write then they demand what word of god i would speak to the khan thinking i mean to prophecy prosperous thing as other have do to this i answer if ye would that i speak the word of god unto the khan get I a interpreter they say they have send for he but urge I to speak by the present one as they would understand I perfectly i therefore say this be the word of god to whom much be give much will be require at he hand and to whom much be forgive he ought the more to love god to manga i would say that god have give much for the power and riches which he enjoy come not from the idol of the tuinian but from the omnipotent god who have make heaven and earth in whose hand be all kingdom and dominion and who transferreth they from nation to nation for the sin of man wherefore if he love god it will go well with he but if otherwise god will require all thing at he hand even to the utmost farthing then they ask if i have be in heaven that i should know the commandment of god i say no but that god have give they from heaven to holy man and have at length descend from heaven to earth to teach we and that we have those thing in the scripture and could judge from they work whether man keep the commandment of god or disobey they they then ask if i mean to say that mangu-khan do not keep the commandment of god to this i answer when i shall have a proper interpreter and be permit i shall then recite the commandment of god before mangu and he shall be he own judge whether he have keep or disobey they upon this they go and tell mangu that i say he be a idolater and tuinian and keep not the commandment of god next day mangu send one of he secretary say ye be here christian mahometan and tuinian wherefore the khan desire that ye will all come together and make comparison of you opinion that he may know the truth to this i answer bless be god that have put this in the heart of the khan but we scripture command the servant of god not to be contentious but meek unto all wherefore i be ready without strife or contention to render a true account of the faith and hope of the christian to every one who may require to be inform they write down my word and bring they to the khan next day another message come from the khan desire again to know on what account i have come to he court to which i answer that this might be know from the letter of bantu but they say that these letter be lose and the khan have forget they contents and would know of I somewhat embolden by this i say the duty and office of we religion be to preach the gospel unto all wherefore have hear of the fame of the mongal i desire to come to they and hear that sartach have become a christian i direct my journey to he and my sovereign the king of the french send he letter contain good word of friendship testify what man we be and request we might be permit to remain with the people of moal that sartach have send we to baatu and he have order we to mangu-khan whom we have entreat and still do entreat to suffer we to stay they write all this and make a report of it to the khan on the morrow he send again that he know we have no message for he but come to pray for he as other priest do but desire to know if any of we ambassador have ever be in they country or any of theirs in we part then i declare unto they all i know respect david and friar andrew all of which be put down in write and lay before mangu they come back say we lord the khan think you have staid long here and he pleasure be that you return into you own country but he desire to know whether you would conduct he ambassador along with you to this i answer that i dare not to carry he ambassador beyond he own dominion as a warlike nation dwelt between they country and ours between the sea and the mountain and be only a poor monk i could not take upon I to be they guide this they likewise set down in write and carry to the khan the nestorian be command to set down in write all that they would speak in favor of the christian religion and they write out a chronicle from the creation of the world to the passion of christ and pass over the passion they speak of the resurrection of the dead and of the day of judgment finding many thing wrong i point they out and we write out the creed or symbol ask they how they mean to proceed in the conference they say they mean to begin with the saracen but i dissuade they from that because as they agree with we in the belief of one only god they would assist against the tuinian i then point out to they the original of idolatry in the world and they desire I to explain these thing before mangu and then to let they speak because i should find it difficult and tedious to speak by a interpreter i then propose to try they by take the side of the tuinian while they should defend the opinion of the christian but they know not how to prove any thing except merely by quote they scripture to this i say that these man believe not in we scripture and would oppose they by advance contrary opinion and position from those book which they account holy then i desire that they would allow I to speak first since if i be overcome they would be permit to speak whereas if they be confute i would be refuse a hearing and to this they consent all thing be arrange we convene at we oratory and mangu-khan send three of he secretary a christian a saracen and a tuinian to be judge of the controversy it be first proclaim this be the order of mangu-khan and none dare say that the commandment of god be otherwise let none speak contentiously or use injurious word to one another or make any tumult whereby this business may be hinder upon pain of death there be a great assembly as every party have convene the wisest of they sect and many other come flock around to listen but all be silent the christian set I in the middle willing that i should contend with the tuinian who murmur against mangu as no khan have ever thus endeavor to search into they secret yet they oppose one from kathay to I who have he interpreter while i have the son of the goldsmith to interpret my word the kathayan say to I friend if you be put to a nonplus who must seek a wiser than thou art to this i make no reply then he demand whether i would dispute as to how the world be make or as to what become of the soul after death for they be desirous to begin with these question as they hold they for the strongest in they doctrine all the tuinian follow the heresy of the manichean believe in a good and a bad principle and they all believe that soul pass from body to body in confirmation of this the goldsmith tell I they have bring a person from kathay who by the size of he body appear to be only three year old yet be capable of reasoning and know how to write and who affirm that he have pass through three several body even one of the wisest of the nestorian demand of I whether the soul of brute could fly to any place after death where they should not be compel to labor to the before-mentioned question of the kathayan i answer : friend this ought hot to be the commencement of we conference all thing be of god who be the fountain and head of we all and therefore we ought first to speak concern god of whom you think otherwise than you ought and mangu desire to know which of we have the better belief the arbitrator allow this to be reasonable and i proceed : we firmly believe that there be but one god in perfect unity what believe you he say fool say there be but one god but wise man say there be many there be great lord in you country and here be still a greater even mangu-khan so it be of the god as in diver country there be diver god to this i answer : you make a bad comparison between god and man for in this way every mighty man might be call a god in he own country and when i mean to have dissolve the similitude he prevent I by ask what manner of god be yours who you say be but one i answer : we god beside whom there be no other be omnipotent and therefore needeth not the help of any other whereas all have need of he help it be not so with man as no man can do all thing wherefore there must be many lord on earthy as no one can support all god be omniscient or knoweth all thing and therefore have no need of any counsellor for all wisdom be from he god be perfectly good and need not therefore any good from we in god we live and move and have we be such be we god and you must not hold that there be any other it be not so say he for there be one highest in heaven whose origin or generation we know not and there be ten under he and on earth they be infinite in number to this he would have add other fable i ask he respect the highest god of whom he have speak whether he be omnipotent or if any of the inferior god be so and fear to answer this he demand why since we god be perfectly good he have make the half of all thing evil to this i answer that this be false for whosoever maketh any evil be no god and all thing whatsoever be good at this all the tuiuian be astonish and set it down in write as false or impossible he then ask I whence cometh evil you ask amiss say i for you ought first to inquire what evil be before you ask whence it come : but let we return to the first question whether do you believe that any god be omnipotent and when that be discuss i will answer whatever you may demand on this he sit a long time without speak and the judge appoint by the khan command he to make answer at length he say that no god be omnipotent on which all the saracen break out into great laughter when silence be restore i say none of you god therefore can save you in all danger since chance may happen in which they have no power besides no man can serve two master how therefore can you serve so many god in heaven and in earth the auditory decree that he should make answer to this but he hold he peace when i be about to have propound reason to prove the truth of the divine essence and to have explain the doctrine of the trinity the nestorian allege that i have say quite enough and that now they mean to speak so i give place to they when therefore they would have dispute with the saracen these man say that they agree to the truth of the law and the gospel of the christian and would not dispute with they in any thing and even confess that they beg from god in they prayer that they may die the death of the christian there be among the idolater a priest of the sect of the jugur who believe in one god and yet make idol with this man the nestorian talk much shewing all thing till the come of christ to judgment and explain the trinity to he and the saracen by similitude all of they hearken to they harangue without attempt to make any contradiction yet none of they say that they believe and would become christian the conference be now break up the nestorian and saracen sing together with a loud voice and the tuinian hold they peace and afterwards they all drink together most plentifully section xxxviii _ the last audience of rubruqui with mangu-khan and the letter he receive for the king of france _ on whitsunday i be call into the presence of the khan and before i go in the goldsmith son who be my interpreter inform I that it be determine i be to return to my own country and advise I to say nothing against it when i come before the khan i kneel and he ask I whether i say to he secretary that he be a tuinian to this i answer my lord i say not so but if it please you highness i will repeat what i then say and i recite what i have speak as mention before and he answer : i think well you say not so for it be a word you ought not to have speak but you interpreter have ill render you word then reach forth the staff on which he lean towards I he say be not afraid to which i answer smile that if i have fear i should not have come hither he then say as if confess he faith : we moal believe that there be but one god and we have a upright heart towards he then say i may god grant you this mind for without he gift it can not be he then add god have give to the hand diver finger and have give many way to man he have give the scripture to you yet you keep they not you certainly find not in the scripture that one of you should dispraise another no say i and i signify unto you highness from the beginning that i would not contend with any one i speak not say he respect you in like manner you find not in you scripture that a man ought to swerve from justice for the sake of money to this i answer that we scripture teach no such evil doctrine neither have i come into these part to get money have even refuse that which be freely offer to I and one of the secretary then present certify that i have refuse a jascot and a piece of silk i speak not of that say the khan god have give you the scripture and you keep they not but he have give to we soothsayer and we do what they bid we and live in peace he drink four time as i think before he disclose these thing and while i wait attentively in expectation that he might disclose any thing farther respect he faith he begin another subject saying : you have stay a long time here and it be my pleasure that you return you have say that you dare not to carry my ambassador with you will you carry my messenger or my letter to this i answer if he would make I understand he word and that they be put in write i would willingly carry they to the best of my power he then ask if i would have gold or silver or costly garment i answer that we receive no such thing but not have wherewith to bear we expence we could not get out of he country without he help he then say that he would provide we in all necessaries through he country and demand how far we would be bring i say it be sufficient if he give we a pass into armenia to this he answer : i will cause you to be carry thither after which look to yourself there be two eye in one head yet they both look to one object you come here from baatu and therefore you must return by he have request and obtain leave to speak i address he thus : sir we be not man of war and desire that they who would most justly govern accord to the will of god may have dominion in the world we office be to teach man to live accord to the law of god : for this purpose we come into these part and would willingly have remain here if it have be you pleasure but since you be pleased that we should return i shall carry you letter accord to my power in obedience to you command i request of you magnificence that when i have deliver you letter it may be lawful for I to come back into you dominion chiefly because you have servant of we nation at balac who want a priest to teach they and they child the law of we religion and i would willingly stay with they he then ask whether i know that we lord would send I back to he to this i answer i know not what may be the purpose of my sovereign but i have licence to go wherever i will where it be needful to preach the word of god and it seem to I necessary in these part wherefore whether my lord send ambassador or not if it be you pleasure i will return then after a long pause as if muse he say you have a lone way to go make yourself strong with food that you may be enable to endure the journey so he order they to give I drink and i depart from he presence and return not again from that time i could have no time nor place to expound to he the catholic faith for a man must not speak before he unless what he pleaseth to order or allow except he be a ambassador who may speak what he will and they always demand of such whether he have any thing more to say the soothsayer be the priest of the mongal and whatever they command to be do be perform without delay i shall describe they office as i learn it from the goldsmith and other of these soothsayer there be great number under the direction of a chief priest whose house be always about a stone 's throw in front of the great house of mangu-khan and under he charge be all the chariot which carry idol the other soothsayer dwell behind the court in place appoint for they and such as have confidence in they art come to consult they from various distant part some of they be skilful in astronomy especially they chief and they foretel eclipse of the sun and moon when these be to happen all the people prepare they food that they may not be under the necessity of go out of door and during the eclipse they play on various instrument of music and set up loud shout : when it be over they indulge in feast and carouse to express they joy these soothsayer pretend to foretell lucky and unlucky day for all affair and the tartar never levy a army or undertake a war without they approbation they have long since resume they attack on hungary but that the soothsayer have always oppose it they make every thing which be send to court pass between two fire as a purification likewise all the household stuff belong to a dead person must be purge in the same manner and if any living creature drop down or any thing whatever fall to the ground during the ceremony it become the property of the soothsayer who besides have a certain proportion of every thing which they purify as they due there be therefore a twofold reason why friar andrew carpinus be make to pass between the fire both because he bring present and because con-khan for whom these have be bring be dead : but as i bring nothing this be not require of I once on a time some very costly fur be present at the court of the christian lady whom pascha the good woman of metz serve and the soothsayer in pass they between the fire take more than be they due another woman who have the custody of the treasure belong to that lady accuse they of the fraud to she mistress who reprove they severely for they conduct sometime afterwards the lady fall sick and the soothsayer accuse the servant who have detect they fraud of have bewitch she she receive the bastinado for seven day successively and other torture to make she confess and on hearing of she mistress 's death beg to be kill that she might follow she for that in truth she have never do she the smallest injury but as she confess nothing mangu-khan command that she should live after this the soothsayer accuse the daughter nurse of the deceased lady which nurse be a christian and wife to the chief of the nestorian priest she and she servant-maid be tortured to make a confession and the maid answer that the nurse have send she to receive response from a certain horse the nurse also confess that she have use some spell to procure the love of she lady but have never do any thing to hurt she on be demand to say whether she husband know of she incantation she excuse he say that he have burn the character which she have make then she be put to death and the husband be send to be judge by he bishop in kathay it happen that the principal wife of mangu bring forth a son and the soothsayer be bring to foretell the destiny of the infant when they prophesy that he should live long and prosperously and become a great lord but he die in a few day on be reproach for they falsehood they say that the nurse of cerina who have be lately put to death have kill the boy and pretend to have see she carry he away there be then in the camp a son and daughter of the nurse whom the lady immediately send for in a rage and order they to be put to death some time afterwards this come to the ear of mangu-khan who be much enraged at the conduct of he wife he cause the man to be behead who have slay the nurse son and make he head to be hung round the neck of the woman who have kill she daughter order she to be cudgel with burn fire-brand through among all the tent and then put to death he would also have put he wife to death if it have not be for the sake of the child he have by she but he command she to be shut up for seven day without food and go out from he court for a whole moon after the feast of pentecost they begin to prepare they letter for you majesty and in the mean time the khan return to caracarum and hold a great feast on the 15th of June at which all the ambassador be desire to be present but i go to church to baptize the three child of a poor german william the goldsmith be chief butler at this feast as he have the charge of the silver tree which pour out the drink on this occasion the khan give during four successive day a complete suit of apparel each day to all he courtier every day a new color and he make they a speech say i have send my brother afar into danger among foreign nation it shall be see how you will conduct yourselve when i send you to extend the boundary of we empire at this time there be a ambassador at the court from the khan of bagdat of whom it be report when mangu declare he would not grant they peace unless they would destroy all they warlike ammunition that he answer we will do this when you pluck off all the hoof from you horse i see there also the ambassador from a soldan of indium who bring with he eight leopard and ten hare-hound who be teach to sit on a horse croup in hunting like the leopard when i ask of they the way to indium they point to the west and they travel with I on we return always westwards for nearly three week i also see there the ambassador of the sultan of turkey who bring rich present to the khan at length the letter be ready for you majesty they call for I and explain they and the follow be they substance so far as i could understand they by my interpreter : the commandment of the eternal god be this : as there be but one eternal god in heaven so upon earth let there be but one lord zingis-khan son of god and mangu-tinij -lrb- 1 -rrb- this be the word which be speak to you whether moal naman market or musselman wherever man may hear or horse may go cause it to be hear and understand that such as have hear my command and do not obey or would levy a army against I shall be as have eye and not see as have hand and unable to hold any thing and as have foot yet unable to walk this be the commandment of the eternal god and by the virtue of the eternal god the commandment of mangu-khan the great emperor of the moal be give to lodowick the french king and to all other lord and priest and to the great world of the frank that they understand my word and the commandment of the eternal god make to zingis-khan neither but from zingis-khan ever come this commandment unto you -lrb- 2 -rrb- a certain man name david come unto you as a ambassador from the moal but he be a liar and with he you send you ambassador to khen-khan after khen-khan be dead you ambassador come to this court and charmi he wife send you a nassick cloth but how could that wicked woman more vile than a dog know matter appertain to war and peace and to settle the great world in quiet those two monk who come from you to sartach be send by sartach to baatu but as mangu-khan be the greatest over the world of the moal baatu send they unto we and now that the great world of the frank and the priest and monk may live in peace and enjoy they goods and that the commandment of god might be hear among you we would have send certain moal as we ambassador to you by you priest but you messenger answer that betwixt we and you there be a warlike nation with many bad man and troublesome way so that they be afraid they could not bring we ambassador in safety to you but if we would deliver they we letter contain we commandment to king lodowick they engage to carry they for this cause we have not send we ambassador along with they but we have send you this the commandment of the eternal god by you priest and this be the commandment of the eternal god which we have give you to understand and when you shall hear and believe it if you will obey send you ambassador unto we so that we may be satisfied whether you will have peace or war when by the power of the eternal god the whole world shall be in unity peace and joy from the rising of the sun to where it set then shall it appear what we will do but if ye shall see and hear the commandment of the eternal god and will not hearken to or believe it say we country be far off we hill be strong we sea be great and in this confidence shall lead a army against we to know what we can do he that make what be hard easy and that which be far off near the eternal god himself know that alone while these thing be go forwards my companion hear that we be to return by the wilderness to baatu under the guidance of a moal on which he run to bulgai the chief secretary signify to he by sign that he should certainly die if he go that way on the day when we be to receive we pass which be a fortnight after the feast of st john 8th July the secretary say to he it be the pleasure of mangu that you companion shall return by baatu and as you be sick you may remain and shall be provide in necessaries till some ambassador come with whom you may return more easily by a way where there be village the friar answer god grant the khan a long and prosperous life i will remain then they bring we three garment say that as we refuse gold or silver and have stay long here pray for the khan he entreat that each would accept a single garment that you may not depart empty handed -lrb- 1 -rrb- explain as signify the sound of iron probably in allusion to he martial power -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- the obscurity of this passage be inexplicable -- e section xxxix _ the departure of rubruqui from the court of mangu-khan and he journey by saray and other place to tripoly in syrium _ leave the leskar or move camp of mangu-khan we come to caracarum and while we remain in the house of william bouchier the goldsmith my guide bring ten jascot five of which he deliver to william command he from the khan to expend these for the use of the friar while he remain there and he leave the other five with my interpreter for my subsistence by the way for william have give they such instruction without my knowledge i immediately change one of the jascot into small money which i distribute among the poor christian of caracarum another be spend in provide garment and other necessaries for we journey with the third my interpreter buy several article of which he afterwards make some profit the other two we expend on the road as after we come into persium sufficient necessaries be nowhere give we william you majesty citizen and subject send you a girdle set with a precious stone which be worn in those part as a defense against thunder and lightning and most humbly salute you always commend you to god in he prayer my companion and i part with tear he remain with master william while i with my interpreter the guide and one servant return to the court of baatu we guide have authority to take a sheep once in four day for the sustenance of all four from caracarum to the court of baatu we journey continue four month and ten day during all which time we never see a town or even the appearance of a single house except one village in which we do not even eat bread nor in all that time do we ever rest except one day when we could not get horse we return for the most part by the same kind of people through whom we have pass in go and yet through other country for we go in the winter and return in the summer by the higher part of the north except that for fifteen day journey we have to travel along a certain river among the mountain where there be no lodging except by the river side -lrb- 1 -rrb- sometimes we have to go two or even three day with no other food than cosmos and at one time we be in great danger not be able to fall in with any people we provision all exhaust and we horse quite tire when we have travel twenty day i hear that the king of armenia have pass by on he journey to the court of mangu in the end of August i meet with sartach who go to mangu accompany by he wife and child and with flock and herd yet the bulk of the family over whom he rule remain between the tanai and etilium or volga i send my duty to he say that i would willingly have remain in he country but that mangu have order I to return and carry he letter he answer be that i must obey the will of mangu-khan i then ask coiac to return we clothes and book what say he do you not bring they to sartach i say that i have certainly bring they to sartach but have not give they and put he in mind of what i have say on that former occasion to this he answer you say truth and none can resist the truth i leave you goods with my father who dwell in saray a new town which baatu have build on the eastern shore of the volga but we priest have some of you vestment if any thing please you say i keep it so that you restore my book i request letter from he to he father to restore my thing but he be in haste to be go and say that we should alight at the train of the lady which be near at hand and he should send I sartachs answer though i be fearful he might deceive I yet i dare not to contend with he late in the evening he messenger come with two coat seemingly all of silk say that sartach have send I these one for myself and that i might present the other to my king on he behalf i answer that i wear no such garment but should present both to my king in honor of he lord and i now send both by the bearer of these letter he deliver I also a letter for the father of coiac to restore all that belong to I we return to the court of baatu on the same day on which i have depart thence the year before be the second day after the invention of the holy cross 16th September 1254 and i find we young man in health though much afflict with poverty gosset tell I they have perish for want if the king of armenia have not comfort they and recommend they to sartach for the tartar believe i be dead and even ask they if they could keep ox and milk mare for if i have not return they have certainly be reduce to servitude after this baatu call I before he and make the letter which mangu-khan send you to be interpret to I he likewise demand what way i would go whether by sea or land i say the sea would be freeze as whiter be approach and i must therefore go by land and believe you majesty be still in syrium i direct my journey to persia for if i have know you be in france i would have go through hungary we have to travel a month with baatu before we could obtain a guide at length they appoint a jugur who understand i would give he nothing and that i wish to go by armenia cause we letter to be make for conduct I to the soldan of turkey hope he might there receive gift we leave the move court of baatu fifteen day before all saint 16th October and go direct southward for saraus always keep near the volga and there the volga divide into three branch or arm each almost twice as large as the branch of the nile at damieta besides these it divide into four lesser arm so that we have to pass seven branch of the river in boat : upon the middle branch be a village call sumerkant -lrb- 2 -rrb- without any wall but which be besiege by the tartar for eight year before they could gain possession and have formerly cost the saracen and alanus nine year for though not fortify it be surround by water we there find a german and he wife with whom gosset have live all the precede winter by the order of baatu on the east side of this river baatu always travel and sartach on the west never go farther south than this place as there be very good grass in great abundance coiac father on receive the letter of sartach restore my vestment except a surplice a alb a almic trim with fine silk a steal a girdle and a tualium adorn with gold embroidery he give I back likewise my silver plate except the censer and a small box for hold chrism all of which be with the priest who attend sartach and he return my book except we lady psalter which he keep with my leave as i could not deny he for he say sartach take great delight in it a bible also and a arabian book worth thirty sultany be retain and many other thing which i never recover saraus and the palace of baatu be on the east side of the river and the valley through which the arm of the river spread abroad be more than seven league in breadth after leave saraus on the feast of all saint 1st November we travel south till the feast of st martin 11th November when we come to the mountain of the alanus in fifteen day travel we find no people except at one little village where one of the son of sartach reside accompany by many falconer and falcon for the first five day we do not meet a single man and be a whole day and night in great danger of perish for want of water the alanus in some of the mountain still hold out against the tartar so that two of every ten of the subject of sartach be oblige to guard certain pass in the mountain of dagistan lest the alanian carry away the cattle in the plain there be likewise certain mahometan call lesghi in these mountain who be not subjugate so that the tartar have to give we a guard of twenty man to see we safe beyond the iron-gate i be glad of this circumstance as i have never see the tartar arm and yet of all those twenty only two have habergion which they say they have procure from the alanus who be excellent smith and armourer in my opinion the tartar have small store of armor except bow and arrow and leather jacket some have iron plate and skull cup from persium and i see two at the court of mangu arm with clumsy and unwieldy coat of rough hog-skin we find one castle of the alanian which have be subdue by the tartar about which there be many vineyard and there we drink wine for the first time on the follow day we reach derbent or the iron-gate build by alexander the macedonian on a small plain between the sea and the mountain one end of the city reach to the shore while the other extend a mile in length to the top of the mountain on which be a strong castle but the breadth of the city scarcely exceed a stone throw it have very strong wall and turret of large polished stone with no trench but the tartar have demolish the top of the turret and the bulwark of the wall two day journey from derbent we come to a city name samaron -lrb- 3 -rrb- in which there be many jew near which we see wall descend from the mountain to the sea and leave the way by the sea because it turn to the east we go up into the high country towards the south next day we pass through a valley in which we could perceive the foundation of wall stretch quite across between two mountain which be themselves quite impassable all these wall be erect of old by alexander for restrain the fierce nation of scythian shepherd inhabit the wilderness from invade the plain and city of the southern country of persium and asia minor there be also other wall and inclosure inhabit by jew next day we come to a great city call samach -lrb- 4 -rrb- and after this we enter the great plain of moan through which run the river cur or cyrus from which the curgus or curdus have they name whom we call georgian and which river pass through the middle of tefflis they capital the cur come directly from the west run east into the caspian and in it be excellent salmon -lrb- 5 -rrb- in the plain of moan or mogan we again meet with tartar and through this plain flow the arax which come from armenia the greater call likewise the land of ararat to the west of that plain be curgium -lrb- 6 -rrb- and in this plain the crosminus krosmian or korasmien -lrb- 7 -rrb- formerly dwelt gange or kanja a great city in the entrance of the mountain towards georgium be they capital and prevent the georgian from come down to plunder the plain country we next come to a bridge of boat fasten together with great iron chain for cross the unite stream of the kur and arax we proceed thence travel up the river call _ pontem inidignatus arax _ leave persium and the caspian mountain on we left hand towards the south curgium and the great sea on we right hand towards the west -lrb- 8 -rrb- go all the way southwards -lrb- 9 -rrb- we pass through the meadow of bacchu - khan the general of the tartar army on the arax who have likewise subjugate the curgus the turk and the persian there be another tartar governor of persium at tauri name argon who preside over the tribute but mangu-khan have recall both of these general to make way for one of he brother as i formerly mention who be to have the command in persium i be in the house of bacchu who give I wine while he drink cosmos and although it be the best new wine i would rather have have cosmos if he have offer it be more restorative for such a half starve wretch as i then be we ascend the arax to its head and beyond the mountain where it rise be the good city of arsorum -lrb- 10 -rrb- which belong to the soldan of turkey -lrb- 11 -rrb- when we depart from bacchu my guide go to tauri to speak with argon and take my interpreter with he but bacchu cause I to be carry to naxuam -lrb- 12 -rrb- formerly the capital of a great kingdom and the greatest and fairest city in those part but the tartar have now make it a wilderness there be formerly eight hundred church -lrb- 13 -rrb- of the armenian here which be now reduce to two very small one in one of which i hold my christmas as well as i could with we clerk gosset next day the priest of this church die and a bishop with twelve monk come from the mountain to he funeral for all the bishop of the armenian be monk and likewise most of those belong to the greek -lrb- 14 -rrb- in the city of naxuam i meet a catalan friar of the order of predicant name barnard who live with a friar of the holy sepulchre resident in georgium and possess extensive land there we be detain in naxuam by the snow till the 6th January 1255 and come in four day to the country of sabensa a curdish prince heretofore powerful but now tributary to the tartar who destroy all he warlike store zacharia the father of sabensa possess himself of all the country of the armenian from whence he drive out the saracen in this country there be many fine village of true christian have church like those of europe and every armenian have in he house in a honorable place a wooden hand hold a cross before which a lamp continually burn and that which we do by holy water they do with frankincense which they burn every evening through every corner of the house to drive away evil spirit i eat with sabensa and both he and he wife do I great reverence he son zachary a wise and comely young man ask I if you majesty would entertain he for though he have plenty of all thing he be so uneasy under the tartar dominion that he would rather retire to a strange country than endure they violent exaction these people say they be true son of the church and if the pope would send they aid they would bring all the neighbouring nation under subjection to the church of rome from naxuam we travel in fifteen day into the country of the soldan of turkey to a castle call marseugen inhabit by armenian curgian and greek the turk only have the dominion from that place where we arrive on the first Sunday of lend till i get to cyprus eight day before the feast of st john the baptist i be force to buy all we provision he who be my guide procure horse for we and take my money for the victuals which he put into he own pocket for when in the field he take a sheep from any flock he see by the way without leave or ceremony in the feast of the purification 2d February i be in a city name aynus belong to sabensa in a strong situation have a hundred armenian church and two mosque and in it a tartar officer reside at this place i meet five preach friar four of whom come from provence and the fifth join they in syrium they have but one sickly boy who could speak turkish and a little french and they have the pope letter of request to sartach baatu and mangu-khan that they might be suffer to continue in the country to preach the word of god but when i have tell they what i have see and how i be send back they direct they journey to teffli where there be friar of they order to consult what they should do i say that they might pass into tartary with these letter but they might lay they account with much labor and would have to give a account of the motive of they journey for have no other object but preach they would be little care for particularly as they have no ambassador i never hear what they do afterwards on the second Sunday in lend we come to the head of the arax and pass the mountain we come to the euphrate by which we descend eight day journey go to the west till we come to a castle name camath or kemac where the euphrate trend to the south towards halapium or aleppo we here pass to the north-west side of the river and go over very high mountain and through deep snow to the west there be so great a earthquake that year in this country that in one city call arsingan ten thousand person be say to have perish during three day journey we see frequent gap in the earth which have be cleft by the convulsion and great heap of earth which have tumble down from the mountain into the vally we pass through the valley where the soldan of the turk be vanquish by the tartar and a servant belong to my guide who be in the tartar army say the tartar do not exceed 10000 man whereas the soldan have 200000 horse in that plain there break out a great lake at the time of the earthquake and it come into my mind that the earth open she mouth to receive yet more blood of the saracen we remain in sebasta siwa or siva a town of the lesser armenia in the easter week and on the succeed Sunday we come to caesarium of capadocium now call kaisarea in about fifteen day make short journey we come to konieh or iconium this delay arise in part from the difficulty of procure horse but chiefly because the guide choose to stop often for three day together in one place to negotiate he own affair and though much dissatisfied i durst not complain as he might have slay I and we servant or sell we for slave and there be none to hinder it i find many frank at iconium and among these a merchant call nicholas de sancto syrio and he partner boniface de molandino who have a monopoly of all the alum of turkey from the soldan and by this mean they have raise the price so much that what use to sell for fifteen byzant be now sell for forty my guide present I to the soldan who say he would willingly get I convey to the sea of armenia or cilicium but the above merchant know that the turk make little account of I and that i be much distressed with my guide cause I to be convey to curruma -lrb- 15 -rrb- a port in the dominion of the king of armenia have remain here from before the ascension till after pentecost or near a fortnight i hear there be messenger arrive from the king to he father and i go to the king father to learn the news i find he surround by all he son except barum usin who reside in a certain castle and he tell I that he son be on he return and that mangu-khan have much ease he tribute grant he a privilege that no ambassador should come into he country on this the old man and all he son make a banquet and he cause I to be convey by sea to the haven call aijax -lrb- 16 -rrb- whence i pass over into cyprus and at nicosia i find we provincial who the same day carry I with he to antiochium -lrb- 17 -rrb- which be in a very weak state we be there on the feast of st peter and st paul 29th June and from thence we go to tripoli in syrium where the chapter of we order be hold on the assumption of the bless virgin 15th August 1255 we provincial be determine that i shall reside at acon -lrb- 18 -rrb- and will not suffer I to come to you majesty but command I to write what i will by the bearer of these present i would willingly see you highness and some spiritual friend in you kingdom and beseech you majesty to write we provincial to allow I to go to you and to return shortly again into the holy land i would have you majesty to understand that in turkey every tenth man be not a mahometan they be all armenian and greek and be rule over by child the soldan who be conquer by the tartar have a lawful wife of iberium by whom he have one feeble son whom he direct to succeed he as soldan he have another son by a greek concubine whom he commit to the guardianship of a certain great admiral the third he have by a turkish woman to whom many turk and turkoman have gather they propose to have slay all the soldan son by christian mother and if successful to have destroy all the church and to compel all to become mahometan on pain of death but he be overcome in battle and many of he man slay he recruit he army and venture a second battle in which he be defeat and take prisoner and still remain confine pacester the son of the greek concubine be soon afterwards make soldan as the other be weak whom they have send to the tartar the kindred by the mother side of this son such as the iberian and curd be much dissatisfied at he be deprive so that at this time a child ruleth in turkey have no treasure few soldier and many enemy the son of vestacius be weak and at war with the son of assan who be likewise a child and wear out with the servitude of the tartar if therefore a army of the church be now to come to the holy land it be easy to subdue all these country or to pass through they the king of hungary have not above 30000 soldier from cologne to constantinople be not above sixty day journey by waggon and from constantinople not so many to the country of the king of armenia in old time valiant man pass through all these country and prosper yet they have to contend with most valiant opponent whom god have now destroy out of the earth in this way we need fear no danger of the sea or the mercy of sailor and the price of freight would defray the expence by land i say confidently if we countryman would go as the king of the tartar do and would be contented with such victuals they might conquer the whole world it do not seem to I expedient that any more friar should be send to the tartar in the way i go or as the predicant friar go but if we lord the pope be to send a bishop in a honorable style capable to answer they folly he might speak unto they as he please for they will hear whatever a ambassador choose to speak and always demand if he will say any more but he ought to have many good interpreter and ought to be at large expence i have thus write to you highness accord to my weak power and understanding craving pardon from you clemency for my superfluity or want or for any thing that may be indiscreetly or foolishly write as from a man of little understanding not accustom to write long history the peace of god which passeth all understand preserve you heart and fortify you mind -lrb- 1 -rrb- the reason of the change be probably that they might fall in with the travel tartar camp who go northwards in the summer that they might procure food and change of horse
