-lrb- 18 -rrb- ptolomai or st john d'acre -- e chap x _ travels of haitho prince of armenia in tartary in 1254 -lrb- 1 -rrb- _ section i introduction haitho or hatto be the son of livon or leon ii nephew of haitho i king of armenia minor in lesser asia at the demise of he father he refuse to accept of the crown which he resign in favor of he brother thore or theodore but assist he and he son and successor leon iii in all the war and trouble in which they be engage during many year during the reign of he father in 1254 accompany by he wife and child he travel to the court of mangu-khan the great sovereign of the tartar or mongal for the purpose of obtain a abatement of the tribute which have be impose by these conqueror upon he country and appear to have be successful in he negotiation he journey into the east take place in the same year in which rubruqui be on he return and while at the court or leskar of sartach he be of material service to two of the attendant of rubruqui who have be leave at that station and who but for he interference must have perish by famine or would have be reduce to slavery forster assert that haitho meet with rubruqui who be then on he return home but we have already see in the account of the travels of rubruqui that the two traveller do not meet in the year 1305 when he must have become very old haitho become a monk of the praemonstratensian order at episcopium in cyprus he afterwards go to poitou in france where he dictate in french to nicholas salconus a history of the event which have occur in the east from the first commencement of the conquest of the tartar or mongal include the reign of zingis-khan and he successor to mangu-khan inclusively and a particular narrative of the history of he own country armenia minor from the reign of haitho i to that of leon ii both inclusive this account salconus translate into latin in 1307 by order of the reign pope the travels of haitho be perfectly contemporary with those of rubruqui be not sufficiently interesting to be here insert and the historical part of he relation have no connection with the plan of this work which it would swell beyond due bound : but the follow brief account of he geographical description of the east as it exist in the thirteenth century and as abstracted by j r forster in he voyage and discovery in the north have be deem worthy of insertion together with the observation or commentary of that ingenious author -lrb- 1 -rrb- forst hist of voy and disc in the north p 113 section ii _ geographical notice of the east in the thirteenth century by haitho _  1 the empire of _ kathay _ be one of the most extensive most opulent and most populous in the world and be entirely situate on the sea coast the inhabitant have a very high notion of they own superior intelligence which they express by say that they only of all the people on earth have _ two _ eye to the latin they allow _ one _ and consider all other nation as blind the kathayan have small eye and no beard they money consist of small square piece of paper impress with the seal of they emperor to the west this empire be bound by that of the tarsa to the north by the desert of belgian and to the south by the sea in which there be innumerable island the inhabitant of kathay be exceedingly skilful and ingenious in all work of art and in manufacture but be of a very timorous disposition in the foregoing description and in the trait of character the empire and inhabitant of northern china be distinctly indicate -- forst  2 the empire of _ tarsa _ be divide into three province each of which have a sovereign who assume the title of king the inhabitant be call jogur the jugur or uigur of other author they be divide into many tribe ten of whom be christian and the rest heathen they abstain from every article of food which have ever have life and drink no wine but raise abundance of corn they town be very pleasant and contain great number of idol temple they be not incline to war but learn all art and science with great facility and have a particular manner of write which be adopt by all the neighbouring nation to the east this country be bound by kathay to the west by turkestan to the north by a extensive desert and to the south by a very rich province name sym or peim in which diamond be find and which be situate between kathay and indium it appear that haitho here describe the country of the uigur in conjunction with that of the gete : but how it come to receive the name of tarsae i know not -- _ forst _  3 _ turkestan _ be bound on the east by the empire of tarsae to the west by khorasmin or khuaresm and to the south it extend to the desert which form the northern frontier of indium in this country there be few good town but many extensive plain which afford excellent pasturage to cattle and the inhabitant be almost universally shepherd and tender of cattle they dwell mostly in tent and in hut which can be transport from place to place they cultivate only a small quantity of corn and have no wine they drink be beer and milk and they subsist upon meat with rice and millet the people be know by the name of turk and be of the mahometan religion such of they as live in town use the arabian letter ocerra or otrar be the capital of this country  4 _ khorasmin _ or khuaresm be a populous pleasant and fertile country contain many good and strong town the capital be khorasme the country produce abundance of corn and very little wine this empire border on a desert of a hundred day journey in extent to the west be the caspian sea to the north kumanium and to the east turkestan the inhabitant be heathen without letter or law the soldinus be the most intrepid of warrior have a particular language of they own for which they employ the greek character in write and they follow the usage and rite of the greek church be subject in spiritual to the patriarch of antioch accord to ulug-beg who be himself prince of this country the capital of khuaresm be the city of korkang and no author except haitho have ever mention a place call khorasme the soldinus whom he mention as christian of the greek church be unknown perhaps they may have be the sogdian -- _ forst _  5 _ kumanium _ be of vast extent but owe to the inclemency of its climate be very thinly inhabit in some part the cold be so intense in winter that neither man nor beast can remain in they and in other part the heat be so extreme and they be so infested with swarm of fly as to be quite intolerable the whole country be flat and level and without wood except some orchard near the town the inhabitant live in tent and use the dung of they cattle as fuel it be bound on the east by a desert towards khorasmium to the west be the great sea or euxine and the sea of tenue tanna or azof to the north be the empire of kaffia or kiow and to the south it extend to the great river etile or wolga which pass the capital this river be freeze over every year and man and beast walk upon the ice as on dry land along the bank of the river be many small tree and on the other side of the river the country be inhabit by a people who though not kumanian be subject to the khan some live towards the high mountain of coca or caucasus in which there be white kite this range of mountain extend between the black sea or euxine on the west and the caspian on the east this latter have no connection with the ocean but be a vast lake call a sea on account of its extent be the largest lake in the world and contain a great quantity of excellent fish it divide asia into two part that to the east be call _ lower _ asia and that to the west _ greater _ asia in the caspian mountain abundance of buffalo and many other wild beast be find in this sea there be many island to which numerous bird resort to breed particularly the falcon call _ pegrim _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- _ esmetlione _ -lrb- 2 -rrb- and _ bousaceus _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- and many other bird not to be find elsewhere the largest town of kumanium be sara or saray which be large and of great renown but have be ravage and almost entirely destroy by the tartar who take it by storm it be obvious that haitho here describe that part of the empire of the mongal which be subject to baatu-khan the euxine or black sea he call the _ great sea _ the sea of tenue be that of tanna or azof the town at the mouth of the tanai or don have be know by both of these name the former evidently derive from the ancient name of the river or the river from the town and of which the modern name don be a mere corruption the empire of kaffia be obviously that of kiow kiovium or kiavium long the capital of the russian empire and the residence of the czar or great duke -- forst  6 beyond the great mountain of belgian or bilkhan the tartar live formerly without religion or the knowledge of letter be chiefly employ in tend they flock and be so far from warlike that they readily submit to pay tribute to any neighbouring prince who make the demand all the tribe of the tartar be know by the name of mogle mogul or mongal and in process of time they increase so much as to form seven populous independent nation the first be call tartar after a province of that name which be they original habitation the second tangot tangut or tongusian the third kunat the fourth jalair or thalair the fifth sonich the sixth monghus and the seventh tabeth prompt by a vision and a command from god the chief of these nation choose changus or zinghi to be they sovereign ruler or great khan and we be tell that when he come down from the mountain of belgian the sea withdraw nine foot and make a way for he where there be none before this seem to be the same history with that of irganekon which be also relate by abulgasi the mountain belgian must be look for in the environs of lake baleha in the country of organum or irganekon accord to the nighiaristan a collection of oriental history the turkomannus likewise come from a place call belgian or bilkhan -- forst -lrb- 1 -rrb- faucon pelerin the pilgrim falcon -- forst -lrb- 2 -rrb- esmerlione or merlin -- forst -lrb- 3 -rrb- the bondree and sacre or the honey-buzzard and sacre -- forst chap xi _ travels of marco polo through tartary china the island of indium and most of asia from a d 1260 to 1295 -lrb- 1 -rrb- _ nicolo polo the father of this intelligent early traveller and maffeus polo he uncle be venetian gentleman engage in commerce and appear to have go into the east in the prosecution of they trade in the year 1260 they reside far some time at the court of kublai-khan the great emperor of the mongal or tartar and return to venice in 1269 they find that the wife of nicolo have die during they absence leave a son marco the author of the follow travels of whom she be pregnant at the time of they departure these circumstance be detail in the first section of this chapter but the date which have be usually assign for the commencement of this first journey 1250 be evidently corrupt as will appear from the follow consideration derive from a comparison of the chronology of the king and prince who be mention in the travels as reign at the time the high probability be that the obvious mistake of assume the year 1250 as the era of the first journey arise from a careless substitution of the figure 5 for 6 in transcription assume the correct date of 1260 as the commencement of the first journey of nicolo and maffeus polo this will appear to be consonant with the chronology of the prince with whose reign they travels be connect while the date of 1250 adopt by ramusio and muller be totally irreconcilable with the truth of history they remain one year at the leskar or camp of bereke-khan whence they travel into bochara where they tarry three year from thence they spend one year on they journey to the court of kublai-khan and be three year on they journey back to venice but as they remain some time at the residence of kublai-khan one year may be allow for that circumstance and this first journey may therefore be allow to have occupy nine year in all kublai-khan reign supreme emperor of the mongal from 1259 to 1294 in which last year he die at eighty year of age if therefore nicolo and maffeus have set out upon they first journey in 1250 they must have arrive at the imperial residence of cambalu or pekin in 1255 at the latest or four year before kublai-khan ascend the throne they first journey commence while baldwin ii be emperor of constantinople who reign from 1234 to 1261 the khan of kiptschak or the western division of the vast empire of the mongal at the time of this journey be bereke who rule from 1256 to 1266 holagu-khan who be then at war with bereke do not begin to reign till 1258 hence it follow that they could not have commence they first journey at the very earliest before 1258 or 1259 rather as it be not to be suppose that holagu would enter upon a dangerous war in the first year of he reign upon the whole therefore the date of 1260 for the commencement of the first journey as already observe be perfectly consistent with the chronology of history the year of they return to venice 1269 be agree upon on all hand and as marco be bear in the first year of they absence he would then be about nine year of age ramusio who date the commencement of the first journey in 1250 suppose marco to have be fifteen year of age at the return of he father and uncle which be absurd as if the era assume by ramusio be possibly true he must then have be in he nineteenth year accord to the opinion of mr j r forster the commencement of the second journey in which marco be engage must have be in 1271 and he found this opinion on the circumstance that gregory ix have then be elect pope from whom they carry letter for kublai-khan but it will appear from the travels themselves that the three polo have commence they journey previously to the election of that sovereign pontiff and that they be detain some time in armenia in consequence of a express send after they for the purpose that they might there wait for he final instruction they may therefore have commence this second journey in 1270 we only know however that they set out from venice for a second journey into tartary soon after they return from the first in 1269 and that they carry young marco along with they on he appearance at the court of cambalu kublai-khan take a fancy to the young venetian and cause he to be instruct in four of the principal language which be speak in the extensive dominion of the mongal marco be afterwards employ by the khan for a considerable number of year in several important affair as will appear in the relation of he travels at length the three polo return to venice in 1295 after a absence of twenty-five or twenty-six year during which long period they have never be hear of by they friend and countryman seventeen year of which marco have be employ in the service of the great khan on they return to they own house in venice they be entirely forget by they relation and former acquaintance and have considerable difficulty to establish they identity and to get themselves recognize by they family and be oblige to use extraordinary means to recover the respect which be they due and a acknowledgement of they name family and rank the particulars of which will be find in the travels themselves about three year after the return of these adventurous traveller hostility arise between the republic of genoa and venice the genoese admiral lampa dorium come to the island of curzolum with a fleet of seventy gally to oppose whom the venetian fit out a great naval force under andrea dandolo under whom marco polo have the command of a galley the venetian be totally defeat in a great naval engagement with the loss of they admiral and eighty-five ship and marco polo have the misfortune to be among the number of the prisoner harri allege that he remain a prisoner during several year in spite of every offer of ransom that be make for he liberation but in this he must have mistake or be mislead by the authority which he trust to as peace be conclude in 1299 the year immediately subsequent to the naval engagement in which he be make prisoner while in prison at genoa many of the young nobility be say to have resort to marco to listen to the recital of he wonderful travels and surprize adventure and they be say to have prevail upon he to send to venice for the note which he have draw up during he peregrination by means of which the follow relation be say to have be write in latin from have dictation from the original latin the account of he travels be afterwards translate into italian and from this again abridgement be afterwards make in latin and diffuse over europe accord to barettus -lrb- 2 -rrb- the travels of marco polo be dictate by he in 1299 while in the prison of genoa to one rustigielo a inhabitant of pisa who be he fellow prisoner they be afterwards publish in italian and subsequently translate into latin by pessurus a dominican monk of bologna copy of the original manuscript though write in the venetian dialect which be extremely different from the tuscan or pure italian be multiply with great rapidity in all part of italy and even make they way into france and germany from one or more of these corrupt by the carelessness or ignorance of transcriber some of whom may have abridge the work or may even have interpolate it from other source a thing quite common before the invention of print the latin translation may have be make and circulate over europe ramusio a early editor of voyage and travels publish these travels in a italian translation from the latin which he erroneously suppose to have be the original dictation of marco to rustigielo and many other edition have be publish in the various language of europe but all from one or other of these corrupted transcript or translation a manuscript of the travels of marco polo in the venetian dialect be long preserve by the soranza family at venice but whether this now exist or have ever be publish be unknown mr pinkerton inform we -lrb- 3 -rrb- that a genuine edition of these travels probably from the original m either of marco himself after he return from genoa or from that of he amanuensis rustigielo be publish at trevigus in 1590 in the dialect of venice which have hitherto escape the attention of all editor and commentator this curious publication be often word in the name of all the three traveller father uncle and son but when the peculiar travels of marco be indicate he name only be employ in the former case the language run thus _ we _ nicolo maffeus and marco have hear see and know & c : in the latter i marco be in that place and see & c in this venetian edition the name of place and person be often widely different from those in the other edition and probably more genuine and correct but that publication be at present inaccessible we be under the necessity of be contented with the edition of harri in which he profess to have carefully collate the edition of ramusio with most of the other translation and with a original m in the royal library of prussium this latter labor however he seem to have take entirely upon trust from muller a german editor and translator probably through the intermediation of bergeron a early french editor of voyage and travel the only freedom which have be assume in the present edition be by divide it into section for more ready consultation and reference and by the addition of explanatory note from various source marco polo be the chief of all the early modern discoverer have be the first who communicate to europe any distinct idea of the immense region of asia from the euxine eastward through the vast extent of tartary to china and japan and the very first author who have make any mention of that distant insular sovereignty even columbus be suppose with some considerable probability to have be prompt to he enterprize which end in the discovery of america by the study of these travels believe that by a western course through the unexplored atlantic he should find a comparatively short passage to those eastern region of the indy which polo have visit describe or indicate in this view he be however so far mislead in he estimation of the distance by the erroneously spread-out longitude of ptolomy bring these region much farther towards the east and consequently nearer by the west than they actual situation and be stop in he western course by the important and unexpected discovery of many island and a vast interpose continent which from preconceived theory he name the west indy such be the account of these travels which have be hand down to we from various source and which they importance and intrinsic merit have induce we to record at some length of these adventurous traveller some notice yet remain which may be worthy of be preserve signior maffio polo the uncle of marco become a magistrate of venice and live for some time in much respect among he countryman nicolo polo the father of marco be say to have marry during the captivity of he son at genoa and to have leave three child by this second marriage marco himself marry after he return to venice from genoa and leave two daughter moretta and fantina but have no male issue he be say to have receive among he countryman the name of marco millionus because he and he family have acquire a fortune of a million of ducat in the east he die as he have live universally beloved and respect by all who know he for with the advantage of birth and fortune he be humble and beneficent and employ he great riches and the interest he possess in the state only to do good -lrb- 1 -rrb- harri i 593 forst voy and disc p 117 modern geogr ii xvi -lrb- 2 -rrb- ital libr p iv -lrb- 3 -rrb- mod geogr ii xvi section i _ introductory general account of the whole travels from the commencement of the first journey of nicolo and maffeus polo in 1260 to they final return along with marco to venice in 1295 _ -lrb- illustration : map of the eastern part of tartary & adjacent country -rrb- in the year 1260 when baldwin be emperor of continople two brother of a illustrious family at venice nicolo and maffeus polo embark in a vessel which be laden with a various assortment of merchandize on they own account and after traverse the mediterranean and bosphoro with a fair wind they arrive in safety at constantinople have remain for some time in the imperial city they cross the great sea to soldadium -lrb- 1 -rrb- from thence they go to the court of a tartar prince name barha -lrb- 2 -rrb- who live in the town of bolgara and alsara -lrb- 3 -rrb- to this prince they shew the fine jewel which they have bring for sale and present he with some of the most valuable he be far from ungrateful for they present which he kindly accept and for which he make they return of greater value have remain a whole year at he court they be desirous of return to venice but before they have any opportunity of depart a war break out between barha and another tartar prince name arau -lrb- 4 -rrb- the army of these rival come to a battle in which barha be defeat and oblige to fly by this unfortunate incident the road to the westwards become quite unsafe for the journey of the polo and they be advise to make a large circuit round the north and east frontier of the dominion of barha and by which route they make they escape from the seat of war to guthacam a town on the tygri -lrb- 5 -rrb- a little farther on they cross the gihon one of the four river of paradise and travel afterwards for seventeen day in the desert in which they see neither town castle nor village and only a few tartar dwelling in hut or tent leave the desert they come to a considerable city name bochara on the frontier of persium then the residence of a prince call barach -lrb- 6 -rrb- who give they a good reception and be unable to proceed any farther on account of the great war which then rage among the tartar they remain there for three year at that time there come to bochara a person of distinction who be go as ambassador from holagu to kublai-khan the great emperor of all the tartar who reside in the remotest country of the earth betwixt the north-east and the east meeting with the brother who have now become well verse in the tartarian language he be much take with they conversation and persuade they to accompany he to the court of the great khan know that he should gratify he in this circumstance and promise they that they should be receive with great honor and gratify with large reward they be well aware that it be utterly impossible for they to return home at this period without the most imminent danger and agree to this proposal take with they some christian servant whom they have bring from venice and travel toward the north-east they employ a whole year on the journey be often oblige to wait the melting of the snow and the decrease of the flood which obstruct they passage at length they arrive at the residence of the great khan and be bring into he presence be most courteously receive and treat with great distinction he interrogate they much concern many thing relative to the country of the west particularly respect the roman emperor -lrb- 7 -rrb- and the other king and prince of europe the form of they different government the nature number and discipline of they military force how peace justice and concord be establish and maintain among they of the manners and custom of the different european nation and concern the pope the discipline of the church and the tenet of the christian faith to all this nicolo and maffeus make proper and suitable reply as prudent and wise man declare the truth and speak orderly in the tartarian language with which the emperor be well satisfy as he acquire a knowledge of the affair of the european insomuch that he often command they to be bring into he presence after some time kublai-khan have consult with he great lord inform they that he be desirous to send they as he ambassador to the pope of the roman accompany by one of he lord name chogatal -lrb- 8 -rrb- request that he would send a hundred man learn in the christian religion to he court that they might instruct he wise man that the faith of the christian be preferable to all other sect be the only way of salvation that the god of the tartar be devil and that they and other people of the east be deceive in the worship of these god he likewise command they on they return from jerusalem to bring he some of the oil from the lamp which burn before the sepulchre of we lord jesus christ to whom the emperor have great devotion believe he to be the true god yield due reverence to the great khan they promise faithfully to execute the charge which he have commit to they and to present to the pope the letter in the tartarian language which he give they for that purpose accord to the custom of the empire the great khan cause to be give they a golden tablet engraven and sign with the mark or signet of the khan in virtue of which instead of a passport the bearer be entitle to be everywhere convey in safety through dangerous place by the governor of province and city throughout the whole empire have they expence everywhere defray and should be furnish with whatever be needful for they and they attendant in all place and for as long as they might have occasion to stay take they leave of the great khan they set out upon the journey into the west carry with they the letter to the pope and the golden tablet after travel twenty day the tartar lord who be associate in they embassy to the pope fall grievously sick on which have consult upon what be best to be do they resolve to leave he and to continue they journey they be everywhere courteously receive through the authority of the imperial tablet yet they be often compel to wait by the overflow of the river in the course of they journey so that they spend three year before they reach the port in the country of the armenian call giazza -lrb- 9 -rrb- from thence they proceed to acre -lrb- 10 -rrb- where they arrive in the month of April 1269 on they arrival at acre they be inform of the death of pope clement iv by tibaldo viscontus of placentium the papal legate who then reside in that place they relate to he what have befall they and declare what commission they have receive from the great khan to the pope and he advise to wait the creation of a new pope to whom they might deliver they letter upon this they take shipping for venice by the way of negropont intend to visit they friend and relation and to remain there until a new pope should be elect on they arrival nicolo find that he wife be dead whom he have leave pregnant at he departure but that she have leave a son now nineteen -lrb- 11 -rrb- year of age who be this very _ marco _ the author of this book in which he will make manifest all those thing which he have see in he travels the election of the pope be defer two year and the polo become afraid least the great khan might be displeased at they delay they go therefore back to acre carry marco along with they and have go to jerusalem for the holy oil request by kublaus they receive letter from the legate testify they fidelity to the great khan and that a pope be not yet choose they then set out on they journey and go to giazza in armenia in the mean time letter come from the cardinal to the legate viscontus declare that he be elect pope and he assume the name of gregory on this the new pope send messenger to the polo to call they back or to delay they departure from armenia until he might prepare other letter for they to present to the khan in he name and to inform they that he mean to join two friar predicant in commission with they nicolo of vicenza and guelmo of tripolus man of learning and discretion the polo accordingly remain at giazza where these two monk arrive with letter and present of great value for the khan and furnish with ample power and privilege and authority to ordain priest and bishop and to grant absolution in all case as fully as if the pope be present but learn that the sultan of babylon bentiochda -lrb- 12 -rrb- be lead a great army to invade armenia and where he commit the most cruel ravages the two friar become afraid of themselves and deliver the letter and present of the pope to nicolo maffeus and marco and to avoid the fatigue of the way and the danger of war they remain with the master of the temple then at giazza and return with he to acre but the three venetian proceed boldly through many danger and difficulty and at length after a journey of three year and a half they arrive at the great city of clemenisu -lrb- 13 -rrb- in this lengthen journey they have often long stoppage on account of the deep snow and extreme cold and on occasion of flood and inundation when the khan hear of they approach though yet at a great distance he send messenger forty day journey to meet they that they might be conduct with all honor and to provide they with every accommodation during the remainder of they journey on they arrival at the court and be introduce into the presence they prostrate themselves before the khan on they face accord to the customary form of reverence and be command to rise be most graciously receive the khan then demand a account of the many danger through which they have pass by the way and of they proceedings with the pope of the roman all this they distinctly related and deliver to he the letter and present from the pope with which the khan be well pleased and give they great commendation for they care and fidelity they present to he also the oil which they have bring from the holy sepulchre of the lord at jerusalem which he reverently receive and give order that it should be honourably preserve the khan inquire who marco be on which nicolo reply he be you majesty 's servant and my son the khan graciously receive he with a friendly countenance and have he teach to write among he honorable courtier whereupon he be much respect by all the court and in a little time make himself familiar with the custom of the tartar and learn to read and write four different language after some time the great khan to make experience of he capacity send marco upon a mission or embassy to a great city call carachan or zarazan at such a distance as he could scarcely travel in six month he execute the commission with which he have be entrust with judgment and discretion and perfectly to the satisfaction of the khan : and know that the khan would be delighted with a account of all the novelty in the place through which he have to pass he diligently inquire into the manners and custom of the people the condition of the country and every thing worthy of be remark make a memorial of all he know or see which he present to the great khan for he information and amusement by this mean he get so much into the favor of the khan that during the twenty-six year which he continue in he service he be continually send through all he realm and dependency chiefly on affair of government but sometimes on he own private matter by the khan 's order and this be the true reason that he should have see and learn so many particulars relate to the east as he have declare in these he memoirs after stay many year in the court of the great khan and have become very rich in jewel of great value and consider that if the khan who be now grow very old should happen to die they should never be able to return home the venetian become exceedingly anxious to be permit to return to they own country wherefore one day that he find the khan in extraordinary good humor nicolo begged permission to return home with he family at this the khan be much displeased and ask what could induce they to undertake so long and dangerous a journey add that if they be in want of riches he would gratify they utmost wish by bestow upon they twice as much as they possess but out of pure affection he refuse to give they leave to depart it happen however not long after this that a king of the indy name argon send three of he counsellor name ulatai apusca and coza as ambassador to kublai-khan on the follow occasion bolgana the wife of argon be lately dead and on she death-bed have request of she husband that he should choose a wife from among she relation in kathay kublum yield to this request and choose a fair young maiden of seventeen year of age name cogalin -lrb- 14 -rrb- who be of the family of the late queen bolgana and determine to send she to argon the ambassador depart with they charge and journey eight month the same way they have come to the court of kublaus but find bloody war rage among the tartar insomuch that they be constrain to return and to acquaint the great khan with the impossibility of they proceeding home in that road in the mean time marco have return from the indy where he have be employ with certain ship in the service of the khan to whom he have report the singularity of the place which he have visit and the facility of intercourse by sea between kathay and the indy this come to the knowledge of the ambassador who confer with the venetian on the subject and it be agree that the ambassador and the young queen should go to the great khan and beg permission to return by sea and should request to have the three european who be skilful in sea affair to accompany and conduct they to the dominion of king argon the great khan be much dissatisfied with this proposal yet at the earnest entreaty of the ambassador he at length give he consent and call nicolo maffeus and marco into he presence after much demonstration of he favor and affection he make they promise to return to he after they have spend some time in christendom among they relation and he cause a tablet of gold to be give they on which he command be engraven for they liberty security and free passage throughout all he dominion and that all the expence of they and they attendant should be defray provide they everywhere with guide and escort where necessary he authorize they also to act as he ambassador to the pope and the king of france and spain and all other christian prince the khan order fourteen ship to be prepare for the voyage each have four mast and carry nine sail four or five of these be so large as to have from 250 to 260 mariner in each but the rest be smaller in this fleet the queen and the ambassador embark accompany by nicolo maffeus and marco have first take leave of the great khan who present they at parting with many ruby and other precious stone and a sum or money sufficient to defray all they expence for two year set sail from kathay or china they arrive in three month at a island call java and sailing from thence they arrive in eighteen month in the dominion of king argon six hundred of the mariner and other die during the voyage and but one woman and only coza of the three ambassador survive on arrive at the dominion of argon he be find to be dead and a person name ghiacato or aka govern the kingdom for he son casan who be under age on make the regent acquaint with they business he desire they to carry the young queen to casan who be then on the confines of persium towards arbor secco -lrb- 15 -rrb- with a army of 60000 man guard certain pass of the frontier against the enterprise of they enemy have execute this order nicolo maffeus and marco return to the residence of chiacato and staid there for nine month at the end of this period they take leave of chiacato who give they four tablet of gold each a cubit long and five finger broad and weigh three or four mark -lrb- 16 -rrb- on these be engraven to the follow purport : in the power of the eternal god the name of the great khan shall be honor and praise for many year and whosoever disobeyeth shall he put to death and all he goods confiscate besides this preamble they farther command that all due honor should be show to the three ambassador of the khan and service perform to they in all the country and district subject to he authority as to himself in person that all necessary relay of horse and escort and they expence and every thing needful should be supply to they freely and gratuitously all this be duly execute so that sometimes they have 200 horse for they safeguard during they journey they be inform that the great emperor of the tartar kublai-khan be dead by which they consider themselves absolve from all obligation of the promise they have make to return to he court they continue they journey to trebisond on the south side of the euxine whence they proceed by the way of constantinople and negropont to venice where they arrive in safety and with great riches in the year 1295 on they arrival at they own house in the street of st chrysostom in venice they find themselves entirely forget by all they old acquaintance and countryman and even they relation be unable to recognize they owe to they long absence now thirty-five year from set out on they first journey into the east besides be much alter by age they have become altogether resemble tartar in they speech dress and manners and be oblige to use some extraordinary expedient to satisfy they family and countryman of they identity and to recover the respect which be they due by a public acknowledgment of they name family and rank for this purpose they invite all they relation arid connection to a magnificent entertainment at which all the three traveller make they appearance in rich eastern habit of crimson satin after the guest be seat and before the polo sit down they put off they upper garment which they give to the attendant appear still magnificently dress in habit of crimson damask these they throw off at the appearance of the last course or service of the entertainment and bestow likewise on the attendant while they themselves still appear clad in magnificent dress of crimson velvet when dinner be over and all the servant have withdraw marco polo produce to the company the coat of tartarian cloth or feel which he and he father and uncle have ordinarily worn during they travels from the fold of which he take out a incredible quantity of rich jewel among which be some that be well know to those who be present at the entertainment and by which the three traveller incontestibly prove themselves member of the polo family and the identical person they represent themselves -lrb- 1 -rrb- the black-sea or euxine be here call the _ great _ -lrb- 16 -rrb- these be most princely letters-patent equal in weight to 400 guinea perhaps equal in efficacious value to 4000 in we time -- e section ii _ description of armenia the lesser of the country of the turk of greater armenia zorzanium the kingdom of mosul of the city of bagdat and tauri and account of a strange miracle -lrb- 1 -rrb- _ there be two armenia the greater and the lesser in the lesser armenia the king reside in a city call sebaste and in all this country justice and good government be strictly enforce this kingdom have many city fortress and castle the soil be fertile and the country abound with game and wildfowl and every necessary article of provision but the air be not very good formerly the armenian gentleman be brave man and good soldier but be now become effeminate and addict to drinking and debauchery the city of giazza on the black sea have a excellent harbor to which merchant resort from diver country even from venice and genoa for several sort of merchandize especially for the different kind of spice and various other valuable goods which be bring here from indium as this place be the settled market for the commodity of the east turcomanium be inhabit by three different nation turcoman greek and armenian the turcoman who be mahometan be a rude illiterate and savage people inhabit the mountain and inaccessible place where they can procure pasture as they subsist only on the produce of they flock and herd in they country there be excellent horse call turkish horse and they mule be in great estimation the greek and armenian possess the city and town and employ themselves in manufacture and merchandize making especially the best carpet in the world they chief city be cogno or iconium caesarea and sebaste where st basil suffer martyrdom this country be under subjection to one of the khan of the tartar the greater armenia be a large province subject to the tartar which have many city and town the principal of which be arsugium in which the best buckram in the world be make in this neighborhood there be excellent hot spring which be celebrate as salutary bath in many disease the city next in consequence be argiron and darziz in the summer season many tartar resort to this country on account of the richness of the pasture and retire again in winter because of the abundance of snow the ark of noah rest on arrarat one of the mountain of armenia this country have the province of mosul and meridin on the east or diarbekir and on the north be zorzanium -lrb- 2 -rrb- where there be a fountain that discharge a liquid resemble oil which though it can not be use as a seasoning for meat be yet useful for burn in lamp and for many other purpose and it be find in sufficient quantity to load camel and to form a material object of commerce in zorzanium be a prince name david melic or king david one part of the province be subject to he while the other part pay tribute to a tartar khan the wood be mostly of box-trees zorzanium extend between the euxine and caspian sea which latter be likewise call the sea of baccu and be 2800 mile in circumference : but be like a lake as it have no communication with any other sea in it there be many island city and castle some of which be inhabit by the people who flee from the tartar out of persium the people of zorzanium be christian observe the same rite with other and wear they hair short like the western clergy there be many city and the country abound in silk of which they make many fine manufacture moxul or mosul be a province contain many sort of people some be call arahus who be mahometan other be christian of various sect as nestorian jacobite and armenian and they have a patriarch stile jacolet who ordain archbishop bishop and abbot whom he send all over indium and to cairo and bagdat and wherever there be christian in the same manner as be do by the pope of rome all the stuff of gold and silk call _ musleim _ be work in moxul -lrb- 3 -rrb- in the mountain of this country of diarbekir dwelt the people call curd some off whom be nestorian or jacobite and other mahometan they be a lawless people who rob the merchant that travel through they country near to they be another province call mu meridin or mardin higher up the tigri than mosul wherein grow great quantity of cotton of which they make buckram -lrb- 4 -rrb- and other manufacture this province be likewise subject to the tartar baldach or bagdat be a great city in which the supreme caliph formerly reside who be pope of all the saracen from this city it be count seventeen day journey to the sea but the river tigri run past on which people sail to balsora where the best date in the world grow but in the passage between these two city there lie another name chisus in bagdat be many manufacture of gold and silk and damask and velvet with figure of various creature in that city there be a university where the law of mahoment physic astronomy and geomancy be teach and from it come all the pearl in christendom when the tartar begin to extend they conquest there be four brother who possess the chief rule of whom mangu the eldest reign in sedium -lrb- 5 -rrb- these brethren propose to themselves to subdue the whole world for which purpose one go to the east another to the north a third to the west and ulau or houlagu go to the south in 1250 with a army of a hundred thousand horse besides foot employ stratagem he hide a great part of he force in ambush and advance with a inconsiderable number entice the caliph to follow he by a pretended flight by this mean he take the caliph prisoner and make himself master of the city in which he find such infinite store of treasure that he be quite amaze send for the caliph into he presence he sharply reprove he that possess such riches he have not employ they in provide soldier to defend he dominion and command he to be shut up in the tower where he treasure be place without any sustenance this seem a just judgment from we lord jesus christ upon the caliph for in the year 1225 seek to convert the christian to the mahometan superstition and take advantage of that passage in the gospel which say he that have faith as a grain of mustard seed shall be able to remove mountain he summon all the christian nestorian and jacobite and give they they choice in ten day to remove a certain mountain to turn mahometan or to be slay allege that there be not one among they who have the least grain of faith the astonished and dismayed christian continue ten day in prayer when by a revelation to a certain bishop a certain shoemaker be choose to perform this compulsatory miracle this shoemaker be once tempt to lust in fitting a shoe to a young woman and have literally and zealously perform the injunction of the gospel by put out he right eye on the day appoint by the caliph he and all the christian of the city follow the cross towards the mountain then lift up he hand he pray to god to have mercy on he afflict people and in a loud voice command the mountain in the name of the holy and ever bless trinity to remove : which it presently do to the great astonishment and terror of the caliph and all he people the anniversary of this day and the evening before be ever since keep holy by fast and prayer -lrb- 6 -rrb- -lrb- 1 -rrb- marco polo have spend much the largest portion of he life among the tartar necessarily use they name for the country place and people which he describe and these name have be subsequently much disfigure in transcription this have occasion great perplexity to commentator in endeavor to explain he geography conformably with modern map and which even be often impossible to be do with any tolerable certainty the arrangement likewise of he description be altogether arbitrary so that the sequence do not serve to remove the difficulty and the section appear to have be draw up in a desultory manner just as they occur to he recollection or as circumstance in the conversation or inquiry of other occasion he to commit he knowledge to paper -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- gurgistan usually call georgium -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- this manufacture from mosul or moxul on the they pretend to have see -- e section iii _ of the country of persium the city of jasdus cermam and camandu and the province of reobarle _ tauri be a great city in the province of hircanium -lrb- 1 -rrb- and be a very populous place the inhabitant live by the exercise of manufacture and trade fabricate especially stuff of silk and gold the foreign merchant who reside there make very great gain but the inhabitant be generally poor they be a mixed people of nestorian armenian jacobite georgian persian and mahometan these last be perfidious and treacherous people who think all well get which they can filch or steal from those of other religion and this wickedness of the saracen have induce many of the tartar to join they religion and if a saracen be kill by a christian even while engage in the act of robbery he be esteem to have die a martyr it be twelve day journey from tauris to persium -lrb- 2 -rrb- in the confines stand the monastery of st barasam of which the monk resemble carmelite : they make girdle which they lay on the altar and give to they friend who esteem they as holy persium be divide into eight kingdom _ viz _ casbin curdistan -lrb- 3 -rrb- laristan susistan or chorassan spahan ispahan or far shira -lrb- 4 -rrb- soncara -lrb- 5 -rrb- and lastly timochaim which be near arboreseco towards the north -lrb- 6 -rrb- persium breed excellent horse which be sell to the indy also very good ass which be sell for a higher price than the horse because they eat little carry much and travel far they have camel also which though not swift be necessary in these country which sometimes for a long way yield no grass or water the people in these country be very wicked and covetous thief and murderer kill the merchant unless they travel in caravan yet they profess to follow the law of mahomet in the city there be excellent artificer in gold silk and embroidery and the country abound with silk-worm wheat barley millet and other kind of grain with plenty of fruit and wine and though wine be forbid by the mahometan law they have a gloss to correct or corrupt the text say that when boil it change its taste and name and may be then drink jasdus be a great city on the confines of persium which carry on a great trade and have many manufacture of silk chiaman -lrb- 7 -rrb- be a kingdom on the frontier of persium to the east which be subject to the tartar in the vein of the mountain the stone commonly call turquoise be find and other valuable jewel they here make all sort of warlike weapon and the woman work admirably with the needle in silken embroidery on which they pourtray the figure of various animal in a most beautiful manner they have the best falcon in the world which be red breasted of very swift flight and more easily trained than those of other country proceed from chiaman or crerina for eight day journey through a great plain in which be many town and castle and many habitation with abundance of game you come to a great descent in which there be abundance of fruit tree but no habitation except those of a few shepherd though in ancient time it be well inhabit from the city of crerina to this descent the cold in winter be quite insupportable after descend for two day journey you come to a wide plain at the beginning of which be a city call adgamad or camandu which in ancient time be large and populous but be now destroy by the tartar this plain be very warm and the province be call reobarle -lrb- 8 -rrb- in which grow pomegranate quince peach date apple of paradise pistachio and other fruit the ox be large white and thin hair with thick short blunt horn and have a hunch like a camel between the shoulder about two span round they be accustom to bear great burthen and when they be to be load they be teach to bow they knee like camel and rise again when load the sheep of this country be as large as small ass have such long and broad tail that some of these weigh thirty pound and this part be most delicate and extremely rich food in this plain there be many city and town have high and thick rampart of earth to defend they against the caraon who be a mixed race between tartar father and indian mother ten thousand of whom be command by one nugodar the nephew of zagathaus who once rule in turkestan this nugodar have hear of the weakness of the malabar subject to soldan asiden go without he uncle knowledge and take dely and other city in which he erect a new sovereignty -lrb- 9 -rrb- and he tartar soldier by mix with the woman of the country produce this spurious breed call caraon who go up and down commit depredation in reobarle and other neighbouring district when these people wish to commit robbery by means of incantation address to the demon they have the means of obscure the air as if it be midnight darkness that they may not be see from any distance this obscurity when once raise last for seven day and they be perfectly acquaint with all the pass of the mountain in which they march one after another in single file so that no one can possibly escape they but all who fall in they way must encounter death or captivity the old be slay and the young sell for slave i marco who write this book be once very near fall into they hand and in the utmost danger of be either kill or take prisoner by they in midst of this darkness if i have not be so fortunate as to make my escape in to a castle call ganosulmus while many of my companion in the journey be either take or slay -lrb- 10 -rrb- after travel in this plain for five day towards the south the road again begin by little and little to descend for twenty mile together the road itself be very bad and not without danger from thief at the bottom of this declivity there be another plain of great beauty and fertility which extend for two day journey in breadth this fine country which be call cormo or ormus -lrb- 11 -rrb- abound in stream of water and plantation of date palm and there be abundance of bird of various kind particularly of popinjay which be not like those of europe after two day journey across this plain country we arrive at the sea in which be the island and city of ormus which be the capital of the kingdom and a great emporium of commerce to which many merchant resort bring spice pearl precious stone cloth of gold and silver and all the other rich commodity of indium the king be call ruchinad ben achomach have many city and castle under he authority and he make himself the heir of all merchant who happen to die in that place yet he be himself tributary to the king of chermain or kerman in summer the heat of this country be quite outrageous and the inhabitant betake themselves to they summer house which be build in the water from nine o'clock in the morning till noon there blow a wind with such extreme heat from the sand that it be quite stifle and insufferable and during this time the people sit in the water the king of kerman once send a array of 5000 foot and 1600 horse against the king of ormus to compel the payment of tribute when the whole army be stifle by that wind the inhabitant of ormus eat no flesh or bread make of corn but live upon date salt fish and onion the ship of this country be not very stout as they do not fasten they with iron nail because the timber be too brittle and would split in drive these home but they be fasten with wooden pin and sew with twine make from the husk of certain indian nut prepare in a peculiar manner this twine or thread be very strong and be able to endure the force and violence of the water and be not easily corrupt -lrb- 12 -rrb- these ship have only one mast one beam or yard and one deck and be not pay with pitch but with the oil and fat of fish and when they cross the sea to indium carry horse or other cargo they lose many ship because they be not strengthen with iron the people of this country be black and have embrace the religion of mahomet it be the custom of this country when the master of a family die that the widow shall mourn for he publickly once every day for four year but there be woman who profess the practice of mourning and be hire to mourn daily for the dead in return from ormus to kerman you pass through a fertile plain but the bread make there can not be eat except by those who be accustom to it it be so exceedingly bitter on account of the water with which it be make in a desert which extend to cobin-ham -lrb- 2 -rrb- seven day journey across the desert in the first three day you have no water except a few salt bitter pond of a green color like the juice of herb and whoever drink even a small quantity of this water can not escape a dysentery and even beast that be compel to drink of it do not escape without a scour it be therefore necessary for traveller to carry water along with they that they may avoid the inconvenience and danger of thirst in the fourth day you find a subterranean river of fresh water -lrb- 3 -rrb- the three last day of this desert be like the first three cobin-ham be a great city where great mirror of steel be make -lrb- 4 -rrb- tutium also which be a cure for sore eye and spodio be make here in the follow manner : from the mine of this country they dig a certain earth which be throw into furnace from which the vapor force downward through a iron grate condense below into tutium of tutty -lrb- 5 -rrb- and the grosser matter remain in the furnace be call spodio leave cobin-ham you meet with another desert of eight day journey in extent and terribly barren have neither tree or water except what be extremely bitter insomuch that beast refuse to drink of it except when mix with meal and traveller be therefore oblige to carry water along with they after pass this desert you come to the kingdom of timochaim -lrb- 6 -rrb- in the north confines of persium in which there be many city and strong castle in this country there be a extensive plain in which one great tree grow which be call the tree of the sun and by christian arbore-secco -lrb- 7 -rrb- or the dry tree this tree be very thick the leaf be green on one side and white on the other and it produce prickly and husky shell like those of chesnut but nothing in they the wood be strong and solid and of a yellow color like box there be no other tree within a hundred mile except on one side where there be tree at the distance of ten mile in this place the inhabitant say that alexander fight a battle against darius -lrb- 8 -rrb- the city of this place be plentifully furnish with good thing the air be temperate and the people handsome especially the woman who be in signify the place of heretic and the people of the place be call huleheticus or heretic in regard to the mahometan law the prince of this country be call the _ old man _ of the mountain concern whom i marco hear much from many person during my travels he name be aloadin and he be a mahometan in a lovely valley between two high and inaccessible mountain he cause a pleasant garden to be lay out furnish with the best tree and fruit that could be procure and adorn with many palace and banqueting house beautify with gilded bower picture and silken tapestry through this place by means of pipe wine milk honey and water be distribute in profusion and it be provide with beautiful damsel skilled in music singing and dancing and in all imaginable sport and diversion these damsel be dress in silk and gold and be see continually sport in the garden and its palace he make this garden with all its palace and pleasure in imitation of that sensual paradise which mahomet have promise to he follower no man could enter into this garden as the mouth of the valley be close up by a strong castle from which there be a secret entrance into the garden which be call the terrestrial paradise aloadin have certain youth from twelve to twenty year of age choose among such as seem of a bold and dauntless character who be initiate in all the pleasure and delight of this paradise and whom he employ to entice other to join the select company of young enthusiast by represent the joy and pleasure of the paradise of aloadin when he think proper he cause ten or twelve of these youth to be cast into a deep sleep by means of a potion and then have they convey severally into different chamber of the garden palace where they be attend upon at they awake by the beautiful damsel and supply with all kind of delicious meat and fruit and excellent wine and in whose company they enjoy all manner of luxurious delight so that they imagine that they be actually transport into paradise when they have revel in delight for a few day they be again cast into a deep sleep and remove from the garden of pleasure and be bring into the presence of aloadin be question by he where they have be the old man then represent that it be the command of the prophet that whoever be faithful and obedient to he lord should enjoy the delight of paradise and that if they would faithfully obey all he command they should be admit to reside continually among the joy of which they have be permit to participate for a short time have thus rouse they passion for pleasure they think themselves happy to execute whatever command they might receive even at the utmost hazard of they life be assure whether living or dead that they obedience would secure they the eternal enjoyment of paradise and all its delight by these means aloadin use to procure the murder of other lord who be he enemy by these he assassin who despise all danger and contemn they life when employ in he service by this procedure he be esteem a tyrant and greatly dread by all around and he have two vicar or deputy one in the neighborhood of damascus and another in curdistan who have similarly instruct young man under they order besides this he use to rob all passenger who go past he border at length in the year 1262 ulau or houlagu-khan send a armed force against he which besiege he castle for three year and at length make themselves master of it partly by famine and partly by undermine the wall -lrb- 2 -rrb- depart from thence -lrb- 3 -rrb- you come to a pleasant enough country diversify by hill and plain with excellent pasture and abundance of fruit the soil be very fertile -lrb- 4 -rrb- this continue for six day journey and then you enter a desert of forty or fifty mile without water after which you come to the city of sassurgan -lrb- 5 -rrb- where there be plenty of provision and particularly the best melon in the world which be as sweet as honey pass from thence we come to a certain city name batach balach or balk which be formerly large and famous have sumptuous marble palace but be now overthrow by the tartar in this city it be report that alexander marry the daughter of darius the eastern and north-eastern frontier of persium reach to this city but in proceed between the east and north-east from this place we find no habitation for two day journey the inhabitant have endure so many grievance from thief that they be compel to fly to the mountain for safety there be many river in this country and much game and lion be also to be meet with as traveller can find no food in this part of they journey they must carry enough with they for two day at the end of two day journey we come to a castle call thaican thalkan or thakan where we see pleasant field and abundance of corn the mountain to the south of this place be high some of which contain white salt so extremely hard that it have to be dig out and break with iron tool and the inhabitant from thirty day journey all around come here to procure salt which be of most excellent quality and be in such amazing quantity that the whole world might be supply from these mine the other mountain produce abundance of almond and pistachio nut go between the east and north-east from hence the country be fruitful but the inhabitant be perfidious mahometan murderer thief and drunkard they wine be boil and truly excellent they go bareheaded except that the man bind a string or fillet ten handbreadth long about they head they make breeches and shoe of the skin of wild beast and use no other garment after three day journey be the town of scasom -lrb- 6 -rrb- seat in a plain through the middle of which there flow a great river and there be many castle in the surround mountain -lrb- 7 -rrb- there be many porcupine in this country which be hunt by dog and these animal contract themselves with great fury cast they sharp quill at the man and dog and often wind they the nation have a peculiar language and the shepherd dwell in cave in the mountain we go three day journey from thence without meet any inhabitant to the province of balaxiam balascium or balasagan which be inhabit by mahometan who have a peculiar language they king who succeed each other hereditarily pretend to derive they lineage from alexander and the daughter of darius and be call dulcarlen which signify alexandrian in this country the famous balla ruby be find and other precious stone of great value particularly in the mountain of sicinam no person dare either to dig for these stone or to send they out of the country without the consent and licence of the king on pain of death and he only send they to such as he think fit either as present or in payment of tribute he likewise exchange many of they for gold and silver lest they should become too cheap and common in other mountain of the same province the best lapi lazulus in the world be find from which azure or ultramarine be make there be mine also of silver copper and lead the climate be very cold yet it produce abundance of large strong and swift horse which have such hard and tough hoof that they do not require iron shoe although they have to run among rock it be say that not many year ago the king 's uncle be in the exclusive possession of a breed of horse descend from the famous bucephalus and mark on the forehead exactly as he be and refuse to let the king have any of he stud he be put to death on which he widow in revenge destroy the whole race the mountain of this country produce the sacre falcon the lanner the goshawk and the sparrowhawk all excellent in they kind and much use by the inhabitant in the chase as they be all much addict to hunting the soil of this country produce excellent wheat and barley without husk and oil make of nut and mustard which resemble the oil from lintseed but be more savoury than other oil the man of the country be excellent archer and keen hunter and be mostly clothe in the skin of beast while the woman contrive to put sixty or eighty yard of cotton cloth into the skirt of they garment as the bulkier they look they be esteem the handsomer the plain of this country be large and well water with fine river but the hill be high and steep and the pass very difficult of access by which the inhabitant be secure against invasion and in these mountain there be flock of from four hundred to six hundred wild sheep which be very difficult to catch if any one contract a ague by live in the moist plain he be sure to recover he health by a few day residence in the mountain which i marco experience in my own person after a whole year sickness the province bascium or vash on a river of that name which fall into the gihon be ten day journey to the south of balaxiam and the country be very hot on which account the people be of a brown color they have a language of they own and wear gold and silver ear-ring artificially ornament with pearl and other precious stone they eat flesh and rice and be crafty and cruel idolater the province of chesmur khesimus khaschimir or cashmere be seven day journey from bascia the inhabitant have also a peculiar language of they own and be give to idolatry beyond all other and addict to enchantment force they idol to speak and darken the day the people of this country be not wholly black but of a brown complexion the air be temperate they be extremely lean although they use abundance of flesh and rice yet the native will shed no blood and employ the saracen who live among they to slaughter they cattle they have many strong city and town and be surround by desert and rugged mountain they be in no danger of any foreign enemy so that the king of this country yield tribute to none coral be hold in great estimation in this country and sell dearer than in any other part of the world there be certain hermit in this province who live with great abstinence in cell and monastery devote they whole life to the service of they idol and observe the strictest chastity many of these man be repute as saint and be hold in high estimation among the people from this province you may go to the indy and the ocean but i shall not now follow out the course to indium but return to balaxiam shall trace the way to kathay betwixt the east and north-east beyond balaxium be a certain river on which there be many castle and village belong to the brother of the king of balaxium and after three day journey we come to vachan -lrb- 8 -rrb- which extend three day journey in length and as much be breadth the inhabitant of this country have a peculiar language and be mahometan they be brave warrior and good huntsman as they country abound in wild beast depart from thence in a direction between the east and north-east we ascend for three whole day journey until we come to a exceed high mountain than which there be none say to be higher in the world in this place between two mountain be a plain in which be a great lake and a fine river run through the plain on the bank of which be such excellent pasture that a lean horse or ox will become quite fat in ten day it contain also great quantity of wild beast and particularly very large wild sheep have horn six span long out of which they make various kind of vessel this plain continue twelve day journey in length and be call _ pamer _ in which there be no habitation so that traveller must carry all they provision along with they this plain be so high and cold that no bird be to be find and it be even say that fire do not burn so bright in this place and do not so effectually boil or dress victuals as in other place -lrb- 9 -rrb- from hence the way to kathay lead for forty day journey between the east and the north-east through mountain hill and vally in which there be many river but no village neither any verdure except that some hut and cottage be to be see among the mountain but the inhabitant be savage and wicked idolater who live by hunting and be clothe in the skin of wild beast the country be call palow -lrb- 10 -rrb- after this you come to the province of caschar -lrb- 11 -rrb- which be inhabit by mahometan who be tributary to the great khan of the mongal or tartar the soil be fertile and the country be full of pleasant field garden and orchard produce vine fruit tree cotton hemp and flax and extend five day journey the inhabitant have a particular language and have many merchant manufacturer and artizan but they be so covetous that they do not allow themselves either good meat or drink among they there be some nestorian christian who also have some church -lrb- 1 -rrb- call likewise mulete or alamut marco make here a sudden return to the north-west of persium and from the abruptness of the transition it have be probably disarrange in transcription this country have be likewise call the land of the assassin it be near cashbin in dilem on the border of mazenderan -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- the last of these prince be name moadin who as
