or belur but care must be take to distinguish this from the chain of belur-tag which run north and south between great and little bucharium -- e section vi _ of the city of samarcand the town of lop the great desert in its neighborhood and other remarkable passage _ samarcand -lrb- 1 -rrb- be a great and famous city in a fertile plain and surround by fine garden it be subject to the nephew of the great khan and be inhabit by a mixed population of christian and mahometan among whom there be little agreement and in one of they dispute the following miracle be say to have happen about a hundred year ago zagathaus the brother of the great khan then govern this country and be persuade to become a christian and the christian through he favor build a church in honor of st john the baptist which be construct with such skill that the whole roof seem to depend for support upon one central pillar which be found upon a large stone which by the permission of zagathaus have be take from a building belong to the mahometan after the death of zagathaus he be succeed by a son who be not of the christian faith and from he the mahometan obtain a order by which the christian be compel to restore that stone and though they offer a sum of money as a compensation the mahometan absolutely insist to have the stone itself hope by that mean to reduce the christian church to ruin : but the pillar lift itself up that the mahometan might remove the contest stone and still continue suspend in the air depart from this city we come into the province of charahan -lrb- 2 -rrb- which be about five day journey in length and have plenty of provision the inhabitant be mostly mahometans intermix with some nestorian christian and be subject to the nephew of the great khan they be diligent artificer in various manufacture but be much subject to thick leg and the _ goitre _ or large wen on they throat occasion by the bad quality of the water of the country the province of cotam follow between the east and the north-east -lrb- 3 -rrb- it be subject to the nephew of the great khan and have many city and town the chief city be call cotam this province extend eight day journey in length and possess every thing necessary for life in sufficient abundance particularly cotton flax hemp corn and wine the people be mahometan and not warlike but be skilful in various article of manufacture proceeding through the same country we come to the province of peim extend four day journey in length and contain many town and castle the city of peim be the chief near which there be a river in which jasper and chalcedony and other valuable stone be find the inhabitant who be mahometan be expert manufacturer and be subject to the great khan there be a custom in this province that when any married man go to a distance from home and remain absent for twenty day it be lawful for he wife to marry another husband and reciprocally if the wife absent herself for twenty day the husband may take another wife the next province ciascian -lrb- 4 -rrb- of which the chief city be name sartan be subject to the tartar and have many city and castle in its river abundance of jasper chalcedony and other fine stone be find which be carry by merchant all the way to ouchach or kathay and sell there with great profit from peim to sartem and quite through this latter province the soil be very sandy have very little water and that generally bad when a army pass through this province all the inhabitant take they wife and child with all they cattle and valuable two day journey into the sand to place where they know that good water be to be find and remain there till the army have quit the country after harvest also they uniformly take all they corn into the desert and hide it in pit and the wind soon obliterate all trace of they footstep so that they enemy be unable to discover where they have deposit these precious hoard after travel for five day through the sand from this province we arrive at the great city of lop which be at the entrance of a great desert call the wilderness of lop -lrb- 5 -rrb- the inhabitant of this place be mahometan and be subject to the great khan all the before-mentioned province cashgar yarkand koten peim sartem and lop be in the bound of turkestan it require a month journey to cross this desert from south to north but to go through it lengthway would take up a whole year those who intend to cross the desert remain for some time in lop on purpose to prepare all necessaries for the journey as no provision be to be meet with for a whole month these with they merchandize be load on ass and camel and if provision fall short in the desert the unfortunate traveller be reduce to the necessity of kill they beast of burden for sustenance prefer the ass for this purpose as the camel can carry much heavier burden and be satisfy with less food this journey be entirely through sand and barren mountain in which water be find every day yet at some of the rest place it be so scanty as hardly to suffice for a caravan of fifty of a hundred person and they cattle in three or four place the water be salt and bitter but in all the rest of the journey it be very good in the whole of this journey there be no beast or bird to be see it be report that many evil spirit reside in the wilderness which occasion wonderful illusion to traveller who happen unfortunately to lag behind they companion call they even by they name and cause they to stray farther from the right course so that they lose they way and perish in the sand in the night time also they hear noise as of they friend and sometimes the sound of music be hear in the air and people imagine that they hear the din of drum as if army be march past to avoid the danger of separation the traveller in the desert keep close together and hang bell about the neck of they beast and if any one stay behind they set up mark in the route that they may know how to follow have cross the desert of lop we come to the city of sachion -lrb- 6 -rrb- or sachiou which be subject to the great khan and be situate in the great country of tangut the inhabitant of this city be mostly idolater who have a peculiar language mix with a good many mahometan and some nestorian christian this people be little addict to merchandize or manufacture and live on the product of they soil in this city there be many temple consecrate to various idol with monastery of priest devote to the service of these false deity to which numerous sacrifice be offer with great reverence when a son be bear to any person he be immediately consecrate to the protection of some particular idol and the father nourish a sheep in he house for a year with great care and on the anniversary day of that idol he present he son and the sheep as a sacrifice with great reverence and many ceremony before the shrine of this tutelary deity the flesh of the sheep be boil and set before the idol during the continuance of the prayer and invocation as a offering for the preservation and protection of the boy and the idol be suppose to inhale the savor of the meat after the religious ceremony be finish the meat be carry home to the father 's dwelling where all the kindred of the family be convene and feast with great joy and devotion but the bone be religiously keep in certain appropriate vessel the priest receive the head foot skin and intrail with a portion of the flesh for they share when a person of any estimation die he funeral be celebrate with much ceremony a astrologer be send for by the kindred and inform of the year month day and hour when the decease be bear when he calculate the aspect of the constellation and assign the day when the burial be to take place sometimes at the distance of seven day or perhaps the planet may not have a favourable aspect for six month during all which time the body be keep in the house for this purpose a fit chest or coffin be provide which be so artificially joint that no noisome smell can escape and in this the body be place have be previously embalm with spice the coffin be ornament with painting and be cover over with a embroidered cloth every day while the body remain unburied a table be spread near the coffin and set out with meat bread and wine which remain for as long a time as a live person would require to eat and drink and the soul of the decease be suppose to feed upon the savor the astrologer sometimes forbid the body to be carry out for interment at the principal door of the house pretend to be regulate in this by the star and order it to be carry out by some other way or will even command a passage to be break out in the opposite wall of the house to propitiate the adverse planet and if any one object to this they allege that the spirit of the dead would be offend and would occasion injury to the family when the body be carry through the city to be bury wooden cottage be build at certain distance by the way have porch cover with silk in which the coffin be set down with a table spread out with bread and wine and delicate viand that the spirit of the dead may be refresh with the savor when the body be carry to the place of the funeral a number of piece of paper make of the bark of tree curiously paint with figure of man and woman servant horse camel money and garment of all kind be carry in procession all the instrument of music in the city sound as the cavalcade move along and all these piece of paint paper be burn in the same funeral pile with the body under the idea that the decease will have as many servant cattle and garment in the next world and as much money as there be picture of these thing burn along with he body and shall live perpetually hereafter in the enjoyment of all these thing -lrb- 7 -rrb- -lrb- many rude nation in honor of they deceased great man -- e section vii _ of the province of chamil and several other country on the road from thence to the city of ezina and of another great desert _ the province of chamil which abound in all the necessaries of life be situate in the wide country of tangut and be subject to the great khan this province of which the city of chamil or hamus be the capital -lrb- 1 -rrb- be bound by two desert the great desert of lop already mention and another which be only three day journey across -lrb- 2 -rrb- the inhabitant be idolater have a peculiar language and appear to live only for amusement devote they whole time to singing dancing and sport play upon instrument of music and reading and write after they fashion when any traveller go into a house for entertainment and lodge the master of the family receive he with great joy and command he wife and family to obey the stranger in all thing so long as he may choose to remain and even depart immediately from he own house that he may not be any restraint upon he guest and while the traveller remain he may choose a female bed fellow every night either the wife daughter or servant of the polite host as he feel inclined the woman of the country be very beautiful and be perfectly ready to obey these singular command and the husband believe that this strange hospitality be conducive to they own honor and glory and be a acceptable service to they idol from whose favor it secure prosperity and abundance to themselves and they country mangu-khan have receive notice of this detestable custom issue a peremptory order for its discontinuance and it be accordingly lay aside for three year but as these year happen to be unusually barren and the inhabitant be vex with some disaster in they domestic concern they send ambassador to the khan earnestly entreat he to revoke so grievous a mandate and to permit they to continue a custom which have be hand down by they ancestor to this the khan answer since you glory in you shame you may go and act accord to you custom the messenger who bring back this favourable answer be receive with great rejoicing by the nation and the above custom continue when i marco be among they after leave the province of chamil we enter into that of chinchintala -lrb- 3 -rrb- subject to the great khan which be bound by the desert on the north and be sixteen day journey in length it have large city and many castle the inhabitant be divide into three sect or religion : the greater number be idolater a considerable number be mahometan and a small proportion be nestorian christian in this province there be mountain contain mine of steel and andanicum or audanicum and also a mineral substance call salamander or asbestos from the wool of which a incombustible cloth be manufacture which if cast into the fire do not burn this cloth be actually make of stone in the follow manner as i be inform by a turk name curifar a intelligent industrious person of my acquaintance who have the superintendence of the mine in this province a certain mineral be find in these mountain which yield fiber resemble wool : after be thoroughly dry in the sun this substance be pound in a brass mortar and then wash to remove all earthy impurity and the clean fibrous matter be spin in the same manner as wool and weave into cloth when this cloth require to be clean or whiten it be throw into the fire for a hour and be then take out unhurt and as white as snow it be say there be a napkin at rome of this salamander wool in which the handkerchief of the lord jesus be keep wrap up which a certain king of the tartar send as a present to the pope but as for the salamander or serpent which be report to live in the fire i could hear of no such creature in all the eastern country leave this province we travel for ten day between the east and north-east during which there be few habitation or thing worthy of remark after which we come to the province of succir -lrb- 4 -rrb- in which there be many town and village the chief city be call succir in this province which be subject to the great khan there be a few christian among a great number of idolater the best rhubarb -lrb- 5 -rrb- be find in great quantity in this province and be carry thence by merchant to various part of the world stranger dare not go to the mountain where the rhubarb grow on account of certain poisonous plant which occasion any beast that feed upon they to cast they hoof but the beast of the country know this plant and avoid feed upon it campion -lrb- 6 -rrb- be a great city and be the chief place in all tangut in it besides idolater and mahometan there be a good many christian who have three fair church the idolater have many temple and monastery dedicate to they idol these idol be very numerous and be make of stone wood or clay some of they curiously inlay with gold and very artificially make : some be very large almost ten pace high standing upright and have many smaller idol place around which seem to give reverence to the great one the priest of these idol appear to live more regularly and be less addict to voluptuousness than other idolater yet wantonness be not look upon in this country as any great sin for they say if a woman invite a man there be no harm in compliance but if the man solicit the woman it be quite otherwise in this country they divide the year by lunation and in every moon they keep certain day as holy in some five or four or three day in which they kill no beast or bird and abstain from animal food the people of this country marry twenty or thirty wife or as many as they be able to maintain but the first wife always have the precedence over the other the husband receive no portion with he wife but on the contrary have to assign she a dower in cattle servant and money accord to he ability if any of the wife do not live in harmony with the rest or if she become dislike by she husband it be lawful for he to put she away they marry they own near relation and even the wife of they deceased father except always they own mother in the manners and custom of this country i marco be sufficiently experienced have dwell a whole year in this place along with my father and uncle for the dispatch of certain affair of business in twelve day journey from campion we come to the city of ezina -lrb- 7 -rrb- which border on a sandy desert towards the north all the province and city before mention viz sachion camul chinchintala succair campion and ezina be comprehend in the great country of tangut the inhabitant of ezina be idolater who live by agriculture and on the produce of they flock and herd have great quantity of camel and other cattle but carry on no trade in this country there be forest of pine tree in which there be wild ass and many other wild beast there be likewise abundance of falcon particularly the lanner and sacre which be reckon excellent such traveller as intend to pass through the great desert of shamo which be forty day journey in extent must provide all they provision in this place as they afterwards meet with no habitation except a few straggle people here and there on the section viii _ of the city of caracarum and of the tartar with some account of they history monarch and manners _ have pass over the before mention desert of forty day travel always to the northward we come to the large city of charachoran or caracarum -lrb- 1 -rrb- which be three mile in circumference and strongly fortify with a earthen rampart as there be no stone in these part near the city there be a great castle with a elegant palace in which the governor usually reside near this place the tartar use to assemble in old time and here therefore i shall explain the original of they empire they dwell at first in the northern part call curza and bargu -lrb- 2 -rrb- where there be many vast plain without city and town but abound in pasture lake and river they have no prince of they own nation but pay tribute to a certain great king name as i have be tell in they language _ umcan _ and which some people believe to signify in the language of europe prester-john -lrb- 3 -rrb- and to whom the tartar give yearly a tenth part of the increase of they flock and herd and of they horse in process of time the tartar so increase in number that umcan become afraid of they and endeavor to disperse they into several part of he empire and when any of they rebel he use to send party into they territory to reduce they to obedience for which purpose he even frequently depute some of they own noble at length it become obvious to the whole nation that they ruin be intend and be unwilling to be separate from each other they retire into the northern desert where they might be safe from the power of umcan to whom they refuse the accustomed tribute after continue in the north for some time they choose a king among themselves name zingis-khan who be a wise and valiant man and reign with such justice that he be beloved and fear of all as a god rather than as a prince so that by he fame and prowess he soon reduce all the tartar in these part under he authority see himself at the head of so many valiant man he determine to leave the northern desert and command he people to provide themselves with bow and other weapon he begin to reduce the neighbouring city and province under he dominion in which conquest he place such just governor that the people be perfectly reconcile to he authority in all he conquest he carry the chief person along with he bestow upon they provision and other gift and by that mean attach they to he person and continually augment he power after sometime find himself advance to power and glory he send ambassador to umcan to entreat that he would bestow he daughter upon he for a wife umcan receive this message with the utmost indignation say to the messenger do my servant presume to demand my daughter begone and tell you master that if ever he dare to repeat so insolent a proposal i will make he die a miserable death zingi seem only to have want a reasonable pretence to justify he in the estimation of he noble for enter into war against umcan he therefore immediately levy a great army with which he march boldly against umcan and encamp in a great plain name tanduc -lrb- 4 -rrb- send a message to umcan to defend himself upon this umcan collect a vast army with which he advance into the plain and pitch he camp within ten mile of that of the tartar zingi command he astrologer to shew he what be to be the event of the approach battle on which they split a reed into two piece on one of which they write the name of zingi and the name of umcan on the other and strike they separately into the ground say to zingi : while we read in we holy book it shall come to pass through the power of the idol that these two piece of reed shall fight together and whose part shall get the better to that king shall the victory be give the astrologer begin to mumble they prayer and incantation while the multitude stand around to observe the result and after some time the two piece of reed seem spontaneously to fight together and the portion inscribe with the name of zingi get the mastery over that of umcan and the tartar be encourage by this prodigy go into the battle fully assure of victory which they actually obtain by this battle in which umcan be slay the sovereignty of all tangut be transfer to zingi who take to wife the daughter of umcan zingi reign six year after this and conquer many province : but at last while he endeavor to take a certain castle call thaigin he approach too near the wall and be wound in the knee by a arrow of which wound he die and be bury in the mountain of altaus zingi be the _ first _ king of the tartar the second be khen-khan the third bathyn-khan the fourth esu-khan the fifth mangu-khan the sixth kublai-khan whose power be greater than that of all he predecessor as besides have inherit all they acquisition he have add almost the whole world to he empire during a long and prosperous reign of sixty year -lrb- 5 -rrb- all the great khan and prince of the blood of zingi be carry for burial to the mountain of altaus even from the distance of a hundred day journey and those who attend the body kill all whom they meet by the way order they to go and serve they lord in the other world and a great number of fine horse be slay on the same occasion and pretence it be say that the soldier who accompany the body of mangu-khan to the mountain of altaus slew above ten thousand man during they journey the tartar woman be remarkably faithful to they husband consider adultery as the greatest and most unpardonable of crime yet it be account lawful and honest for the man to have as many wife as they can maintain but the first married be always account the principal and most honorable these wife live all in one house in the utmost harmony and most admirable concord in which they carry on various manufacture buy and sell and procure all thing necessary for they husband and family the man employ themselves only in hunting and hawk and in martial affair they have the best falcon in the world and great number of excellent dog and they live upon flesh and milk and what they procure by hunting they eat the flesh of horse and camel and even of dog if fat and they chief drink be cosmos make of mare milk in a particular manner and very much resemble white wine when the father of a family die the son may marry all he father wife except only he own mother neither do they marry they sister and on the death of a brother the survive brother may marry the widow of the decease the husband receive no portion with they wife but must assign sufficient dowry to they wife and mother as the tartar have many wife they often have great number of child neither be the multitude of they wife very burthensome as they gain much by they labor and they be exceedingly careful in the management of family concern in the preparation of food and in all other household duty the tartar feed many herd of cattle and numerous flock of sheep and great number of camel and horse they remain with these during the summer in the pasture of the mountain and colder region of the north where they find abundance of grass and wood but in winter they remove into the warmer region of the south in search of pasture and they generally travel forwards for two or three month together they house be make of slender rod cover with feel mostly of a round form and be carry along with they in cart or waggon with four wheel and the door of these moveable house be always place front the south they have also very neat cart on two wheel cover so closely with feel that the rain can not penetrate in which they wife and child and household goods be convey from place to place all these be draw by ox or camel the rich tartar be clothe in sable and ermine and other rich fur and in cloth of gold and all they apparel and furniture be very costly they arm be bow sword battle-axis and some have lance but they be most expert in the use of the bow in which they be train from they infancy they be hardy active and brave yet somewhat cruel be exceedingly patient and obedient to they lord and will often remain two day and night arm on horseback without rest they believe in one supreme god of heaven to whom they daily offer incense pray to he for health and prosperity but every person have a little image cover with feel or something else in he house call _ natigay _ and to this household god they make a wife which be place on he left hand and child which be set before he face this image or idol be consider as the god of earthly thing to whom they recommend the protection of they wife and child they cattle corn and other valuable this god be hold in great reverence and before eat any thing themselves they anoint the mouth of the idol with the fat of they boil meat and they cast some broth out of door in honor of other spirit after which they eat and drink they fill say that now they god and he family have have they due portion if the son of one tartar and the daughter of another die unmarried the parent meet together and celebrate a marriage between they deceased child on this occasion they draw up a write contract and paint representation of man and woman for servant of horse camel cattle and sheep of clothes of all kind and of paper money and all these thing be burn along with the contract conceive that these will all follow they child substantially to the other world to serve they and that they will be there unite in affinity as if they have be actually marry while live when the tartar go to war the prince usually lead a army of not less than a hundred thousand man all cavalry each man have usually eight or more horse or mare they troops be regularly distribute into band of ten hundred thousand and ten thousand a troop of a hundred be call a _ tuc _ and a body of ten thousand be call a _ toman _ they carry they feel house along with they for shelter in bad weather when necessity require they will ride for ten day together without victuals subsist upon the blood of they horse by cut a vein and suck the blood but they likewise prepare dry milk for take with they in they expedition in the follow manner : after take off the cream which be make into butter they boil the milk and dry it in the sun into a kind of hard curd of which every man in the army carry about ten pound along with he every morning they take about half a pound of this curd which they put into a leathern bottle with a quantity of water and as he ride along the motion of the horse shake and mix these together and this mess suffice for the food of one day when they approach towards the enemy they send out numerous scout on all side that they may not be assault unaware and to bring intelligence of the number motion and posture of the enemy when they come to battle they ride about in apparent disorder shooting with they arrow and sometimes make a show of precipitate flight discharge they arrow backwards as they fly and when by these means they have break or disperse the enemy they suddenly rally they force and make a unexpected assault which generally decide the victory they horse be all so thoroughly under command as to turn any way merely by a signal if any tartar steal a thing of small value he be not put to death but receive a certain number of blow with a cudgel accord to the measure of the offence either seven or seventeen or twenty-seven thirty-seven or forty-seven though some die through the severity of this cudgelling but if any one steal a horse or other thing of great value for which he deserve to die accord to they law he be cut asunder with a sword unless he redeem he life by restore the theft nine fold such as have horse oxen or camel brand they with they particular mark and send they to feed in the pasture without a keeper leave the city of caracarum and the mountain altai we enter the champaign country of bargu -lrb- 6 -rrb- which extend northwards for about fifty day journey the inhabitant of this country be call medite -lrb- 7 -rrb- and be subject to the great khan and resemble the tartar in they manners they have no corn or wine and employ themselves chiefly during summer in the chase of wild beast and in catch bird on the flesh of which they subsist in winter and they have great abundance of a kind of stag which they render so tame that they allow themselves to be ride in the winter this country be so excessively cold that fowl and all other live thing remove to warmer region after forty day journey we arrive at the ocean near which be a mountain frequent by stork and fine falcon as a breed place and from whence falcon be bring for the amusement of the great khan -lrb- 1 -rrb- caracarum caracorum taracoram korakarum karakarin karakum call holin by the chinese this city be lay down by danville with acknowledged uncertainty on the onguin-pira river in lat 44  50 ' n long 107  e while other assign its situation on the orchon in lat 46  30 n long 108-1\/2 e : about 150 mile to the nw -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- the original residence of the moal or mongui whom marco always call tartar appear to have be limit by the selinga and lake baikal on the west or perhaps reach to the bogdo altaus and sayanak mountain the soilkus mountain on the east divide they from the mandshur and the ungar-daga mountain on the south divide they from the great empire of tangut which they overthrow bargu may have be on the baikal near which there still be a place call barsuzin of cursa no trace be to be find in we map -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- prester-john presbyter or priest or as call by the german priester johann from which we english denomination be prince of the naymannus or karaite a tribe reside on tke river kallassuus or karasibus which discharge itself into the jeniseus he original name be say to have be togrul and for some service to the chinese in they war he be honor with the title of 0ng uang or wang from whence arise he tartarian style of ung-khan likewise erroneously write aunaek or avenaek-khan perhaps this prince may have be convert by the nestorian christian and may even have receive priest order -- forst it be more probable that he may have belong to the dalai-lama religion which some ignorant traveller from resemblance in dress and the use of rosary in prayer may have suppose a christian sect reside in eastern scythium -- e -lrb- 4 -rrb- tenduc tenduch teuduch -- forst -lrb- 5 -rrb- accord to the genealogical history of the tartar by abulgasus bayadur-khan ugadai-khan succeed zingi in 1230 in 1245 he be succeed by he son kajuk-khan call khen-khan by marco in the text to he mangu-khan succeed in 1247 who hold the empire till 1257 when he be succeed by koplaus or kublai-khan who reign thirty-five year and die in 1292 -- harri marco probably date the reign of kublai-khan which he extend to sixty year from he have receive a great delegated government a long time before he become great khan or emperor of the tartar -- e -lrb- 6 -rrb- bargu-fin or bargouin be the name of a river on the east side of lake baikal on which be a town or village name barguzin or barguzinskoy ostrog signify the town of the burguzian but by the description in the text marco appear to have comprehend the whole north-east of tartary to the north of the changaus mountain under the general name of bargu in which he now include curza mention separately at the commencement of the precede section and where the situation of bargu have be already more particularly describe in a note -- e -lrb- 7 -rrb- metrite meclite or markaet -- forst no such appellation be to be find in modern geography but the discontinuance of the designation of temporary and continually change association of the wander tribe of the desert be not to be wonder at and even if they record be preserve they would be altogether unimportant -- e section ix _ of the vast country to the north of tartary and many other curious particulars _ we now return to campion or kantcheou on the river etzin proceed thence five day journey towards the east we come to the country of erginul -lrb- 1 -rrb- in the province of tangut which be subject to the great khan in this kingdom there be many idolater with some nestorian and turk it contain many city and castle the chief place being of the same name with the province go south-east from this place towards kathay we come to the famous city of cinguy -lrb- 2 -rrb- situate in a province of the same name which be tributary to the great khan and be contain in the kingdom of tangut some of the people be christian some of they mahometan and other be idolater in this country there be certain wild cattle nearly as large as elephant with black and white hair which be short all over the body except on the shoulder where it be three span long exceedingly fine pure white and in many respects more beautiful than silk i bring some of this hair to venice as a rarity many of these ox be tame and break in for labor for which they be better adapt by they strength than any other creature as they bear very heavy burden and when yoke in the plough will do twice the work of other the best musk in the world be find in this province and be procure from a beautiful animal the size of a goat have hair like a stag the foot and tail resemble a antelope but have no horn it have two tooth in the upper jaw above three inch long as white as the finest ivory -lrb- 3 -rrb- when the moon be at the full a tumor or imposthume grow on the belly of this animal resemble a bladder fill with blood and at this time people go to hunt this animal for the sake of this bag or swell which they dry in the sun and sell at a high price as it be the best of musk the flesh also of the animal be good for eat i marco bring the head and foot of one of these animal to venice the people of this country of singui live by trade and manufacture and they have abundance of corn they be idolater have fat body small nose black hair and no beard except a few scattered hair on they chin the woman be exceedingly fair and the man rather make choice of they wife by they beauty than by they nobility or riches so that when a great nobleman marry a poor but beautiful wife he have often to assign a large dowery to obtain the consent of the mother this province extend twenty-five day journey in length and be very fertile in it there be exceedingly large pheasant with tail eight or ten handbreadth long and many other kind of bird some of which have very beautiful and finely variegated plumage after eight day farther travel to the east we come to the district of egrigaium -lrb- 4 -rrb- which be still in the kingdom of tangut and subject to the great khan it contain many city and castle calacium be the principal city which be inhabit by idolater though the nestorian christian have three church in this city excellent camblet be manufacture from white wool and the hair of camel -lrb- 5 -rrb- which be export by the merchant to all part of the world and particularly to kathay east from this province of egrigaium be that of tandach -lrb- 6 -rrb- in which there be many city and castle the king of this nation be call george who be a christian and a priest -lrb- 7 -rrb- and most of the people also be christian he be descend of prester john formerly mention under the name of umcan from whom he be the fourth in descent and he pay tribute to the great khan and ever since the battle in which umcan be slay by zingi the great khan have give they daughter in marriage to the king of this country who do not possess all the dominion which be formerly subject to prester john there be a mixed race in this country call argon descend of idolater and mahometan who be the handsomest people in these part and be most ingenious manufacturer and cunning merchant this province be the chief residence of prester john and there be two neighbouring district call ung and mongol by the native which the people of europe call gog and magog travel eastward for seven day towards kathay there be many city inhabit by idolater mahometan and nestorian who live by commerce and manufacture and who make stuff work with gold and flower and other silken stuff of all kind and color like those make among we and also woollen cloth of various kind one of these town be sindicin or sindacuus where very excellent arm of all kind fit for war be manufacture in the mountain of this province call idifa or ydifu there be great mine of silver three day journey from sindicin stand another city name iangamur -lrb- 8 -rrb- which signify the white lake near this place the khan have a palace in which he take great delight as he have fine garden with many lake and river and multitude of swan and the adjacent plain abound in crane pheasant partridge and other game there be five sort of crane here some of which have black wing other be white and bright they feather be ornament with eye like those of a peacock but of a golden color with beautiful black and white neck a third kind be not unlike we own in size and appearance the fourth kind be very small and beautiful variegate with red and blue the fifth be very large and of a gray color with black and red head in a valley near this city there be astonishing number of quail and partridge for the maintenance of which the khan cause millet and other seed to be sow that they may have plenty of food and a number of people be appoint to take care that no person may catch any of these bird which be so tame that they will flock around they keeper at a whistle to receive food from they hand there be also a great number of small hut build in different part of the valley for shelter to these bird during the severity of winter where they be regularly feed by the keeper by these means when the emperor choose to come to this part of the country he be certain to find abundance of game and during winter he have great quantity send to he on camel or other beast of burden three day journey south-west from iangamur be the city of ciandu -lrb- 9 -rrb- which be build by the great emperor kublai-khan and in which he have a palace erect of marvellous art and beauty ornament with marble and other rare stone one side of this palace extend to the middle of the city and the other reach to the city wall on this side there be a great inclosed park extend sixteen mile in circuit into which none can enter but by the palace in this inclosure there be pleasant meadow grove and river and it be well stock with red and fallow deer and other animal the khan have here a mew of about two hundred ger-falcon which he go to see once a-week and he cause they to be feed with the flesh of fawn when he ride out into this park he often cause some leopard to be carry on horseback by people appoint for this purpose and when he give command a leopard be let loose which immediately seize a stag or deer and he take great delight in this sport in the middle of a fine wood the khan have a very elegant house build all of wood on pillar richly gilt and varnish on every one of the pillar there be a dragon gilt all over the tail be wind around the pillar while the head support the roof and the wing be expand on each side the roof be compose of large cane three hand breadth in diameter and ten yard long split down the middle all gilt and varnished and so artificially lay on that no rain can penetrate the whole of this house can be easily pull down and take to piece like a tent and readily set up again as it be all build of cane and very light and when it be erect it be fasten by two hundred silken rope after the manner of tent cord to prevent it from be throw down by the wind every thing be arrange in this place for the pleasure and convenience of the khan who spend three month here annually in June July and August but on the twenty-eighth day of August he always leave this to go to some other place for the performance of a solemn sacrifice always on the twentieth day of August he be direct by the astrologer and sorcerer to sprinkle a quantity of white mare milk with he own hand as a sacrifice to the god and spirit of the air and the earth in order that he subject wife child cattle and corn and all that he possess may flourish and prosper the khan have a stud of horse and mare all pure white nearly ten thousand in number of the milk of which none be permit to drink unless those who be descend from zingis-khan except one family name _ boriat _ to whom this privilege be grant by zingi on account of they valor these white horse be hold in such reverence that no one dare go before they or disturb they in they pasture there be two sect of idolatrous priest call chebeth and chesmu who ascend the roof of the palace in the midst of storm and persuade the people they be so holy that they can prevent any rain from fall on the roof these people go about in a very filthy condition as they never wash or comb themselves they have also a abominable custom of eat the body of malefactor who be condemn to death but they do not feed on any who die naturally these be likewise call bachsus which be the name of they order as we friar be name predicant minor and the like these fellow be great sorcerer and seem to be able to do any thing they please by magic art when the great khan sit in he hall at a table which be raise several foot above the other -lrb- 10 -rrb- there be a great sideboard of plate at some distance in the midst of the hall and from thence these sorcerer cause wine or milk to fill the goblet on the khan table whenever he command these bachsus also when they have a mind to make feast in honor of they idol send word to the khan through certain officer depute for the purpose that if they idol be not honor with the accustomed sacrifice they will send blight on the fruit of the ground and murrain among the beast and entreat therefore that he will order a certain number of black-headed sheep with incense and aloes-wood to be deliver to they for the due and honorable performance of the regular sacrifice these priest have vast monastery some of which be as large as small city and several of they contain about two thousand monk or person devote to the service of the idol all of whom shave they beard and head and wear particular garment to denote that they be set apart from the laity for the service of they god yet some of they may marry in they solemnity these man sing the praise of they idol and carry light in they procession some of they call sensim or santom lead a austere life eat nothing but meal mingle with water and when all the flour be expend they content themselves with the bran without any savoury addition these man worship the fire and those who follow other rule allege that these austere santom be heretics against the religious law because they refuse to worship idol and never marry these santom shave they head and beard wear coarse hempen garment of a black or bright yellow color sleep on coarse thick mat and live the severest life imaginable amid every conceivable deprivation and austerity -lrb- 11 -rrb- -lrb- 1 -rrb- erigrinul eriginul erdschi-nur and this ought to be read _ fifty _ day south-west instead of five day east -- forst this may probably be some district in the country of the elut of kokonor not mention in we modern map -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- singuus sigan or singan-fou in the chinese province of shensee -- forst -lrb- 3 -rrb- in the edition of harri it be say likewise to have two similar tusk in the lower jaw but this error must have be put in by some ignorant editor -- e -lrb- 4 -rrb- accord tangut seem to have follow no regular order but go from one to another as fancy or memory serve -- forst -lrb- 9 -rrb- cyandus xandu or tshangtu -- forst -lrb- 10 -rrb- in harri the elevation be say to be _ eighty _ foot perhaps a typographical error for eight as in a subsequent passage the table of the khan be merely say to be higher than those of the rest who have the honor to dine along with he the particular height therefore be leave indeterminate in the text -- e -lrb- 11 -rrb- in all age of the world except the social yet irrational ancient superstition of greece and rome mankind have vainly think to propitiate the almighty beneficence by ridiculous act of austere self-torment and even the ignorant or design follower of the pure and rational religion of jesus have copy all the monstrous mummery and abominable practice of the heathen which they have engraft upon he law of love and harmony -- e section x _ of the great power of kublai-khan and various circumstance respect he family government and dominion _ i now propose to relate the great and marvellous act of kublai-khan the great emperor of the tartar he name express in we language signify lord of lord and he certainly be the greatest prince in city people and treasure that ever reign in the world he be lineally descend from zingis-khan the first prince of the tartar be the sixth emperor of that race and begin to reign in 1256 be then _ twenty-seven _ year of age -lrb- 1 -rrb- and he have long rule this immense empire with great gravity and wisdom he be a very valiant man strong of body and well exercise in arm and evince himself such in many action before he attain to empire which he effect by he superior wisdom and management contrary to the will of he brethren before he accession he shew himself a more valiant soldier and a wiser general than ever the tartar have before he time yet since he have sway the empire he have always depute he son and other general upon military expedition and have only since then go into the field on the follow occasion in the year 1257 or 1258 he uncle -lrb- 2 -rrb- name naiam be then thirty year of age who have the command of so many country and nation that he could easily have muster 400000 horse become puff up with youthful vanity determine to take away the empire from he lord and draw into he scheme another great tartar prince name caydu who be nephew to kublai and command on the border of great turkey and who engage to bring a 100000 man into the field in aid of the ambitious project of naiam both of these confederate begin to gather force but this could not be do so secretly as not to come to the knowledge of the great khan who immediately set guard on all the road into the desert and assemble all the force which lay within ten day journey of cumbalu -lrb- 3 -rrb- the imperial residence in twenty day he have collect a army amounting to 360000 horse and 100000 foot a large part of which vast force be compose of huntsman and falconer and person belong to the imperial household with this army kublaus march with all expedition into the province occupy by naiam where he arrive at the end of twenty-five day march altogether unexpectedly and before naiam have complete he preparation or have be join by he confederate caydu after give he troops two day rest and have encourage he man in the confident expectation of victory by means of he astrologer and soothsayer he advance towards the encampment of naiam and appear with he whole army on a hill over against the camp of the rebel who have not even send out any scout to procure intelligence kublai-khan be seat on the top of a wooden castle carry by four elephant and fill with archer and cross-bow man from which the royal standard be display on which the picture of the sun and moon be pourtray divide he army into three body he keep one as a reserve on the hill beside himself and send the two wing to attack the army of naiam who resolve to stand the issue of a battle to every ten thousand horse in the army of kublai five hundred light armed footman with lance be assign who have be teach to leap up behind the horseman on any occasion when flight or retreat become necessary and be instruct to alight and kill the horse of the enemy during battle the two army join in a well contest battle which last from morning till mid-day when naiam be make prisoner and all he follower submit themselves to the clemency of the victor and have renew they oath of allegiance be pardon and dismiss have a new governor set over they in whose fidelity the great khan could confide -lrb- 4 -rrb- naiam be order to be sew up between two carpet and toss up and down till he die to avoid shed the blood of any one belong to the imperial house of zingi naiam be say to have be secretly baptize and to have profess himself a christian have he principal ensign mark with the sign of the cross and to have have a great number of christian in he army who be all slay on this occasion the jews and mahometan who serve in the army of kublaus upbraid he christian soldier with the disaster which have happen to the cross in this battle the christian complain to kublai of this injurious conduct who sharply reprove the jew and mahometan for they behavior then turn to the christian he address they as follow : surely you god and he cross would not give aid to naiam be not you therefore ashamed of what have happen see that god who be good and just do not defend iniquity and injustice naiam be a traitor and a rebel and seek the aid of you god in he mischievous purpose : but you good and upright god would not favor he bad design kublai-khan return after this great victory to cambalu and on easter day he call the christian into he presence and kiss they gospel with great reverence make all he great officer and baron do the same and he act in a similar manner on the great festival of the mahometan jew -lrb- 5 -rrb- and heathen that segomamber-khan the great god of the idol mahomet mose and jesus or whosoever be greatest in heaven may be favourable to he yet he make the best shew of liking to the christian faith but allege that the ignorance of the nestorian priest and the great interest of the sorcerer among the people hinder he from make a profession of christianity for the better rewarding he brave and faithful soldier the khan have a military council compose of twelve tartar baron who give he notice of the meritorious service of all commander that they may be promote to higher station give to one the command of a hundred to another the command of a thousand and to a third the command of ten thousand and so on the captain of a hundred man have a badge or tablet of silver the captain of a thousand have a tablet of gold or silver gilt and the commander of ten thousand have a tablet of gold ornament with the head of a lion these tablet differ in size and weight accord to the dignity of the wearer on each tablet there be a inscription of the follow import : by the strength and power of the almighty god and by the grace which he have give to we empire : let the name of the great khan be bless and let all die or be destroy who will not obey he command besides these badge of distinction all officer have commission in write in which all they duty privilege and authority be recite when the general appear in public they have a cloth or canopy carry over they head and they give audience sit on chair of silver the badge or tablet of a general weigh three hundred _ sagus _ or fifty ounce of gold laving image of the sun and moon and such as have the representation of a ger-falcon may take with they a whole army for they guard kublai-khan be a comely handsome man of middle stature with a fresh complexion bright black eye a well form nose and every way well proportion he have four lawful wife every one of whom have the title of empress and the eldest bear son of these wife be to succeed he in the empire each of these empress have she own magnificent palace and peculiar court and be attend by three hundred woman besides many eunuch and the suite of each extend at least to ten thousand person the great khan have also many concubine and every second year he send messenger to a remarkably fair tribe among the tartar name _ virgut _ to make search for die fairest young woman among they for he use these messenger usually bring with they four or five hundred young woman more or less as they see cause examiner be appoint to take a view of all they beauty who fix value upon they in proportion to they various merit at sixteen seventeen eighteen nineteen twenty or more carat and only those be bring to court whose value reach to a certain appoint rate on they arrival at cambalu other examiner again view they and choose out twenty or thirty of the handsomest for the chamber of the khan those who be thus select be place for some time under the care of some of the wife of the great baron about the court who be direct to report whether they do not snore in they sleep and if they be not offensive in smell or behavior such as be finally approve be divide into party of five and one such party attend in the chamber of the khan for three day and night in they turn while another party wait in a adjoining chamber to prepare whatever the other may command they those who be less prize in the course of these rigid examination of they quality be employ in cookery or other office about the palace or be bestow by the khan on he favored officer with large portion the man of the country from whence these young woman be bring deem it a great honor when they daughter be find worthy of the khan regard and esteem themselves unfortunate when they be reject at court kublaus have twenty-two son by he four legitimate wife and the first bear of he first wife name zingi would have succeed he in the empire if he have not die before he father zingi leave a son name timur who be a wise and valiant prince of great military experience and who be destine to succeed he grandfather on the imperial throne instead of he deceased father by he concubine he have twenty-five son all of whom be daily exercise in martial employment and be all promote to high military post and government seven of he son by he lawful wife be king of great province and rule the country commit to they charge with great prudence and discretion -lrb- 1 -rrb- in a former note it have be mention on the authority of abulgazus - khan himself a descendant of zingi and prince of khuaresm that kublai-khan be only the fifth emperor of the tartar and that he ascend the throne in 1257 the difference of date in this latter circumstance be quite unimportant and may have proceed either from a different way of reckoning or the delay of intelligence from so vast a distance but kublaus die in 1292 after reign thirty-five year accord to abulgazus and be say to have be then eighty year of age he must therefore have be forty-five year old at he accession instead of twenty-seven harri indeed mention in a note that the age of kublaus in the mss and even in many of the print edition be leave blank -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- in harri this date
