therefore that can be say be that the two city in the text must have stand on opposite side of the hoang-ho in the day of marco polo -- e section xv _ a account of the kingdom of mangus and the manner of its reduction under the dominion of the great khan together with some notice of its various province and city _ the kingdom of mangus be the richest and most famous of all that be to be find in the east in the year 1269 this kingdom be govern by a king name fanfur -lrb- 1 -rrb- who be richer and more powerful than any who have reign there for a hundred year fanfur maintain justice and internal peace in he dominion so that no one dare to offend he neighbor or to disturb the peace from dread of prompt severe and impartial justice insomuch that the artificer would often leave they shop fill with valuable commodity open in the night yet no one would presume to enter they traveller and stranger travel in safety through he whole dominion by day or night he be merciful to the poor and carefully provide for such as be oppress by poverty or sickness and every year take charge of 20000 infant who be desert by they mother from poverty all of whom he breed up till they be able to work at some trade but in process of time betake himself more to pleasure than be fit he employ he whole time in delight in the midst of 1000 concubine he capital be encompass with ditch full of water but fanfur be entirely addict to the art of peace and so beloved of he subject for he justice and charity that trust to they number and attachment and to the natural strength and resource of the country both king and people neglect the use of arm keep no cavalry in pay because they fear no one and believe themselves invincible cublai-khan be of a different disposition from fanfur and delighted in war and conquest and have resolve upon make a conquest of the kingdom of mangus he levy a great army of horse and foot for that purpose over which he place a general name chinsan-baian -lrb- 2 -rrb- he accordingly march with he army accompany by a fleet into the province of mangus and summon the city of coiganzu -lrb- 3 -rrb- to surrender to the authority of the great khan on this be refuse he depart without make any assault to the second the third and the fourth city all of which he summon and on they refusal march on without siege or assault but receive the same answer from the fifth he assault it with great courage and have take it by storm he massacre the whole inhabitant without spare any of either sex or of any age or condition this severe military execution so terrify the other city that they all immediately surrender on this successful commencement be report to the khan he send a new army to reinforce chinsan-baian whose army be now much diminish by the garrison he have to leave in the conquer city with he army thus reinforce chinsan march against quinsaus -lrb- 4 -rrb- the capital city of the kingdom of mangus in which fanfur reside he be much terrify at this formidable invasion and have never see any war he flee with all he wealth on board a great fleet which he have prepare retire to certain impregnable island in the ocean -lrb- 5 -rrb- commit the custody of he capital to he wife whom he desire to defend it as well as she could as be a woman she need not fear be put to death if she be make prisoner it may be observe that fanfur have be tell by he diviner that he kingdom would never be take from he except by one who have a hundred eye and this be know to the queen she be in hope or preserve the city in all extremity think it impossible for any one man to have a hundred eye but learn that the name of the commander of the tartar have that signification she send for he and deliver up the city believe he to be the person indicate by the astrologer and to whom destiny have predetermine the conquest of the city and kingdom -lrb- 6 -rrb- she be send to the court of the great khan where she be most honourably receive and entertain as become she former dignity after the surrender of the capital the citizen and inhabitant of the whole province yield to the obedience of the great khan -lrb- 7 -rrb- i shall now speak of the city in the kingdom of mangus coiganzu be a very fair and rich city situate towards the south-east and east in the very entrance of the province of mangus -lrb- 8 -rrb- in this city which be situate on the river carama -lrb- 9 -rrb- there be vast number of ship employ in trade and great quantity of salt be make in that neighborhood proceeding from coigan-zu we ride one day journey to the south-east on a stone causeway on both side of which be great fence with deep water through which people may pass with proper vessel -lrb- 10 -rrb- and there be no entrance into mangus but by this causeway except by ship at the end of this day journey be a large and fair city call paughin of which the inhabitant be idolater and manufacturer of stuff of silk and gold in which they drive a considerable trade it be plentifully supply with all the necessaries of life and the paper money of the khan be current in the whole province one day journey farther south-east be the large and famous city of caim the neighbouring country abound in fish beast and fowl of all kind especially with pheasant as large as peacock which be so plentiful that three may be buy for a venetian groat proceed another day journey through a well cultivate fertile and well peopled country we come to a moderate size city call tinguus which be much resort to by ship and merchant and abound in all the necessaries of life this place be in the south-east on the left hand three day journey from the ocean and in the country between it and the sea there be many salt pit in which great quantity of salt be make after this be cinguus -lrb- 11 -rrb- a great city whence the whole country be furnish with salt of which the khan make immense profit almost beyond belief the inhabitant be idolater and use paper money ride farther to the south-east be the noble city of janguus -lrb- 12 -rrb- which have twenty-seven other city dependent on its government in this city one of the twelve baron who be governor of province usually reside but i marco have the sole government of this place for three year instead of one of these baron by a special commission from the great khan the inhabitant be idolater live chiefly by merchandize and they manufacture arm and harness for war naughin -lrb- l3 -rrb- be a province to the west -lrb- 14 -rrb- of tangui one of the greatest and noblest in all mangus and a place of vast trade have abundance of beast and fowl wild and tame and plenty of corn the inhabitant be idolater and manufacture stuff of silk and gold use only paper money this country produce large revenue to the khan especially in the custom which he receive from trade sian-fu be a large and noble city in the province of mangus have twelve great and rich city under its jurisdiction this city be so strong that it be three year besiege by the army of the tartar and could not be vanquish at the time when the rest of the kingdom of mangus be subdue it be so environ with lake and river that ship come continually with plenty of provision and it be only accessible from the north the long resistance of this city give much dissatisfaction to the khan which come to the knowledge of nicolo and maffeus polo then at he court they offer they service to construct certain engine after the manner of those use in europe capable of throw stone of three hundred weight to kill the man and ruin the house in the besiege city the khan assign they carpenter who be nestorian christian to work under they direction and they make three of these engine which be try before the khan and approve of these be accordingly send by ship to the army before sian-fu and be plant against the city cast great stone into it by which some of the house be beat down and destroy the inhabitant be very much astonished and terrify by the effect of these machine and surrender themselves to the authority and dominion of the khan on the same condition with the rest of mangus and by this service the venetian brethren acquire great reputation and favor from this city of sian-fu to another call sin-gui it be account fifteen mile to the south-east this city though not very large have a prodigious number of ship as it be situate on the greatest river in the world call quiam -lrb- l5 -rrb- be in some place ten in other eight and in other six mile broad but its length extend to a distance of above a hundred day journey from its source to the sea receive numberless navigable river in its course from various and distant region by which mean incredible quantity of merchandize be transport upon this river there be about two hundred city which participate in the advantage of this river which run through or past the boundary of sixteen province the greatest commodity on this river be salt with which all the province and city which have communication with its water be supply i marco once see at singui five thousand vessel yet some other city on the river have a greater number all these ship be cover have but one mast and one sail and usually carry 4000 venetian cantharus and upward some as far as 12000 in these vessel they use no cordage of hemp even they hawser or tow rope be make of cane about fifteen pace long which they split into thin piece from end to end and bind or wreath together into rope some of which be three hundred fathom long and serve for drag they vessel up or down the river each vessel have ten or twelve horse for that purpose on that river there be rocky hillock in many place on which idol temple with monastery for the priest be build and in all the course of the river we find cultivate vally and habitation innumerable cayn-guus be a small city on the same river to the south eastward of sin-gui where every year great quantity of corn and rice be bring which be carry for the most part to cambalu for from the quiam or kian-ku river they pass to that city by means of lake and river and by one large canal which the great khan cause to be make for a passage from one river to another so that vessel go all the way from mangus or southern china to cambalu without ever be oblige to put to sea this great work be beautiful and wonderful for its size and vast extent and be of infinite profit to the city and province of the empire the khan likewise cause great causeway to be construct along the bank of this prodigious canal for the conveniency of travel by land and for tow the vessel in the middle of the great river there be a rocky island with a great temple and monastery for the idolatrous priest cin-ghian-fu -lrb- 16 -rrb- be a city of the province of mangus which be rich in merchandize and plentiful in game and provision of all kind in 1274 the great khan send marsachis a nestorian christian to govern this city who build here two christian church from the city of cin-ghian-fu in a journey of three day journey to the south-eastward we find many city and castle all inhabit by idolater and at length come to the great and handsome city of tin-gui-guus which abound in all kind of provision when chinsan baian conquer the kingdom of mangus he send a large body of christian alanus -lrb- 17 -rrb- against this city which have a double inclosure of wall the inhabitant retire from the outer town within the inner wall and the alanian find great store of wine indulge themselves too freely after a severe march in the night time the citizen sally out upon they while all be drunk and asleep and put every man of they to the sword but baian send afterwards a fresh army against they which soon master the city and in severe revenge massacre the whole inhabitant the great and excellent city of sin-guus -lrb- 18 -rrb- be twenty mile in circumference and contain a vast population among whom be great number of physician and magician and wise man or philosopher it have sixteen other city under its jurisdiction in each of which there be much trade and many curious art and many sort of silk be make in its territory the neighbouring mountain produce rhubarb and ginger in great plenty the name sin-guus signify the city of the earth and there be another city in the kingdom of mangus call quin-saus which signify the city of heaven from singui it be one day journey to vagiu where also be abundance of silk and able artisan and many merchant as be universally the case in all the city of this kingdom -lrb- 1 -rrb- call tou-tsong by the chinese historian the fifteenth as no name in the least similar appear in the map of china -- e section xvi _ of the noble city of quinsaus and of the vast revenue draw from thence by the great khan _ in a journey of three day from vagiu we find number of city castle and village all well peopled and rich the inhabitant be all idolater and subject to the great khan at the end of these three day journey we come to quinsay or guinsai its name signify the city of heaven to denote its excellence above all the other city of the world in which there be so much riches and so many pleasure and enjoyment that a person might conceive himself in paradise in this great city i marco have often be and have consider it with diligent attention observe its whole state and circumstance and set down the same in my memorial of which i shall here give a brief abstract by common report this city be a hundred mile in circuit -lrb- 1 -rrb- the street and lane be very long and wide and it have many large market place on one side of the city there be a clear lake of fresh water and on the other there be a great river which enter into the city in many place and carry away all the filth into the lake whence it continue its course into the ocean this abundant course of run water cause a healthful circulation of pure air and give commodious passage in many direction both by land and water through those numerous canal as by means of these and the causeway by which they be border cart and bark have free intercourse for the carriage of merchandize and provision it be say that there be twelve thousand bridge great and small in this city and those over the principal canal be so high that a vessel without she mast may go through underneath while chariot and horse pass above on the other side of the city there be a large canal forty mile -lrb- 2 -rrb- long which inclose it on that side be deep and full of water make by the ancient king both to receive the overflowing of the river and to fortify the city and the earth which be dig out from this canal be lay on the inside as a rampart of defense there be ten great market place which be square half a mile in each side -lrb- 3 -rrb- the principal street be forty pace broad have a canal in the middle with many bridge and every four mile -lrb- _ li _ -rrb- there be a market place two mile -lrb- _ li _ -rrb- in circuit there be also one large canal behind the great street and the market place on the opposite bank of which there be many storehouse of stone where the merchant from indium and other place lay up they commodity be at hand and commodious for the market in each of these market the people from the country to the number of forty or fifty thousand meet three day in every week bring beast game fowl and in short every thing that can be desire for subsistence in profusion and so cheap that two goose or four duck may be buy for a venetian groat then follow the butcher market in which beef mutton veal kid and lamb be sell to the great and rich as the poor eat of all offal and unclean beast without scruple all sort of herb and fruit be to be have continually among which be huge pear weigh ten pound each white within and very fragrant -lrb- 4 -rrb- with yellow and white peach of very delicate flavor grape do not grow in this country but raisin be bring from other place they likewise import very good wine but that be not in so much esteem as with we the people be contented with they own beverage prepare from rice and spice every day there be bring up from the ocean which be at the distance of twenty-five mile such vast quantity of fish besides those which be catch in the lake that one would conceive they could never be consume yet in a few hour all be go all these market place be encompass with high house underneath which be shop for all kind of artificer and all kind of merchandize as spice pearl and jewel and so forth and in some the rice wine be sell many street cross each other lead into these market in some of which there be many cold bath accommodate with attendant of both sex who be use to this employment from they infancy in the same bagnio there be chamber for hot bath for such stranger as be not accustom to bathe in cold water the inhabitant bathe every day and always wash before eat in other street there be such number of mercenary prostitute that i dare not pretend to say how many these be find near the market place and in all quarter of the city in place appoint for they residence where they shew themselves pompously adorn and perfumed attend by many servant and have they house richly furnished they be very skilful in sport and dalliance and in contrive pleasure to rob man of they sens in other street there be physician and astrologer and person who teach to read and write and a infinity of other trade at each end of every market place there be a palace or tribunal where judge appoint by the khan be station for determine any dispute which may happen between merchant and other also to superintend the guard upon the bridge and other matter of police punish all who be negligent or disorderly along both side of the principal street there be great palace with garden and between these the house of artificer and such multitude be perpetually go to and fro in all the street that one would wonder how so vast a population could be provide in food i be inform by a officer of the custom that it appear by a very accurate computation the daily expenditure of pepper in quinsaus be forty-three _ soma _ each soma be 223 pound -lrb- 5 -rrb- from this some idea may be form of the immense quantity of victuals flesh wine and spice which be expend in that place there be twelve principal company or corporation each of which have a thousand shop and in each shop or factory there be ten fifteen or twenty man at work and in some forty under one master -lrb- 6 -rrb- the rich tradesman do not work themselves although the ancient law ordain that the son of all should follow the trade of they father but the rich be permit not to work with they own hand but to keep shop and factory superintend the labor of other in they particular trade these rich people and especially they wife stand in they shop well dress or rather sumptuously array in rich silk and adorn with valuable jewel they house be well build and richly furnished and adorn with picture and other ornament of immense price and they exercise they trade with great integrity the whole inhabitant be idolater of a very fair complexion and mostly dress in silken garment as silk be produce in great abundance in they neighborhood or bring from other place they dwell together in great amity insomuch that the inhabitant of a street seem only to compose one family and be particularly circumspect in they behavior to female as it would be repute exceedingly disgraceful to use any indecorous language to a married woman the native be of a most peaceable disposition and no way addict to strife or quarrelling and altogether unused to arm which they do not even keep in they house they be extremely hospitable to foreign merchant whom they entertain kindly in they house give they the best advice in regard to the conduct of they affair : but they be by no means fond of the soldier and guard of the great khan as by they means they have be deprive of they natural king and ruler about the lake there be many fair building and palace of the principal man and numerous idol temple with monastery of idolatrous priest there be two island in the lake on each of which be a palace contain a incredible number of room to which they resort on occasion of marriage and other festival in these palace abundance of plate linen and all other thing necessary for such purpose be keep up at the common expence and sometimes 100 separate company be accommodate at one time in the several apartment in the lake also there be vast number of pleasure boat and barge adorn with fair seat and table under cover be flat on the top where man stand to push the boat along with pole as the lake be very shallow these be all paint within and have window to open or shut at pleasure nothing in the world can be more pleasant or delightful than this lake from its immense variety of rich object on all side particularly the city ornament with so many temple monastery palace garden tree barge and innumerable people take they recreation for they ordinarily work only a part of each day spend the remainder in party of pleasure with they friend or with woman either on the lake or in drive through the city in chariot all the street be pave with stone as be all the highway in the kingdom of mangus only a space on one side be leave unpaved for the use of the foot post the principal street of quinsaus have a pavement of ten pace broad on each side the middle be lay with gravel and have channel in every place for convey water it be keep always perfectly clean in this street there be innumerable long close chariot each of which be accommodate with seat and silk cushion for six person who divert themselves by drive about the street or go to the public garden where they pass they time in fine walk shady bower and the like and return at night in the same chariot to the city -lrb- 7 -rrb- when a child be bear the father note down the exact point of time and with this memorandum go immediately to some astrologer of whom there be many in every market place to consult the destiny in regard to he future fortune and they use the same form before celebrate they marriage to ascertain the lucky time when a person of note die the kindred clothe themselves in canvas or sackcloth and accompany the body to the funeral both man and woman people be employ to play on musical instrument and singing all the way prayer to they idol and be come to the place they cast into the fire in which the body be burnt many piece of cotton paper on which figure of slave horse camel stuff of silk and gold money and all other thing be paint which by this mean they believe the dead person will really possess in the next world and they make a grand concert of music under the idea of the joy with which the soul of they depart friend will be receive by they idol in the other life which he be now to begin as they timber house be very liable to accident by fire there be stone tower in every street to which they carry they goods for security on such occasion on most of the bridge there be guard-house in which soldier continuallv watch five in each by day and five by night in case of any alarm or disturbance in every guard-house there hang a great bason -lrb- 8 -rrb- on which the warder strike the successive hour begin one at sunrise and begin a new series at sunset these guard patrole during the night and if they see any light or fire in a house after the appoint time or meet any person in the street after legal hour they cause they to answer before the judge or magistrate of the district when a fire happen the guard collect from they different station to assist in quench it and to carry away the goods to the stone tower or into the island in the lake for during the night none of the citizen be permit to go out except such as be in danger from fire the khan keep always a large body of he best and most faithful soldier for the security of the city which be the largest and richest in the whole earth and besides the small guard-house on the bridge already mention there be larger lodge build of wood all over the city for the accommodation of party of guard to preserve peace and order on the reduction of mangus to obedience the khan divide it into nine great province place a viceroy in each to administer the government and to dispense justice every year each of these viceroy give a account to the tribunal of the khan at cambalu of the revenue and all other matter connect with he government and every third year the viceroy and all the other officer be change the viceroy who reside in quinsaus command over 140 other city all large rich and populous nor be the extent of this government to be wonder at as there be in mangus 12000 city all inhabit by rich and industrious people in every one of which the khan maintain a garrison proportional to its greatness and importance in some 1000 man and even up to 10 or 20000 man -lrb- 9 -rrb- these be not all tartar for the tartar soldier be cavalry only and be keep in place where there be conveniency for exercise they horse the great majority of the troops in mangus be kathayan and the garrison in kathay be compose of people from mangus every third year such a number of man fit to carry arm as be want be select for fill up the garrison and be send to serve in place at least twenty day journey from they home and after serve four or five year they be permit to go home and be replace by fresh recruit most part of the revenue of the khan be expend in this way and on the other necessary expence of government and by this distribution of so powerful a military force a army can be suddenly call together in the event of any town rebelling in the city of quinsaus there be a constant garrison of 30000 soldier and the smallest city in all mangus contain at least 1000 regular troops if any person be not able to work he be carry to some hospital of which there be many in quinsaus found by the ancient king and endowed with large revenue : but when they be well again they must return to they labor i come next to speak of the palace of the late king fanfur he predecessor cause a large park to be inclose with high wall ten mile in circuit -lrb- 10 -rrb- and divide within into three part that in the middle be enter by a gate lead to a range of large gallery or hall whose roof be sustain by pillar finely work and paint and richly adorn with gold and azure the smallest of these gallery be that nearest the gate of entrance and they gradually become larger and fairer in succession the most sumptuous be at the farthest end the wall of all these apartment be elegantly paint with the portrait and history of the former king every year on certain holiday dedicate to the idol fanfur use to hold open court on which occasion he feast he chief lord the principal merchant and rich artificer of quinsaus 10000 at a time in these hall the feast continue for ten or twelve successive day with incredible magnificence every guest use he utmost endeavor to appear in the most pompous dress on one side of this magnificent range of gallery there be a wall divide it from a great cloistered court have a terrace all round set with pillar communicate with which be the chamber of the king and queen all curiously work carve gilded and paint with the utmost splendor and magnificence from this cloister a covered gallery six pace wide extend a great length all the way to the lake and on each side of this gallery there be ten court answer to each other like cloister each have fifty chamber with they garden and in these there be 1000 concubine for the king service sometimes with the queen and sometimes with these concubine the king use to go in he barge for recreation on the lake or to visit the idol temple the rest of the great inclosure be divide into grave lake and garden in which all sort of beast of chase be keep as stag roebuck hare cony and other and there the king use to divert himself with he damsel in chariot or on horseback no man be allow to enter there in this place the lady hunt with dog and when wearied with sport they retire into the grove and throw off they garment come forth naked and fall to swim in the lake in the king presence sometimes he banquet in these grove be serve by he damsel all of these particulars i learn from a old rich merchant of quinsaus who have be familiar with king fanfur and know all the incident of he life and reign and have see the palace in its most flourishing state and he carry I to see it the viceroy now reside there the first describe gallery remain still in they original state but the chamber of the damsel be fall to ruin the wall also which encompass the wood and garden be all fall down the beast and tree be all go and all the other ornament be destroy twenty-five mile from quinsai we come to the ocean between the east and the north-east near which be a city call gampu -lrb- 11 -rrb- have a excellent port frequent by merchant ship from the indy while i marco be in quinsaus a account be take for the great khan of the revenue and the number of inhabitant and i see that there be enrol 160 toman of fire reckon for each fire a family dwelling in one house each toman be 10000 which make 1600000 family -lrb- 12 -rrb- and for all this population there be only one nestorian church all the rest be idolater every householder be oblige to have write over he door the name of every individual in he family whether male or female as also the number of horse add or efface as the family increase or diminish and this rule be observe in all the city of mangus and kathay those also who keep inn must write down in a book the name of all they guest with the day and hour of they arrival and departure and these book be send daily to the magistrate who preside at the market place the revenue which accrue to the khan from quinsaus and the other city under its authority be first from salt eight toman of gold every toman be 80000 sazzus and a sazzus be more than a gold florin which will amount to six million and four hundred thousand ducat the cause of this be that be near the sea there be many lake or saline of sea water which dry up and coagulate into salt in summer and five other province in mangus be supply from the coast of quinsaus this province produce plenty of sugar which pay like all other spice three and a third in the hundred which be likewise pay for rice-wine all the twelve company which we say before have twelve thousand shop and all merchant who bring goods hither by sea or carry any away pay a similar rate those who come from indium or other remote country pay ten per cent all breed cattle and all production of the earth as silk rice corn and the like pay to the khan the whole computation be make in my presence amount yearly besides the above mention produce from salt to two hundred and ten toman of gold which be equal to sixteen million and eight hundred thousand golden ducat -lrb- 13 -rrb- a day journey from quinsaus to the south-east we pass the whole way through house village fine garden and abundant cultivation and then come to a fine city call tapin-zu three day hence be uguiu and two day farther we still ride past castle city and well cultivate field so near adjoining that the whole seem to traveller like one continue city in this district be great cane fifteen pace long and four palm thick two day farther be the large and handsome city of conguus and travel thence for four day through place well fill with industrious people have plenty of beef buffalo goat and swine but no sheep we come to the city of zengian which be build on a hill in the middle of a river which after encompass it divide into two branch one of which run to the south-east and the other to the north-west three day journey thence through a most pleasant country exceedingly well inhabit we come to the large city of gieza which be the last in the kingdom of quinsaus after this we enter into another province of the kingdom of mangus call concha the principal city of which be fugiu by which you travel six day journey south-east through hill and dale always find inhabit place and plenty of beast fowl and game and some strong lion be find in the mountain and forest ginger galingal and other spice grow here in great plenty and there be a herb of which the fruit have the same color smell and effect with saffron which it be not and be much use in they meat -lrb- 15 -rrb- the inhabitant be idolater and subject of the great khan and eat man flesh if the person have not die of disease even consider it as better flavored than any other when they go into the field they shave to the ear and paint they face with azure all they soldier serve on foot except the captain who be on horseback and they arm be sword and lance they be very cruel and when they kill a enemy they immediately drink he blood and afterwards eat he flesh after six day journey be quelinfu a great city with three bridge each of which be eight pace broad and above a hundred pace long the man be great merchant and manufacturer and the woman be fair and delicately shape the country produce plenty of ginger and galingal and great abundance of silk and cotton i be tell but see they not that they have hen without feather hairy like cat which yet lay egg and be good to eat -lrb- 16 -rrb- in this part of the country there be many lion which make the way very dangerous after three day journey we arrive in a populous country inhabit by idolater who make great quantity of silk stuff the chief city be unguem near which abundance of sugar be produce and send from thence to cambalu before the reduction of this country by the great khan the inhabitant of this country could only manufacture a bad kind of sugar by boil down the juice of the cane into a black paste but certain inhabitant from _ babylonium _ teach they refine it by means of the ash of a certain tree -lrb- 17 -rrb- fifteen mile farther be the city of cangiu still in the province of concha and here the khan have always a army in readiness for keep the country under subjection through this city there run a river of a mile broad with handsome building on both side and the river be constantly cover with vessel carry sugar and other goods this river disembogue itself at the distance of five day journey south-east from cangiu into the sea at zaitum all the country between be extremely pleasant and abound in tree and shrub of camphor zaitum be a famous port and much frequent by ship with rich cargo from indium for the supply of mangus and kathay and from this port the production of these region be disperse all over indium at this port such quantity of pepper be import that what come through alexandrium into we western world be not to be compare to it be hardly a hundredth part the concourse of merchant to this famous emporium be incredible as it be one of the most commodious port in the whole world and be exceedingly productive in revenue to the great khan who receive ten in the hundred of all merchandize the merchant pay likewise so high for freight that not above a half of they cargo remain to themselves for sale and yet of that moiety they make immense profit the inhabitant of zaitum be idolater and much give to pleasure and in it there be many artizan employ in embroidery and arras-work -lrb- 18 -rrb- this river be large wide and swift one arm of it reach to quinsaus and the other to zaitum -lrb- 19 -rrb- and at the parting of these branch the city of tringuus be situate where porcelain dish be make -lrb- 20 -rrb- i be tell of a certain earth which be cast up into conical heap and leave expose to the weather for thirty or forty year without stir after which refine by time it be make into dish which be paint and baked in furnace and so cheap be this manufacture that eight of these dish may be buy for one venetian groat -lrb- 21 -rrb- from this province of concha the great khan derive nearly as great a revenue as he do traveller in the _ ninth _ century four hundred year earlier as use in all the city of china -- e section xvii _ of the island of zipangu and of the unsuccessful attempt make by the tartar for its conquest _ i shall now leave the country of mangus and proceed to discourse of indium the greater the middle and lesser in which i have be both in the service of the great khan and also on we return home along with the queen who be send from kathay to argon the ship which be build in the kingdom of mangus be make of fir have only one deck on which be build twenty cabin more or less accord to they size each for one merchant they have each a good rudder and four mast with four sail which they raise or let down at pleasure but some have only two mast some of the largest ship have thirteen division in the inside make of board let into each other so that if by the blow of a whale or by touch on a rock water should get into one of these division it can go no farther and the leak be find be soon stop they be all build double or have two course of board one within the other both of which be well caulk with oakum and nail with iron but they be not pitch as they have no pitch in mangus instead of which they be pay all over with the oil of a certain tree mix up with lime and chop hemp which bind faster than pitch or lime the largest of these ship have three hundred marine other two hundred or a hundred and fifty accord to they size and they carry from five to six thousand bag of pepper in ancient time they use to build larger ship than now but owe to the great number of island and shoal in some place of these sea they now build they less -lrb- 1 -rrb- besides they sail they use oar occasionally to propel these ship four man be employ to each oar the larger ship be usually attend by two or three of a smaller size able to carry a thousand bag of pepper and have sixty mariner in each and these smaller ship be sometimes employ to tow the greater vessel each of the larger ship hare ten small boat for fishing and other service which be fasten aloft on they side and let down when want for use after have be employ for a year these ship be sheathe all over so that they then have three course of board : and they proceed in this manner till they sometimes hare six course alter which they be break up zipangu -lrb- 2 -rrb- be a very large island on the east and fifteen hundred mile distant from the shore of mangus the people of this island be of a white complexion and of gentle manners and have a king of they own they have gold in great plenty as jew merchant report thither and no gold be allow to be export such as have trade to this island speak of the king palace as be cover over with gold as we church be with lead and that the window and floor be likewise of gold it abound in pearl and be amazingly rich hearing of the vast opulence of this island kublaus khan send two of he baron abasa and vensaasin -lrb- 3 -rrb- with a fleet and a great army to attempt the conquest sailing from zaitum and quinsaus -lrb- 4 -rrb- they arrive safely on the island but fall out between themselves they be only able to take one city all the garrison of which they behead except eight person who could not be wound with steel because each have a enchanted stone inclose between the skin and flesh of they right arm these man be beat to death with club by order of the general soon after this a violent north wind arise which fly so hard as greatly to endanger the ship some of which be lose and other blow out to sea on this the whole army re-embarked and sail to a uninhabited island at the distance of about ten mile : but the tempest continue many of the ship be wreck and about thirty thousand of the people escape on shore without arm or provision the two general with a few of the principal person return home after this tempest cease the people of zipangu send over a army in a fleet of ship to seize the tartar but have land without any order the tartar take the advantage of a rise ground in the middle of the island under cover of which they wheel suddenly round between the zipanguer and the ship which have be leave unmanned with ail they streamer display in these ship the tartar sail to a principal city of zipangu into which they be admit without any suspicion finding hardly any within its wall except woman the man be all absent on the expedition into the uninhabited island the zipanguer collect a new fleet and army to besiege the city and the tartar receive no succor be constrain to surrender after a defense of six month on term by which they life be spare this happen in the year 1264 -lrb- 5 -rrb- for the bad conduct of the two commander the great khan order one to be behead and send the other to the desert island of zerga in which malefactor be punish by sew they up in the new flayed hide of a buffalo which shrink so much in dry as to put they to exquisite torture and bring they to a miserable death the idol in zipangu and the adjoining island be strangely make some have the head of a bull other of a hog or a dog and in other most monstrous fashion some have head with four face other three head on one neck while some have face on they shoulder some have four arm other ten or even a hundred arm and that idol be repute the most powerful and be hold in greatest reverence which have the greatest number when ask the reason of make they idol in such distorted and ridiculous form they answer that such be the custom which have be hand down from they ancestor it be report of these islander that they eat such of they enemy as they take prisoner esteem human flesh a peculiar dainty the sea in which zipangu lie be call the sea of _ chus _ or _ chin _ or the sea over against mangus which be call _ chan _ or _ chint _ in the language of that island this sea be so large that mariner who have frequent it say it contain seven thousand four hundred and forty island most of they inhabit and that in ail those island there be no tree which be not odoriferous or do not bear fruit or be not useful in some other respects in they likewise there be great abundance of spice of various kind especially black arid white pepper and lignum aloe -lrb- 6 -rrb- the ship of zaitum be a whole year on they voyage to and from zipangu go there during the winter and return again in summer as there be two particular wind which regularly prevail in these season zipangu be far distant from indium but i will now leave zipangu because i never be there as it be not subject to the khan and shall now return to zaitum and the voyage from thence to indium -lrb- 1 -rrb- in this passage in the edition of harri the sense seem obscurely to insinuate that this have be occasion by the sea have break down or overwhelmed certain in the indy _ sailing from zaitum 1500 mile to the south westwards we pass a gulf call cheinan -lrb- 1 -rrb- which extend two month sail to the northward still confine on the south-east -lrb- 2 -rrb- of mangus and elsewhere with anium and toloman and other province mention formerly within it be infinite island all in a manner inhabit -lrb- 3 -rrb- and in they be find abundance of gold and they trade with each other this gulf seem like another world and after 1500 mile sailing be the rich and great country of ziambar -lrb- 4 -rrb- the people be idolater and pay a yearly tribute to the great khan of twenty elephant and great quantity of aloe wood in the year 1268 hearing of the riches of this country the khan send one of he general name segatu to invade it acambute who be then king of the country be old and choose to avoid the danger and misery of war by agree to pay the before-mentioned tribute in ziambar there be many wood of black ebony of great value sailing thence for 1500 mile betwixt the south and southeast we come to java -lrb- 5 -rrb- which be consider by mariner to be the largest island in the world be above 3000 mile in circumference it be govern by a king who pay tribute to none as owe to the length and danger of the voyage the great khan have make no attempt to annex it to he vast dominion the merchant of zaitum and mangus bring from thence abundance of gold and spice south and south-westwards six hundred mile be the island of sondur and condur both desolate of which sondur be the larger -lrb- 6 -rrb- fifty mile south-east from they be a rich and great province or island call lochae -lrb- 7 -rrb- the people be idolater and have both a king and language of they own in it there grow great plenty of brazil wood and it have much gold many elephant wild beast and fowl and a excellent fruit call bercia as large as lemon the country be mountainous and savage and the king permit no person to come into he dominion lest they should get acquaint with the county and attempt its conquest it produce abundance of porcelain shell which be transport to other place where they serve as money five hundred mile southward from lochae be the isle of pentan -lrb- 8 -rrb- a savage place which produce sweet tree in all its wood for sixty mile of this voyage between locha and pentan the sea in many place be only four fathom deep thirty mile to the south-east from pentan be the island and kingdom of malaiur -lrb- 9 -rrb- which have a king and a peculiar language of its own and have a great trade carry on in spice from pentan one hundred mile south-east be java the less -lrb- 10 -rrb- which be about two thousand mile in circuit and be divide into eight kingdom each have its own language i be in six of these kingdom of which i shall give some account omit those i do not see one of these kingdom be felech or ferlach in which the formerly idolatrous inhabitant of the city have be convert to the mahometan religion in consequence of much trade and intercourse with the saracen but the mountaineer be very savage eat human flesh and living upon every kind of unclean food and they worship all day what they first happen to meet in the morning the next kingdom be call basma which have a language peculiar to itself the people live without law or religion like beast : but they sometimes send hawk to the khan who lay claim to the sovereignty of the whole island besides wild elephant there be unicorn in this country which be much less than elephant be hair like the buffalo but they foot be like those of die elephant these animal have one horn in the middle of they forehead but they hurt no one with this weapon use only they tongue and knee for they trample and press any one down with they foot and knee and they tongue be beset with long sharp prickle with which they tear a person to piece the head be like that of a wild boar which the animal carry hang down to the ground they be filthy beast that love to stand and wallow in the mire and they do not in the least resemble those unicorn which be say to be find in some other part of the world which allow themselves to be take by maid -lrb- 11 -rrb- in this country there be many ape of different kind some of they be black with face like man which they put into box preserve with spice these they sell to merchant who carry they to various part of the world and pass they for pigmy or little man this country likewise produce large goshawk as black as raven which be excellent for sport samare or samara be the next kingdom in which i remain for five month against my will in consequence of bad weather -lrb- 12 -rrb- during all which time none of the star in the constellation of the great-bear be see be force to remain here for five month i land with 2000 man and erect fortification to defend we against any unforeseen attack from the savage cannibal of the island with whom we establish a trade for provision they have excellent wine both red and white make from the palm tree which be a very wholesome beverage as it be medicinal for consumption the dropsy and for disorder of the spleen they have likewise abundance of fine fish and eat of all sort of flesh without make any difference they cocco nut be as large as a mans head and the middle of they be full of a pleasant liquor better than wine dragoian -lrb- 13 -rrb- be another of those kingdom claim by the khan which have a king and a peculiar language i be tell of a abominable custom in this country that when any one be sick he relative send to inquire at the sorcerer if he be to recover if they answer no the kindred then send for a person whose office it be to strangle the sick person whom they immediately cut in piece and devour even to the marrow of they bone for they allege that if any part be to remain worm would breed in it which would be in want of food and would therefore die to the great torture of the soul of the dead person they afterwards carry away the bone and conceal they carefully in cave in the mountain that no beast may touch they if they can lay they hand on any stranger they treat he in the same barbarous manner lambrus be the fifth kingdom of java-minor or sumatra in which be great plenty of brazil wood some of the seed of which i bring to venice but they would not vegetate as the climate be too cold for they in this country there be great number of unicorn or rhinoceros and plenty of other beast and bird fanfur be the sixth kingdom have the best camphor which be sell weight for weight with gold in that kingdom they make a kind of meal from great and long tree as thick as two man be able to fathom have take off the thin bark the wood within be only about three finger thick all the rest be pith from which the meal be make this pith be break to piece and stir among water the light dross swimming and be throw away while the finer part settle at the bottom and be make into paste -lrb- 14 -rrb- i bring some of this to venice which taste not much unlike barley bread the wood of this tree be so heavy as to sink in water like iron and of it they make excellent lance but be very heavy they be under the necessity of make they short these be harden in the fire and sharpen and when so prepared they will pierce through armor easier than if make of iron about 150 mile to the northward of lambrus there be two island one call nocueran and the other angaman ceylon and various part of hither india _ sailing from angaman 1000 mile west and a little to the south we come to the island of zelan or ceylon which be 2400 mile in circumference but be anciently 3600 mile round as appear from the former chart of the country the north wind have occasion the sea to destroy a great part of it this be the finest island in the world and its king be call sendernaz the man and woman be idolater and go entirely naked except a small cloth before they they grow no corn except rice and they have plenty of oil of sesame milk flesh palm wine brazil wood the best ruby in the world sapphire topaze amethyst and other gem the king of the island be say to have the finest ruby that ever be see as long as the hand and as thick as a man wrist without spot or blemish and glowing like a fire cublai-khan once send to purchase this ruby offer the value of a city for it but the king answer that he would not part with it for all the treasure in the world because it have belong to he ancestor the man of this island be unfit for soldier and hire other when they have occasion to go to war there be a high mountain in ceylon to the top of which no one can ascend without the assistance of iron chain and on which the saracen report that the sepulchre of adam be situate but the idolater say that it be the body of sogomon burchan the first founder of idol worship son of a king of the island who betake himself to a recluse life of religious contemplation on the top of this mountain from whence no pleasure or persuasion could induce he to withdraw after he death he father cause a image of he to be make of solid gold and command all he subject to adore he as they god : and hence they say be the origin of idol worship people come here in pilgrimage from remote region and there he fore-tooth and a dish which he use be solemnly exhibit as holy relic as the saracen pretend that these belong to adam cublai-khan be induce in 1281 to send ambassador to the king of this country who obtain the dish two tooth and some of the hair of sogomon barchan : these the great khan cause to be receive without the city with great reverence and solemnity by the whole people of cambalu and bring into he presence with great honor sixty mile to the west of ceylon be moabar -lrb- 1 -rrb- this be no island but lie on the firm continent which may be call the greater indium in it there be four king the principal one of whom be sinder candus in whose kingdom they fish for pearl between ceylon and moabar in a bay where the sea do not exceed ten or twelve fathom deep here the diver descend to the bottom and in bag or net which be tie about they body bring up the oyster which contain the pearl on account of certain great fish which kill the diver they hire bramin to charm they from do harm and these have the twentieth part of the pearl the king get the tenth part -lrb- 2 -rrb- these oyster be only find from the beginning of April to the end of may in this place but from the beginning of September to the middle of October they be get in another place about three hundred mile distant the king of this country go naked like the rest of he subject except that he wear some honorable mark of distinction as a collar of precious stone about he neck and a thread of silk hang down to he breast on which be string 104 large fine pearl by which he count he prayer as with a rosary these prayer be merely the word _ pacaupa _ repeat 104 time over he wear a sort of bracelet on three place of he arm and on he leg and ring on all he finger and toe this king have a thousand concubine and if any woman please he fancy he take she away from whoever she may happen to belong to he once do this unjust deed to he own brother in consequence of which a civil war have nearly ensue but as they mother threaten to cut off she own breast if they continue they enmity they be reconcile he have a numerous guard of horseman who be under a vow when he die to throw themselves into the fire in which he body be consume that they may serve he in the next world this prince and the other king of moabar buy they horse from ormus and other part as they country produce none or if any happen to be breed there they be ugly and useless -lrb- 3 -rrb- condemn person often offer themselves to die in honor of a particular idol on which the devotee put himself to death with twelve knife give himself twelve deep wound in various part of he body call out aloud on the infliction of each that he do this in honor of such or such a idol and the last of all be through he own heart after which he body be burn by he kindred the woman of this country voluntarily burn themselves along with the body of they deceased husband and those who neglect to do this be hold in disrepute they worship idol and most of they hold cow in such high veneration that they would not eat they holy flesh for any consideration on earth a certain tribe be call gauus who feed upon such ox as die of themselves but never kill any these gauus be descend from the people who slew st thoma and dare not enter the shrine in which he body be preserve the people of this country sit on carpet on the ground use no chair or stool they only grain be rice they be not a martial people and kill no animal but when they be incline for animal food they get the saracen or some other people to kill for they both man and woman wash themselves twice a-day and always before eat and those who neglect this ceremony be reputed heretic they never touch they meat with they left hand which they only employ for wipe themselves or other unclean purpose each drink from he own pot neither do they allow it to touch they mouth but hold it above and pour in the drink and to stranger who have no pot they pour liquor into they hand from which they must drink as they will not allow they pot to be touch by any other person justice be severely administer for crime and in some case a creditor have a singular manner of compelling payment by draw a circle round he debtor out of which he must not stir till he have satisfy he creditor or give security for the debt under the pain of death i marco once see the king on horseback thus encircle by a merchant whom he have long put off with delay and the king would not come out of the circle which the merchant have draw till he have send for the means of pay the merchant all the people who be present highly applaud the king justice they be very scrupulous of drinking wine and those who be addict to that practice be hold disreputable and unworthy of be admit as witness which be the case likewise with those who go to sea as they reckon they desperate person they look on letchery as no sin in the month of June July and August they have no rain and it be excessively hot insomuch that they could not live if it be not for the refreshing wind which blow from the sea they have many physiognomist and soothsayer who observe omen from bird and beast and other sign these people consider one hour in every day of the week as unlucky which they name choiach and which be different on all the day all of which be carefully record in they book and they be curious observer of nativity at thirteen year of age they boy be put out to gain they living who go about buy and sell by means of a small stock give they to begin with in the pearl season these boy will buy a few pearl and sell they again for a small profit to the merchant who be unable to endure the sun what gain they get they bring to they mother to lay out for they as it be not lawful for they to live at they father cost they daughter be dedicate to the service of the idol and appoint by the priest to sing and dance in presence of the idol and they frequently set victuals before the idol for some time as if they would eat singing all the while when they fall to eat themselves and then return home the great man have a kind of litter make of large cane artificially work which be fix in some high situation to avoid be bite by tarantula -lrb- 4 -rrb- and other vermin and for the benefit of fresh air the sepulchre of st thoma be in a small city not much frequent by merchant but very much by christian and saracen on account of devotion the saracen hold he as a great prophet or holy man and call he ananias the christian take of a red earth which be find in the place where he be slay which they mix with water and administer to the sick with great reverence it happen in the year 1288 that a great prince who have more rice than he have room to keep it in choose to make bold with that room in st thoma 's church in which pilgrim be receive and convert it into a granary : but he be so terrify by a vision of st thoma in the night follow that he be glad to remove it with great speed the inhabitant be black although not bear so but by constantly anoint themselves with the oil of jasmine they become quite black which they esteem a great beauty insomuch that they paint they idol black and represent the devil as white the cow worshipper carry with they to battle some of the hair of a ox as a preservative against danger -lrb- 1 -rrb- this pinkerton call moabar on the margin and nachabar in the text of he dissertation on the trevigus edition of marco polo very justly observe that it refer to coromandel or the carnatic below the gaut harri erroneously substitute scorpion which be common all over indium -- e section xx _ of the kingdom of murfilus and the diamond mine and some other country of indium _ murfilus or monsul -lrb- 1 -rrb- be five hundred mile northwards from moabar and be inhabit by idolater in the mountain of this country there be diamond which the people search for after the great rain they afterwards ascend these mountain in the summer though with great labor on account of the excessive heat and find abundance of these precious stone among the gravel and be on these occasion much expose to danger from the vast number of serpent which shelter themselves in the hole and cavern of the rock in which the diamond be find in greatest abundance among other method of obtain the diamond they make use of the follow artifice : there be great number of white eagle which rest in the upper part of these rock for the sake of feed on the serpent which be find at the bottom of the deep vally and precipice where the man dare not go they therefore throw piece of raw meat down into these deep place which the eagle see stoop for and seize with all the little stone and gravel which adhere to they the people afterwards search the eagle nest when they leave they and carefully pick out all the little stone they can find and even carefully examine the eagle dung in quest of diamond -lrb- 2 -rrb- the king and great man of the country keep all the largest and finest diamond that be procure from these mine and allow the merchant to sell the rest lac be westwards from the shrine of st thoma from whence the bramin have they original who be the honestest merchant in the world and will not lie on any account they faithfully keep any thing commit to they charge or as broker they will sell or barter merchandize for other with great fidelity they be know by a cotton thread which they wear over they shoulder and tie under they arm across they breast they have but one wife be great astrologer of great abstinence and live to great age they constantly chew a certain herb which keep they tooth good and help digestion there be certain religious person among they call _ tangui _ who live with great austerity go altogether naked they principal worship be address to cow of which they wear a small brass image on they forehead and they make a ointment of ox bone with which they anoint themselves very devoutly they neither kill nor eat any living creature and even abstain from green herb or fresh root till dry esteeming every thing that live to have a soul they use no dish but lay they victuals on dry leaf they ease themselves in the sand and they disperse it lest it should breed worm which might die for want of food some of these people be say to live to 150 year of age and when they die they body be burn cael be a great city govern by aster one of the four brethren -lrb- 3 -rrb- who be very rich and kind to merchant he be say to have three hundred concubine all the people this country be continually chew a and even they own sister it also contain jew and christian who have a peculiar language they have pepper brazil indigo black lion parrot of many kind some white as snow some azure and other red peacock very different from ours and much larger and they fruit be very large in this country there be many astrologer and physician in camarus there be ape so large that they seem like man and here we again come in sight of the north star delaus have a king and its inhabitant have a peculiar language -lrb- 6 -rrb- and be idolater ship from mangus come here for trade malabar be a kingdom in the not good for spin and be only fit for make quilt canhau be a great city have plenty of frankincense and carry on a great trade in horse in cambaium be much indigo buckram and cotton semenath or indium near this there be say to be two island one inhabit by man and the other by woman the man visit they wife only during the month of march April and may and then return to they own island and it be report that the air of that country admit of no other procedure the woman keep they son till twelve year old and then send they to they father these people be christian have a bishop who be subject bagdat the people of socotora be say to be great enchanter though excommunicate for the practice by they prelate and be report to raise contrary wind to bring back the ship of those who have wrong chesmacoran on the north-west there be thirteen kingdom indium minor be from ziambo to murfilus -lrb- 5 -rrb- in which be eight kingdom and many island the second or middle indium be call abascium -lrb- 6 -rrb- of which the chief king be a christian who have six other king subject to he authority three of whom be christian and three of they mahometan there be also jew in he dominion st thoma after preach in nubium come to abascia where he preach for some time and then go to moabar or coromandel the abyssinian be valiant soldier always at war with the sultan of aden and the people of nubium i be tell that in 1288 the great emperor of the abyssinian be extremely desirous to have visit jerusalem but be dissuade from the attempt on account of the saracen kingdom which be in the way he send a pious bishop to perform he devotions for he at the holy sepulchre on he return the bishop be make prisoner by the sultan of aden and circumcise by force on this affront the abyssinian monarch raise a army with which he defeat the sultan and two other saracen king and take and destroy the city of aden abyssinium be rich in gold escier subject to aden be forty mile distant to the south-east and produce abundance of fine white frankincense which be procure by make incision in the bark of certain small tree and be a valuable merchandize some of the people on that coast from want of corn use fish which they have in great abundance instead of bread and also feed they beast on fish they be most abundantly take in the month of march April and may i now return to some province more to the north where many tartar dwell who have a king call caidu of the race of zingi but who be entirely independent these tartar observant of the custom of they ancestor dwell not in city castle or fortress but continually roam about along with they king in the plain and forest and be esteem true tartar they have no corn of any kind but have multitude of horse cattle sheep and other beast and live on flesh and milk in great peace in they country there be white bear of large size twenty palm in length very large wild ass little beast call _ ronde _ from which we have the valuable fur call sable and various other animal produce fine fur which the tartar be very skilful in take this country abound in great lake which be freeze over except for a few month in every year and in summer it be hardly possible to travel on account of marsh and water for which reason the merchant who go to buy fur and who have to travel for fourteen day through the desert have wooden house at the end of each day journey where they barter with the inhabitant and in winter they travel in sledge without wheel quite flat at the bottom and rise semicircularly at the top and these be draw by great dog yoke in couple the sledgeman only with he merchant and fur sit within -lrb- 7 -rrb- beyond these tartar be a country reach to the extremest north call the _ obscure land _ because the sun never appear during the greatest part of the winter month and the air be perpetually thick and darkish as be the case with we sometimes in hazy morning the inhabitant be pale and squat and live like beast without law religion or king the tartar often rob they of they cattle during the dark month and lest they might lose they way in these expedition they ride on mare which have suck foal leave these at the entrance of the country under a guard and when they have get possession of any booty they give the rein to the mare which make the best of they way to rejoin they foal in they long-continued summer -lrb- 8 -rrb- these northern people take many of the finest fur some of which be carry into russium which be a great country near that northern land of darkness the people in russium have fair complexion and be greek christian pay tribute to the king of the tartar in the west on whom they border in the eastern part of russium there be abundance of fine fur wax and mine of silver and i be tell the country reach to the northern ocean in which there be island which abound in falcon and ger-falcon -lrb- 1 -rrb- this conclude section may be consider as a kind of appendix in which marco have place several samojed be extremely short but the expression here use must allude to the long-continued summer day when for several month the sun never set -- e chap xii _ travels of oderic of portenau into china and the east in _ 1318 -lrb- 1 -rrb- introduction oderic of portenau a minorite friar travel into the eastern country in the year 1318 accompany by several other monk and penetrate as far as china after he return he dictate in 1330 the account of what he have see during he journey to friar william de solona or solangna at padua but without order or arrangement just as it occur to he memory this traveller have be name by different editor oderic oderisius and oldericus de foro julii de udina utinensis or de porto vahonis or rather nahonis porto-nahoni or portenau be the _ mutatio ad nonum _ a station or stage which be mention in the itinerarium hierosolymitanum or description of the various route to jerusalem a work compile for the use of pilgrim and its name be apparently derive from the kymerian language apparently a celtic dialect in which _ port _ signify a stage station or resting-place and _ nav _ or _ naou _ signify nine _ port-nav _ latinize into portus naoni and frenchify into portenau imply therefore the ninth station and be at present name pordanone in the friul the account of he travels together with he life be to be find : in _ bolandus acti sanctorum 14to januarius _ in which he be honor with the title of saint oderic die at udina in 1331 in 1737 basilio asquinus a italian barnabite of udina publish _ la vita e viaggi del beato qderico da udihe _ probably a italian translation from the latin of bolandus the account of these travels in the collection of hakluyt be call the journal of friar odericus concern the strange thing which he sawe among the tartar of the east and be probably transcribe and translate from bolandus in which these travels be entitle _ de mirabilibus mundus _ or the wonder of the world they have very much the air of a ignorant compilation fabricate in the name of oderic perhaps upon some slight foundation and stuff with ill-assorted story and description from marco polo and other writer intersperse with a few ridiculous miracle for the honor or disgrace of the minorite order mr pinkerton assert that oderic be not canonize until 1753 but the act of the saint be a publication of considerable antiquity and he be call _ beatus _ in the work of asquinus already mention as have be publish in 1787 -lrb- 1 -rrb- hakluyt ii 142 for the latin ii 158 for the old english translation -- forst voy and disc 147 section i _ the commencement of the travels of oderic _ many thing be relate by various author concern the custom fashion and condition of this world : yet as i friar oderic of portenau in the friul have travel among the remote nation of the unbeliever where i saw and hear many great and wonderful thing i have think fit to relate all these thing truly have cross over the great sea -lrb- 1 -rrb- from pera close by constantinople i come to trebizond in the country call pontus by the ancient this land be commodiously situate as a medium of intercourse for the persian and mede and other nation beyond the great sea with constantinople and the country of the west in this island i beheld a strange spectacle with great delight a man who lead about with he more than 4000 partridge this person walk on the ground while he partridge fly about he in the air and they follow he wherever he go and they be so tame that when he lay down to rest they all come flock about he like so many chicken from a certain castle call zauena three day journey from trebizond he lead he partridge in this manner to the palace of the emperor in that city and when the servant of the emperor have take such a number of the partridge as they think proper he lead back the rest in the same manner to the place from whence he come from this city of trebizond where the body of st athanasius be preserve over one of the gate i journey into the greater armenia to a city name azaron which be rich and flourish in former time but the tartar have nearly lay it entirely waste yet it still have abundance of bread and flesh and victuals of all sort except wine and fruit this city be remarkably cold and be say to be situate on a higher elevation that any other city of the world it have abundance of excellent water which seem to originate from the great river euphrate -lrb- 2 -rrb- which be only at the distance of a day journey azaron stand in the direct road between trebizond and tauri in journey farther on i come to a mountain name -rrb- four of we friar tolentinus de marchia jame of padua demetrius a lay brother and peter de seni suffer martyrdom in the city of thana these friar have engage for they passage at ormus to that there be four priest of the frank who be present and could attest the bad usage she have receive on this a person of alexandrium who be present request of the kadi that these man might be send other three go to the kadi who begin to dispute with they concern we faith say that christ be a mere man and not god but friar thoma -lrb- 2 -rrb- shew evidently both from reason and by example draw from scripture that christ be really god and man and so confound the kadus and the other infidel that they be unable to produce any rational argument in contradiction to he on this some one exclaim and what do you say concern mahomet to this friar thoma reply since i have prove to you that christ be really god and man who have give the law to mankind and since mahomet set himself contrary thereto and teach a opposite law if ye be wise you may well know what ought to be conclude respect he but the kadus and the other saracen insist that he should declare he own opinion concern mahomet you may all see say he what must be my opinion and as you insist that i should speak out plainly i must declare that you mahomet be the son of perdition and be in hell with he father the devil and not he only but all who have hold he law which be entirely abominable and false contrary to god and adverse to the salvation of soul on hearing this the saracen cry out let he die let he die who have thus blaspheme against the prophet then they seize upon the friar and expose they to the burning sun that they might suffer a severe death by the adust heat of the sun ray : for such be the excessive heat of the sun in that place that any person who remain expose to its direct influence during the time necessary to say the mass be sure to die but the friar remain hale and joyful from the third to the ninth hour of the day praise and glorify the lord the saracen astonish at this come to the friar say we intend to make a large fire and to throw you therein and if you faith be true as you say the fire will not be able to burn you but if you be burnt it will plainly appear that you faith be false to this the friar answer that they be ready to endure chain and imprisonment and even the fire and all other torment for the faith but should the fire consume they it be not to be infer that it do so on account of they faith but as a punishment for they sin : declare that they faith be most true and perfect and the only one by which the soul of man could possibly be save while they thus determine upon burn the friar the report of this affair spread over the whole city and all the people of both sex young and old flock to behold the spectacle the friar be accordingly lead to the most public square of the city where a great fire be light up into which friar thoma endeavor to throw himself but a saracen hold he back say : you shall not do so old man as you may have some spell or contrivance about you for prevent the fire from hurt you and you must allow another of you people to go into the fire then four of the saracen seize upon friar jame intend to have throw he into the fire but he request permission to walk in of he own accord to shew he devotion to the faith this however they refuse and throw he in headlong the fire be so large and fierce that he could not be see yet he voice be hear from the midst of the flame call upon the name of the glorious virgin when the fire be totally consume friar jame be see standing on the ember unhurt and joyful with he hand raise to heaven in form of the cross and himself praise and glorify god who have thus manifest the greatness of he faith and nothing whatever about he person not even he clothes or he hair be find in the slightest degree injure by the fire upon this all the people begin to cry aloud they be holy they be holy it be sinful to do they any injury for we see now that they faith be good and holy to this the kadi object say that he be not holy notwithstanding he remain unhurt amid the fire but that he tunic be fabricate from the wool of the land of habraa have protect he : that he ought therefore to be throw naked into the fire and they should then see whether or not he would be consume after this the oil upon the faggot which compose the fire and when the fire be fully kindle they throw friar jame into the midst friar thoma and demetrius retire from among the people remain on they knee pray to god time likewise the people be full of astonishment and admiration of what they have see and be so fill with wonder at the miracle that they know not what to believe or how to conduct themselves the but though they search frequently and carefully and even often touch the bone of the martyr they eye be always delude so that they could not perceive they : and thus we bring they reverently to the what manner it be procure _ pepper grow in the kingdom of minibar -lrb- malabar -rrb- where it be more plentiful than in any other part of the world be find abundantly in that country in a forest in quarrel and even in war in which the christian be always victorious in this forest which we have mention the plant which produce the pepper be plant near the large tree as we plant vine in italy it grow with numerous leaf like we pot herb and climb up the tree produce the pepper in cluster like we grape when these be ripe they be of a green color and be gather be lay in the sun to dry after which they be put into earthen vessel for sale in this forest there be many river have great number of crocodile and serpent and the native make large fire of straw and other dry fuel at the proper season for gather the pepper that they may do so without danger from these noxious animal at one end of this forest the city of polumbrum be situate which abound in all kind of merchandize the inhabitant of that country worship a living ox as they god which be make to labor in husbandry for six year and in he seventh year he be consecrate as holy and be no more allow to work with this strange animal god they use the follow strange ceremony : every morning they take two bason of silver or gold in one of which they collect the urine of the holy ox and he dung in the other and the devotee wash they face eye and all they five sens in the urine and anoint they eye cheek and breast with the dung after which they consider themselves sanctify for the whole of that day and even the believe and sometimes require the sacrifice of forty virgin on this account the people consecrate they son and daughter to the idol even as we christian dedicate we son and daughter to some particular order of religion or to some of the saint in heaven they even sacrifice they son and daughter so that many be put to death in honor of this accursed idol and they commit many other abominable and shame or reproach yet most of they prefer to be burn with the body of they husband but husband be not influence by any similar law as when they lose they wife they may marry again there be some other strange custom among the people of this country insomuch that the woman drink wine which the man do not and the woman shave they eyebrow and eyelid and they beard besides many other filthy custom contrary to the true decorum of the sex from that country i travel ten day journey to another kingdom call moabar -lrb- 3 -rrb- in which there be many city and in a certain church of that country the
