have many island under he dominion in this country there be tree which produce meal honey and wine and likewise the most deadly poison in the world the only remedy for which be human ordure dissolve in water which drink in considerable quantify act as a cathartic and expel the poison these tree be very large and when cut down a quantity of liquor exude from the trunk which be receive into bag country cause one of the arm of they child to be cut open when young put one of these stone into the wound which they heal up by means of the powder of a certain fish with the name of which i be unacquainted and through the virtue of these wonderful stone the native be generally victorious in they war both by sea and land there be a stratagem however which they enemy often successfully use against they to counteract the power of these stone provide themselves with iron or steel armor to defend they from the arrow of these people they use wooden stake point like weapon of iron and arrow e section viii _ of vast multitude of fish which throw themselves on the dry land _ the follow most wonderful circumstance be to be observe in this country of siampa all the kind of fish which frequent those sea swim towards the shore at certain time in such abundance that nothing can be see for a great way but the back of fish the fish throw themselves upon the shore and for the space of three day allow the people to take up as many of they as they please at the end of these three day this shoal return again to sea and a different kind come to the shore in the same manner and remain for a similar period and in the same way all other kind of fish in these sea come to the shore in succession each kind by itself this strange phenomenon happen once every year and the native pretend that the fish be teach by nature to do this in token of homage to they emperor i see many other strange thing in this country which would be incredible to any one who have not see they and among these i may mention that they have tortoise as large as oven in this country the body of they dead be burn and the living wife be burn along with they dead husband as have be already mention when describe the custom of the city of polumbrum and they be believe by this mean to accompany they husband into the other world travel from this country to the southward along the coast of the ocean i pass through many country and island one of which be call moumoran -lrb- 1 -rrb- and be 2000 mile in circumference the people of this country both man and woman go naked except a small cloth before the middle of they body they have dog face and worship a ox as they god and all of they wear the image of a ox in gold or silver on they forehead the man be very tall and strong and when they go to battle they carry target of iron or steel large enough to cover and protect they whole body all the prisoner whom they take in war unless they can ransom themselves with money be eat but those who be able to pay ransom be set free the king of this country wear a string of 300 large and fair pearl about he neck which he employ as a rosary for count he prayer and say every day as many prayer to he god he wear also on he finger a marvellously large and brilliant stone of a span long which resemble a flame of fire so that no one dare approach he and it be say to be the most valuable precious stone in all the world the great tartar emperor of cathay have often use every endeavor to procure this wonderful jewel but have never be able to prevail either by force policy or money -lrb- 1 -rrb- it be soul on this occasion they smear they body with lemon juice which prevent the leech from hurt they while they be in the water the water from this lake run into the sea at which place the inhabitant bodin -lrb- 1 -rrb- which name signify _ unclean _ and this island be inhabit by a most wicked people who devour raw flesh and commit all manner of wickedness and abominable uncleanness to a incredible extent insomuch that they kill and eat each other the father eat he son the son he father the husband he wife and the wife she husband if any man be sick the son go to the soothsayer or prognosticate priest request he to inquire of he god whether or not he father be to recover then both go to a idol of gold or silver which they thus address : we adore thee as we lord and god and we beseech thee to inform we whether such a man be to die or to recover from he present infirmity then the devil return a answer from the idol and if he say the man be to recover the son return to the house of he father and minister to he in all thing necessary until he regain he former health but if the response be that the man be to die the priest then go to he and put a cloth into he mouth immediately strangle he after this the dead body be cut in piece and all the friend and relation be invite to feast upon this horrible banquet which be accompany with music and all manner of mirth but the bone be solemnly bury on my blame this abominable practice they allege as its reason and excuse that it be do to prevent the worm from devour the flesh which would occasion great torment to he soul and all i could say be quite insufficient to convince they of they error there be many other novel and strange thing in this country to which no one would give credit who have not see they with he own eye yet i declare before god that i assert nothing of which i be not as sure as a man may be of any thing i have be inform by several credible person that this indium contain 4400 island most nicolo zeno _ nicolo zeno surname _ il cavaliere _ or the knight have a strong desire to see distant country that he might become acquaint with the manners and language of foreign nation by which he might acquire credit and reputation and might render himself the more useful to he country be a man of great property he fit out a ship with this view at he own expence in 1380 and sail through the strait of gibraltar to the northwards intend to visit england and flander by a storm which last many day he ship be cast away on the coast of _ frislanda _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- the vessel be entirely lose but the crew get safe on shore and part of the cargo be save zeno and he people be soon attack by the native attract by the hope of a rich plunder against whom they be hardly able in they weary and weather-beaten state to defend themselves but fortunately for they _ zichmnus _ or sinclair the reign prince or lord of _ porlanda _ -lrb- 2 -rrb- who happen to be then in _ frislanda _ and hear of they shipwreck come in all haste to they relief of which they stand in great need after discourse with they for some time in latin he take they under he protection and find nicolo zeno very expert both in naval and military affair he give he after some time the post of admiral of he fleet which nicolo for some time refuse but at length accept not long afterwards nicola write a account of these circumstance to he brother antonio invite he to come to _ frislanda _ who accordingly soon arrive there and live four year along with nicolo in that country and remain ten year in the service of _ zichmnus _ or sinclair the prince of that country after the death of he brother nicolo nicolo zeno have be shipwreck in 13so on the island of _ frislanda _ and save by prince _ zichmnus _ from the rude attack of the native put himself and all he people under the protection of this prince who be lord of certain island lie to the south of _ frislanda _ which be call _ porlanda _ and be the most fertile and most populous of all the island in those part _ zichmnus _ or sinclair be besides this duke of _ sorany _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- a place which lie on one side of scotland of these northern part i antonio zeno have construct a map which hang up in my house and which though it be much decay by time may serve to give some information to the curious _ zichmnus _ the lord of all these country be a man of great courage and famous for he skill in navigation the year before the arrival of nicolo zeno he have defeat the king of norway in a pitched battle and be now come with he force to conquer _ frislandium _ which be much larger than iceland on account of the knowledge of nicolo zeno in maritime affair the prince take he and all he crew on board he fleet and give order to he admiral to treat he with the highest respect and to take he advice in every affair of importance _ zichmnus _ have a fleet consist of thirteen vessel two of which only be galley the rest be small bark and only one of the whole be a ship -lrb- 4 -rrb- with all these they sail to the westward and without much difficulty make themselves master of _ ledovo _ and _ ilofe _ -lrb- 5 -rrb- and several other smaller island and turn into a bay call _ sudero _ in the haven of the town of _ sanestol _ -lrb- 6 -rrb- they take several small bark laden with fish -lrb- 7 -rrb- and here they find _ zichmnus _ who come by land with he army conquer all the country as he go they stay here but a short time and then shape they course to the westwards till they come to the other cape of the gulf or bay and here turn again they find certain island and broken land all of which they bring under subjection to _ zichmnus _ or sinclair these sea be all full of shoal and rock insomuch that if nicolo zeno and the venetian mariner have not act as pilot the whole foot in the opinion of all who be in it must have be lose so small be the skill of they people in comparison with ours who have be train up in the art and practice of navigation from they childhood after the proceedings already mention the admiral by the advice of nicolo zeno determine to make for the shore at a town call _ bondendon _ -lrb- 8 -rrb- with a view to get intelligence of the success which _ zichmnus _ have meet with in the prosecution of the war on land they here learn to they great satisfaction that he have fight a great battle in which he have put the army of the enemy to flight and in consequence of this intelligence the inhabitant send ambassador from all part of the island agree to yield the country to he pleasure and take down they flag and ensign in every town and castle it be therefore think advisable to remain at _ bondendan _ for he arrival as they have receive report that he would certainly be there in a short time on he arrival there be great congratulation and rejoicing as well for the victory obtain by land as for the success of the naval expedition and the venetian be much honor and extol for they skill every tongue be loud in they praise and nicolo zeno be much applaud for he prowess the prince cause nicolo to be bring into he presence and bestow high commendation for the skill he have exert in save the fleet and for the great valor he have display in the taking of many town where indeed there be no great difficulty or opposition in reward for which he bestow upon he the honor of knighthood and distribute rich and liberal present among he follower depart from _ bondendon _ the fleet return in triumph to _ frislanda _ the chief city of which be situate on the south-east side of the island within a gulf of which there be many in that island in this gulf or bay there be such vast quantity of fish take that many ship be yearly laden thence to supply flander britannium -lrb- 9 -rrb- england scotland norway and denmark and the produce of this fishing bring great riches into the country the foregoing circumstance be contain in a letter send by nicolo zeno to he brother antonio in which he invite he to come to _ frislanda _ and accordingly the latter set sail for this purpose and have surmount many danger safely join he brother in that far distant country antonio remain fourteen year in frisland or orkney four year of that time along with he brother and ten year alone after the death of nicolo the elder zeno ingratiate himself so much into the favor of the prince that he be appoint admiral of a fleet which be send out upon a expedition against _ estland _ -lrb- 10 -rrb- which lie between frisland and norway the invader commit great ravages in that country but hearing that the king of norway be come against they with a considerable fleet they depart in haste and be assail by a violent tempest they be drive on certain shoal where a part of they ship be lose and the remainder be save upon _ grisfand _ -lrb- 11 -rrb- a large but uninhabited island the fleet of the king of norway be overtake by the same storm and mostly perish of which _ zichmnus _ who be personally engage in this expedition be apprize in consequence of one of the enemy 's ship have likewise be force to take refuge in _ grisland _ finding himself drive so far to the north and have repair he ship zichmnus now resolve to make a attack upon the island of iceland which be under the dominion of the king of norway but find it too well fortified and defend for he small force and reflect that he diminish fleet be now in bad repair he deem it prudent to retire in he way homewards however he make a attack upon the island of _ estland _ of which there be seven in number these be _ tola _ yeal or zel _ broa _ brassa sound _ iscant _ unst or vust _ trans _ trondra _ mimant _ mainland _ danbert _ -lrb- 12 -rrb- and _ bre _ or bressa all of which he plunder and build a fort in bre where he leave nicolo zeno in the command with a sufficient garrison and a few small bark while he return himself to frisland in the ensue spring nicolo zeno resolve to go out upon discovery and have fit out three small vessel he set sail in July shape he course to the northward and arrive in _ engroveland _ -lrb- 13 -rrb- where he find a monastery of predicant friar and a church dedicate to st thoma hard by a mountain that throw out fire like etna or vesuvius in this place there be a spring of boil hot water by means of which the monk heat they church monastery and cell it be likewise bring info they kitchen and be so hot that they use no fire for dress they victuals and by enclose they bread in brass pot without any water it be baked by means of this hot fountain as well as if a oven have be use for the purpose the monk have also small garden cover over in winter which be water from the hot spring be effectually defend from the extreme cold and snow which be so rigorous in this region so near the pole by these means they produce flower and fruit and different kind of herb just as they grow in temperate climate and the rude savage of those part from see these to they supernatural effect take the friar for god and supply they with poultry flesh -lrb- 14 -rrb- and various other thing reverence the monk as they lord and ruler when the frost and snow be considerable the monk warm they apartment as before describe and by admit the hot water or open they window they be able in a instant to produce such a temperature as they may require in the building of they monastery they use no more material than be present to they by the before mention volcano take the burning stone which be throw from the crater they throw they while hot into water by which they be dissolve into excellent lime which when use in building last forever the same stone when cold serve to make they wall and vault as they can not be break or cut except with a iron instrument the vault which they build with these stone be so light as to require no prop for support they -lrb- 15 -rrb- on account of these great convenience the monk have construct so many wall and building of different kind as be really wonderful to see the covering or roof of they house be construct for the most part in the follow manner : have carry the wall to its full height they make it to incline or bend in gradually till it form a regular vault they be little incommoded with rain in this country as the climate be so extremely cold that the first snow that fall do not thaw for nine month the monk live mostly on fish and wild fowl for in consequence of the boil hot water run into a large and wide haven of the sea that bay be keep from freezing and there be so great a concourse of sea fowl and fish in that place that they easily take as many of they as they can possibly have occasion for with which they maintain a great number of people round about whom they keep constantly employ either in building or in catch fish and fowl and in a thousand other necessary occupation relative to the monastery the house of these native be build on the hill near the monastery of a round form about twenty-five foot wide at the bottom and grow gradually narrower as they go up in a conical form end in a small hole at top to admit light and air and the floor of the house be so hot that the inhabitant feel no cold within door at any season to this place many bark resort in summer from the neighbouring island from the cape above norway and from _ trondon _ or drontheim which bring to the father all kind of commodity and merchandize that they have occasion for take fish in exchange dry either in the sun or by means of cold and the fur of various animal the commodity bring here for sale be wood for fuel wooden utensil very ingeniously carve corn and cloth for make into garment by these mean the monk be plentifully supply with every thing they need in exchange for they fur and fish which be in great request by all the neighbouring nation monk resort to this monastery from norway and sweden and other country but principally from iceland it often happen that many bark be detain here ail the winter by the sea become freeze over the fishermen boat of this country be make in the form of a weaver shuttle long and narrow and point at each end construct of a light frame of fish bone case all over with the skin of fish sew together in many double and so tight and strong that it be wonderful to see the people bind themselves fast within they during storm and allow the wind and wave to drive they about without fear of they boat splitting or of themselves be drown even when they be drive against a rock they remain sound and without hurt or damage in the bottom of each boat there be a kind of sleeve or nose tie fast in the middle by a string and when any water get into the boat they let it run into the upper half of the sleeve which they then fasten with two piece of wood after which they loosen the under band and squeeze the water out and they repeat this operation as often as may be necessary with great facility and without danger the water of the boiling spring be sulphureous be convey into the monastery and the cell of the principal friar by means of pipe make of copper tin or stone and be so hot that it heat the apartment like a stove without communicate any disagreeable or unwholesome stench they sweet water for drinking be convey in a subterraneous canal of masonry into a great copper reservoir in the middle of the court of the convent and this reservoir be contain within a larger bason supply from the boiling spring be continually keep of a proper temperature and prevent from freezing this they use in the preparation of they victuals for drinking and for water they garden thus they derive much convenience and comfort from the adjoining volcano and these good friar make it they chief study to keep they garden in order and to erect commodious and even elegant building for this latter purpose they be in no want of good workman and ingenious artizan as they give good wages so that there be a great resort of workman and artizan of every denomination they be likewise very bountiful to those who carry they fruit and seed and other article and as great profit be to be make and provision be very cheap there be a great resort of workman and artist of every denomination and of trader to this place most of these monk speak latin particularly the superior and principal of the monastery this be all that be know of _ engroveland _ or greenland from the relation of nicolo zeno who give likewise a particular description of a river that he discover as be to be see in the map which i antonio zeno have draw of all these country not be able to bear the cold of these northern and inhospitable region nicolo zeno fall sick and soon afterwards return to frisland where he die he leave two son behind he john and thoma the latter of whom have likewise two son nicolo the father of the celebrated cardinal zeno and peter from whom be descend the rest of the zeno who be now live after the death of nicolo he fortune honor and dignity devolve upon he brother antonio and though he make great supplication and entreaty for the purpose he be not permit to return to he native country as zichmnus who be a man of a high spirit and great valor have resolve to make himself master of the sea and for this purpose make use of the talent and advice of antonio and order he to go with a few bark to the westwards because in the summer several island have be discover by some of the fisherman of this voyage and the discovery which be make in consequence of it antonio give a account in a letter to he brother carlo which we here give exactly as it be write have only alter a few ii _ sequel of the narrative by antonio zeno _ twenty-six year ago four fishing boat which have be overtake by a violent storm be drive out to sea for a great many day and on the cessation of the tempest they discover a island call _ estoitland _ which lay above a thousand mile to the westward of _ frisland _ one of the boat contain six man be cast away upon this island and the man be make prisoner by the inhabitant be conduct to a fine and populous city where the king reside who send for various interpreter but none could be find except one who speak latin this man who in like manner have be cast by accident on the same island ask they by order of the king from what country they have come and be make acquaint with they case the king order that the should stay in the country these order they obey as indeed they could not do otherwise and they remain five year on the island during which time they learn the language of the people one of they be in various part of the island and affirm that it be a very rich country abound in every commodity and convenience in life be little less than iceland but much more fertile have a very high mountain in the center from whence four great river take they source and traverse the whole country the inhabitant be a very ingenious and sensible people and have art and handicraft of every kind as we have and it be highly probable that they formerly carry on some traffic with europe as this man say he see latin book in the king library but which at present they do not understand for they have a language of they own and peculiar letter or character in which it be write they trade with _ engroveland _ or greenland and get from thence fur brimstone and pitch to the south of _ estoitland _ there be a very large and populous country which abound with gold the people sow corn and make the liquor call beer which be drink by the people of the north as wine be among we in italy they have large and extensive wood make they building with wall and have a great number of town and castle they build ship and navigate the sea but they have not the loadstone and know nothing about the use of the compass on which account these fisherman be hold in high estimation insomuch that the king send they with twelve ship to the southward to a country call drogio in they voyage thither they have such contrary wind and stormy weather that they think to have founder at sea but escape that death they meet with a fate still more dreadful as they be make prisoner by the savage who be cannibal and most of they be devour but the frisland fisherman and he companion by teach these barbarian the way to catch fish with net save they life this man use to go every day to the sea or the river in which he catch vast quantity of fish which he give away among the principal people of the country by which mean he get into such high favor that he be beloved and respect by every body the fame of this man spread abroad through the whole country and one of the lord be very desirous to have he that he might see and learn this new and wonderful art of catch fish make war against the lord with whom he live and prevail in consequence of he superior power and greater skill in war the fisherman and he companion be give up to he as the price of peace during thirteen year that he reside in these part he say that he be transfer in this manner to twenty-five different lord as they be continually at war with each other to procure possession of he so that by wander about the country in this manner he become perfectly well acquaint with every part of it he say that it be a very extensive country and as it be a new world but that the inhabitant be a rude unpolished people without the enjoyment of any convenience of life for although they take or kill many wild animal in hunting they have not the sense to make they skin into garment but all go naked and be miserably pinch with cold they be besides extremely uncivilized and savage continually engage in war against each other in which they commit horrible ravages and devour they prisoner they know not the use of any metal and live by the chase be arm with spear of wood make sharp at the point and use bow the string of which be make of slip of hide they be divide into small tribe each of which have its lord or governor and the law or custom of the several tribe differ much from each other farther to the southwest however the manners be more civilized in proportion to the increase mildness of the climate and there the people be not without some degree of knowledge make use of gold and silver and have city and temple dedicate to idol in which they offer up human sacrifice after reside many year among this savage people the principal fisherman become desirous of return into he own country but he companion be without hope of ever see it again wish he prosperity in he attempt and resolve to remain where they be bid they farewell he flee through the wood in the direction which lead towards _ drogio _ and be receive with great kindness by one of the lord of that country who know he and who be a determine enemy to the lord from whence he have escape thus pass from one lord to another with all of whom he be well acquaint as he have formerly reside with they all he at length and with great difficulty arrive in drogio where he stay three year then fortunately hear that some small vessel have arrive on the coast he go thither and learn to he unspeakable satisfaction that they be from _ estoitland _ upon this he earnestly request to be take on board which they do very willingly and as he understand the language of the country which the other do not he become they interpreter he afterwards make repeat voyage from _ estoitland _ to _ drogio _ and acquire great riches after which he equip a bark of he own in which he return to _ frisland _ where he make a report to he lord of all that have befall he and of the discovery he have make of a extensive and wealthy country as this strange and marvellous story be confirm by the testimony of the sailor he have bring along with he it gain full credit and accordingly zichmnus determine to send I antonio zeno with a fleet into these part and so great be the desire among the people to embark in this expedition that we fleet be well man and equip without expence to the public i accordingly set sail with a great number of ship and man but not commander in chief as i expect for zichmnus go in person on the expedition we great preparation for the voyage to _ estoitland _ begin in a unlucky hour as three day before we departure the fisherman die who be to have be we guide yet zichmnus would not give up the enterprise but take for he guide several of the sailor who have return with the fisherman from _ estoitland _ shape we course to the westwards we pass several island subject to _ frisland _ and arrive at _ ledovo _ or the lewi where we staid a week to refresh ourselves and to provide the fleet with necessaries depart thence we arrive on the first of July off the island of _ ilofe _ or islay and the wind be favourable do not stop there but stand on we voyage not long afterwards be in the main sea we be overtake by a dreadful tempest which toss we to and fro at the mercy of the wind and wave for eight day so that we know not whereabouts we be by the violence of this tempest we lose many of we vessel but after the return of good weather we collect the remains of we shatter fleet and have a fair wind we stand on to the westward and at length descry the coast of _ estoitland _ and arrive in a good and safe harbor here we see a infinite number of armed man run furiously towards the shore apparently for the purpose of defend the island upon this zichmnus command sign of peace to be make and the islander send ten man to we who could speak ten different language but we could understand none of these except one man who happen to be a icelander this man be bring to we prince and give the follow account of the country and people the land be call _ icarta _ and all its king be name _ icarus _ after the name of its first king who be the son of _ daedalus _ king of scotland this _ daedalus _ have discover and conquer the island and after institute the body of law by which they be still govern have leave they he son to be they king after this _ daedalus _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- sail in quest of farther discovery but be overtake by a violent storm and drown in memory of which they name they island icarium the sea surround it the _ icarian _ sea and all they successive king _ icarus _ he state moreover that they be perfectly contented with the state in which they have be place by providence and not choose to make the smallest change in they manners and custom would admit no stranger into they land and therefore request the prince not to attempt violate the law of they king of glorious memory as any such attempt would turn to he manifest destruction since they be resolve to sacrifice they life in defense of they law they be willing however to receive _ one _ of we man who should be advance to the rank of a chief on purpose to learn we language have already receive _ ten _ different man with that view from ten different nation upon this _ zichmnus _ sail from the harbor as if mean to go away from the island but be in want of wood and water he skirt along the coast at some distance and put into another harbor on the eastern side of the island with all he fleet here the mariner go on shore and procure the necessary supplies with all possible speed lest they might be attack by the native this precaution be by no means unnecessary for the inhabitant near this harbor make signal by fire and smoke to the rest of the country and take to they arm be soon join by other and come down upon we man with bow and arrow and other weapon and in the conflict many of they be kill and other dangerously wound -lrb- 2 -rrb- we be therefore oblige to depart and make a large circuit round the island always accompany on the shore and on the hill by a vast number of armed man to oppose we landing see that nothing could be do here zichmni set sail to the eastward with a fair wind and after six day sail we come in sight of land which we find to be a very good country with a excellent harbor we descry a mountain at a considerable distance which emit smoke and zichmnus send a hundred soldier to explore the country and to inquire if it be inhabit in the meantime we take in wood and water and catch vast quantity of fish and sea-fowl and procure immense number of egg so that we people before almost famish have now more provision than they could eat to this harbor we give the name of port _ trin _ and the point that stretch out into the sea be name cape _ trin _ the soldier who have be send out to examine the country return at the end of eight day and report they have be all through the island quite to the smoking mountain and that the smoke we see proceed from a fire at its bottom where there be a spring of liquid pitch which run into the sea they say likewise that the interior of the island be inhabit by a wild people who be very short in stature and timid and hide themselves in cave on receive this piece of intelligence and consider that the island be bless with a pure and wholesome air good soil fine river and many other advantage ziehmnus resolve to tartary in 1394 _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- john schildtberger a native of munich in bavarium go with the army of king sigismund of hungary against the turk in 1394 in 1395 be take prisoner he be send by bajazet whose name he always write _ weyasit _ into asia in the great battle in which bajazet be defeat and take captive by timur schildtberger be again make prisoner and accompany that conqueror in all he expedition till he death in 1405 at otrar or farab though schildtberger say that he die in he capital of samarcand after the death of timur he enter into the service of shah-rokh and be leave by that prince among the auxiliary troops which assist he brother miran-shah against kara-joseph a turkomanian emir of the black-weather tribe miran-shah have be make prisoner and behead by kara-joseph schildtberger follow the standard of abubekr the son of miran-shah at this time there live in the court of abubekr a prince name zegra a son of the khan of great tartary to whom ideku -lrb- 2 -rrb- send word that he would resign to he the sovereignty of kiptschak zegra accordingly set out for great tartary accompany by schildtberger and four other they route lay through _ strana _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- which produce good silk then through _ gursey _ gurghium or georgium which be inhabit by christian after this through the country of _ lahinsham _ -lrb- 4 -rrb- where silk be cultivate and through _ schurban _ or shirvan where the silk be produce from which the silk stuff of damascus and _ kaffer _ -lrb- 5 -rrb- be make they next pass through _ bursa _ -lrb- 6 -rrb- which be situate in turkey and from whence the fine silk of which velvet be manufacture be send to venice and lucca : this be a unhealthy country they route next lay through _ temur-capit _ demir-kapus or derbent which signify in the tartarian language the iron-gate and which separate persium from tartary they then go through a town of great strength call _ origen _ -lrb- 7 -rrb- situate in the middle of the _ edil _ after this they way be through the mountainous country of setzalet in which there be many christian who have a bishop and some carthusian monk who perform the service in the tartarian language that the common people may understand what be sing and read they be now arrive in great tartary at the camp of ideku who have just assemble all he force and be go to march into the land of _ ibissibur _ -lrb- 8 -rrb- in this expedition they employ two month of continual march in the course of which they cross a range of mountain thirty-two day journey in length and at they extremity there be a desert which be the end of the world -lrb- 9 -rrb- which desert be uninhabitable from the number of reptile and wild beast with which it be infested these mountain be inhabit by roam savage who be hairy all over except they face and hand -lrb- 10 -rrb- and who subsist on green leaf and root or whatever they can procure in this country also there be wild ass as large as horse the inhabitant employ dog as large as ass to draw cart and sledge and some time feed upon they they be christian and they bury they young people who die in celibacy with music and rejoice eating and drinking at they grave in this country they cultivate nothing but bean and they eat no bread have make a conquest of _ bissibur _ they march into _ walor _ -lrb- 11 -rrb- which they also conquer and then return into kiptschak at this period there be a high officer of state among the tartar call obmann who have usurp the power of nominating and depose the khan and to whom all the lord or chief be subservient this anomalous dignity be now hold by ideku who as have be already mention have invite zegra to accept the dignity of khan this ideku with the khan all the nobility and the whole people wander continually up and down the country with they wife and child they cattle and whole property to the number of about 100000 people have no fixed abode but dwelling in moveable hut at all season of the year at this time there be a king in tartary name _ schudicho chey _ or _ kom _ or schadibeck-knan the son of timur-utluck grandson of timur-melik-aglen and great-grandson of urus - khan this schadibeck reign from 1401 to 1406 immediately on hearing that ideku be approach he take to flight but be pursue and kill in a skirmish ideku appoint _ polat _ or pulad-khan the son -lrb- 12 -rrb- of schadibeck to be he successor who reign a year and a half between 1406 and 1408 after he _ segel-aladie _ or zedy-khan the son of _ tokatmysch _ or toktemysch-khan get possession of the throne but he be soon expel by timur-khan the son of timur-uduck and brother of pulad - khan who reify fourteen month thebak the brother of pulad-khan take the field against timur-khan and kill he but be unable to attain the sovereignty as he brother kerunhardin ascend the throne which he only hold for five month thebak again endeavor to dispossess he brother kerunhardin but be unable to effectuate he purpose for at this juncture ideku interpose and confer the sovereignty on zegra in the room of both zegra however continue khan only for nine month when mohammed-khan son of the before-mentioned timur-khan and grandson of timur utluck gain a pitched battle against ideku and zegra in which ideku be make prisoner and zegra flee into a country call descht-kiptscha mohammed be in he turn drive from the throne by waroch from whom mohamm soon after retake he dominion he be again drive out by doblaberd who only keep possession for three day when he be in he turn dethrone by waroch he again be soon afterwards slay by mohammed who a third time attain the sovereign power after these repeat revolution zegra make ah unsuccessful attempt to recover the throne in which enterprize he lose he life on the death of zegra schildtberger and the other four christian who have be in he service attach themselves to manustzusch who have be counsellor to that prince this person go upon a journey to kaffa in the crimea where six different religion be profess among the mixed inhabitant of that peninsula a part of whom be christian after a residence there of five month manustzusch cross the strait of zabake in the country call _ zeckcha _ or zikchium where he sojourn for six month but the sultan of turkey send a message to the sovereign of that country request that manustzusch might not be allow to remain there any longer and upon this he remove into the land of _ magrill _ -lrb- 13 -rrb- schildtberger and he christian companion reflect that they be now only three day journey from the black sea form a resolution to endeavor to return into they own country with this view have take leave of manustzusch they go to the capital of the country of _ bathan _ -lrb- 14 -rrb- whence they request to be convey across into christendom but be refuse upon this they ride four day journey along the coast when at length they espy a ship at about eight italian mile from the shore they make signal to the people on board by means of fire and a boat be send to inquire they purpose and have convince the boat crew that they be christian by rehearse the lord prayer ave marium and creed and these people have report a account of they to the captain of the ship boat be send back to bring they on board have escape many danger they land at constantinople where they be well receive by john palaeologus the grecian emperor who : send they by sea to the castle of kilium at the mouth of the danube schildtberger here part from he companion and go with some merchant to akkerman -lrb- 15 -rrb- in wallachium from thence he go to _ sedhof _ sutschawa the capital of moldavium or the lesser walachium hence to _ lubick _ call otherwise lwow or lemberg the capital of white russium where he be detain by illness for 1426 or 1427 -- e chap xvii _ travels of the ambassador of mirza shah rokh king of persium from herat to khanbalek in katkay in 1419 _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- introduction this curious embassy send by mirza shah rokh one of the son of timur or timor the great better know in europe by the name of tamerlane travel from herat in persium the residence of they sovereign to khanbalek cambalu or peke the imperial city of kathay khatay kitay or northern china where yong-lo or ching-tsu the third emperor of the race of ming then keep he court yong-lo begin to reign in 1404 and die in 1425 the year in which the ambassador return to persia the race of ming a chinese dynasty be found in 1368 fifty-one year before the present embassy by hoang-vu who have expel the mongol khan the degenerate and enervated descendant of gingi or zengi this journey be describe by the famous persian historian emir-khond or emir-khovand usually know by the name of mirchond in he performance entitle of the wonder of the world nicola witsen -lrb- 2 -rrb- a learn burgomaster of amsterdam have insert this curious journey in he curious work of north and east tartary have translate it for that purpose from the persian into dutch the singularly excellent work of witsen be extremely rare and very seldom to be meet with as the author suppress the work from motive which be now unknown the library of the university of goettingen formerly possess a copy which have belong to the library of the empress of russium and which be purchase at the sale of the effect of the late mr thunnman for eighty-six dollar these travels be contain in the fourth volume of the french collection by thevenot who say that it be write in persian in twelve page without note or explanation he make no mention of the translator but probably borrow the article from witsen without acknowledgment the present edition be take from astley collection and be enrich by several note and elucidation by mr john reinhold forster who while he regret the scarcity of witsen valuable work in dutch forget to inform we of the existence of this tract in thevenot or in the collection of astley this journey throw some light on the interior part of tartary or central asia and be therefore a important addition to we scanty knowledge of that little known and interesting country the real storehouse of nation and the scourge during many century of all the surrounding country from the sea of japan to the baltic and from the frozen ocean to the sea of china indium persium arabium and roum or the mediterranean the present edition have be carefully correct and enlarged by collation with the abstract which forster publish from the dutch translation by witsen this journal give many curious remark on the magnificence of the chinese court and respect the ceremonial observe in give audience to ambassador which still continue nearly the same the editor of astley labor hard to explain away the want of notice in these travels and in the repeat journey of marco polo respect the great chinese wall but the only rational explanation of this omission be the clear conclusion that it be not then build we learn from this narrative that the paper money of the former mogul khan of kathay be no longer in use and that silver money under the same denomination of balish have be substitute in its place -lrb- 1 -rrb- astley khanbalek and they reception at the court of the emperor of kathay _ in the year of the hejirah 822 or 1419 of the christian era the sultan mirza shah rokh king of persium send ambassador from herat he royal residence to the emperor of kathay or china of whom shadi khoja be the chief at the same time mirza baysangar the son of shah rokh send soltan ahmet and a painter name khoja gayath addin to accompany he father ambassador give order to he servant to keep a exact journal of they travels and to take notice of every thing that be remarkable in every city and country they travel through carefully note the nature of the road the police and custom of the people and the magnificence and government of the various sovereign leave herat -lrb- 1 -rrb- on the 11th of the month zus ` lkaa-deh -lrb- 2 -rrb- the ambassador arrive at balkh on the 8th of zus ` lhejjeh where they be detain by the rain till the first of moharram in the year 823 of the hejira -lrb- 3 -rrb- or Thursday 16th January 1420 on which day they depart from balkh and arrive in twenty-two day journey at samarkand they here find soltan shar and mehemmed bakhshus the ambassador of ulug-beg -lrb- 4 -rrb- who have be send to accompany they together with all he kathayan : and the ambassador of khorassan badakshan and from other prince have here join company they all set out together with those of kathay -lrb- 5 -rrb- have pass through the city of tashkend sayram and ash -lrb- 6 -rrb- they enter into the country of the mongol -lrb- 7 -rrb- on the eleventh of _ rabiya-al - akher _ and learn that the _ horde _ be in great confusion awis-khan be at war with shir mehemmed aglan these disturbance be settle amir khudadad who command in that country come to inform they that the ambassador might proceed safely on they journey on the 18th of jomada - al-awal they come to a place name bilgotu -lrb- 8 -rrb- on the territory of mehemmed-beg where they wait for the daji -lrb- 9 -rrb- and the retinue of the shah of badakshan after they arrival they pass the river _ kenker _ -lrb- 10 -rrb- on the twenty-second of jomada-al-awal and next day they see mehemmed - beg prince of that horde whose son soltan shadus karkan -lrb- 11 -rrb- be son-in - law to shah rokh and a daughter of that prince have marry mirza mehemmed jukus -lrb- 12 -rrb- on the twenty-eighth of the before name month they enter the country of ilduz -lrb- 13 -rrb- which be occupy by the tribe of jel and under the dominion of shir behram or scheir begrahim and though the sun be then in the summer solstice they be often astonished to find ice two inch thick in this vast desert on the eighth of jomada-al-akher they be alarm by receive news that the son of ahmed beg have plunder the dajus who be ambassador from awis or oweys khan and they make every possible haste to pass through the defile of the mountain notwithstanding of much hail and rain fall at the time at the end or the month they arrive at tarkan -lrb- 14 -rrb- where there be a great temple with a huge idol which the idolatrous inhabitant say be the image of shakmonnus or shamku depart from thence on the second of rajeb they come on the fifth to karakoja -lrb- l5 -rrb- and certain kathayan come here on the tenth who take a list of the name of the ambassador and all they retinue on the nineteenth they arrive at the town of ata-sufus where kha zadeh taj ` oddin reside a person descend from the prophet originally of the city of tormul and son-in-law to amir fakr ` oddin chief of the moslem in kabul -lrb- 16 -rrb- on the twenty-second of rajeb they arrive at kabul -lrb- 17 -rrb- in which place amir fakr ` oddin have build a fine mosque near which be a temple of the idolater set round with image and strange figure of various size and at the door there be two gigantic statue that seem to fight mengli timur bayrus a handsome young man be governor of this city depart thence on the twenty-fifth of rajeb they enter on the desert of noman cobus where they only find water once in two day and on the twelfth of shaaban they see lion oxen and other wild beast the ox name gau kottah be very large and strong insomuch that they be able to toss a man and horse into the air they tail be remarkably long and hairy and be in great estimation all over the east where they be often carry on long pole by way of ornament and be likewise much employ for drive away fly on the fourteenth they arrive at a place within twelve stage of sekju -lrb- 18 -rrb- the first city in kathay from this time the kathayan come daily to meet they erect tent or hut adorn with green bough in the desert for they accommodation and plentifully supply they table with fowl and various kind of flesh fruit fresh and dry and other victuals all serve on porcelain or china dish besides several kind of strong liquor and henceforward they be as splendidly regale in the desert as they afterwards be in the city of kathay accord to the list take by the kathayan amir shadus khoja and gaksheh have 200 person in they retinue soltan ahm and gayath-addin 500 argdak sixty ardvan fifty and taj ` oddin fifty in all 860 person among whom be many merchant who be pass as belong to the retinue of the ambassador and who be afterwards under the necessity of perform the service which fall to they lot accord to the register in take this list the kathayan officer make they swear that there be no other person besides those name and inform they that they would be despise if they do not tell the truth it be remarkable that among the many viand and liquor supply to they in the before-mentioned entertainment there be a pot of chinese _ tea _ which the jesuit trigault imagine have only come into use in china of late year tea be call _ tscha _ by the chinese and its use be very ancient as the earlier of the two mahometan traveller who write in 851 and 867 mention the use by the chinese in that early period of the infusion of the leaf of a shrub call _ sah _ or _ tsha _ even at that time the use of tea must have become a article of constant and extensive consumption in china as the emperor derive a large revenue from the tax on that article -lrb- 19 -rrb- on the sixteenth of the month shaaban they be inform that the dankji governor of the border of kathay intend to entertain they that day with a imperial feast and on they arrival at he encampment they find a square arpent -lrb- 20 -rrb- of ground inclose with tent the cord of which fasten to peg in the ground be so interlace together that there be no entrance into the inclosure but by four gate which be leave on purpose in the midst of this place they have erect a great and very high awning of cloth support on wooden pillar at one end of which be a imperial canopy of state erect on two richly varnished pillar between which stand a great chair of state as if for the emperor and other seat on both side the ambassador be place on the left hand of the imperial throne arid the kathayan officer on the right before each ambassador there be two table one of which be cover with various meat and fruit and the other with cake and delicate bread ornament with festoon of silk and paper the other person present have only one table to each at the opposite end of this great banqueting tent there stand a buffet or side-board full of vessel of china and of silver for serve the liquor during the entertainment they be regale by a band of music and a number of young person in strange dress perform various trick for they amusement they be likewise much amuse by the performance of a comedy the actor of which wear mask represent the face of animal and a child inclose in the body of a artificial stork walk about and perform a variety of surprising motion in short nothing could be more magnificent next day be the seventeenth of shaaban they continue they journey through the desert and arrive in a few day at a karaul -lrb- 21 -rrb- or strong fortress in the mountain which be build across the road in a pass or defile so that traveller must necessarily enter by one gate and pass through the other here the ambassador and all the member of they retinue be carefully number and a new list make of all they name from the karaul they go to sekju or so-chew -lrb- 22 -rrb- where they be lodge in a large public building over the gate of the city in which as in all they other lodgings they be amply provide with every necessary and convenience as provision bed and horse and even the servant have mattress and coverlet allow for they bed so-chew be a large and strong city quite square in the entrance into kathay it have sixteen market place each fifty cubit square which be always keep clean in these there be several covered hall or gallery have shop on both side and a handsome hall of entrance adorn with picture there be hog keep in every house and the butcher hang they pork in the shambles along with the mutton -lrb- 23 -rrb- the city wall be flank with tower at every twenty pace distance and there be a gate in the middle of each side from each of which one may see the opposite gate as the street pass straight through the middle of the city divide it into four quarter over each gate there be a pavilion of two story the roof of which be tile with porcelain and be shape like a ass back or penthouse accord to the fashion of kathay which be likewise follow in mazanderan each of the temple in this place occupy nearly ten arpent of ground and all be very neat with they brick pavement polish like glass at the gate there stand a number of fine youth who after regale stranger show they the temple from so-chew it be ninety-five day journey to cambalu or khanbalek where the emperor reside the whole way lead through a populous country insomuch that traveller always lodge at night in a large town throughout the whole way there be many structure name kargu and kidifu the former be a species of corps-de-garde which be sixty cubit high and be build within sight of each other have always person on guard who be relieved every ten day these be intend to communicate alarm speedily to the seat of government which they do by means of fire and intelligence can be send in this manner in the space of a day and a night from the distance of three month journey -lrb- 24 -rrb- the kidifus be a kind of post-house which be build at ten _ merre _ -lrb- 25 -rrb- from each other have fix establishment of people with house to live in and ground to cultivate for they support and all letter to the imperial city be send by courier from one to another from sakju or so-chew to kamju -lrb- 26 -rrb- there be nine stage or day journey and the dankjus who reside in kan-chew be superior to all the other governor on the frontier at each stage the ambassador be furnish with 450 horse mule and ass and fifty-six chariot or waggon the servant who tend the horse be call _ ba-fu _ the muleteer who have charge of the mule and the asses_lu-fu _ and the man who draw the chariot _ jip-fu _ these chariot be each draw by twelve young man with cord on they shoulder and they drag through all difficulty from one lodging to another the _ ba-fu _ always run before as guide at all the lodging place where the ambassador and they retinue stop nightly provision be always find in abundance at every city the ambassador be feast in a hall set apart for that special purpose call _ rasun _ in each of which there stand a imperial throne under a canopy with curtain at the side the throne always face towards the capital of the empire at the foot of the throne there always be a great carpet on which the ambassador sit have they people rank in regular row behind they like the moslem at they prayer when all be properly arrange a guard beside the throne give a signal by call out aloud three time on which all the kathayan officer bow they head to the ground towards the throne and oblige the ambassador to make a similar reverence after which every one sate down to he appoint table on the twenty-fifth of ramazan the dankjus or governor of kan-chew invite the ambassador to a feast intimate that they be to consider it as a banquet give they by the emperor but as it be the fast of the moslem the ambassador send a apology yet he send they all the victuals which have be prepare for the entertainment in kanchew they see a temple each side of which extend 500 _ ke _ or cubit have in the middle of it a idol fifty foot in length lie as if asleep the hand and foot of this gigantic idol be nine foot long and the head be twenty-one foot round there be number of smaller idol each a cubit high behind this large one and above he head in such natural attitude that they seem alive the great idol be gilt all over have one hand under he head and the other stretch down along he thigh this idol be call _ samonifu _ and vast number of people be constantly prostrate themselves before he the wall be also adorn with many figure all round the great temple there be numerous small temple like the chamber in caravanseras have curtain of tapestry or brocade gilded easy chair and stool chandelier and vessel for ornament there be ten other temple in the city of kan-chew like the former and a tower have eight front twenty cubit in circumference and fifteen story high each story be twelve cubit high so that the whole tower be 180 cubit in height in every story be a chamber finely varnish and a gallery round embellish with painting one of these painting represent the emperor of kathay sit among he courtier and with boy and girl on either hand this structure be call _ teherki felek _ by the moslem and resemble a kiosk at the bottom there be the figure of giant which seem to carry the whole tower on they back the whole be construct of wood richly gilded and varnished and so exquisitely polish that it seem of burnish gold in a vault under the edifice there be a iron axis rest on a plate of iron and reach from the bottom to the top of the tower : and the whole be so ingeniously contrived that it could easily be turn round on this axis in so surprize a manner that all the smith carpenter and painter of the world ought to go there to learn the secret of they respective trade -lrb- 27 -rrb- before the ambassador leave kan-chew they be furnish with horse and carriage which they return here in they way back in this place also they consign the present which be intend for the emperor except a lion which they carry along with they to the imperial court in proportion as they approach towards the capital the kathayan magnificence always increase every evening they arrive at a _ yam _ -lrb- 28 -rrb- or lodging and once every week at a city on the fourth of the month shawal they reach the river karamuran -lrb- 29 -rrb- which be as large as the jihon or amu across this river there be a bridge of twenty-six boat lay over with plank and keep together by iron hook and chain which be fasten to iron pillar on each bank as thick as a man thigh so that the whole be keep perfectly firm and even on cross this river they come to a great city where the ambassador be more splendidly feast that in any other place and here they see a more magnificent idol temple than any of the former they take notice also of three public stew full of very beautiful harlot and as the woman here be handsomer than any other in kathay this place have the name of _ rosnabaad _ or the _ city of beauty _ after pass through several other city they arrive on the twelfth of the month zu ` lkaadeh at another river -lrb- 30 -rrb- twice as large as the jihon which they pass over in boat continue they journey and cross over several river some in boat and other by means of bridge they arrive on the twenty-seventh of the last mention month at the great and populous city of _ sadin-fu _ -lrb- 31 -rrb- in one of the temple of this city there stand a gilded brass image fifty cubit high call the _ image with a thousand hand _ for such be the number with which this idol be furnished and on the palm of each there be a eye the foot of this idol be near ten cubit long round this idol there be several other of different height place in chamber or niche some reach only as high as the ankle of the great one other to the knee and other again as high as the breast it be reckon that this prodigious work require 100000 load of brass the top of the temple be exquisitely finish and terminate in a open hall it be surround by eight mount or eminence which may be ascend both on the outside and the inside and these have several grotto the wall of which be adorn with various painting represent priest idol hermit tiger leopard serpent and tree these with the idol mountain and arch seem all to be compose of plaster around this great temple there be many fine building and among these a turn tower similar to that of kan-chew but larger and finer continue they journey at the rate of four or five pharasang each day -lrb- 32 -rrb- the ambassador arrive before day-break of the eighth of zu ` lhajieh at the imperial city of khanbalik -lrb- 33 -rrb- or pekin this city be so great that each side be a pharasang in length or about four and a quarter english mile but at this time 100000 house within its wall lay in ruin the ambassador and they retinue be conduct on foot along a causeway 700 foot long to the palace gate where there stand five elephant on either side on pass this outward gate they enter a very beautiful paved court of great extent where they find 100000 man wait at the emperor gate although it be not yet day face this court there be a great _ kiosk _ or pavilion the basis of which be thirty cubit high on which stand pillar fifty cubit high support a gallery sixty cubit long and forty cubit wide this pavilion have three gate the middle one be reserve for the emperor and that on each side be smaller above this kiosk and over the right and leave gate be a _ kurkeh _ or great drum and a bell hang over the middle gate attend by two person to give notice of the appearance of the emperor on he throne they reckon that near 300000 person be assemble before the palace among whom be 2000 musician who sing hymn for the prosperity of the emperor two thousand man arm with halbert baton dart arrow lance sword and mace have enough of business in keep the crowd in order other hold fan and umbrella around this court there be many apartment and it be surround by high portico close with grate and contain sofa when day appear the drum trumpet flute and hautboy begin to sound and the great bell toll at which the great gate be throw open and the people crowd in to see the emperor on pass from the first court into the second the ambassador find a larger and more magnificent pavilion than the former on which be a raise platform or sofa of a triangular form four cubit high cover with yellow satin and sumptuously adorn with gilding and painting represent the _ simorg _ -lrb- 34 -rrb- or phoenix which the kathayan call the royal bird on this sofa be a seat or throne of massy gold and on both side stand rank of officer of different order some commander of 10000 man some of a 1000 and other of 100 man each of these hold a tablet in he hand a cubit long and a quarter broad on which they all continue to look with much gravity without attend to any thing around they and behind these stand a infinite number of guard all in profound silence at length the emperor make he appearance from a inner apartment and ascend the throne by nine step of silver the emperor be a man of middle stature and he beard consist of 200 or 300 long hair which descend from he chin upon he breast on each side of the throne there stand two very beautiful maiden have they face and neck bare with they hair tie on the top of they head and large pearl in they ear each of these hold paper and a pen in they hand and write down with great attention whatever be speak by the emperor and when he retire they present he with the papers to see if he have any alteration to make in he order these be afterwards carry to the _ diwan _ or tribunal of state that they may be carry into execution when the emperor be seat on he throne the seven ambassador be bring forwards face the emperor and at the same time a great number of criminal be present there be seven hundred of these some of whom be fasten by the neck other have they head and hand inclose by a board six sometimes fasten thus to one board each criminal be attend by a keeper who hold he prisoner by the hair : and all thus wait the imperial sentence most of these be remand to prison and only a few be condemn to die which power reside solely in the emperor all the governor of this vast empire however distant from court send all malefactor to khanbalik to appear in presence of the emperor each person crime be write on one end of the board which he carry about he neck and the crime against religion be the most severely punish of all great care be take to examine into all the fact on these occasion insomuch that the emperor hold council twelve several time before he condemn any one to death hence a person who have be condemn in eleven successive council be sometimes acquit in the twelfth which be always hold in presence of the emperor who never condemn any but those he can not save when the criminal be dismiss the ambassador be lead by a officer within fifteen cubit of the throne and this officer on he knee read out of a paper the purport of they embassy add that they have bring rarity as present to he majesty and be come to knock they head against the ground before he then the _ kadhi mulana haji yusof _ a commander of ten thousand who be a favorite of the emperor and one of he twelve councillor approach to the ambassador with some moslem who speak the persian language and order they to fall on they knee and knock they ground with they forehead but they only bow they head three time then they deliver the letter of shah rokh and the other prince wrap up in yellow satin to kadhi mulana who give they into the hand of a khoja of the palace at the foot of the throne and he present they to the emperor he take they into he own hand open they and look at they and deliver they back to the khoja who descend from the throne and sit down on a seat at the foot of the step at the same time be bring out three thousand vestment of fine stufi and two thousand coarse such as be the usual clothing of the imperial child and household -lrb- 35 -rrb- the emperor then command the ambassador to draw near and be on they knee he inquire after the health of shah rokh and put many other question to they all of which they answer he then order they to rise and go eat say that they have come a far journey from thence the ambassador be conduct back to the first court where they be feast in a similar manner as at other time already mention when this entertainment be finish they be conduct to they lodgings in which the principal chamber be furnish with a large sofa or raise platform lay with fine silk cushion a great basin and a pan for fire on the right and left of this there be other chamber with bed silk cushion and foot carpet or fine mat for lodge the ambassador separately each person have a kettle a dish a spoon and a table every day for six person there be allow a sheep a goose and two fowl and to each person two measure of flour a chesnut and other dry fruit they be likewise attend from morning till night by a number of handsome servant -lrb- 1 -rrb- the capital of khorassan or corassan in the north-east of persium then the spice which be frequently mention in the travels of marco polo -- e section ii _ the several audience of the ambassador they entertainment present and return _ on the ninth of the month zu ` lhajjeh the _ sekjin _ or officer belong to the court who have charge of the ambassador come to they lodgings before day and raise they from they bed say that the emperor mean to feast they that day he bring they to the palace on horse which be send for the purpose and place they in the outer court where two hundred thousand person be in attendance as soon as the sun be up they be lead to the foot of the throne where they salute the emperor by bow they head to the ground five several time at length the emperor descend from the throne and the ambassador be lead back to the outer court where they be separate for a while that they might perform the deed of necessity be tell that no person could be allow to stir out on any pretence during the continuance of the feast after this they be lead through the first and second court and thence into a third which be entirely open and pave with fine freestone in the front of this court there be a great hall sixty cubit long have chamber over it and in the hall be a great sofa higher than a man which be ascend by three silver stair one in front and the other at the two side in this place there stand two khoja of the palace have a kind of pasteboard cover on they mouth and fasten to they ear upon the great sofa or platform there be a smaller one in form of a couch have pillow and cushion for the foot and on each side there be pan for fire and perfume pan this smaller sofa be of wood beautifully gilded and look quite fresh though sixty year old and every thing be finely varnish the most eminent of the dakji stand on each side of the throne armed and behind they be the soldier of the imperial guard with naked sabre the ambassador be place on the left hand as the most honorable station three table be place before each of the _ amir _ and other most distinguished person while other have only two and the more ordinary person but one and there be at least a thousand table at this entertainment before the throne near a window of the hall there be a great kurkeh or drum on a raise stage attend by two man and near it a great band of musician part of the hall be divide off by curtain which come close to the throne that the lady belong to the palace might see the company without be see after all the victuals and liquor be bring in and properly distribute two khoja withdraw the curtain which cover a door behind the throne and the emperor come forth amid the sound of many instrument of music and take he seat under a canopy of yellow satin ornament with four dragon after the ambassador have make five prostration they sit down to table and be treat as at other time during the entertainment many comic trick be act for the amusement of the emperor and the company the first performer that appear be paint with white and red like girl and dress in gold brocade hold nosegay of artificial flower after this a man lay down on he back as if asleep hold he foot raise up in the air then another person hold several thick cane in he hand seven cubit long place the other end between he leg on which a youth of ten or twelve year of age mount with surprising agility and perform several trick at the top at last the cane slip away from under he and every person think he must have fall to the ground and be dash to piece but the pretended sleeper instantly start up and catch he in the air there be one musician who play tune after the twelve different mode of the kathayan two man play the same air together each have one hand on he own instrument and the other on that of he companion during this entertainment several thousand bird of different kind fly about the court of the palace and light among the people to eat up what they could find scatter on the ground without appear to be in the least scared at the multitude during the five month that the ambassador remain at khanbalik they be regale at several other banquet where play be act much surpass that now mention on the seventeenth of the month zu ` lhajjeh all the criminal be carry to be punish accord to the nature of they offence and as prescribe by the law the twenty-fifth of moharram mulana kadhi yusof send to acquaint the ambassador that next day be the first of the new year accord to the reckoning of the kathayan the emperor be to go to he new palace and that no person must wear white as that be the dress of mourning in this country on the twenty-eighth at midnight the sekjin come to conduct they to the new palace which have be nineteen year building and be only newly finish every person have he house or shop illuminate with torch lantern candle and lamp so that it appear as light as noon-day at the palace they find a hundred thousand people who have come from all part of kathay the country of tachin and machin kalmak kabul karakoja jurga and the sea coast this day the ambassador table be set out of the hall where the throne stand while those of the _ amir _ or great officer and lord of the court be within and there be near two hundred thousand armed man carry umbrella and buckler this feast last till the afternoon and among the music be many song in praise of the new palace to give some idea of this superb structure it may be mention that from the gate of the hall to the first inclosure measure 1925 pace on each side be building and garden one within another the edifice be of freestone porcelain or marble so delicately put together that they seem inchase there be many hundred cubit of pavement the stone of which be so even and well join that they look like the checkered ruling in book nothing in other country can equal the kathayan in masonry joiner-work make relievo or raise figure in plaster and in paint the ambassador be call early to audience on the ninth of the month safar the emperor have then come out from a retirement of eight day for it be he custom to retire every year for some day during which he eat no kind of victuals and abstain from go near he lady neither do he during all that time see or converse with any one in this retirement the emperor have no picture or idol of any of he god as during this period all he devotions be address solely to the god of heaven on this occasion the imperial elephant be all adorn in a style of magnificence which be quite inexpressible many of they have silver seat like litter on they back adorn with standard of seven different color and the seat be fill with armed man fifty of the elephant carry the imperial musician this grand procession of elephant be precede or follow by at least 50000 person who all preserve the most exact order and the most profound silence in all this pomp and splendor the emperor be conduct from the place of he religious retirement to the female apartment of the palace the court astrologer have predict that the palace of the emperor be this year to suffer by fire on which account a solemnity accompany by splendid firework and illuminations be exhibit during seven day on this occasion a artificial mount be erect in the middle of the imperial court cover all over with branch of cypress and plant with 100000 torch by means of little artificial mouse make of bitumen or wild fire which run along a number of rope fix for the purpose these torch be all light up in a moment form a wonderful blaze of light from the bottom of the mountain to the top and many other light appear all over the city during all the seven day of this festival no criminal be seek after the emperor discharge all debtor under arrest for debt and set free all person in prison for crime except murderer and he distribute large present all this be notify on the thirteenth of the month safer by a imperial edict or proclamation the emperor be seat on he throne in the grand _ kiosk _ or pavilion of the first court surround by more than 100000 person and in this edict the emperor notify that he would send no ambassador to any country during three year after this edict have be read aloud by three officer of the court who stand on a bench before the emperor it be convey down from the pavilion into the court below by means of ring fasten to yellow silk cord and be reverently place on a board with a golden border it be carry to the city follow by music and accompany by a multitude of the people after the conclusion of this ceremony the emperor leave the pavilion and the ambassador be feast as at other time on the first of the month rabiya-al-awal the ambassador be again call to court before the emperor who have several shankar -lrb- 1 -rrb- bring in which he say he mean to give to those who have present he with good horse and at this time he cause three to be give to each of the ambassador of the mirza ulug-beg mirza baysangar and sultan shah-rokh next day he send for they again when address himself to arjak the ambassador of mirza siurgatmish he say i have no shankar to give you and even if i have i should not give you any lest it should be take from you as be do from ardeshir a former ambassador from you master to this arjak make answer : if you majesty will do I that honor i will engage my word that no person shall take it from I to this the emperor reply : on that condition i will give you two which i have order to be bring for that purpose on the eighth day of the month the ambassador of soltan shah and bakshus malek be send for to receive the shankish or imperial present they compliment to he in he particular court to the east of the imperial palace where they find he seat in state amid he attendant and have he table serve in the same manner with that of the emperor on the first of the month rabiya-al-akher the ambassador receive notice to go to meet the emperor who be then on he return from hunting and on get on horseback before day for that purpose they find mulana kazus yusof wait for they at the door of they hotel in great dejection inquire the cause he tell they privately that the emperor have be throw in hunting from the horse they have present he from shah rokh and have give order that they should be carry in chain to certain city in the east of kathay the ambassador be much afflict at this news and continue they journey for about twenty mile to the emperor camp at this place the kathayan have in one night inclose a plot of ground 500 pace square with wall ten foot high this wall be compose of earth hard press down between two plank as in a mould leave two gate and the place whence the earth be dig serve for a ditch there be strong guard post at both of the gate and other soldier post along the ditch within this outer inclosure there be two other each twenty-five cubit high form of yellow satin support upon square post and all set round with tent of yellow satin when the ambassador be arrive within 500 pace of the imperial quarter mulana cazus yusof desire they to alight and wait for the emperor while he go forwards to the presence the emperor be on the point of give order for have the ambassador arrest when _ lidajus _ and _ jandajus _ officer name _ setalid _ and _ jik-fu _ in the kathayan or chinese language who stand before the emperor and kazus yusof fall prostrate before he entreat he not to proceed to that extremity as it might have very bad consequence to put they to death and would give occasion for the world to say that the emperor have violate the law of nation in the person of these ambassador the emperor at length yield to they reason and entreaty and kazus yusof go with great joy to let they know that they be pardon the emperor even condescend to send they victuals but be mix with pork they could not eat of it on account of they religion afterwards the emperor approach mount on a great black horse with white foot richly caparison with brocade housing which have be send to he by mirza uleg beg and
