and the cavalcade reach all the way to the city the emperor ride in the middle attend by ten daji or governor of province and by the three lord who have so warmly plead in flavor of the ambassador when the emperor draw near kazus jusof one of these friendly lord come up and order the ambassador to prostrate themselves and when they have do so the emperor order they to arise and mount they horse and to accompany he then turn to they he thus address shadus khoja one of the ambassador : the present rarity horse and wild beast which be send to I in future must be better choose in order to preserve and increase the amity which i have for you prince at the hunt i mount the horse which you present I but he be so vicious and i be so old that he throw I by which i be wound and have receive a contusion on my head which give I great anguish but by lay much gold on the place the pain be assuage upon this shadus khoja say that it be the horse on which the great amir timid karkan -lrb- 5 -rrb- use to ride and that shah rokh who keep he as a rarity have send he to the emperor as the most valuable horse in all he dominion be satisfy with this apology the emperor call for a shaker which he let fly at a crane but on the bird return without seize he prey the emperor give it three stroke on the head he then alight from he horse and sit down in a chair rest he foot on another and give a acclamation on the fourth of the before name month the ambassador be bring to court to receive they present from the emperor who be seat on he throne and cause table to be set before he on which the present be display these be much of the same nature with those already mention which be give to soltan shah and bakshus malek sometime afterwards the most beloved of the emperor 's wife die and she death be make public on the eighth day of the month jomada-al-awake the next day be appoint for she interment the lady belong to the imperial family be bury on a certain mountain on which all the horse that belong to they be turn out to graze at liberty for the rest of they life at the same time several maiden and khoja of the palace who have belong to the retinue of the decease be place in attendance on the grave have provision allow they to subsist upon for live year perhaps more and when they victuals be expend they be permit to die of famine but on the ensue night the new palace take fire not without suspicion of the astrologer hay a hand in it by this misfortune the principal apartment which be eighty cubit long and thirty cubit broad adorn with pillar paint blue and richly varnish so large that three man could hardly grasp they be entirely consume from thence the flame communicate to a kiosk or gallery of twenty fathom and to the apartment of the lady which be still more magnificent by this fire 250 house be destroy and several man and woman lose they life -lrb- 6 -rrb- the emperor and he _ amir _ do not consider that this chastisement fall upon they for be infidel on the contrary the emperor go to a idol temple -lrb- 7 -rrb- where he say on he knee the god of heaven be angry with I and therefore have burn my palace yet have i do no evil for i have neither offend my father nor my mother nor can i be charge with the exercise of any tyranny on my people the emperor be so deeply affect by these untoward circumstance that he fall sick and the prince he son assume the administration of the government and give the ambassador a audience of leave -lrb- 8 -rrb- after which they receive no farther subsistence from the court till they departure they leave kham-balik on the fifteenth of the month jomada-al-awal accompany by certain daji from the court and they be lodge and treat with all necessaries on they return in the same manner as they have be on they journey to court they arrive on the first of rajeb at the city of _ nikian _ -lrb- 9 -rrb- where the magistrate come out to meet they but do not search they baggage as be customary there as xviii _ voyage and travels of pietro quirinus into norway in 1431 _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- introduction pietro quirinus a venetian nobleman be a merchant and master of a ship belong to the island of candium which at that time be in the possession of the venetian republic with a view both to fame and profit he undertake in 1431 a voyage from candium to flander and towards the end of autumn of that year suffer shipwreck on the coast of norway not far from the island of rost he winter in that island and in the follow summer 1432 travel through drontheim to wadstena in sweden and from thence return to venice that year he have himself give a account of he adventure and two of he companion christopho fioravente and nicolo di michiel do the same both of these journal be to be find in the collection of ramusio and extract have be publish from they by hieronimus megiserus in a work entitle septentrio novantiquus print in 8vo at leipsic in 1613 -- forst -lrb- 1 -rrb- forster voy and disc in the north p 209 section i _ voyage and shipwreck of quirinus _ on the 25th of April 1431 pietro quirini set sail from candia steer westwards to the strait of gibraltar but owe to contrary wind he be oblige to keep near the coast of barbary on the 2d of June he pass the strait and through the ignorance of the pilot the ship get upon the shoal of st peter in consequence of which accident the rudder be throw off the hinge and the ship admit water in three several place insomuch that it be with great difficulty they could save the vessel from sink and get she into cadiz the vessel be here unloaded and have give she a thorough repair the lading be again put on board in twenty-five day after they arrival have learn in the meantime that the republic of venice have enter into a war with genoa he think proper to augment the number of he man so that he crew in all amount to sixty-eight he set sail again on the 14th of July and endeavor to bear up for cape st vincent but owe to a strong north-east wind which on that coast be call _ agione _ he be force to beat up to windward forty-five day at a great distance from land and be drive into dangerous and unknown sea near the canary island when at length they stock of provision be nearly exhaust they get a fair wind from the south-west and direct they course towards the north-east and the iron work about they rudder give way they mend it up as well as they could and arrive safe at lisbon on the 25th of August have here carefully repair the iron work of they rudder and take in a fresh stock of provision they again set sail on the 14th of September and be a second time baffle by contrary wind insomuch that they have to put in at the port of mure in spain whence quirinus go with thirteen of he crew to perform he devotions at the shrine of st jago di compostella they return from thence with all speed and again set sail with a fair wind at south-west and keep at the distance of 200 mile from the land in hope the wind might continue but on the 5th November the wind shift to the east and south-east prevent they from enter the english channel and force they beyond the scilly island the wind now again increase in violence and on the 10th November carry the rudder a second time from its hinge they sling it by means of rope to the quarter of the ship but it soon break loose and be drag after the ship for three day when by exert they utmost effort it be again make fast the vessel now drive continually farther from land and as the crew consume the victuals and drink without bound or moderation two or three of the man be appoint to guard the provision with order to distribute regular share to each person on board twice a day quirinus himself not except as a substitute for they disabled rudder they construct by the advice of the carpenter out of some spare mast and yard two rudder with triangular board end in order to steady the course of the vessel these be properly fasten proved highly serviceable and inspire they with fresh hope of safety but by the extreme violence of the wind and wave this they last refuge be tear away on the 26th of November the storm increase to such extreme violence that they expect every moment to founder and have no doubt this be to have prove the last day of they life by degree indeed the storm abate but they be drive out to sea to the wnw and the sail from be perpetually fatigue by the rain and wind be now tear to shiver and though they put up new one they be soon likewise destroy the ship now drive without either sail or rudder at the mercy of the wind and wave and be fill by the sea which continually beat over it insomuch that the crew wear out with constant labor anxiety and watch be scarcely able to keep the water under on heave the lead they find water at 80 fathom on which they splice all they four cable on end and ride at anchor for the space of forty hour when one of die crew terrify at the dreadful working of the ship occasion by the wind and wave cut the cable at the forecastle and the ship now drive about as before on the 4th December four large wave break in succession over they ill-fated vessel and fill it so full of water that it seem just ready to sink by exert they utmost strength and resolution the crew bale the water out though it reach to they waist and at length succeed in empty the vessel entirely on the 7th the tempest increase with such violence that the sea flow into the ship uninterruptedly from the windward and they speedy destruction seem quite inevitable so that they be now of opinion they only chance of safety be by cut away the mainmast which might lighten the ship this be do therefore immediately and a large wave fortunately carry the mast and yard clear away by which the ship work with considerably less strain and violence the wind and wave too now become less violent and they again bale out the water but now the mast be go the ship would no longer keep upright and lay quite over on one side so that the water run into she in torrent and the people be quite exhaust with labor and want of food have not strength remain to clear out the water in this desperate situation expect every moment that the vessel would sink or go to piece they come to the resolution of endeavor to save themselves in the boat of which the larger hold only forty-seven man and the smaller twenty-one quirinus have the choice of either of the boat and at last go with he servant into the larger boat in which the officer have embark they take with they a stock of provision and on the 17th December the wind and wave have somewhat moderate they quit they unfortunate ship among other costly article of commerce the ship be laden with 800 cask of malmsey wine and a great quantity of sweet-scented cyprus wood with pepper and ginger on the follow night the small boat in which twenty-one of the crew be embark be separate from they by the violence of the storm and they never hear of she more those in the larger boat be oblige to throw overboard most of they stock of wine and provision and all they clothes except those they have on in order if possible to lighten she a little as the weather prove fair for some time they steer to the eastward in hope of get as they think to iceland but the wind again chop about drive they about at its will and they be quite ignorant whereabouts they be they liquor now begin to fail and many of the people be quite exhaust with incessant labor long watching and the other hardship they have undergo and through scarcity of provision a great number of they die so great particularly be the scarcity of drink that the allowance for each man be only a fourth part of a moderate cupful once in twenty-four hour they be better provide with salted meat cheese and biscuit but this dry and salt food excite a intolerable thirst which they have no means to quench in consequence of which some of they die suddenly and without have exhibit any previous symptom of illness and it be particularly observe that those be first carry off who have formerly live in the most intemperate manner and have give themselves up to drunkenness or have continually indulge themselves in hover over the fire though these have the external appearance of be strong and healthy they be least able to endure the hardship they have now to suffer and two or three of they use to die in a day this mortality prevail for ten day from the 19th to the 29th of December on the 29th the last remainder of the wine be serve out and every one resign himself to meet death which seem at hand some of the people urge by rage thirst drink sea water which evidently hasten they dissolution other have recourse to they own urine and this nauseous beverage join to the precaution of eat as little salt provision as possible contribute most of all to the preservation of they life for the space of five day they continue in this dreadful situation sailing all the time to the north-eastward at length on the 4th of January one of the people who sit in the bow of the boat descry somewhat to leeward which he conceive to be the shadow of land and immediately inform the crew of he discovery in a anxious voice all eye be now eagerly direct to this object and as day break they see with extreme joy that it really be the land the sight of this welcome object inspire they with fresh vigor and they now ply they oar in order to arrive the sooner at the shore but on account of its great distance as well as the shortness of the day which be only two hour long they be unable to accomplish this desire besides they be now so weak as to be unable to make use of they oar for any length of time and as night soon overtake they and be of long continuance it seem to man in they forlorn state as if it would never end when the next day break they could no longer discern the land which they have see the day before but they discover another mountainous country very near they and to leeward that they might not lose the way to this during the ensue night they take its bearing by the compass and hoist sail with a fair wind they reach it about four o'clock in the evening on approach the shore they observe that it be surround by many shallows as they distinctly hear the sea break over these but they give themselves up to the guidance of providence and at one time the boat ground on a shoal but a vast wave come and float they over and at the same time carry they safely to land upon a shelve rock which be now they great security as the spot be encompass on every side with rugged project rock and they could not possibly have get on shore in any other place here therefore they run they boat on shore and those who be on the bow leap directly on the coast which they find entirely cover with snow which they swallow in immense quantity fill they parch and burn stomach and bowels they likewise fill a kettle and pitcher for those who from weakness remain in the boat and quirinus allege that he swallow as much snow as he would have find it difficult to have carry on he back all he happiness and welfare seem to depend upon the quantity of it he could swallow this extravagant quantity of snow agree so ill with some of the people that five of they die that night though they death be attribute to the sea water which they have previously drink section ii _ preservation of quirinus on the coast of norway and residence in the isle of rostoe _ as they have no rope with which to make fast they boat to the shore and prevent it from be dash to piece they remain in it the whole night next day at dawn sixteen weak miserable and exhaust wretch the sad remains of forty-seven who have originally take refuge in the large boat go on shore and lay themselves down in the snow hunger however soon oblige they to examine if there might not remain some of the provision which they have bring with they from the ship : all they find be a very small ham a inconsiderable remnant of cheese and some biscuit dust in a bag mix with the dung of mouse these they warm by means of a small fire which they make of the boat seat and in some measure appease they hunger on the follow day have convince themselves beyond doubt that the rock on which they then be be quite desert and uninhabited they resolve to quit it in hope of be able to reach some inhabit island or part of the adjacent coast of norway but after fill five small cask with snow water and get into the boat to put they resolution into execution the water run in torrent through all the seam and the boat go to the bottom immediately so that they be force to get on shore again quite drench in the sea during the whole of the precede long night the boat have be beat against the rock which have loosen its plank and open all the seam despair now of any relief as they be utterly destitute of any means to repair they boat they construct two small tent of they oar and sail to shelter themselves from the weather and hew the material of they boat in piece to make a fire to warm themselves the only food they be able to procure consist in a few muscle and other shell-fish which they pick up along the shore thirteen of the company be lodge in one of the tent and three in the other the smoke of the wet wood cause they face and eye to swell so much that they be afraid of become totally blind and what add prodigiously to they suffering they be almost devour by louse and maggot which they throw by handful into the fire the secretary of quirinus have the flesh on he neck eat bare to the sinew by these vermin and die in consequence besides he three spaniard of a robust frame of body likewise die who probably lose they life in consequence of have drink sea water while in the boat and so weak be the thirteen who still remain alive that during three day they be unable to drag away the dead body from the fire side eleven day after landing on this rock or uninhabited island quirini 's servant have extend he search for shellfish they only food quite to the farthest point of the island find a small wooden house both in and around which he observe some cow-dung from this circumstance the forlorn people conclude that there be man and cattle at no great distance which inspire they with fresh hope of relief and revive they drooping spirit this house afford they abundant room and good shelter and all except three or four who be too weak to be able for the fatigue of remove to such a distance change they abode to this hut crawl with great difficulty through the deep snow the distance be about a mile and a half and they take with they as much as they be able of the ruin of they boat to serve they for fire-wood two day after this while go along the shore in search of the usual supply of shell-fish one of the company find a very large fish quite recently cast up by the sea which appear to weigh about two hundred pound and be quite sweet and fresh this most providential supply they cut into thin slice and carry to they dwelling where they immediately set to work to broil and boil it but so great be they famine and so tempting its smell that they have not patience to wait till it be thoroughly dress but devour it eagerly half raw they continue to gorge themselves with this fish almost without intermission for four day but at length the evident and rapid decrease of this stock of food teach they more prudent economy and by use it sparingly in future it last they ten day more those who staid behind in one of the tent near the place of they first landing send one of they number to see what have become of the rest and when he have be refresh with some of the fish he carry a portion to he two companion and the whole survivor be soon afterwards reassemble in the wooden hut during the whole time that they subsist upon the providentially find fish the weather be so exceedingly tempestuous that they certainly would not have be able to have look out for shellfish and they must inevitably have perish of famine have make a end of the large fish which seem to have last they for fourteen day they be oblige to have recourse again to the precarious employment of gathering shellfish along the shore for they subsistence about eight mile from the rock upon which they now be which fioravente inform we be call _ santus _ or sand-ey by the native there be another isle name _ rustene _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- which be inhabit by several family of fisher it happen that a man and two of he son come over from rost to sandey to look after some cattle which be amiss observe the smoke from the hut in which quirinus and he wretched companion have take shelter curiosity lead they to examine the hut on they approach they voice be hear by the people within the hut but they believe it to be only the scream of the sea-fowl who devour the body of they deceased companion christopher fioravente however go out to examine whence the unusual sound proceed and espy the two youth he run back in haste call aloud to he companion that two man be come to seek they upon this the whole company run out immediately to meet the lad who on they part be terrify at the sight of so many poor famished wretch these latter debate for some time among themselves whether they should not detain one of they visitor with the view of make themselves more certain to procure assistance but quirinus dissuade they from this project violence they all accompany the youth to the boat and entreat the father and son to take two of they people along with they to they habitation in order the sooner to procure they assistance from thence for this purpose they choose one gerrard of lyon who have be purser of the ship and one cola a mariner of otranto as these man could speak french and a little german the boat with the fisherman and the two man who have be depute to seek assistance go over to rostoe on Friday the 31st of January 1432 on they landing the inhabitant be much astonished at they appearance but be not able to understand they though the stranger address they in different language till at last one of the stranger begin to speak a little german with a german priest of the order of friar predicant who live there and inform he who they be and whence they come on Sunday the 2d February which happen to be the festival of the purification of the bless virgin the priest admonish all the people of rostoe to assist the unhappy stranger to the utmost of they power at the same time represent the hardship and danger they have undergo and point to the two famished wretch then present many of the congregation be soften even to tear at the recital and a resolution be form to bring away the miserable survivor as soon as possible which they accomplish next day in the mean time those who remain behind at sandey consider the absence of they companion as extremely long and what with hunger cold and anxiety they be almost dead they joy may be more easily conceive than express when they perceive six boat approach to they relief on landing the dominican priest inquire which of they be the captain of the unhappy crew and when quirinus make himself know as such the priest present he with some rye bread and some beer which he look upon as manna send from heaven after this the priest take he by the hand and desire he to choose two of he companion to accompany he and quirinus pitch upon franci quirinus of candium and christopher fioravente a venetian all three embark in the boat of the principal man of rostoe along with the priest the rest of the company be distribute in the other five boat and these good samaritan go even to the tent where these unfortunate have first dwelt take away with they the only survivor of the three man who have staid behind from weakness and bury the other two but the poor invalid die next day on the arrival of the boat at rostoe quirinus be quarter with the principal person of the island : this man 's son lead he to he father 's dwelling as he debility be so great he be unable to walk without assistance the mistress of the house and she maid come forwards to meet he when he would have fall at she foot but she would not permit he and immediately get he a bason of milk from the house to comfort he and restore he strength during three month and a half that quirini dwelt in this house he experience the greatest friendship and humanity from the owner while in return he endeavor by complaisance to acquire the good will of he kind host and to requite they benevolence the other partner of he misfortune be distribute among the other house of the place and be all take good care of the rocky isle of rost or rostoe lie 70 italian mile to the westward of the southern promontory of norway which in they language they call the world backside and be three mile in circumference -lrb- 2 -rrb- this rocky isle be inhabit at this time by 120 soul of whom 72 receive the holy communion on easter-day like good catholic they get they livelihood and maintain they family entirely by fishing as no corn of any kind grow in this very remote part of the world from the 20th of November to the 20th of February the night be twenty-one hour long and on the contrary from the 20th of may to the 20th of August the sun be either always see or at least the light which proceed from it thus during June July and August they may be say to have one continue day of three month while in the opposite month of winter they have one almost continue night during the whole year they catch a incredible quantity of fish which however be almost solely of two kind one of these they catch in prodigious quantity in the great bay which they call _ stockfish _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- the other call halibut be a kind of flat fish of a astonishing size for one of they be find to weigh near two hundred pound the stockfish be dry without be salt in the sun and air and as they have little fat or moisture they grow as dry as wood when they be to be prepare for eat they arc beat very hard with the back part of a hatchet by which they be divide into filament like nerve after which they be boil and dress with butter and spice to give they a relish the people of this country carry on a considerable trade with these dry stockfish into germany the halibut be cut into piece on account of they great size and be then salt in which state they be very good eating with these two kind of fish the people of rostoe load every year a ship of about 50 ton burthen which they send to bergen a place in norway about a thousand mile from they island and from whence a great number of ship of 300 or 330 ton burthen carry all the produce of the fishery of different part of norway into germany england scotland and prussium where they be exchange against the produce of these country particularly for every necessary article of food drink and clothing as they own country be so extremely barren and unfruitful that they can not raise these thing for themselves thus most of they traffic be carry on by means of barter they have little money among they nor be it very necessary when these exchange have be make at bergen the vessel return to rostoe landing in one other place only whence they carry wood sufficient for a whole year 's fuel and for other necessary purpose the inhabitant of these rock be a well-looking people and of pure moral not be in the least afraid of robbery they never lock up any thing and they door be always open they woman also be not watch in the smallest degree for the guest sleep in the same room with the husband and they wife and daughter who even strip themselves quite naked in presence of the stranger before go to bed and the bed allot for the foreigner stand close to those in which they son and daughter sleep every other day the father and son go out a fishing by day-break and be absent for eight hour together without be under the least anxiety for the honor and chastity of they wife and daughter -lrb- 4 -rrb- in the beginning of may the woman usually begin to bathe and custom and purity of moral have make it a law among they that they should first strip themselves quite naked at home and they then go to the bath at the distance of a bow-shot from the house in they right hand they carry a bundle of herb to wipe the moisture from they back and extend they left hand before they as if to cover the part of shame though they do not seem to take much pain about the matter in the bath they be see promiscuously with the man -lrb- 5 -rrb- they have no notion of fornication or adultery neither do they marry from sensual motive but merely to conform to the divine command they also abstain from cursing and swearing at the death of relation they shew the greatest resignation to the will of god and even give thanks in the church for have spare they friend so long and in now call they to be partaker of the bounty of heaven they shew so little extravagance of grief and lamentation on these occasion that it appear as if the decease have only fall into a sweet sleep if the decease be marry the widow prepare a sumptuous banquet for the neighbor on the day of burial when she and she guest appear in they best attire and she entreat she guest to eat heartily and to drink to the memory of the deceased and to he eternal repose and happiness they go regularly to church where they pray very devoutly on they knee and they keep the fast day with great strictness they house be build of wood in a round form have a hole in the middle of the roof for the admission of light and which hole they cover over in winter with a transparent fish skin on account of the severity of the cold they clothes be make of coarse cloth manufacture at london and elsewhere they wear fur but seldom and in order to inure themselves to the coldness of they climate they expose they new bear infant the fourth day after birth naked under the sky-light which they then open to allow the snow to fall upon they for it snow almost continually during the whole winter that quirini and he people be there from the 5th of February to the 14th of may in consequence of this treatment the boy be so inure to the cold and become so hardy that they do not mind it in the least the isle of rostoe be frequent by a great number of white sea-fowl call _ muri _ -lrb- 6 -rrb- in the language of the country these bird be fond of live hear mankind and be as tame and familiar as common pigeon they make a incessant noise and in summer when it be almost one continue day for three month they be only silent for about four hour in the twenty-four and this silence serve to warn the inhabitant of the proper time of go to rest in the early part of the spring there arrive a amazing quantity of wild goose which make they nest on the island and even sometimes close to the wall of the house these bird be so very tame that when the mistress of the house go to take some egg from the nest the goose walk slowly away and wait patiently till the woman have take what she want and when the woman go away the goose immediately return to she nest in the month of may the inhabitant of rostoe begin to prepare for they voyage to bergen and be willing also to take the stranger along with they some day before they departure the intelligence of they be at rostoe reach the wife of the governor over all these island and she husband be absent she send she chaplain to quirinus with a present of sixty stockfish three large flat loaf of rye-bread and a cake : and at the same time desire he to be inform that she be tell the islander have not use they well and if he would say in what point they have be wrong instant satisfaction should be afford it be also strongly recommend by that lady to the inhabitant to give they good treatment and to take they over to bergen along with themselves the stranger return they sincere thanks to the lady for the interest she take in they welfare and give they full testimony not only to the innocence of they host in regard to what have be allege but speak of the kind reception they have experience in the highest term as quirinus still have remain a rosary of amber bead which he have bring from st jago in gallicium he take the liberty of send they to this lady and request she to use they in pray to god for they safe return into they own country when the time of they departure be come the people of rostoe by the advice of they priest force they to pay two crown for each month of they residence or seven crown each and as they have not sufficient cash for this purpose they give besides money six silver cup six fork and six spoon with some other article of small value which they have save from the wreck as girdle and ring the greater part of these thing fall into the hand of the rascally priest who that nothing might be leave to they of this unfortunate voyage do not scruple to exact these as he due for have act as they interpreter on the day of they departure all the inhabitant of rostoe make they present of fish and on take leave both the inhabitant and the stranger shed tear the priest however accompany they to bergen to pay a visit to he archbishop and to give he a part of the booty -lrb- 1 -rrb- rost or rostoy -- forst -lrb- 2 -rrb- the small island of _ rust _ probably the one in question be the south-westernmost of the loffoden isle of norway in lat 67  80 n long 11  e and be about 80 statute mile from the nearest land of the continent of norway to the east the rest of the loffoden island be of considerable size and be divide from norway by the westfiord which grow considerably narrower as it advance to the north-east -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- the cod or gadus morrhua be term stock-fish when dry without salt -- e -lrb- 4 -rrb- this must have appear a most wonderful reliance upon female chastity in the opinion of jealous italian unaccustomed to the pure moral of the north -- e -lrb- 5 -rrb- this custom of promiscuous bathing be very ancient and exist among the roman from whom it be learn by the greek but give rise to such shameful lewdness that it be prohibit by hadrian and antoninus this law seem to have fall into oblivion as even the christian in after time fall into the practice and give occasion to many decree of council and synod for its prohibition yet with little effect as even priest and monk bath promiscuously along with the woman justinian in he 117th novel among the lawful cause of divorce mention a married woman bathing along with man unless with the permission of she husband russium probably adopt bathing from constantinople along with christianity and in that country promiscuous bathing still continue and they likewise use a bundle of herb or rod as mention in the text for rub they body -- forst norway certainly do not learn the practice of bathing either from rome or constantinople some learn man be never content unless they can deduce the most ordinary practice from classical authority as in the above note by mr forster -- e -lrb- 6 -rrb- the norwegian call this species of sea fowl _ maase _ which be probably the larus candidus a new species name in the voyage of captain phipp afterwards lord mulgrave _ larus eburneus _ from be perfectly white by john muller plate xii it be name _ lam albus _ and seem to be the same call _ rath kerr _ in marten spitzbergen and _ wald maase _ in leom lapland the greenlander call it _ vagavarsuk _ it be a very bold bird and only inhabit the high northern latitudes in finmark norway iceland greenland and spitzbergen this _ maase _ or sea-gull be probably the white _ muxi _ of the text -- forst section iii _ voyage from rostoe to drontheim and journey thence into sweden _ at they departure from rostoe the season be so far advance be now the end of may that during this voyage they see the image of the sun for forty-eight hour above the horizon but as they sail farther to the south they lose the sun for one hour though it continue broad day the whole time they whole course lay between rock and they perceive here and there near the project point of land the mark of deep navigable water which intersect the coast many of these rock be inhabit and they be receive very hospitably by the inhabitant who freely give they meat and drink and would accept of no recompense the sea-fowl which when awake be always loud and noisy they find have build they nest in all the rock past which they now sail and the silence of these bird be a signal for they likewise to go to rest in the course of they voyage they meet the bishop of drontheim who with two gally and attend by 200 people be make the tour of he diocese which extend over all these country and island they be present to this prelate who be inform of they rank country and misfortune express great compassion for they and give they a letter of recommendation for he episcopal residence at drontheim where st olave one of the king of norway be bury this letter procure they a kind reception at this place as the king of norway happen at this time to be at war with the german the host of quirinus who be likewise master of the vessel refuse to sail any further but land they at a small inhabit island near drontheim recommend they to the care of the inhabitant and immediately return home on the next day which be ascension day they be conduct to drontheim and go into the church of st olave which be handsomely ornament and where they find the lord-lieutenant with a great number of the inhabitant after hear mass they be conduct before the lord-lieutenant who ask quirini if he speak latin and be inform by he that he do invite he and all he attendant to he table to which they be conduct by a canon they be afterwards take by the same canon to good and comfortable lodgings and be amply provide with all kind of necessaries as quirinus wish for nothing more than to return to he own country he desire therefore advice and assistance to enable he to travel either by the way of germany or england that they might avoid travel too much by sea which be not safe on account of the war they be advise to apply to they countryman _ giovanne franco _ who have be knight by the king of denmark and who reside at he castle of stichimborg or stegeborg in east gothland in the kingdom of sweden at the distance of fifty day journey from drontheim eight day after they arrival in drontheim the lord-lieutenant give they two horse and a guide to conduct they to stegeborg and as quirinus have present he with he share of the stockfish a silver seal and a silver girdle he receive in return a hat a pair of boot and spur a leathern cloak-bag a small axe with the image of st olave and the lieutenant coat of arm engrave on it a packet of herring some bread and four rhenish guilder besides the two horse from the lieutenant they receive a third horse from the bishop and be now twelve in number they set out together on they journey with they guide and three horse they travel on for the space of fifty-three day chiefly to the south or sse and frequently meet with such miserable inn on the road that they could not even procure bread at they in some place they be reduce to such shift that the wretched inhabitant grind the bark of tree and make this substance into cake with milk and butter as a substitute for bread besides this they have milk butter and cheese give they and whey for drink sometimes they meet with better inn where they could procure meat and beer they meet with a kind and hearty welcome and most hospitable reception wherever they go there be but few dwelling in norway and they often arrive at the place where they be to stop in the night or time of repose though broad daylight on these occasion they guide know the custom of the country open the door of the house without ceremony in which they find a table surround by bench cover with leathern cushion stuff with feather which serve they for mattress as nothing be lock up they take such victuals as they could find and then go to rest sometimes the master of the house in which they stopt would come in and find they asleep and be much amaze till the guide acquaint they with they story on which they astonishment become mingled with compassion and they would give the traveller every thing necessary without take any remuneration by which mean these twelve person with the three horse do not spend more than the four guilder they have receive at drontheim during they journey of fifty-three day on the road they meet with horrid barren mountain and vally and with a great number of animal like roe -lrb- 1 -rrb- besides abundance of fowl such as hasel-hen and heath-cock which be as white as snow and pheasant the size of a goose -lrb- 2 -rrb- in st olave 's church at drontheim they see the skin of a white bear which be fourteen foot and a half long and they observe other bird such as gerfalcon goss-hawk -lrb- 3 -rrb- and several other kind of hawk to be much whiter than in other place on account of the coldness of the country four day before they reach stegeborg they come to a town call wadstena in which st bridget be bear and where she have found a nunnery together with chaplain of the same order at this place the northern king and prince have build a most magnificent church cover with copper in which they count sixty-two altar the nun and chaplain receive the stranger with great kindness and after rest two day they set out to wait on the chevalier giovanne franco who relieve they in a manner that do honor to he generosity and do every thing in he power to comfort they in they distressed situation a fortnight after they arrival at he residence a plenary indulgence be give at the church of st bridget in wadstena to which people from denmark norway and sweden and even from germany holland and scotland come to partake some of whom come from a distance of more than 600 mile they go to the indulgence at wadstena along with giovanne franco in order to inquire if there be any ship bind for germany or england there be always a great concourse of people on such occasion the chevalier be five day on the road and have more than 100 horse in he train at wadstena they take leave of they beneficent countryman who furnish they amply with money and clothes for they journey and order he son matthew a very amiable young man to accompany they eight day journey on they way to lodese on the river gotha and where he lodge they in he own house for some time till the ship in which they be to embark be ready to sail the chevalier franco lend they he own horse all the way from he castle of stegeborg and as quirinus be ill of a fever he mount he on a horse which have a wonderfully easy pace from lodese three of quirini 's crew go home in a vessel bind for rostock and eight of they accompany he to england where they come to they friend in london by way of ely and cambridge after reside two month at london they take shipping thence for germany and probably the tetrao lagopus lin -- forst -lrb- 3 -rrb- falco gyrfalcus and falco astur -- forst chap xix _ travels of josaphat barbaro ambassador from venice to tanna now call asof in 1436 _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- introduction josaphat barbaro a venetian be send in the year 1436 by the republic of venice as ambassador to tanna now call asof which at that time be in the hand of the genoese this relation be print in a small and scarce collection at the aldus press in venice by antonio minutio in 1543 and be afterwards insert in the collection of giovanne baptista ramusio the follow be a abstract of that journey he go afterwards into persium in 1471 as ambassador to ussum hassan or assambeus a turkomanian prince of the white weather tribe and be sixteen year among the tartar and on he return to he native country write a account of both these expedition he die at venice at a very advanced age in 1494 these travels be not give in any regular order nor be any itinerary mention it would appear that he reside for some time at tanna now asof make several journey into the crimea and among the nation which inhabit between the don and the wolga the black sea and the caspian and that he return home by way of moscow novogorod warsaw and francfort on the oder and through germany into italy \* \* \* \* \* josaphat barbaro begin he journey to tanna in 1436 and explore that country with great assiduity and a spirit of inquiry that do he much honor partly by land and partly by water for sixteen year the plain of tartary be bound on the east by the great river ledil edil or wolga on the west by poland on the north by russium on the south by the great or black sea alanium kumanium or comanium and gazarium all of which border on the sea of tebache -lrb- 2 -rrb- alanium have its name from the people call alanus who call themselves _ as _ in they own language these people be christian and they country have be ravage and lay waste by the tartar or mongal the province of alanium contain many mountain river and plain and in the latter there be many hill make by the hand of man serve for sepulchral monument on the top of each of which there be a flat stone with a hole in it in which a stone cross be fix about 110 year before the journey of barbaro or in 1326 the religion of mahomet be adopt by the tartar or mongal though indeed before that period there be some mahometan in the country but every one be permit to follow what religion he choose in consequence of this some worship wooden image which they carry about with they on they cart or moveable hut : but the compulsatory establishment of the mahometan religion take its date from the time of hedighus edigus or jedigheus who be a general under the tartarian emperor sidahameth khan this hedighus be the father of naurus in whose day ulu-mohameth or mahomet the great be khan of the tartar a misunderstanding happen between the naurus and the khan ulu-mohameth in consequence of which naurus retire to the river ledil or wolga attend by the tartar tribe who adhere to he personally and join himself to khezi-mohamet or _ little _ mahome who be a relation to the khan or emperor naurus and khezus resolve to make war against ulu and accordingly march with they combined force by way of giterchan or astrakan and through the plain of tuman or the great step or desert which extend from the wolga to the don and quite down the mountain of caucasus on this march westwards they keep southwards close to circassium and turn off towards the don and the sea of asof both of which be freeze over in order to find food for they cattle and horse they march in separate party at so great a distance from each other that some cross the river don at a place call palastra while other cross it where it be cover with ice near bosagaz which two place be 120 mile separate from each other yet so well be they movement combine that they come upon ulu-mohameth quite unexpectedly and he be constrain to fly with he wife and child leave every thing in confusion behind he as khezus mohameth become emperor or khan in he stead and again cross the don in the month of June proceeding westwards to the leave from tanna or asof along the coast of the sea of zabachus or the palus maeoti and then for some distance along the great or black sea quite to the province of mingrelium one arrive after three day journey at the province of _ chremuch _ kremuk or kromuk the sovereign of which be call _ bisserdi _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- and he son be name _ chertibeus _ -lrb- 4 -rrb- which signify the true or real lord bisserdus possess a beautiful country adorn with fertile field considerable river and many fine wood and can raise about a thousand horse the higher order of the people in this country chiefly subsist by plunder the caravan they have excellent horse the people be valiant inure to war and very artful but have nothing singular in they manners and appearance they country abound in corn cattle and honey but produce no wine beyond this country there be other province which have a different language and be not far from each other -lrb- 5 -rrb- these in they order consider kremuk as the first be 2 _ elipehe _ -lrb- chippiche or kippike -rrb- 3 _ tartarkosium _ -lrb- otherwise tatakosium titarcossa tatartofium or tatartussium -rrb- 4 _ sobaus _ 5 _ chernetheus _ -lrb- otherwise cheuerthei khewerthei kharbatei kherbarthei or khabarda -rrb- 6 _ as _ or the alanus all these province extend for twelve day journey quite to mingrelium which latter province border on the _ kaitacchi _ or chaitaki who live about the caspian mountain and partly also near _ georgiana _ and on the shore of the black sea and on the range of mountain which extend into circassium on one side likewise mingrelium be encompass by the river phasis which fall into the black sea the sovereign of this country be call _ bendian _ or dadian and be in possession of two fortify town near the sea one of which be call _ vathi _ or badias and the name of the other be savastopol -lrb- 6 -rrb- besides these he have several other castle and fortify rock the whole country be stony and barren and millet be the only kind of grain that it produce they get they salt from kaffa they manufacture some dark coarse stuff and be a gross and barbarous people in this country _ tetartus _ signify _ white _ and the word be likewise use to denote silver coin : thus likewise the greek call silver money aspro -lrb- 7 -rrb- the turk akeium and the kathayan _ teugh _ all of which word signify _ white _ and hence both in venice and in spain certain silver coin be all call _ bianchus _ which have the same signification we must now give some account of georgiana georgium or gurgistan which lie opposite to the last mention place and border on mingrelium the king of georgium be call pancratius and be sovereign of a delightful country which produce bread corn wine cattle and all other fruit of the earth in great abundance and they train up they vine around tree as in trebisond the people be very handsome and well make but they have the most horrid manners and the worst custom of any people i ever meet with they head be shave except a few hair all around like we rich abbot and they wear whisker six inch long on they head they wear a cap of various color with a feather on the top they body be cover by a strait-bodied jacket have tolerably long skirt which be cloven behind quite up to they loin as otherwise they could not conveniently sit on horseback but i do not blame they for this fashion as the french wear the same kind of dress on they foot and ankle they wear boot but the sole be so strangely make that when a man walk he heel and toe only touch the ground while the middle of the foot be raise up so high that one may thrust the fist through below and thence they walk with great difficulty i should blame they for this if i have not know that the same fashion prevail in persium at they meal they have the follow custom which i saw in the house of one of they great man they use a quadrangular table about half a ell across have a project rim on the middle of which they heap up a quantity of boil millet which be without salt or fat or any other seasoning and this they eat to they meat by way of bread on another similar table but have live coal underneath there be some wild boar flesh but so little roasted that the blood run out when it be cut and of this they be very fond for my part i think it quite disgusting and be force to content myself with a little millet as we have no other provision there be wine however in abundance which be hand round the company with great hospitality in this country there be a great number of wood and mountain one of its district be name tifli in which be a town of the same name situate on the kur or kyrus which run into the caspian gorus be likewise a fortify place in the same country and lie nearer to the black sea go from tanna or asof by the river don and along the sea of tabache or asof quite to kaffa and keep that sea close on the left hand we come to a isthmus or narrow neck of land which connect the peninsula of the crimea with the mainland and which be name zuchalum -lrb- 8 -rrb- this be similar to that call essimilium formerly the isthmus of corinth which connect the morea or peloponnesus with the continent of greece near this isthmus of zuchalum there be large salt water lake from which the salt crystallize in summer and be take out in large quantity for the supply of the surround nation within the peninsula and on the sea of tabache or asof the first province we come to be _ kumanium _ derive its name from the people call kumanian the chief province be call _ gazzarium _ or chazarium in which caffa be situate and the measure of length use by merchant in all these country be call the gazzarian ell which be even use at tanna -lrb- 9 -rrb- the low country of the island of kaffa -lrb- 10 -rrb- be occupy by the tartar who be govern by a prince name _ ulubi _ -lrb- 11 -rrb- the son of _ azichareus _ they be able in case of need to bring 3000 or 4000 horse into the field these people possess two walled town which be by no means strong one of these _ sorgathus _ -lrb- 12 -rrb- be by they likewise call _ incremia _ or _ chirmium _ which signify a fortification the other be _ cherchiarde _ or _ kerkiarde _ -lrb- 13 -rrb- which signify forty place in they language -lrb- 14 -rrb- on the island which the italian call the cimmerian bosphorus close to the mouth of the sea of asof be _ cherz _ kersch or kar -lrb- 15 -rrb- then come kaffa -lrb- 16 -rrb- saldaium -lrb- 17 -rrb- grassuus -lrb- 18 -rrb- cymbalo -lrb- 19 -rrb- _ sarsona _ or cherson -lrb- 20 -rrb- and kalamita -lrb- 21 -rrb- farther on from kaffa lie _ gothia _ and still farther alania which be without the island towards moncastro -lrb- 22 -rrb- the goth of these place speak a dialect of the german language as i learn from a german servant who accompany I on my travels for he converse with they and they understand each other tolerably well just as a native of friulus in the pope dominion might understand a florentine -lrb- 23 -rrb- from the vicinity or intermixture of the goth and alanian originate the denomination of _ gotitalanus _ the alanian be the first inhabitant of this county : the goth come at a after period and make a conquest of part of the country inhabit by the alanian and as the two nation mingle together this mixed name become likewise into use all these people profess the greek religion which be likewise follow by the tscherkassian or circassian have already make mention of tuman and githerean i shall now relate some remarkable particulars concern they go from tuman eastward or rather to the north-east in seven day journey we arrive at the river _ ledil _ -lrb- 24 -rrb- on the bank of which stand _ githercan _ -lrb- 25 -rrb- a small insignificant town lay waste and in ruin it be formerly a very considerable and celebrated place as before the devastation of it by tamerlane the spice and silk which go to syrium -lrb- 26 -rrb- be carry by githercan and thence to tanna from whence they be bring by six or seven large gally to venice for at that time no other nation besides venice trade to syria the ledil or wolga be a large and very broad river which discharge itself into the sea of baku or the caspian twenty-five italian mile below astracan and both this river and the caspian which be tolerably salt contain innumerable quantity of fish call tunny and sturgeon one may sail up this river to within three day journey of moscow in russium and the inhabitant of that place go every year with they vessel to astracan to procure salt the passage downward be easy as the river mosco run into the oka and that again into the wolga in this river there be many island and many forest along its bank some of these island be thirty mile in circumference and in the forest there be tree of such vast size that one of they may be hollow into a boat that will require eight or ten horse and twice as many man to draw it against the stream cross the river wolga and go fifteen day journey to the north-west along the river we meet with innumerable horde of tartar but in travel northwards towards russium we come to a small town call risan -lrb- 27 -rrb- which belong to a relation of the grand duke of russium the inhabitant of this place be all christian and follow the usage of the greek church this country abound in corn cattle honey and other good thing and they import a species of beer call _ bossa _ -lrb- 28 -rrb- and the country abound in wood and village without number somewhat farther and about half way between riazan and moscow be a town call colonna the fortification both of riazan and colonna be build of timber as be also the house as nothing be to be see in these part construct of brick or stone three day journey from colonna to the north-west we come to the city and province of moscow or mosqua where the great duke jvan or john reside and through this province there run a river of the same name have several bridge over it and from which the city and province have probably acquire they name the castle of moscow be situate upon a hill and be encompass round with wood -lrb- 29 -rrb- the fertility of this country in respect to corn and cattle may be understand from this circumstance that flesh be not sell by weight but they give it out in large piece as much as would weigh four pound -lrb- 30 -rrb- seventy hen may be buy for a ducat worth four or five shilling and a goose may be have for less than threepence in this country the cold of winter be very severe and the river be long freeze over : take advantage of this circumstance they carry ox and other beast to market in winter ready slaughter skin and embowell which they set up on they foot in the market place freeze as hard as a stone and in such number that one may buy 200 or more of they at a time cut they in piece as in we market be quite impossible as they be as hard as marble and be deliver out whole the only fruit to be meet with be apple nut and small walnut when the russian have a mind to travel especially if the distance be very great they prefer the winter season when the whole country be cover over with frozen snow and all the river be passable on the ice they then travel with great convenience and expedition be only subject to the severity of the cold at this season they use sledge which be to they as waggon be to we and in they they take every thing along with they with the utmost ease that they have a mind to in the summer the road be extremely miry and full of inequality proceed from the country be extremely woody and they do not therefore take long journey at that season more especially as it be very thinly inhabit they have no grape but make a species of wine from honey and a kind of beer from millet into which they put hop blossom of which the odour be so strong as to occasion sneezing and which intoxicate like wine i must not omit to mention in this place that about twenty-five year ago the great duke on finding that he subject be much addict to drinking which make they neglect they affair give order that no more beer or mead should be make by which mean he oblige they to live sober and regular life besides this he do many other thing for the advantage of he dominion before the reign of this prince the russian pay tribute to the tartar but they have now conquer a country call kasan which be 500 mile to the east of moscow and the chief city of which lie on the left bank of the wolga in descend towards the sea of _ bochrus _ or the caspian -lrb- 31 -rrb- this country of kasan enjoy considerable trade especially in fur of which large quantity be carry from thence by way of moscow to poland prussium and flander these fur come from a great distance to the north-east out of the empire of zagathaus -lrb- 32 -rrb- and from moxium -lrb- 33 -rrb- both of which northern district be inhabit by tartar part of whom be idolater particularly the moxian who continue so to this day have receive some account of these moxian i shall relate what i know concern they religious custom at a certain season they lead a horse into the middle of they assembly and fasten it strongly by the head and foot to five stake drive into the ground for that purpose after this a particular person go to some distance with he bow and arrow and shoot at the heart of the animal till he have kill he the horse be then flay and the flesh eat after the performance of certain ceremony they then stuff the horse skin with straw and sew it up so as to appear entire fix piece of wood under the skin of the leg that the stuff animal may stand up as it do when alive they next construct a scaffold amid the branch of a large tree upon which they fix the stuff horse skin and worship it as a god offer up to it the fur of sables ermines gray squirrel and fox which they hang among the bough of the sacred tree just as we offer up wax-light to the image of the saint the food of this people consist mostly of flesh and that chiefly of venison get by hunting but they likewise catch abundance of fish in the river of they country many of the tartar be idolater and carry the idol which they worship about with they on cart in they moveable hut and some of they have the strange custom of worship each day the animal they meet first in a morning after go out of they house the grand duke of russium have likewise conquer nowgorod or novogorod -lrb- 34 -rrb- this be a extensive province about eight day journey to the north-west of moscow which be formerly a republic the inhabitant be without sense or reason and have a great many heretic among they but at present the catholic faith make its way among they by degree though some be still misbeliever in the meantime however they lead more rational life and justice be properly administer poland be twenty-two day journey from moscow and the first place we come to in poland be a fortified town call trockus or trozk -lrb- 35 -rrb- to which we arrive through wood and over hill travel a long way in a uninhabited desert there be it be true certain place by the way in which traveller may rest a while and make a fire if order before hand and sometimes though very rarely one find a small hamlet or two a little way out of the road go beyond trozk one meet with more hill and forest in which there be some habitation and nine day journey beyond trozk we come to a fortified town call _ lonirus _ or lonin -lrb- 36 -rrb- after this we quit that part of poland call lithuanium and come to a district name _ varsonich _ -lrb- 37 -rrb- which belong to certain lord who be subject to _ kazimir _ or cassimir king of poland this part of the country be fertile and contain a great many walled town and village but none of any great importance from warsaw it be seven day journey to the frontier of poland through a good and beautiful country where one meet with _ mersaga _ -lrb- 38 -rrb- a tolerably good town where poland end respect the town and province of poland i shall say nothing farther for want of proper information except that the king and he son and whole household be very good christian and that the eldest of he son be king of bohemia travel four day more beyond poland we come to francfort a city which belong to the margrave of bandenburgh but have reach germany i shall say nothing of it as we be now in a manner at home and in a country with which most people be well acquaint -lrb- 1 -rrb- forster voy and disc in the north p 165 -lrb- 2
